PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Aiken, South Carolina. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1980 Code, as supplemented through April, 1999, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1980 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE APPENDIX 	CDA:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Index 
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Jan Shekitka, Code Attorney, and Bill Eddy, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Sara Ridout, City Clerk, Richard Pearce, City Solicitor/Staff Attorney and Gary Smith, III, City Attorney for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Aiken, South Carolina.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 06112001 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code of Ordinances of the City of Aiken, South Carolina; Establishing this New Code; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Within the New Code, Except as Expressly Provided in this Ordinance; Providing for the Manner of Amending this Code; and Providing When this Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
WHEREAS, the City of Aiken has a Code of Ordinances; and 
WHEREAS, this City Code was adopted by Ordinance 22580 on February 25, 1980; and 
WHEREAS, the City Clerk, City Attorney, and City Solicitor and Staff Attorney have undertaken an effort to review the 1980 Code book and the revisions to it made since its adoption, and determined that a change of format to make the Code more research friendly and incorporate changes made to the original 1980 Code; and 
WHEREAS, the City Council, on first reading, agreed to amend Section 2-64(a)(5)(b)(3) of the proposed Code of Ordinances to read as follows: 
"3.  The presiding officer may alternate between proponents and opponents when recognizing individuals to address council." 
WHEREAS, the Council of the City of Aiken has concluded that the adoption of the 2001 Code of Ordinance for the City of Aiken is essential to the general health, safety, welfare, and economic stability of the City, and is in the best interest of its citizens; 
NOW, THEREFORE, THE COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF AIKEN HEREBY ORDAINS THAT: 
Section 1: That the Code of Ordinances, as amended hereinabove, consisting of Chapters 1 to 46, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of the City of Aiken, South Carolina," which Code shall supercede all general and permanent ordinances passed by the City Council on or before April 1, 1999, to the extent provided in Section 2 below. 
Section 2: That all provisions of such Code shall be in full force in effect from and after May 29, 2001, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the City of Aiken enacted on final passage on or before April 1, 1999, and not included in such Code, or recognized in continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of such Code; PROVIDED HOWEVER, that nothing in this repealer shall repeal the City of Aiken Zoning Ordinance, the Comprehensive Plan of the City of Aiken, the Historic Preservation Ordinance, or other such ordinances not previously incorporated within the City of Aiken Code. 
Section 3: Any and all additions or amendments to the City Code, which passed in such form as to indicate the intention of City Council to make the same a part of this Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the City of Aiken Code so that a reference to the "Code of the City of Aiken, South Carolina," shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
Section 4: A copy of the City of Aiken Code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk, preserved in loose leaf form, or in such other form or data compilation as the City Clerk may consider most expedient. It shall be the express duty of the City Clerk, or the City Clerk's designee, to insert in designated places all amendments or ordinances which indicate the intention of City Council to make these amendments or ordinances a part of the City Code when these amendments or ordinances have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from the City of Aiken Code, all provisions, which may, from time to time, be repealed by the City Council. The City Clerk's copy of the City of Aiken Code shall be available for all persons desiring to examine it. 
Section 5: In case of the amendment of any section to the City of Aiken Code, for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty provided in Section 1-13 of the Aiken City Code shall apply to the section as amended; or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section of the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended unless such penalty is specifically repealed in it. 
Section 6 : It shall be unlawful for any person in the City to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, which will cause the law of the City of Aiken, to be misrepresented. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in Section 1-13 of the Aiken City Code. 
Section 7 : All ordinance or parts of ordinances in conflict with this ordinance are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
Section 8 : This ordinance shall become effective on June 11, 2001. 
ADOPTED by the Council of the City of Aiken at its regular meeting held this 11 th day of June, 2001, at which a quorum was present and voting. 
INTRODUCTION AND FIRST READING:   May 28, 2001 
SECOND READING AND ADOPTION:      June 11, 2001

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Aiken City Code," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1980, § 1-1) 
State Law reference— Duty to provide for codification and indexing of ordinances, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-290.  
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
In the interpretation and construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council or the context clearly requires otherwise. 
City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Aiken, South Carolina. 
Code. Whenever the term "Code" or "this Code" is used without further qualification, it shall mean the Code of the City of Aiken, South Carolina, as designated in section 1-1. 
Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; provided however, that if the last day of the period so computed is a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday, such day shall be excluded and the time period shall run until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday. 
Council. Whenever the term "council" or "city council" is used, it shall be construed to mean the city council of the City of Aiken. 
County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Aiken, South Carolina. 
Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations, as well as to males. 
Number. Words used in the singular include the plural, and the plural includes the singular number. 
Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
Officers, boards, etc. Whenever reference is made to a particular officer, department, board, commission or other agency by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Aiken, South Carolina." 
Official time standard. Whenever particular hours are referred to, the time applicable shall be official standard time or daylight saving time, whichever may be in current use in the city. 
Or, and. "Or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to firms, partnerships, associations, organizations and bodies politic and corporate, or any combination thereof, as well as to individuals. 
Shall, may, must. The words "shall" or "must" are mandatory; the word "may" is permissive. 
Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" means a strip of land in front or on the sides of a house or lot of land lying between the property line and the street. 
Signature or subscription. Signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of South Carolina. 
Statute references. Whenever reference is made, for example, to S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-10, it shall be construed to refer to the Code of Laws of South Carolina 1976, section 5-7-10, as amended, or whatever section is cited. 
Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past or present. 
Written; in writing. The terms "written" and "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
(Code 1980, § 1-2)  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes and references. 
(a)  The catchlines of sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended merely as catchwords to indicate the contents of the section, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. 
(Code 1980, § 1-3)  
Sec. 1-4. - Provisions of Code considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances previously adopted and included herein, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1980, § 1-4)  
Sec. 1-5. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  An ordinance granting any franchise or right; 
(3)  Any ordinance appropriating funds, levying or imposing taxes or relating to an annual budget; 
(4)  Any ordinance relating to salaries of city officers and employees or to compensation or pay plans or classification plans for such officers or employees; 
(5)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city; 
(6)  Any ordinance authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any public improvement; 
(7)  Any zoning ordinance including amendments to the zoning map and ordinances zoning or rezoning specific property; 
(8)  Any ordinance prescribing regulations for land development and the subdivision of land; 
(9)  Any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the city or establishing and prescribing street grades; 
(10)  Ordinance No. 041387, as amended, adopted April 13, 1987, and entitled "An Ordinance to Minimize Damage from Floods; to Regulate Land Uses in the Floodplains; and for Other Purposes;" 
(11)  Any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; or 
(12)  Any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1980, §§ 1-5, 20-1)  
Sec. 1-6. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, or any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered, on or before the effective date of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 1-6)  
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of the City of Aiken, South Carolina (or the Aiken City Code), is hereby amended to read as follows …" The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
(b)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of the City of Aiken, South Carolina (or the Aiken City Code), is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered _____, which said section (or article or chapter) reads as follows: …" The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
(c)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1980, § 1-7)  
Sec. 1-8. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by municipal personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1980, § 1-8) 
State Law reference— Duty to provide for maintenance of ordinances in current form, reflecting amendments and repeals, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-290.  
Sec. 1-9. - Copies of Code and supplements to be available for public inspection. 
At least three copies of this Code and every supplement thereto shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and shall there be available for public inspection, during normal business hours. 
(Code 1980, § 1-9) 
State Law reference— Codified ordinances to be available for public inspection at reasonable times, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-290.  
Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby, except by ordinance of the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 1-10)  
Sec. 1-11. - Severability of parts of Code. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1980, § 1-11)  
Sec. 1-12. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1980, § 1-12)  
Sec. 1-13. - General penalty for violations of Code and ordinances; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this Code or any other ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the person violating any such provision of this Code or other ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 30 days, or both. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance continues shall constitute a separate offense, unless otherwise provided. 
(b)  In addition any person found guilty of violating any provision of this Code may be ordered to pay restitution in an amount not to exceed $5,000.00. In determining the amount of restitution the judge shall determine and itemize the actual amount of damage or loss in the order. In addition the judge may set an appropriate payment schedule. A municipal judge may hold a party in contempt for failure to pay the restitution ordered if the judge finds the party has the ability to pay. 
(c)  Where there is any conflict between the maximum penalty provided by the statutory law of the state and this Code or any other ordinance of the city, for the same or similar offenses, the maximum punishment provided by the state statute shall govern. 
(d)  In addition to the penalties provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be, by the city, abated as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(Code 1980, §§ 1-13, 1-14) 
State Law reference— Authority of council to fix fines and penalties for violation of ordinances, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-30; trial of persons charged with ordinance violations, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-90; maximum penalty that municipal courts may impose, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-65.  
Sec. 1-14. - Police jurisdiction over parking lots. 
(a)  The procedure for bringing parking lots not owned or leased by the city under public safety department jurisdiction of the city shall be as follows: The owner of a parking lot in the city which is open to use by the public for motor vehicle traffic shall petition the director of public safety requesting that the city exercise police jurisdiction over such parking lot. The director of public safety should determine that such petition is signed by, or on behalf of, the owners or owner, of a majority of the area of such parking lot, and should ascertain the number of signs to be posted to inform the public that the area is subject to the police jurisdiction of the city. The petitioner[s] shall pay the city for the number of signs determined by the director of public safety to be necessary, at a rate specified by the director. 
(b)  Upon the requirements of subsection (a) of this section being met, the director of public safety should request that the parking lot in question be posted with appropriate signs informing the public that the area is subject to the police jurisdiction of the city, with regard to the unlawful operation of motor vehicles and violations of applicable city ordinances. 
(c)  Upon an owner, or owners, filing a request or petition to put a parking lot under public safety jurisdiction referred to in subsection (a), jurisdiction of the city and the city, acting through its department of public safety, shall thereupon have the authority to enforce, in such parking lot, all laws and ordinances relating to the unlawful operation of motor vehicles applicable to the public streets and highways immediately adjoining or connecting to the parking area, as well as all other applicable ordinances of the city and laws and statutes of the state. 
(Code 1980, § 1-15; Ord. No. 02232004, § 1, Exh. A, 2-23-2004)  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration of business license regulations, § 12-39; administrative record for adult entertainment, § 12-87; elections, ch. 14; human relations, ch. 18; municipal court, ch. 20; taxation, ch. 38; utilities, ch. 44. 
State Law reference— Municipal corporations, S.C. Code 1976, title 5. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Adoption of council-manager form of government. 
The council-manager form of municipal government, with a mayor and six council members elected as provided in chapter 14 for four-year terms of office, as provided in S.C. Code 1976, §§ 5-13-10—5-13-100, is hereby adopted for the city, to be effective on July 1, 1976, or as soon thereafter as prescribed by state law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-1) 
State Law reference— Selection of form of government, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-5-10 et seq.  
Sec. 2-2. - Payment of unemployment taxes by city. 
The mayor, by and with the attest of the city clerk, is hereby authorized and directed to execute any and all documents necessary to enter into an agreement with the state employment security commission pertaining to the payment of unemployment taxes by the city. The city hereby adopts the reimbursement method of paying such unemployment taxes. 
(Code 1980, § 2-4)  
Sec. 2-3. - Unauthorized taking of city records. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to take any record from any municipal office of the city, without the consent of the officer having control of such records. 
(Code 1980, § 2-5)  
Sec. 2-4. - Language for transaction of city business and affairs. 
All city business, transactions, and affairs will be conducted and communicated orally and in written form in the English language. Provided, however, that this section shall not apply to judicial proceedings in the municipal court or matters required to be transacted in another language by federal or state law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-10)  
Secs. 2-5—2-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-31. - Composition. 
The mayor and six council members shall be termed "the council" and shall be the governing body of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-16) 
State Law reference— Composition of council in cities with council-manager form of government, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-13-20.  
Sec. 2-32. - Oath of office. 
Before entering upon the duties of their offices, the mayor and members of the council shall take the oath of office prescribed by S.C. Code 1976, § 5-15-150. Other officers of the city and such members of commissions and committees as may be designated by the council shall take the following oath to be administered by the city clerk: 
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I am duly qualified according to the Constitution of this state, to exercise the duties of the office to which I have been elected (or appointed); that as  (Name of Office)  of the City of Aiken, I will equally, fairly and impartially, to the best of my ability and skill, exercise the trust reposed in me, and I will use my best endeavors to preserve the peace and to carry into effect according to law the purposes for which I have been elected (or appointed) and will preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of this state and the United States. So help me God." 
(Code 1980, § 2-2)  
Sec. 2-33. - Qualifications of council members. 
The mayor and council members shall be qualified electors of the city and shall hold no other public office or public employment with the city, county or state, except that of notary public, appointed school board member or a member of the national guard or other federal military reserve. If a council member or the mayor shall cease to possess any of these qualifications or shall be convicted of malfeasance in office or a crime involving moral turpitude, his office shall immediately become vacant. 
(Code 1980, § 2-17) 
State Law reference— Mayor and council member to be qualified electors of city, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-15-20.  
Sec. 2-34. - Filling of vacancies. 
Vacancies in the office of mayor or council member shall be filled by special election, if the vacancy occurs more than 180 days prior to the next city general election, for the unexpired portion of the term. If the vacancy occurs less than 180 days before a city general election, the vacancy shall be filled at the general election for the unexpired term as provided by law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-18) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-200.  
Sec. 2-35. - Election schedule. 
(a)  The following dates and times are hereby established for nomination and election of candidates for regularly scheduled municipal general elections to council, including the mayor, that are conducted in odd-numbered years: 
(1)  The opening of filing for nomination petitions and other filing of candidates for nomination in municipal political party primaries or conventions shall be 12:00 noon on the first Monday in July. 
(2)  The closing of the filing of candidates for nomination by political parties shall be 12:00 noon on the second Monday of July. 
(3)  Closing of entries for nomination by petition shall be 12:00 noon on the 75th day prior to the municipal general election. 
(4)  Municipal party primaries or conventions shall be conducted on the second Tuesday in August. 
(5)  Municipal party primary runoffs, if necessary, shall be conducted on the fourth Tuesday in August. 
(6)  Last day for certifying candidates to the municipal election commission shall be 12:00 noon on the 60th day prior to the municipal general election. 
(7)  The municipal general election for council members and mayor shall be conducted on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November. 
(b)  In the event of a vacancy on council requiring a special election, council shall follow the election schedule for special elections in S.C. Code § 7-13-190, as amended, or any successor provisions thereto. 
(c)  If a date set by this section falls on a Saturday or Sunday or legal holiday in a given year, the date therefor shall be changed to the next preceding weekday. 
(Code 1980, § 2-18.1; Ord. No. 04272015 , § 1, 4-27-2015) 
State Law reference— Municipalities to establish election schedules, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-15-70.  
Sec. 2-36. - Compensation of members. 
(a)  The annual salary of the members of city council shall be $9,000.00 per year. The annual salary of the mayor pro tem shall be $12,000.00 per year. The annual salary of the mayor shall be $15,000.00 per year. Pursuant to Section 5-7-170 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1976, as amended, this salary change shall not go into effect until the commencement date of the terms of two or more members of city council elected at the next general election [the 2007 election] following the adoption of this section. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  The members of city council, the mayor pro tem, and the mayor shall also be entitled to be reimbursed the actual expenses they incur for attending functions for professional development, or where members of council are acting in their official capacity as a representative of the city or they are otherwise performing their official duties. This reimbursement shall be paid upon submission of a signed city reimbursement form as provided by the finance department. 
(d)  The mayor shall be authorized to use an automobile purchased or leased by the city during his term of service as mayor. The guidelines for the use of this automobile shall be the same as those which govern the use of city vehicles by department heads. 
(e)  The members of the city council, the mayor pro tem, and the mayor shall be allowed to participate in the city's retirement plan as set forth in such retirement plan. 
(f)  Members of the city council, including the mayor, are eligible to continue to participate in the city's health insurance program. They must be participants in the city employees' retirement plan who retire on or after attaining age 55 with at least 12 years of service. 
(1)  An eligible council member who retires with at least 12 years of service with the city but is less than age 55 may continue his coverage under the city's health insurance program at his own cost until attaining age 55. At age 60, the city will offset any monthly pension check which may be payable to a former member of the council by the monthly premium for health insurance payable by the former member. The remaining portion of the pension check shall be directly deposited by the city. 
(2)  All eligible council members who retire on or after age 55 may elect to continue their health insurance coverage and the cost of continued coverage shall be divided between the city and the retiree as follows: 
Retirement at or After 
Age 55 With Years of 
Service 	Percentage of Cost Paid 
by City 
Less than 12 	 0 
12 	28 
15 	40 
20 	60 
25 	80 
 
An additional four percent is added for each full year of service after 12 years up to 25 years of service. Example: For 12 years of service, the city will pay 28 percent of the cost of health insurance coverage. In no event will the city pay more than 80 percent of the monthly insurance premium. 
(3)  The city reserves the right to change or modify its health insurance program from time to time, and continue coverage as is available under the health insurance program as modified from time to time. 
(4)  A former council member's election to continue coverage under the city's health insurance program must be made at the time of the member's retirement when the member is first eligible to elect continued health insurance coverage. If the member fails to elect to continue coverage under the city's health insurance program at the time the member is first eligible, the former member may not later elect to participate. Also, if the former member elects to participate in the city's health insurance program after retirement and later stops participating or the coverage ceases due to the member's failure to pay the required premiums, the member shall not be allowed to rejoin or re-elect health insurance coverage under the city's program. 
(5)  The mayor and council members shall be responsible for 100 percent of any dependent coverage for health insurance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-19; Ord. No. 091195C, §§ 1—3, 9-11-1995; Ord. No. 06262000, §§ 1—6, 6-26-2000; Ord. No. 07102000F, §§ 1, 2, 7-10-2000; Ord. No. 10232000, § 1, 10-23-2000; Ord. No. 03262007B, § 1, 3-26-2007) 
State Law reference— Determination of salary of mayor and council members, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-170.  
Sec. 2-37. - General powers. 
All legislative powers of the city and the determination of all matters of policy shall be vested in the council. Without limitation of the foregoing, the council shall have power to: 
(1)  Adopt the budget of the city. 
(2)  Authorize the issuance of bonds by a bond ordinance subject to such restrictions and limitations as may be prescribed by law. 
(3)  Inquire into and investigate the conduct of any city office, department or agency and make investigations as to municipal affairs. 
(4)  Adopt plats. 
(5)  Adopt the official map of the city and modify the official map from time to time as the need may require. 
(6)  Regulate and restrict the height and number of stories of buildings and other structures, the size of yards and courts, the density of population of land and the location and use of buildings for trade, industry, business, residence or other purposes. 
(7)  Provide for safe and sanitary housing accommodations for families of low income. 
(8)  Create a housing authority. 
(9)  Adopt, modify and carry out plans proposed by the planning commission for the clearance of slum districts and rehabilitation of blighted areas. 
(10)  Adopt, modify and carry out plans proposed by the planning commission for the replanning, improvement and development of neighborhoods and for the replanning, reconstruction or redevelopment of any area or district which may have been destroyed in whole or in part by disaster. 
(11)  Provide for an annual independent audit by a qualified certified public accountant designated by the council. Such certified public accountant shall, as of the end of each fiscal year, make an independent audit of the accounts and other evidence of financial transactions of the city government for the immediate past year, and shall submit this report to the council and to the city manager. The designated accountant shall have no personal interest, direct or indirect, in the fiscal affairs of the city government or of any of its officers, but within specifications approved by the council, shall post-audit the books and documents kept by any office, department, board, agency or commission of the city government. 
(Code 1980, § 2-20) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 5-7-240, 5-13-30, 5-23-10.  
Sec. 2-38. - Powers with respect to offices, boards, commission, etc. 
(a)  The council, by ordinance, may create, change and abolish offices, departments, boards, agencies and commissions. 
(b)  The council may appoint and remove all members of the municipal boards, agencies and commissions established by the council, state law or constitution, except as otherwise provided by state law. Such boards and commissions shall serve as advisory bodies to the council and shall not exercise administrative responsibility, except as may be otherwise provided by law. Terms of the board, agency or commission members shall be as provided by ordinance, state law or constitution. 
(Code 1980, § 2-21)  
Sec. 2-39. - General functions of mayor. 
The mayor shall be recognized as head of the city government for all ceremonial purposes and by the governor for purposes of military law, and shall execute all official documents of the city, but shall have no regular administrative duties. 
(Code 1980, § 2-22)  
Sec. 2-40. - Emergency powers of mayor. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section a state of emergency shall be deemed to exist whenever, during times of great public crisis, disaster, rioting, civil disturbance, catastrophe or for any other reason, municipal public safety authorities are unable to maintain public order or afford adequate protection for lives, safety, health, welfare or property. 
(b)  In the event of a state of emergency threatening or endangering the lives, safety, health and welfare of the people within the city or threatening damage to or destruction of property, the mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the existence of such a state of emergency, and, in order more effectively to protect the lives, safety and property of people within the city, to define and impose a curfew applicable to all persons within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(c)  The mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to limit the application of such a curfew to any area specifically designated and described within the jurisdiction of the city and to specific hours of the day or night; and to exempt from the curfew public safety officers, doctors, nurses and such other classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and immediately necessary to serve the safety, health and welfare needs of the people within the city. 
(d)  The city council shall be called into session within 24 hours after a state of emergency has been proclaimed by the mayor. 
(e)  The mayor shall proclaim the end of such state of emergency and curfew as soon as circumstances warrant or when directed to do so by the city council. 
(f)  During the existence of proclaimed state of emergency, when a curfew has been defined and imposed, it shall be unlawful for anyone subject to such curfew: 
(1)  To be or travel upon any public street, alley or roadway or upon public property unless such travel is necessary to obtain medical assistance. 
(2)  To possess off one's own premises, buy, sell, give away or otherwise transfer or dispose of any explosives, firearms, ammunition or dangerous weapon of any kind. 
(3)  To sell beer, wines or intoxicating beverages of any kind; or to possess or consume beer, wines or intoxicating beverages of any kind off one's own premises. 
(4)  To sell gasoline or any other similar petroleum products or any combustible or inflammable substances, except as expressly authorized by the provisions of the curfew imposed. 
(Code 1980, § 2-23)  
Sec. 2-41. - Mayor pro tempore. 
The council shall elect one of its members as mayor pro tempore to serve as such for two years, who shall act as mayor during the absence or disability of the mayor, and if a vacancy occurs, shall become mayor until a successor is duly qualified and elected. 
(Code 1980, § 2-24) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-190.  
Sec. 2-42. - Limitations on dealing with administrative service. 
Neither the council nor any of its members shall direct or request the appointment of any person to, or his removal from, office by the city manager or by any of his subordinates, or in any manner take part in the appointment or removal of officers and employees in the administrative service of the city. Except for the purposes of inquiry and investigation, the council and its members shall deal with the administrative service solely through the city manager and neither the council nor any member thereof shall give orders to any subordinates of the city manager, either publicly or privately. Any council members violating the provisions of this section, or voting for a resolution or ordinance in violation of this section, shall be guilty of malfeasance in office, and shall thereby disqualify himself as a member of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-25)  
Secs. 2-43—2-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Council meetings, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-250. 
 
Sec. 2-61. - Regular and special meetings generally. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the council shall be held on the second and fourth Monday in each month, unless changed by a majority vote of members present at any regular or special meeting. 
(b)  Special meetings of the council may be held on the call of the mayor or of a majority of the members. Notice of a special meeting shall be given immediately to all available members and the news media by the city manager. 
(c)  All regular and special meetings of the council shall be open to the public. 
(d)  For annexations, rezonings, and utility requests before Aiken City Council affecting a particular piece of real estate, such matter shall also be given public notice by posting a public notice sign, at least 20 days prior to the first scheduled public hearing before city council, on the subject property and in a location clearly visible from each street adjacent to the particular piece of property. This public notice sign shall be in substantially the same form as the public notice sign utilized by the planning department for matters pending before the historic preservation commission, board of zoning appeals, and planning commission, and conformed for the purposes of this section, as appropriate. This notice shall be posted by the planning department director, or a designee of the director. Where more than one lot is involved in an application, the planning director shall determine the number and location of required public notice signs. 
(Code 1980, § 2-31; Ord. No. 06092003, § 1, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 2-62. - Conference meetings. 
(a)  The city council may have conference meetings as permitted by the state Freedom of Information Act at such times and in such places as may be deemed necessary and in the public interest by the mayor or any member of the council. No formal vote shall be taken upon any matter under discussion at any such conference, but an informal polling of the council may be made, if desired by any member of the council. 
(b)  The city manager may, if time permits, give notice to the local news media or anyone requesting in writing advance notice that a conference meeting will be held pursuant to law without stating the specific matters to be discussed. When advance notice is not given, the city manager may give notice of such meeting after it has been held. 
(c)  No vote of the council shall be necessary to call a conference meeting. 
(Code 1980, § 2-32)  
Sec. 2-63. - Quorum; presiding officer; rules of order. 
A majority of the members of the council serving shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of business at any meeting. The mayor or mayor pro tempore shall preside, except that, in the absence of both, the members shall elect a presiding member. Except as otherwise required by state law or this Code, all proceedings of the council shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(Code 1980, § 2-33)  
Sec. 2-64. - Rules of order. 
(a)  Rules of procedure. 
(1)  Authority. S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-250 provides that: "The council shall determine its own rules and order of business and shall provide for keeping minutes of its proceedings which shall be a public record." 
(2)  Purpose. The purpose of city council in adopting rules of order is to enable the council to transact business with speed and efficiency while protecting the rights of all persons whether in the majority or the minority. Arbitrary technical rules must not prevent the council from accomplishing the public's business. Therefore, it is the intent of the council that common sense and courtesy be applied when enforcing the rules of procedure so that the will of the majority of the council may be achieved while insuring that all positions are heard and considered. 
(3)  Presiding officer. Normally the mayor or, in the mayor's absence, the mayor pro tempore, shall preside at any meeting. Notwithstanding that however, city council may, upon motion passed by a two-thirds majority of all council members serving, elect a council chairperson and vice-chairperson who shall then serve as presiding officer at all future meetings until the next general or special election at which any member of the council, including the mayor, is elected and takes office. In the event that the mayor or mayor pro tempore (or chairperson or vice-chairperson) is not in attendance or is ineligible to preside at any meeting, the members present shall elect a member to preside. 
(4)  Order of business. The standard order of business, which shall be reflected in the meeting agenda, shall be as follows: 
a.  Call to order. 
b.  Invocation. 
c.  Pledge of allegiance. 
d.  Approval or correction of agenda. [3] 
e.  Approval or correction of minutes. 
f.  Public requests, presentation of petitions, awards, memorials. 
g.  Nonagenda items from the public (total time limited to 30 minutes and each speaker limited to three minutes). 
h.  Second reading and adoption of ordinances. 
i.  First reading and advertisement of ordinances. 
j.  Resolutions. 
k.  Motions. 
l.  Nonagenda items from the public (each speaker limited to three minutes). 
m.  Communications from the city council and the city manager. 
n.  Reports and information presentations from city staff. 
o.  Executive session. [4] 
p.  Adjournment. 
(5)  Procedure pursuant to the agenda. 
a.  Information and presentation items. Many items on a meeting agenda do not involve a decision making or legislative action on the part of the council. These include the invocation, presentations, awards, and nonagenda items from the public. When these items are reached on the agenda, the presiding officer should simply announce them and introduce the individual or group who will be making the presentation or providing the information. If a discussion involving the presenters and council members is appropriate, the presiding officer should control the discussion to maintain proper decorum and to insure that the discussion remains relevant to the agenda topic. When it becomes apparent that the subject has been thoroughly covered or the discussion has become redundant or strayed from the topic, the presiding officer should, with the consensus of the council, end the discussion and announce the next agenda item. 
b.  Legislative items. The council takes action by resolution or ordinance. Ordinances must be in writing and in the form required for final adoption when introduced. Resolutions are most commonly introduced in writing but may be introduced and approved in oral form. Upon reaching an ordinance or resolution on the agenda, the presiding officer will read the ordinance or resolution by title (or the presiding officer may ask the city clerk to read it) and ask the city manager to present a brief explanation of the ordinance to include its expected effect and who has proposed it. The manager may ask a staff member or a retained expert to give this briefing. 
After the manager's briefing, the presiding officer will call for a motion from the council. If no motion is made, or if the motion is not seconded, the presiding officer will move on to the next agenda item. If a motion is made and seconded, the presiding officer will call for discussion in the following order: 
1.  The applicant or its representative. Council members may ask questions of the applicant or its representative during the applicant's presentation. 
2.  Individuals to address council. [5] Any citizen, resident, or other interested individual may address council during the first or second reading of an ordinance or resolution. The presiding officer may alternate between proponents and opponents when recognizing individuals to address council. Council members may ask questions of the individual during the individual's presentation. 
3.  The mayor and members of council. During the presentation of each member of council and the mayor, they may also ask questions of any speaker who will be asked to return to the podium to respond to the questions. 
After the discussion is completed, the presiding officer shall, if the motion has not been disposed of or postponed by subsidiary motion, immediately restate the motion before council and call for the vote of council. Following the vote, the presiding officer should immediately announce the results. 
c.  Nonagenda items. Nonagenda items from the public or staff will be accepted only for the information of the council. 
(6)  Motions. A motion is the means by which the city council takes any legislative action. Motions are ranked in order of precedence: a motion may be made only if no motion of equal or higher precedence is on the floor. The precedence of each motion is indicated in brackets after its title. All motions must be seconded, and are adopted by majority vote unless otherwise noted. All motions may be debated unless otherwise noted. These motions (indicated by an asterisk) may be made at any time that they are relevant to the issue presently on the floor or the decision which has just been made: 
a.  Motion to adjourn [1]. Not debatable; goes to immediate majority vote. 
b.  Call for the orders of the day [1]. Directs the presiding officer to return to the approved agenda. Not debatable. 
c.  Call the question [1]. Not debatable. Closes debate on the motion on the floor and forces a vote on that motion. Requires a two-thirds-majority vote. 
d.  Motion to limit or extend limits of debate [2]. Not debatable, can be amended, requires a two-thirds-majority vote. 
e.  Motion to refer [2]. Should specify which committee, board, or commission the matter is to be referred to, what council expects the group to do, and when it should be reported back to council. Approval of this motion ends discussion of the matter and the presiding officer should proceed to the next agenda item. 
f.  Motion to continue [3]. May be made instead of a main motion when an agenda item comes before the council or at any time before the main motion is disposed of. Should specify when the matter is to be brought back before the council and what action or information is desired before it is brought back. If approved it ends consideration of the agenda item for the current meeting and the presiding officer should move to the next item. 
g.  Motion to amend [3]. 
h.  Main motion [4]. 
i.  Motion to appeal decision of the presiding officer. [6] Not debatable. Requires immediate vote. Always stated by presiding officer so that a yes vote sustains his or her decision. Presiding officer retains the chair, but must proceed as voted by the majority. 
j.  Object to the consideration of a question.* Once agenda is approved, requires two-thirds-majority vote. Not debatable. 
k.  Point of order.* This is a request from a member for action by the presiding officer and may be made even when someone else has been recognized to speak. No second is required; no amendment is permitted; and no vote is required unless the presiding officer asks the council to decide the issue or the decision of the presiding officer is appealed. The point of order is frequently used to question a procedure undertaken by the presiding officer or to suggest an alternate procedure to the presiding officer. 
l.  Motion to reconsider.* May only be made before adjournment of the meeting at which the original action was taken. Must be made by a council member who voted on the winning side on the original action. Nothing in this subsection should be construed to prevent the original matter from being placed on the agenda for a subsequent meeting if requested by at least three council members. After 90 days, the original matter may be added to a meeting agenda using the same procedure as with any other matter not previously decided by council. 
m.  Motion to suspend the rules.* Can be made at any time that no question is pending. If a matter is before the council and the motion to suspend is applicable to that matter, the motion to suspend takes precedence over all other motions. It is not debatable or amendable and requires a two-thirds-majority to pass. This motion permits the council to do something it wishes to do but cannot without violating one or more of the rules contained in its rules of procedure. This motion cannot be used to modify or suspend any requirement of state law. 
(7)  Public hearings. A public hearing is a special type of meeting. It is intended to provide the council the opportunity to gather information from public input and provide information to the public. State law requires that a public hearing be conducted under certain circumstances. The presiding officer should call the hearing to order and announce the purpose of the hearing. The presiding officer should recognize individuals who wish to address council and should ensure that representatives of all competing views have a fair opportunity to express those views. The council can take no action during the public hearing. 
A public hearing may be a separate meeting or may be held during a regular council meeting. If it is during a regular council meeting it generally occurs at the point on the agenda where the subject of the public hearing is listed for action. In that case the presiding officer must clearly announce the start of the hearing and the adjournment of the hearing so that it is clear when the special rules applicable to the hearing apply and when the rules of procedure for regular council business are restored. A record of each public hearing must be kept and should include: 
a.  A hearing agenda. 
b.  A record of all the members of the public who participate. 
c.  Proof of any required notice or publication. 
d.  Minutes or a tape of the proceedings. 
e.  Copies of any materials received from the public or distributed to the public. 
(8)  Disruptive conduct. These rules of procedure are adopted based on the expectation that all persons attending a meeting of the city council will be honorable and will conduct themselves with courtesy for all other individuals present. In most situations where an individual's conduct becomes disruptive, it will be inadvertent and a warning from the presiding officer will be sufficient to correct the offensive behavior. If that is not the case, or if the presiding officer is determined by council to be disrupting or obstructing the proceedings of a council meeting, the following shall apply. 
a.  It is unlawful for any person to disrupt a meeting of city council. If a person who is determined by the presiding officer, or by a majority vote of council, to be disruptive, refuses to discontinue the disruptive behavior, the matter will be immediately reported to the police department who will, upon responding, take necessary action to end the disruption. Action by the police may include, if necessary, removing the offending individual from the meeting room. 
b.  In a case where the disruptive person is a member of council, a determination that the disruptive behavior is in violation of these rules shall be made by a majority vote of council. 
c.  If the presiding officer refuses to call for action on a matter on an approved agenda, ignores a motion apparently made and seconded in good faith, refuses to allow council to vote on an appeal from a decision or ruling of the presiding officer, or in any other way refuses to conduct the meeting in accordance with these rules, council may by majority vote declare the chair vacated. Any council member may move to vacate the chair based on the refusal of the presiding officer and, upon receiving a second, the member who made the motion may call for the immediate vote of council. If the motion receives a majority vote the position of presiding officer shall be filled for the remainder of the meeting as provided in subsection (b)(3) of this section, as if the presiding officer were absent. Unless the original presiding officer is removed from the meeting as provided in subsection (b)(8)a of this section, he shall be permitted to remain in the meeting and participate as any other council member. 
(9)  Items not covered. Any matter or order of procedure not covered by these rules shall be referred to the presiding officer who shall decide the matter in conformity with the purpose of these rules. The decision of the presiding officer may be reversed on appeal by a majority vote of council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-43; Ord. No. 06112001, 6-11-2001; Ord. No. 02112008C, § 1, 2-11-2008) 
State Law reference— Council to determine its own rules and order of business, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-250(b). 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— The South Carolina Freedom of Information Act requires that an agenda be advertised 24 hours before the scheduled meeting time. It has been argued by some parties that this prevents the amendment of the agenda after the advertisement. The better argument seems to be that when it is necessary in the public interest to add a matter to the agenda after it is published, the council may do so. 

--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— When related to the item being considered, an executive session may be held at the time a matter is being discussed if a majority of the council votes to do so. 

--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— There is no state law requirement that public input be accepted during the consideration of a resolution or ordinance. With limited exceptions, there is no state law requirement for a public hearing on a resolution or ordinance. 

--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— These motions may be made at any time that they are relevant to the issue presently on the floor or the decision which has just been made. 
 
Sec. 2-65. - Agenda. 
Matters to be considered by the council at a regular meeting shall be placed on a written agenda prepared by the city manager and publicly posted by the city manager by noon of the day preceding the meeting. Matters not on the agenda may be considered upon request of a member, unless two members object. 
(Code 1980, § 2-34)  
Sec. 2-66. - Voting requirements; permission required for member to leave chamber. 
(a)  All actions of the council shall be by majority vote of the members present at a public meeting. 
(b)  The vote on every question shall be recorded in the council minutes. 
(c)  No member of the council may leave the council chamber, while the council is in public session, without permission of the presiding officer. 
(Code 1980, § 2-35)  
Sec. 2-67. - Minutes. 
The city clerk shall keep the minutes of all public meetings of the council, which shall be a matter of permanent public record. At each council meeting, the minutes of the previous meeting shall be presented for approval. Minutes shall not be considered the official record of a meeting until approved by the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-36)  
Sec. 2-68. - City attorney to attend, act as parliamentarian, etc. 
The city attorney shall attend all meetings of the council, unless excused by the council. The city attorney shall act as parliamentarian, propose ordinances and resolutions, review all ordinances, resolutions and documents presented to the council and give opinions upon questions of procedure, form and law to any member of the council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-37)  
Sec. 2-69. - Hearings by special committees. 
The city council may appoint a special committee to assist in or hold a public hearing for the council at any time upon any matter pending before it. Minutes or reports of hearings held by special committees shall be filed with the city clerk as public records. 
(Code 1980, § 2-39)  
Secs. 2-70—2-85. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— City to establish rules and procedures for adoption of ordinances, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-270. 
 
Sec. 2-86. - Notice required prior to introduction of certain ordinances. 
Prior to the introduction of an ordinance granting a franchise, license or right for the use of any street or public property, or for the permanent closing of any abandoned street, the city clerk shall publish a notice in three issues of a newspaper having general circulation in the city stating the nature of the franchise, license or right sought or a description of the street sought to be closed, and the date on which the application is to be presented to the city council, which shall be at least one week after the last notice. This requirement shall not apply to the temporary closing of a public street initiated by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-45)  
Sec. 2-87. - Form generally. 
(a)  Every proposed ordinance shall be introduced in writing and in the form required for final adoption, which shall include: 
(1)  A title briefly describing the content; 
(2)  Findings, reasons or basis for the ordinance, if desired and appropriate; 
(3)  An enacting clause; 
(4)  Citation of any ordinance repealed; 
(5)  The provisions of the ordinance, including section numbers, if the ordinance is to be codified or amends an existing codified ordinance; 
(6)  The effective date of the ordinance; 
(7)  The approval of the city attorney as to form and the assignment of an ordinance number; and 
(8)  Space for the signatures of the mayor or presiding member of the council and the city clerk attesting notice, if required, and adoption. 
(b)  Written resolutions shall be in such similar form as deemed appropriate by the city attorney. 
(Code 1980, § 2-46) 
State Law reference— Ordinances to be introduced in writing and in form required for final adoption, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-270.  
Sec. 2-88. - Introduction, notice, etc., of ordinances. 
(a)  A proposed ordinance shall be referred to the city attorney for approval as to form. The city attorney shall render assistance in the preparation of notices and ordinances. After an ordinance is in proper form and required notices have been given, the city attorney shall send the ordinance to the city manager to be held for public inspection. An ordinance shall be deemed to be introduced when its title is read. 
(b)  Every ordinance shall be introduced in writing in the form in which it is to be finally passed and, after passage on first reading, the title and a summary of the content of the ordinance shall be published stating the time and place, it will be given a public hearing and be considered for final passage. Any individual desiring to speak to council during either first or second reading of each ordinance shall be allowed to speak to council as set forth in section 2-64(5)b. 
(Code 1980, § 2-47; Ord. No. 02112008C, § 1, 2-11-2008)  
Sec. 2-89. - Introduction of resolutions. 
A voice motion of a member of the council shall be considered to be the introduction of an oral resolution, which shall require no written record other than a notation of the city clerk in the council minutes. A resolution proposed in writing shall be introduced in the same manner as an ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 2-48)  
Sec. 2-90. - Enactment of ordinances. 
(a)  An ordinance to levy a tax, adopt a budget, appropriate funds, grant a franchise, license or right to use or occupy a public street or public property for commercial purposes shall be complete in the form in which it is to be finally passed and in such form remain on file with the city clerk for public inspection at least one week before final adoption. 
(b)  No ordinance shall be adopted until it shall have been read two times and on two separate days with at least six days between each reading. 
(c)  Emergency ordinances may be adopted on one reading without notice or hearing by affirmative vote of two-thirds of the members present. An emergency ordinance may not levy taxes, relate to a franchise or a service rate and shall expire automatically on the 61st day following enactment. [8] 
(d)  The, first reading of an ordinance shall be by title only, unless a member of the council requests full reading. However, reading of an ordinance by title only shall be a sufficient reading upon both first and second readings, as to any ordinance more than 500 words in length, as to any ordinance adopting a technical code such as building, zoning, housing, gas, electric, plumbing or other similar codes, and as to adoption of sections of the Code of Laws of South Carolina by reference, provided that, in regard to such ordinances, reading in full may be required upon either first or second reading, or both, by majority vote of the council members present. [9] 
(e)  After the introduction of an ordinance, whether on first reading or on second reading, any member of the council or any citizen of the city, or any other individual, interested therein may request a public hearing, which may be held at any time designated by the council prior to final adoption. 
(f)  Upon final adoption by vote of the council, an ordinance shall be signed by the mayor or presiding member and attested by the city clerk, who shall file the original in the council minutes. 
(Code 1980, § 2-49; Ord. No. 02112008C, § 1, 2-11-2008) 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-270. 

--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-250(d). 
 
Sec. 2-91. - Adoption of resolutions. 
Written or oral resolutions may be adopted on one reading, unless a public hearing is set by a majority of the members of the council present. 
(Code 1980, § 2-50)  
Secs. 2-92—2-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance relating to salaries of city officers and employees or to compensation or pay plans or classification plans for such officers or employees saved from repeal, § 1-5(4). 
 
Sec. 2-111. - Personnel regulations. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect the validity of the city employee handbook. 
(Code 1980, § 2-3)  
Sec. 2-112. - Grievance procedure for complaints by disabled persons concerning services, programs, or activities. 
(a)  The following grievance procedure is adopted to meet the requirements of the regulations promulgated by the United States Department of Justice to enforce the provisions of Subtitle A of Title II of the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990 concerning the alleged exclusion from participation in or denial of benefits of city services, programs, or activities. This grievance procedure should be used by any qualified individual with a disability who wishes to file a complaint alleging discrimination on the basis of that disability concerning his or her exclusion from participation in or denial of the benefits of city services, programs, or activities. 
(b)  The grievance complaint shall be in written form and contain as much information as possible about the alleged discrimination. Other arrangements for submission of a grievance, such as a personal interview or tape recording, may be made available for those individuals with a disability that make it impractical to submit a written grievance complaint. The grievance complaint should be submitted within 30 calendar days of the alleged violation, unless good cause is shown for submitting the complaint at a later date, to the Assistant City Manager, Municipal Building, 214 Park Avenue South West, Aiken, South Carolina 29801, (803-642-7654). The office hours for this location are from 8:10 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(c)  Within 15 working days of receipt of the grievance complaint, the assistant city manager will respond in writing to the complainant concerning the grievance or may respond in such other manner as is reasonably calculated to communicate the response to the complainant. The response will offer a resolution or explanation of the position of the city on the complaint. 
(d)  If the response by the assistant city manager is not sufficient or does not satisfactorily resolve the issue for the complainant, the complainant may, within 15 calendar days of the date of the response, request an informal hearing before the city council. This request should be in writing, or in such other form as is practical for the complainant based upon his or her disability, and submitted to the Assistant City Manager, Municipal Building, 214 Park Avenue South West, Aiken, South Carolina, 29801, (803-642-7654). The office hours of this location are the same as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. Within 30 calendar days of the hearing conducted by council, the complainant, will receive the written resolution of the complaint as determined by city council. 
(e)  All complaints received by the assistant city manager and all responses by that official or by city council shall be kept by the city for such period as is required by law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-8)  
Sec. 2-113. - City employees employed at-will. 
It is hereby declared to be city policy that, notwithstanding any policies, memoranda, or handbooks promulgated by the city or any employment practices by the city: 
(1)  All employees of the city are employed at-will and may resign or be discharged from employment at any time. 
(2)  Only the city council shall have the right to enter into employment contracts for other than at-will employment on the city's behalf. Any contract for employment other than at-will employment must: 
a.  Be in writing; 
b.  Be executed by the city mayor; 
c.  Specify the duration of the employment; and 
d.  Specifically state that the contract is being created pursuant to the city's authority under this section. 
(Ord. No. 08112003C, § 1, 8-11-2003)  
Secs. 2-114—2-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Election commission, § 14-3. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-141. - Attendance of members of boards and commissions. 
Any appointed member of a board or commission created by an ordinance of the city council who during a calendar year is absent from 40 percent or more of the regular meetings or three or more successive regular meetings of the board or commission shall automatically be removed therefrom shall not be reinstated to the remainder of his term except by a resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-9)  
Sec. 2-142. - Composition and terms of specific boards and commissions. 
(a)  This section shall apply to the following boards and commissions whose makeup is as follows: 
	Number of 
Members 	Terms 
Accommodations tax committee 	7 	2 years 
Arts commission 	7 	2 years 
Board of zoning appeals 	7 	3 years 
Building code appeals commission 	7 	2 years 
Community development committee 	7 	2 years 
Design review board 	7 	2 years 
Energy and environmental committee 	7 	2 years 
Equine committee 	14 	2 years 
General aviation commission 	7 	2 years 
Housing authority board 	7 	5 years 
Park commission 	7 	2 years 
Planning commission 	7 	2 years 
Recreation commission 	7 	2 years 
Senior commission 	7 	2 years 
 
(b)  These boards and commissions shall be comprised of seven members (14 members for the equine committee) with the terms set forth above. Each member of city council shall have appointment power for one member of each commission or board (two members for the equine committee). Upon the expiration of a member's term, the applicable council member shall nominate a replacement. Each nomination shall be voted upon by city council in a public session. If a nomination fails to be approved by a majority of council, the council member making the nomination shall nominate a replacement member. This process shall be repeated until city council approves a council member's nominee by a majority vote. 
(c)  Members of boards, commissions, and committees who are appointed by city council shall serve for a period of time to coincide with the current term of the council member who recommended that appointment, unless a shorter term is provided. In the event that members of boards, commissions, and committees have time remaining to serve on a board, commission, or committee following the election or appointment of a new council member, their terms shall expire once the newly elected or appointed council member has appointed that member's replacement in accordance with section 2-142(b). 
(d)  City staff shall maintain a list of citizens who volunteer to serve on boards and commissions. A short application or resume may be used to show a citizen's interest in serving on boards and commissions. Council members may review current volunteer applications before selecting candidates for appointment to a board or commission. Council members should make sure that proposed candidates have no apparent conflict of interest. Council members should exert every effort to propose individuals who broadly represent the Aiken community. Nominations to the boards and commissions shall be accompanied by an application, or resume, of the proposed appointee. 
(e)  These appointments shall be made under all applicable federal laws, state statutes and city ordinances, including, but not limited to, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 6-29-350, 6-29-360, 6-29-780, 6-29-790 and 6-29-870. 
(Code 1980, § 2-9.1; Ord. No. 02252002, § 1, Exh. A, 2-25-2002; Ord. No. 04142003B, § 1, 4-14-2003; Ord. No. 02282005A, § 1, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 10092017D , § 1, 10-9-2017; Ord. No. 03122018 , § 1, 3-12-2018; Ord. No. 05132019 , § 1, 2, 5-13-2019)  
Sec. 2-143. - Authority to appoint sub-committees. 
From time to time, the city's boards, commissions, and committees, hereinafter referred to as "boards," and more specifically set forth in section 2-142 above, have the need to appoint advisory committees to perform a study about a particular matter before the boards; provide the boards with research and insight about a particular matter before the boards; and to advise the boards about the effect of proposed changes to various codes, ordinances and/or regulations of the city. In order to allow the swift appointment of members to these various advisory committees, the chair of each board may appoint a committee chair or ad hoc or task force members of these advisory committees unless otherwise appointed by city council in accordance with their rules and regulations. However, if more than one individual expresses an interest in a position being filled by the chair, then the position(s) shall be filled by a vote of the entire board.
