The bylaws of the city boards shall be amended to comply with this section. 
(Ord. No. 03272006A, § 1, 3-27-2006)  
Secs. 2-144—2-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-161. - Membership. 
The community development committee shall consist of seven members to be appointed by the city council. The terms of office of the members of the community development committee shall be for two years, except that the terms of the initial members shall be staggered. Any vacancy in membership of the community development committee shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor who shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause on written charges after a public hearing. All members of the community development committee shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1980, § 2-170)  
Sec. 2-162. - Organization; meetings; rules; staff and finances. 
The community development committee shall elect a chair and vice-chair from among its members. The term of the chair and other offices shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. It shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or an employee of the city. The community development committee shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its recommendations, transactions, findings and determinations and shall meet at the call of the chair and at such times as the chair or committee may determine. All meetings of the community development committee at which official action is taken shall be open to the public, and all records of the committee shall be a public record. 
(Code 1980, § 2-171)  
Sec. 2-163. - Powers and duties. 
From and after the time when the community development committee shall have organized and selected its officers and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then such committee shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities as set forth as follows: 
(1)  To establish criteria, guidelines and procedures for the administration and disbursement of housing assistance funds previously approved by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, through the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. 
(2)  To approve or disapprove any application for housing assistance based on fair and equitable evaluation of the application in relation to adopted criteria, guidelines and procedures. 
(3)  To let construction bids and negotiate contracts for housing work with "approved" contractors. 
(4)  To approve all contractors and establish a register of contractors to work in the CD (community development) program. 
(5)  To inspect or have inspected all completed work and certify to the satisfactory performance of such work before authorizing payment. 
(6)  To negotiate with local lending institutions their role in the implementation of CD (community development) housing activities, if desired. 
(7)  To encourage home improvements through conventional financing and to assist applicants where possible. 
(8)  To establish a revolving fund for making low-interest housing improvement loans to low and moderate income persons. 
(9)  To perform and assist in all other related housing activities as deemed necessary to encourage the rehabilitation of substandard housing and the preservation of standard housing. 
(Code 1980, § 2-172)  
Secs. 2-164—2-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - FARMERS MARKET COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-181. - Definition. 
As used in this division, the term "commission" shall mean the farmers market commission created by this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-151) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 2-182. - Created. 
There is hereby created a commission to operate and regulate a farmers market in the city, to be known and designated as the farmers market commission. 
(Code 1980, § 2-152)  
Sec. 2-183. - Composition; appointment and terms of members. 
The farmers market commission shall consist of seven members who shall be residents of the county, to be appointed by the city council for terms of two years each. 
(Code 1980, § 2-153)  
Sec. 2-184. - Election and terms of officers. 
The members of the farmers market commission shall annually elect one of their number as chair and another as secretary and treasurer to serve in such respective offices for a term of one year or until their successors have been appointed. 
(Code 1980, § 2-154)  
Sec. 2-185. - Rules and regulations. 
The farmers market commission shall have the authority and is hereby directed to make and promulgate such necessary rules and regulations for its operation and for the licensing and fees to be granted and charged for the use of the farmers market facilities. When adopted by the commission, filed with the city clerk and approved by the city council, such rules and regulations shall have the force and effect of law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-155)  
Sec. 2-186. - Authority to purchase equipment, hire employees and enter into contracts; limitation on city's liability. 
The farmers market commission is authorized and empowered to purchase such equipment, hire such employees and enter into such contracts as may be necessary to carry out its functions; provided, however, that the city shall not be bound or obligated on any debts, contracts or other obligations or liabilities of the commission, but all debts and obligations of the farmers market commission shall be payable solely out of revenues and funds of the commission. 
(Code 1980, § 2-156)  
Sec. 2-187. - Employment and duties of market manager. 
The farmers market commission shall employ a market manager who shall be responsible to the commission for the business-like operation of the farmers market, for collecting all rental fees, for keeping all necessary records, and for enforcing all duly approved rules and regulations of the commission. 
(Code 1980, § 2-157)  
Secs. 2-188—2-205. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PLANNING COMMISSION[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference— Local planning commission, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-29-310 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-206. - Definition. 
As used in this division, the term "commission" shall mean the city planning commission. 
(Code 1980, § 2-136) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 2-207. - Created; composition; appointment of members. 
There shall be a city planning commission, which shall consist of seven members, who shall be appointed by the council. No commission member may hold any other public office or position in the city. The city manager and mayor shall serve as ex officio members of the commission. 
(Code 1980, § 2-137)  
Sec. 2-208. - Terms of office for members; filling of vacancies. 
The term of office for the seven appointive members of the planning commission shall be two years. Each such term shall commence on December 1 on the first year of the appointment and expire on November 30 of the last year of term. The terms of office shall be staggered so that two expire simultaneously each year except for the year in which only one shall expire. Any vacancy during an unexpired term of an appointive member of the planning commission shall be filled by the city council for the remainder of the term. 
(Code 1980, § 2-138)  
Sec. 2-209. - Election of chair. 
The planning commission shall elect from among its appointed members a chair. 
(Code 1980, § 2-139)  
Sec. 2-210. - Duties. 
The planning commission shall be required to: 
(1)  Recommend to the council a master plan and subsequent modifications and additions thereto. 
(2)  Recommend platting and subdivision regulations. 
(3)  Cause to be prepared and recommend to the council the adoption of an official map of the city and any modifications or additions thereto. 
(4)  Recommend to the council a zoning plan, including all necessary regulations, modifications and additions thereto. 
(5)  Recommend to the council plans for the clearance and redevelopment of slum districts and blighted areas within the city. 
(6)  Submit annually to the city manager, not less than 90 days prior to the beginning of the budget year, a list of recommended capital improvements which, in the opinion of the commission, are necessary or desirable to be constructed during the forthcoming five-year period. Such list shall be arranged in order of preference with recommendations as to which projects shall be constructed in which year. 
(7)  Promote public interest in and understanding of the master plan and planning, zoning and slum clearance. 
(8)  Keep a public record of its resolutions, findings and determinations. 
(Code 1980, § 2-140)  
Secs. 2-211—2-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DEPARTMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-231—2-245. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER AND ADMINISTRATIVE BRANCH OF GOVERNMENT[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of council to establish administrative departments and assign and distribute work thereof, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-13-30(2). 
 
Sec. 2-246. - Composition of administrative branch. 
The administrative branch of the city shall be composed of the office of the city manager and the department, divisions and offices listed in this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-61)  
Sec. 2-247. - Appointment, term and removal of city manager. 
(a)  The city council shall appoint, by a majority vote of all its members, a city manager. No council member shall receive such appointment during the term for which he shall have been elected, nor within two years after the expiration of his term. 
(b)  The council shall appoint the city manager for an indefinite term and may remove him only by a majority vote of all of its members. At least 30 days before such removal shall become effective, the council shall, by a majority vote of all its members, adopt a preliminary resolution stating the reasons for his removal. The manager may reply in writing and may request a public hearing, which shall be held not earlier than 20 days nor later than 30 days after the filing of such request. After such public hearing, if one be requested, and after full consideration, the council, by majority vote of all its members, may adopt a final resolution of removal. By the preliminary resolution, the council may suspend the manager from duty, but shall, in any event, cause to be paid him forthwith any unpaid balance of his salary for the next calendar month following adoption of the preliminary resolution. 
(Code 1980, § 2-62) 
State Law reference— Employment, qualifications, term and removal of city manager, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 5-13-50, 5-13-70.  
Sec. 2-248. - City manager as chief administrative officer; general powers and duties of manager. 
The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer and the head of the administrative branch of the city government. The city manager shall be responsible to the council for the proper administration of all affairs of the city and to that end, the city manager shall have the power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Appoint and, when necessary for the good of the public, remove all officers and employees of the city, except as otherwise provided by this chapter or other provisions of this Code and except as he may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint and remove subordinates in such department or office. 
(2)  Prepare the budget annually and submit it to the council and be responsible for its administration after adoption. 
(3)  Prepare and submit to the council, as of the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the city for the preceding year. 
(4)  Keep the council advised of the financial condition and future needs of the city and make such recommendations as may seem to him desirable. 
(5)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by this Code or state law or required of the city manager by the council, not inconsistent with this chapter or state law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-63) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-13-90.  
Sec. 2-249. - City manager shall establish fees for review of annexation, zoning, subdivision, utilities, and similar applications and for planning commission special meetings. 
The city manager shall establish fees to be charged applicants who file requests with the planning commission or department of planning and community development for annexations, zoning approvals, signs, site plans, landscape plans, subdivisions, utilities, telecommunications towers site plans and similar actions and for special meetings of the planning commission. Such fees shall be based upon the manager's estimate of the actual costs and staff time incurred by the city in reviewing each type of application or request or conducting the special meeting. The city manager annually shall review such fees for the purpose of making adjustments based upon his estimates of such costs. The city manager shall promptly report all such adjustments to the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-63.1)  
Sec. 2-250. - Administrative regulations. 
The city manager shall be authorized to prepare and issue regulations concerning the administration of the city's affairs and the enforcement of this Code and all city ordinances in accordance with policies prescribed by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-64)  
Sec. 2-251. - Inquiries and investigations by city manager. 
The city manager, or any person or committee authorized by him, shall have power to inquire into the conduct of any office, department, agency or officer of the city and to make investigations as to municipal affairs, and for that purpose may subpoena witnesses, administer oaths and compel the production of books, papers and other evidence. 
(Code 1980, § 2-65)  
Sec. 2-252. - Distribution of administrative functions. 
The administrative functions of the city shall be distributed among the office of the city manager and the various departments, divisions and offices referred to in this division. 
(Code 1980, § 2-66)  
Sec. 2-253. - Department directors generally. 
(a)  At the head of each department, there shall be a director, who shall be an officer of the city and shall have supervision and control of the department, subject to the direction of the city manager. Two or more departments may be headed by the same individual. The city manager may head one or more departments and directors of departments may also serve as heads of divisions. 
(b)  Each department head shall be responsible to the city manager and shall exercise administrative authority within his department. Each department head shall be responsible for preserving public records relative to the function of his department and, subject to the city manager's directives, he shall furnish other departments such service, labor and materials as may be necessary in accordance with such procedures and budgetary controls as may be established. Each department head shall submit annual and monthly reports in writing to the city manager, following the format prescribed by the city manager. Each department head shall submit to the city manager, at such date and in such detail as the city manager may require, estimates of operating and capital expenditures. Each department head shall also submit work programs when required by the city manager. 
(c)  Each department head shall perform such additional duties relating to the conduct of city affairs as may be assigned to him by the city manager or by law. 
(Code 1980, § 2-67) 
State Law reference— Department heads designated as directors, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-13-100.  
Sec. 2-254. - Department divisions. 
(a)  The departments of the city government shall be composed of such divisions, with such duties and functions, as are prescribed by the city manager. 
(b)  At the head of each departmental division, there shall be an officer who shall have the authority to direct and supervise the division under the general supervision of the director of the department. Two or more divisions may be headed by the same individual. 
(Code 1980, § 2-68)  
Sec. 2-255. - City clerk. 
(a)  The city clerk shall be appointed by and shall be subject to removal by the city manager. 
(b)  The city clerk shall be the custodian of the official seal of the city and all official documents of the city, serve as clerk to the city council, record and file council actions, administer oaths and perform such other duties as may be assigned him by law or by the city manager. 
(c)  The city clerk shall make available for inspection by any citizen, any representative of a citizen's organization or any representative of the press, at all reasonable times and under reasonable regulations established by the city manager, all official documents in his custody, except records and documents, the disclosure of which, in the discretion of the city manager, would tend to defeat the lawful purpose which they are intended to accomplish. 
(Code 1980, § 2-69) 
State Law reference— Appointment and general duties of clerk, S. C. Code 1976, § 5-7-220.  
Sec. 2-256. - Administration department. 
There shall be an administration department headed by the city manager who shall be responsible for the preparation and execution of the budget, the purchase of supplies, materials and equipment required by the city, the administration of the personnel program in accordance with regulations of the merit system and the development of a city insurance program. 
(Code 1980, § 2-70)  
Sec. 2-257. - Finance department. 
There shall be a finance department, headed by a finance director. The director shall be responsible to the city manager for financial planning, accounting, licensing, property and fiscal records, collections, internal auditing and other fiscal activities. 
(Code 1980, § 2-71)  
Sec. 2-258. - Department of public safety. 
(a)  There shall be a department of public safety, headed by a director of public safety. The director of public safety shall be responsible to the city manager for the enforcement of state laws and city ordinances, protection of life and property, preservation of law and order, traffic control, investigation of crimes, apprehension and custody of criminals, the suppression of vice and the prevention and control of juvenile delinquency. The director of public safety shall likewise be responsible to the city manager for the direction of all firefighting, fire prevention and fire service activities of the city. 
(b)  The director of public safety shall direct the assignment of public safety officers, establish training programs, establish departmental procedures pursuant to this Code or other city ordinances and administrative regulations issued by the city manager and shall cooperate with other law enforcement and firefighting agencies. 
(c)  The director of public safety, with the approval of the city manager, may appoint volunteer part-time law enforcement officers with limited duties for the purpose of enforcing specific laws or ordinances within the jurisdiction of the municipal court. The director of public safety shall establish written policies regulating the appointment, training, supervision, and duties of such officers. Such officers shall receive no compensation or benefits, shall serve at no cost or liability to the city, shall not have the power of arrest, and are subject to dismissal by the director of public safety for any reason at any time. 
(d)  When any public safety officer impounds or takes possession of any vehicle in the discharge of his duties, an inventory of the contents of such vehicle shall be made immediately and filed with the department of public safety. 
(Code 1980, §§ 2-72, 2-73) 
Cross reference— Removal of illegally stopped vehicles, § 42-73.  
Sec. 2-259. - Department of public works; director. 
There shall be a department of public works headed by a director. The director of the department of public works shall be responsible to the city manager for all activities relating to the planning, construction, maintenance and operation of municipal utilities, public ways, garbage collection and waste disposal facilities, city buildings, parks and other physical properties of the city which have not been otherwise assigned by the city manager. The director of the department of public works shall also be responsible for the animal shelter. The director of the department of public works shall render such assistance to the planning commission and other departments as shall be authorized by the city manager. 
(Code 1980, § 2-74)  
Sec. 2-260. - Department of parks and recreation—Powers and duties of director. 
(a)  There shall be a parks and recreation department headed by a director. The director of parks and recreation shall be responsible to the city manager for the operation and supervision of all existing public playgrounds, athletic fields, swimming pools, tennis courts, baseball and other ball fields, municipal camps, and all other recreational facilities on or in any public grounds or buildings, either within or without the city, owned by the city; or on or in any public grounds or buildings now or hereafter acquired which the city may from time to time authorize, designate or set apart for recreational purposes. 
(b)  The director of parks and recreation shall be required to: 
(1)  Promote public interest and participation in all of the recreational activities of his department. 
(2)  Keep himself advised and informed of the recreational activities in the greatest demand and those which would yield maximum public participation, and whenever possible, organize and conduct such recreational activities. 
(3)  Cooperate with other public and private organizations in the utilization of available private and public facilities and personnel, which serve the recreational needs of the community. 
(c)  The director of parks and recreation shall be responsible for permitting the use of public playgrounds, parks, baseball and other ball fields under his control, but shall not have the authority for the granting of leases or concessions on, in or at such recreational facilities. The city manager shall have the authority to grant leases or concessions to be operated in or at the recreational facilities of the city, subject to approval by the city council. 
(d)  The director of parks and recreation shall be responsible for the care of property, personal and real, under his control. 
(e)  With the consent of public school authorities, the director of parks and recreation may organize and conduct play and recreational activities on grounds and in buildings under the control of such school authorities. 
(f)  The director of parks and recreation shall have authority to operate and maintain privately owned lands or buildings where use for public recreational purposes may be temporarily granted by the owners and accepted by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-75) 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, ch. 26.  
Sec. 2-261. - Same—Charges for use parks and recreational facilities. 
All fees, rentals, admissions and other charges made to the public for the use of city recreational facilities shall be recommended by the director of parks and recreation, reviewed by the city manager and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-76)  
Sec. 2-262. - Disposition of money collected. 
All moneys collected, derived or received by or from any operation of the parks and recreation department shall be paid daily to the city manager or any other officer of the city designated by him. 
(Code 1980, § 2-77)  
Secs. 2-263—2-280. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DEPARTMENT OF LEGAL SERVICES[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 03262012A, § 1(Exh. A), adopted March 26, 2012, amended Div. 3 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 3, §§ 2-281—2-286, pertained to the same subject matter, and derived from Code 1980, §§ 2-88—2-93. 
 
Sec. 2-281. - Appointment of city attorney, city solicitor; terms; removal. 
(a)  The city attorney shall be appointed by, serve at the pleasure of, and be subject to removal by the city council. The city council, with the advice and consent of the city manager, may appoint one person to serve as the city attorney/city solicitor, and in the event of such appointment, it shall be considered one position or office. 
(b)  The city solicitor shall be appointed by, serve at the pleasure of, and be subject to removal by the city manager. 
(c)  All appointments for city attorney and city solicitor shall require the execution of a contract which shall be prepared by the city manager's office and must set forth the terms of the appointment to include compensation details, malpractice insurance coverage requirements, worker's compensation insurance requirements, and other details which may be deemed important by the city manager and city council. 
(Ord. No. 03262012A, § 1(Exh. A), 3-26-2012) 
State Law reference— Authority of council to appoint city attorney, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-230.  
Sec. 2-282. - Qualifications. 
The city attorney shall be an attorney at law who has been admitted to practice before the supreme court of the state. The city attorney shall be a member in good standing of the bar of the state at the time of his appointment and throughout his term of office. If for any reason he shall cease to be a member in good standing of the state bar at any time while serving as city attorney, he shall thereupon become immediately disqualified and shall be dismissed as city attorney by the city council. The qualifications for city solicitor shall be the same as those for city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 03262012A, § 1(Exh. A), 3-26-2012)  
Sec. 2-283. - Compensation. 
The salary of the city attorney shall be established by the city council. The salary of the city solicitor shall be established by the city manager and subject to approval by city council as part of the city's annual budget process. 
(Ord. No. 03262012A, § 1(Exh. A), 3-26-2012)  
Sec. 2-284. - Department of legal services. 
There shall be a department of legal services headed by the city solicitor who shall also serve as the director of the department. The city solicitor shall be responsible to the city manager for operations of the department as provided by section 2-253. The department shall consist of such other personnel as are assigned to it by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 03262012A, § 1(Exh. A), 3-26-2012)  
Sec. 2-285. - Duties of city attorney. 
The duties of the city attorney shall be as follows: 
(1)  The city attorney shall be the chief legal advisor to the city council and all offices, departments, boards, commissions and agencies of the city and all officers and employees of the city in matters relating to their official powers and duties, and in that capacity may communicate directly with the council and those offices, departments, boards, commissions, agencies, officers and employees. 
(2)  The city attorney shall advise the city council, its committees, the city manager or any other city officer upon all legal questions arising in the conduct of city business. 
(3)  The city attorney shall prepare and revise ordinances when so requested by any member of the city council, any committee thereof or the city manager. 
(4)  The city attorney shall prepare, for execution, contracts and other written instruments to which the city is a party and shall approve, as to form, all bonds required to be submitted to the city. 
(5)  The city attorney shall enter appearances for the city in all actions, cases and special proceedings. The city attorney shall conduct all suits and other proceedings before all courts in which the city is, or shall be, a party. This subsection shall not apply to prosecutions handled by the city solicitor. The city attorney may elect not to enter appearances in suits and proceedings in which the city is represented by outside counsel employed or retained by an insurer of the city or by the city, or in which he determines there is a conflict of interest. 
(6)  The city attorney shall make recommendations to the city manager and city council on retaining outside legal counsel on specified matters. The retaining of counsel where the estimated cost does not exceed $1,000.00 may be approved by the city manager. 
(7)  A city officer or employee who is being sued civilly for action taken in good faith in the course of his official duties may be represented by the city attorney if there is no conflict of interest as determined by the city attorney. 
(8)  With the approval of the city manager, he may settle claims against the city for an amount of $1,000.00 or less. 
(9)  The city attorney may assign any of the duties provided in this division to another attorney retained or employed by the city. 
(10)  The city attorney shall perform such other duties as are prescribed by ordinance or state law or directed by the city council or the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 03262012A, § 1(Exh. A), 3-26-2012)  
Sec. 2-286. - Duties of city solicitor. 
The city solicitor shall prosecute and represent the city in all criminal and related proceedings in municipal court and all appeals therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 03262012A, § 1(Exh. A), 3-26-2012)  
Secs. 2-287—2-310. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE[15] 
Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-5(1); taxation, ch. 38. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-311. - Service charge for returned checks and bank drafts. 
(a)  A service charge is hereby imposed upon all persons issuing checks, drafts or other orders to the city or any of the agencies or departments thereof that are returned to the city from the bank on which they were drawn for whatever reason, including but not limited to insufficient funds, closed account, or no such account, in the maximum amount allowed by S.C. Code 1976, § 34-11-70 or any successor state laws or provisions thereof. 
(b)  In the event the charge, license, fee, penalty or other obligation for which such check, draft, or other order is given is or may be secured by lien in favor of the city, the service charge applicable thereto also shall be secured by such lien. 
(Code 1980, § 2-7)  
Sec. 2-312. - Forgiveness of late fees for payments due on weekends, city holidays, federal holidays, and other emergency situations. 
In the event a payment for city services, city taxes, or city fees is due to the city on a date that falls on a Saturday or Sunday, a date that is a city holiday, or a date that is a federal holiday, then that payment shall not incur a penalty provided the full payment is made before 5:00 p.m. on the next business day following the weekend or holiday. In the event that the city manager, in his discretion, determines that circumstances such as a weather emergency or other state of emergency makes it difficult for citizens and businesses to make timely payment of their bills for city services, city taxes, or city fees, then that payment shall not incur a penalty provided the full payment is made before 5:00 p.m. on the next business day following the weather emergency of other state of emergency. 
(Ord. No. 04252011A, § 1, 4-25-2011; Ord. No. 03272017 , § 1, 3-27-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 03272017 , § 1, adopted March 27, 2017, amended § 2-312 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Payments due on weekends or city holidays" to "Forgiveness of late fees for payments due on weekends, city holidays, federal holidays, and other emergency situations," as set out herein.  
Secs. 2-313—2-330. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING AND SALES 
 
Sec. 2-331. - Purchasing agents generally. 
The city manager, or such officers of the city as designated by the city manager, shall be the purchasing agents for the city. They shall be responsible for: 
(1)  The purchase of supplies, materials, and equipment and contractual services required by any office, department, or agency of the city government. 
(2)  The storage and distribution of all supplies, materials, and equipment required by any office, department or agency of the city government. 
(3)  Establishing written specifications, whenever practicable, for supplies, materials, and equipment required by any office, department, or agency of the city government. Such specifications shall be definite and certain and shall permit competition. 
(4)  Maintaining, wherever practicable, a perpetual inventory record of all materials, supplies, or equipment stored in storerooms or warehouses. 
(5)  Soliciting and maintaining an up-to-date list of qualified suppliers who meet the criteria set forth in section 2-338 for lowest responsible bidders and have requested their names to be added to a bidders' list. The city manager or designated purchasing agents shall have authority to remove temporarily the names of vendors who have defaulted on their quotations, failed to respond to three consecutive requests for bid, attempted to defraud the city, or who have failed to meet established specifications or delivery dates. 
(6)  Obtaining as full and open competition as possible on all purchases, contracts, and sales. 
(7)  Obtaining the approval and signature of the assistant city manager or other person designated by the city manager on an appropriate form for those purchases in excess of $5,000.00 prior to the award of the bid to the lowest responsible bidder and ordering the supplies or services bid upon. 
(Code 1980, § 2-112; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-112), 3-27-2000; Ord. No. 02102014 , § 1, 2-10-2014)  
Sec. 2-332. - When formal contract required. 
All supplies and contractual services, except as otherwise provided in this article, when the estimated cost thereof shall exceed $25,000.00, shall be purchased by formal, written contract from the lowest responsible bidder after due notice inviting proposals. All sales of personal property which has become obsolete or unusable, when the estimated value shall exceed $25,000.00, shall be sold by formal, written contract to the highest responsible bidder after due notice inviting proposals. 
(Code 1980, § 2-113; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-113), 3-27-2000; Ord. No. 02102014 , § 1, 2-10-2014)  
Sec. 2-333. - General bid requirements. 
Before any purchases of or contracts for supplies, materials, equipment, or services exceeding $2,500.00 but less than $5,000.00 are made, oral bids from at least three suppliers on the bidders list, whenever possible, should be obtained. For purchases or contracts exceeding $5,000.00, but not exceeding $25,000.00 that are made, bids from at least three suppliers on the bidders list, whenever possible, must be obtained in writing. All purchases or contracts exceeding $25,000.00 are subject to the requirements set forth in sections 2-332, 2-334, 2-336 and 2-338, as well as other applicable requirements set forth in these sections. 
(Code 1980, § 2-114; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-114), 3-27-2000; Ord. No. 10102005C, § 1, 10-10-2005; Ord. No. 02102014 , § 1, 2-10-2014)  
Sec. 2-334. - Advertising for bids. 
All contracts for city improvements, materials, equipment, or services costing more than $25,000.00 shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder after publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least five days before the last day set for receipt of proposals. The newspaper notice required in this section shall include a general description of the articles or services to be purchased and shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured and the time and place for opening bids. 
(Code 1980, § 2-115; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-115), 3-27-2000; Ord. No. 02102014 , § 1, 2-10-2014)  
Sec. 2-335. - Bid deposits. 
When deemed necessary by purchasing agents, bid deposits shall be prescribed in the public notices inviting bids. Upon entering into a contract, bidders shall be entitled to return of the bid deposit where the purchasing agent has required one. A successful bidder shall forfeit any bid deposit required by the purchasing agent upon failure on his part to enter into a contract within ten days after the award; provided, however, that the city manager in his discretion may waive this forfeiture. 
(Code 1980, § 2-116; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-116), 3-27-2000; Ord. No. 01232006A, § 1 (Exh. A), 1-23-2006)  
Sec. 2-336. - General procedures for sealed bids. 
The procedure for sealed bids shall be as follows: 
(1)  Bids shall be submitted to the assistant city manager, or another designated purchasing agent, securely sealed in an envelope, and shall be identified on the envelope in accordance with all bid instructions. 
(2)  Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. 
(3)  A tabulation of all bids received shall be available for public inspection. 
(4)  The purchasing agent shall have the authority to reject all bids, parts of all bids, or all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposed contract, when the public interest will be served by doing so. 
(5)  The assistant city manager, or another designated purchasing agent, shall not accept the bid of vendors or contractors who are delinquent in the payment of taxes, licenses, or any other money due by them to the city. 
(6)  For those bids on unbudgeted items over $25,000.00, the city council must approve the bid of the lowest qualified bidder prior to its award. 
(Code 1980, § 2-117; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-117), 3-27-2000; Ord. No. 01232006A, § 1 (Exh. A), 1-23-2006)  
Sec. 2-337. - Performance and payment bonds. 
The purchasing agent shall have the authority to require a performance bond and, where appropriate, a payment bond before entering into a contract, in such form and amount as he shall find reasonably necessary to protect the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-118; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-118), 3-27-2000)  
Sec. 2-338. - Award of contract generally; determination of lowest responsible bidder. 
(a)  The purchasing agent shall have the authority to award contracts within the purview of this division; provided, however, that city council approval is required in the following instances: 
(1)  For contracts in excess of $25,000.00 for purchases not included specifically as budgeted items in the current budget; or 
(2)  Purchases which are not replacement items funded under the city depreciation accounts. 
(b)  Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the lowest responsible bidder, in addition to price, the purchasing agent or city council shall consider: 
(1)  The ability, capacity, and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required. 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract, provide the service promptly, or do so within the time specified without delay or interference. 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience, and efficiency of the bidder. 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services. 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or services. 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service. 
(7)  The quality, availability, and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use required. 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract. 
(9)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(10)  Whether the bidder has failed to fully perform prior contracts to the city's satisfaction, or is past due, delinquent, or owes the city any money of any type. 
(Code 1980, § 2-119; Ord. No. 03272000A, § 1(2-119), 3-27-2000; Ord. No. 01232006A, § 1 (Exh. A), 1-23-2006)  
Sec. 2-339. - Local vendor preference in awarding bids. 
(a)  Local vendor means a vendor who is considered to be a resident of the city or county if the vendor: 
(1)  Is an individual, partnership, association, or corporation that is authorized to transact business of the city or county; 
(2)  Maintains an office in either the city or county; 
(3)  Maintains an inventory for expendable items which are representative of the general type of commodities on which the bid is submitted and located in the city or county at the time of the bid having a total value of $10,000.00 or more based on the bid price, but not to exceed the amount of the contract; and 
(4)  Has paid all assessed taxes, fees, costs, or other revenue due to the city. 
(b)  No requirement contained in section 2-338 shall preclude the award of bids to local vendors on the following basis: 
(1)  A bid from any vendor located within the city which is no more than five percent higher than the lowest bid received may be given preference under the terms of the city purchasing process, provided that the difference between the two bids is not greater than $3,000.00. 
(2)  A bid from any vendor located outside the municipal limits of the city but within the county which is not more than three percent higher than the lowest bid received from a vendor located outside the county may be given preference under the terms of the city purchasing process, provided that the difference between the two bids is not greater than $3,000.00. 
(c)  Competitive procurements made by the city shall be made from vendors resident in the city or county, provided that the bidder has certified in writing in the bid that he or she is a resident of the city or county. In order to receive the award the vendor must be a responsible and responsive bidder and the bid must otherwise comply with the Code of the city. In the case of a request for local vendor status, this requirement shall apply to the entire solicitation. 
(d)  Protest of any awarded bid is subject to these procedural requirements: 
(1)  Right to protest; exclusive remedy. Any actual bidder, offeror, contractor, or subcontractor who claims to be aggrieved in connection with the bid award shall protest to the purchasing agent in the manner stated in subsection (2) below within three business days of the date of award notification is given in accordance with this Code. 
The rights and remedies granted in this article to a disappointed bidder, offeror, contractor, or subcontractor are to the exclusion of all other rights and remedies of disappointed bidders, offerors, contractors, or subcontractors against the city at common law, or otherwise, for the loss or potential loss of an award of a contract under the city procurement code. 
(2)  Protest procedure. A protest under subsection (1) above shall be in writing, submitted to the purchasing agent, and shall set forth the grounds for the bid protest and the relief requested by them with enough particularity to give notice of the issues to be resolved. 
(3)  Duty and authority to attempt to settle protests. Prior to commencement of an administrative review as provided in subsection (4) below, the purchasing agent, the head of the department, or designees thereof shall attempt to settle by mutual agreement a protest by aggrieved bidders, offerors, contractors, or subcontractors, actual or prospective, concerning the solicitation or award of the bid. City department directors, or their designees, shall have the authority to approve any settlement reached by mutual agreement. 
(4)  Administrative review and decision. If, in the opinion of the purchasing agent, after reasonable attempt, a protest cannot be settled by mutual agreement, the purchasing agent shall promptly conduct an administrative review and shall issue a decision in writing within ten days of completion of this review. The decision shall state the reasons for the action taken. 
(5)  Notice of decision. A copy of the decision under subsection (4) above shall be mailed or otherwise furnished immediately to the protestant and any other party intervening. The purchasing agent shall also post a copy of the decision at a date and place communicated to all parties participating in the administrative review, and such posted decision shall indicate the date of posting on its face. 
(6)  Finality of decision. A decision under subsection (4) above shall be final and conclusive, unless fraudulent, or unless any person adversely affected by the decision requests a further administrative review by the city manager within ten days of posting of the decision. The request for review shall be directed to the purchasing agent, who shall forward the request to the city manager and shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons why the person disagrees with the decision of the purchasing agent. 
(e)  A bidder shall be suspended or debarred from doing business with the city if the city manager or designee determines that the certification made by the bidder as to the local vendor request was filed under false pretenses and is not valid. In addition, if the bidder with the invalid certification of origin was awarded the contract, he shall also pay the city the amount by which the bid based on the invalid certification exceeded the lowest responsible and responsive bid that would have been selected but for the invalid certification, plus reasonable attorney fees and costs. If a bidder has not requested the reference, he will neither be entitled to claim any preference against another bidder nor will he be protected from application of another bidder's claim to a preference against his bid in determining contract award. 
(Code 1980, § 2-120; Ord. No. 01232006A, § 1 (Exh. A), 1-23-2006; Ord. No. 03272006B, § 1 (Exh. A), 3-27-2006)  
Sec. 2-340. - Award of contract in case of tie bids. 
If all bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, quality and service being equal, the contract shall be awarded to the local bidder. If two or more of such bids are submitted by local bidders, the purchasing agent shall award the contract to one of the local tie bidders by drawing lots in public. If local bidders are not involved in tie bids, the purchasing agent shall award the contract to one of the outside tie bidders by drawing lots in public. 
(Code 1980, § 2-121)  
Sec. 2-341. - Cooperative purchasing plans; purchases through state without publication and bidding. 
The purchasing agent shall have authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interests of the city would be served thereby. The purchasing agent is hereby given the authority to make purchases of supplies and equipment through the property division of the state budget and control board, without the formality of publication and receiving competitive bids. 
(Code 1980, § 2-122)  
Sec. 2-342. - Financial interest of city officials and employees prohibited; exception. 
No member of the city council or any officer or employee of the city shall have a financial interest in any contract or in the sale to the city or to a contractor supplying the city of any land or rights or interests in any land, material, supplies or services, except when a majority of the city council determines an exception to this provision is in the best interest of the city; provided that no council member whose interest is involved shall vote on the question. Any wilful violation of this section shall constitute malfeasance in office, and any officer or employee of the city found guilty thereof shall thereby forfeit his office or position. Any violation of this section with the knowledge, express or implied, of the person contracting with the city shall render the contract voidable by the city manager or the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-123) 
State Law reference— Prohibition against municipal officers contracting with municipality, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-21-30.  
Sec. 2-343. - Tests. 
The purchasing agent shall have the authority to require chemical and physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries which are necessary to determine their quality and conformance with the specifications. In the performance of such tests, the purchasing agent shall have the authority to make use of laboratory facilities of any agency of the city government or any outside laboratory. 
(Code 1980, § 2-124)  
Sec. 2-344. - Records of open-market orders and bids. 
The purchasing agent shall keep a record of all open-market orders and the bids submitted in competition thereon, and such records shall also be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1980, § 2-125)  
Sec. 2-345. - Obsolete or surplus supplies. 
(a)  All offices, departments or agencies of the city government shall submit to the purchasing agent, at such times and in such form as he shall prescribe, reports showing stocks of all supplies which are no longer used or which have become obsolete, worn out or scrapped. 
(b)  The purchasing agent shall have authority to transfer surplus supplies to other offices, departments or agencies of the city government. 
(c)  The purchasing agent shall have the authority to sell all supplies which have become unsuitable for public use, or to exchange the supplies for, or trade in the supplies on, new supplies. Such sales shall be made to the highest bidder and in conformance with section 2-332. All moneys received from such sales shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 2-126)  
Sec. 2-346. - Sole source purchases or contracts. 
A purchase of or contract for supplies, materials, equipment or services may be made, regardless of the amount involved, without competitive bidding when the purchasing agent affirms in writing that there is only one source for the required supplies, materials, equipment or services. Written documentation must also include the determination and basis for the proposed sole source procurement. In cases of reasonable doubt that there is only one such source, competitive bidding must be solicited. Any decision by the purchasing agent that a procurement be restricted to one vendor must be accompanied by an explanation as to why no other will be suitable or acceptable to meet the city's need. 
(Code 1980, § 2-127)  
Sec. 2-347. - Emergency purchases and testing. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the purchasing agent may make or authorize others to make emergency procurements only when there exists an immediate threat to public health, welfare or safety under emergency conditions; provided that such emergency procurement shall be made with as much competitive bidding, if any, as practical under the circumstances. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular vendor shall be included in the contract file and reported to the city council. The purchasing agent also may authorize limited testing or sampling of supplies, materials, equipment or services without solicitation of competitive bids and shall prepare written documentation of the need for the testing or sampling and time required for the evaluation thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 2-128)  
Sec. 2-348. - Professional services/selection. 
Professional services are those services rendered by licensed professionals including consulting engineers, planning consultants, architects, auditing firms, banking institutions, and law firms. Professional services shall be obtained through the process of requesting interested firms to submit their qualifications; reviewing the qualifications submitted and determining which firms are qualified; requesting the qualified firms to submit proposals; selecting the qualified firm with the best proposal; and negotiating the necessary contract. Except for agreements for less than $25,000.00 and that are provided for in the annual operating budget of a department, agreements for professional services shall state the terms and conditions and shall be approved by city council. 
(Code 1980, § 2-129; Ord. No. 02102014 , § 1, 2-10-2014; Ord. No. 05092016A , § 1, 5-9-2016) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02102014 , § 1, adopted Feb. 10, 2014 changed the title of § 2-348 from professional and artistic services and supplies to professional services/selection, as set out herein.  
Sec. 2-349. - Construction. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Construction manager agent means a business that has been awarded a separate contract with the city to provide construction management services but not construction. 
Construction manager at-risk means a business that has been awarded a separate contract with the city to provide both construction management services and construction using the construction management at-risk project delivery method. A contract with a construction manager at-risk may be executed before completion of design. 
Construction management services are those professional services associated with contract administration, project management, and other specified services provided in connection with the administration of a project delivery method defined in this section 2-349. 
Construction management at-risk means a project delivery method in which the city awards separate contracts, one for architectural and engineering services to design an infrastructure facility and the second to a construction manager at-risk for both construction of the infrastructure facility according to the design and construction management services. 
Design-bid-build means a project delivery method in which the city sequentially awards separate contracts, the first for architectural and engineering services to design an infrastructure facility and the second for construction of the infrastructure facility according to the design. 
Design-build means a project delivery method in which the city enters into a single contract for design and construction of an infrastructure facility. 
Design-build-operate-maintain means a project delivery method in which the city enters into a single contract for design, construction, maintenance, and operation of an infrastructure facility over a contractually defined period. All or a portion of the money required to pay for the services provided by the contractor during the contract period are (1) appropriated by the city, (2) secured by the city through fare, toll, or user charges, (3) provided in the form of a concession agreement with the contractor or an assignee, or (4) any combination of the foregoing. 
Infrastructure facility means a building; structure; or networks of buildings, structures, pipes, controls, and equipment, or portion thereof. 
Operations and maintenance means a project delivery method in which the City enters into a single contract for the routine operation, routine repair, and routine maintenance of an infrastructure facility. 
(b)  Construction services authorization. 
(1)  Project delivery methods authorized. 
a.  The following project delivery methods are authorized for procurements relating to infrastructure facilities: (a) design-bid-build; (b) construction management at-risk; (c) operations and maintenance; (d) design-build; (e) design-build-operate-maintain. 
b.  In addition to those methods identified in item (1), the Council may approve as an alternate project delivery method any combination of design, construction, finance, and services for operations and maintenance of an infrastructure facility. 
c.  Participation in a report or study that is later used in the preparation of design requirements for a project does not disqualify a firm from participating as a member of a proposing team in a construction management at-risk, design-build, or design-build-operate-maintain delivery procurement, unless the participation provides the business with a substantial competitive advantage. 
(2)  Choice of project delivery method. The project delivery method used for a city construction project must be that method which is most advantageous to the city and results in the most timely, economical, and successful completion of the construction project. The city shall select the appropriate project delivery method for a particular project and shall state in writing the facts and considerations leading to the selection of that particular method. 
(3)  Source selection methods assigned to project delivery methods. 
a.  Competitive sealed bidding, as provided in this Code, must be used to procure construction in design-bid-build procurements. 
b.  Construction management at-risk. Contracts for construction management at-risk must be procured by either competitive sealed bidding or competitive sealed proposals. 
c.  Operations and maintenance. Contracts for operations and maintenance must be procured by either competitive sealed bidding or competitive sealed proposals. 
d.  Design-build. Contracts for design-build must be procured by competitive sealed proposals. 
e.  Design-build-operate-maintain. Contracts for design-build-operate-maintain must be procured by competitive sealed proposals. 
f.  Other. Contracts for an alternate project delivery method approved by the council must be procured by a source selection method specified by the council when approving the alternative project delivery method. 
g.  The procedures for receipt and evaluation of competitive sealed proposals applicable to a solicitation will be outlined in that solicitation. 
(4)  Prequalification on construction. The city may limit participation in a solicitation for construction to only those businesses, including potential subcontractors, that are prequalified. If businesses are prequalified, the city must issue a request for qualifications. The request must contain, at a minimum, a description of the general scope of work to be acquired, the deadline for submission of information, and how businesses may apply for consideration. The evaluation criteria must include, but not be limited to, prior performance, recent past references on all aspects of performance, financial stability, and experience on similar construction projects. Using only the criteria stated in the request for qualifications, businesses must be ranked from most qualified to least qualified. The basis for the ranking must be determined in writing. If fewer than two businesses are prequalified, the prequalification process must be canceled. The determination regarding how many offers to solicit is not subject to protest. 
(5)  Additional procedures applicable to procurement of certain project delivery methods. 
a.  Evaluation factors. A request for proposals for design-build or design-build-operate-maintain must: (a) state the relative importance of (i) demonstrated compliance with the design requirements, (ii) offer or qualifications, (iii) financial capacity, (iv) project schedule, (v) price, or life-cycle price for design-build-operate-maintain (including the effects of proposed or alternative short- and long-term financing options), and (vi) other factors, if any. 
(c)  Integration with remainder of city procurement code. This section 2-349 supplements the tools available to the city under Aiken City Code, Division 2, Purchasing and Sales, but the specific provisions of this section 2-349 in a procurement activity will supersede incompatible provisions of any other section of Aiken City Code, Division 2, Purchasing and Sales. For example, but not by way of exhaustive listing: the use of competitive sealed proposals is incompatible with provisions requiring award to "lowest bid" and the like (e.g., sections 2-232, -233, -234, -238(b)), but compatible general requirements such as advertising (section 2-324), security (section 2-337), and responsibility (section 2-338(b)(1) et seq.) will apply to procurements under this section 2-349. 
(Ord. No. 10242016A , § 1(Exh. A), 10-24-2016)  
Secs. 2-350—2-365. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SETOFF DEBT COLLECTION PROCEDURES 
 
Sec. 2-366. - Participation in setoff collection. 
The city manager shall set the minimal amount for delinquent debts owed the city which it may submit to the state tax commission, or any successor agency, for collection pursuant to the Setoff Debt Collection Act, or any successor provisions thereto. In determining this amount, the city manager shall consider the administrative and related costs of utilizing this collection procedure, the amount of the potential recovery to the city, and any other relevant factors. 
(Code 1980, § 2-180) 
State Law reference— Levy on and seizure of intangibles, S.C. Code 1976, § 12-53-20.  
Sec. 2-367. - Procedures. 
(a)  The city shall notify a delinquent debtor of its intention to cause the debtor's state tax refund to be setoff by notice given in person, left at the dwelling or usual place of business of the debtor, or sent by certified or registered mail to the debtor's last known address no less than 30 days before the city submits its setoff request to the state tax commission, or any successor agency. The notice shall include a statement which sets forth the administrative appeal procedures available to the debtor provided by this section and any alternatives available to the debtor which may avoid the setoff. The city shall promptly notify the debtor when the liability out of which the setoff arises has been satisfied. 
(b)  If a debtor disputes that he owes a delinquent debt or the amount of a delinquent debt, the debtor may submit a written request for review of the debt to the city manager. The city manager shall review all of the relevant facts to determine whether the debt is owed and whether the amount claimed by the city is correct. If the city manager determines the amount setoff exceeds the amount properly due, the city shall refund the appropriate amount to the debtor. If the city manager determines that the city is entitled to no part of the amount setoff, the city shall refund the entire amount plus any administrative fee retained by the state tax commission, or any successor agency, to the debtor. If a tax refund has been setoff based upon an error committed by the city, the city shall pay the debtor interest as required by the Setoff Debt Collection Act. If the debtor's request is received and resolved prior to a setoff request being submitted to the state tax commission, or any successor agency, the amount of the delinquent debt owned shall be adjusted accordingly. The city manager may decline to consider a debtor's request received more than 30 days after the city sends the debtor the notice required by subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Upon receipt by the city of proceeds collected on its behalf by the state tax commission, or any successor agency, together with an accounting therefor, the city shall credit the debtor's obligation and notify the debtor in writing of the amount of the setoff and the balance due, if any. 
(Code 1980, § 2-181)  
Sec. 2-368. - Collection agreement. 
Upon a resolution being adopted by city council, the city manager may enter into an agreement with the Municipal Association of South Carolina or any other authorized agency or entity for services related to collection of delinquent debt pursuant to the Setoff Debt Collection Act. 
(Code 1980, § 2-182)  
Sec. 2-369. - Collection costs charge. 
To the extent allowed by law, the city manager may set and assess against delinquent debtors a charge for the estimated actual costs to the city of collecting debts pursuant to this division, and the charge shall be added to and become part of such delinquent debt. If the city contracts with another agency or entity for services related to this collection procedure, the collection charges of that agency or entity shall be added to and become part of the delinquent debt, to the extent allowed by law, in the same manner as the city charge. The city manager shall notify the city council of the schedule of collection charges and any changes therein. 
(Code 1980, § 2-183)  
Secs. 2-370—2-385. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - ANNEXATION INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR LARGE TRACTS OF REAL ESTATE LOCATED OUTSIDE THE CITY 
 
Sec. 2-386. - Owners to apply. 
An owner of more than 500 acres of land located outside, but contiguous to, the city who plans to develop this property for residential and/or commercial purposes may apply to the city manager for the annexation incentive program. 
(Ord. No. 03262001A, § 1, 3-26-2001)  
Sec. 2-387. - Requirements to qualify for incentive. 
(a)  The property to be annexed by the owner shall comprise more than 500 acres of real estate presently located outside the city limits of the City of Aiken. The property must be contiguous to the city limits. 
(b)  The owner must file an annexation petition with the city planning department. This petition shall include a copy of the deed showing that the applicant is the actual owner of the real estate. The owner shall also file a recent plat showing that all of the property owned by the owner is to be annexed. The petition shall also describe any areas on the property that will become common areas for the proposed development and/or what portions of the real estate will not be developed. 
(c)  The property must be accepted for annexation by the city council following a review by the planning commission. Nothing in the ordinance from which this article derives shall obligate city council to accept the annexation of a proposed development that is not in the best interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. 03262001A, § 1, 3-26-2001)  
Sec. 2-388. - Incentive payment. 
(a)  If approved by city council, the owner shall be entitled to an incentive payment for up to three years to be determined by applying the following formula: 
No. of acres owned by owner at the end of the applicable year × per acre/per lot appraised value [per the county assessor] × .06 × The applicable millage rate = incentive payment 
(b)  The number of acres entitled to this incentive shall initially be determined in a written agreement between the owner and the city council. This incentive may be set forth in a development agreement if one is entered into by the owner and the city. Thereafter, the number of acres entitled to the reimbursement shall be reduced by the number of acres/lots sold by the owner in each calendar year. The owner shall provide a copy of each deed to the city to show all real estate sold by the owner during each calendar year. Failure of the owner to provide a copy of all deeds for property sold during the applicable year may result in the termination of this incentive payment for the particular development and will enable the city to seek reimbursement of all previous incentives paid. This property and its acreage shall be clearly delineated on the plat presented to the city. The owner must be current on all real estate tax payments for the property in order to apply for the incentive program. 
(c)  In no event shall the owner be entitled to this incentive for more than three years except that property being developed as a golf course may be entitled to this incentive for up to five years. This shall be more particularly described in the agreement to be executed by the city and the owner. 
(d)  The owner shall apply for this incentive on or before January 10 of the year following the calendar year for which the incentive is sought. No incentive shall be paid for the initial year that the property is annexed. The city shall have up to 60 days to confirm the owner's entitlement to the incentive being requested. 
(Ord. No. 03262001A, § 1, 3-26-2001)  
Sec. 2-389. - Expiration of annexation incentive program. 
This incentive program shall expire at midnight on December 31, 2006, unless otherwise renewed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 03262001A, § 1, 3-26-2001)  
Secs. 2-390—2-400. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - ECONOMIC PROJECT INCENTIVE PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 2-401. - Title. 
This ordinance shall be titled the "City of Aiken Economic Project Incentive Program," and is referred to herein as the "program." 
(Ord. No. 08132018 , § 1, 8-13-2018)  
Sec. 2-402. - Findings. 
The city council hereby affirms the findings made in this ordinance and incorporates such findings as if set forth fully herein. 
(Ord. No. 08132018 , § 1, 8-13-2018)  
Sec. 2-403. - Definitions. 
In addition to those capitalized terms defined elsewhere in this article, unless the context shall otherwise require, the following terms shall have the following respective meanings: 
Benefits means those tangible benefits, such as increased revenues for the city from property taxes and other sources, and those intangible benefits to the city and its citizens of providing the incentives, which generally include: (a) increased property values within the area in which the incentives are offered and the city as a whole; (b) increased revenues from property taxes, business license fees, permit fees, utility revenues, and other fees imposed by the city from other properties within the area in which incentives are offered; (c) greater amenities for the benefit of the city's citizens; and (d) increased tourism and commercial activity within the area in which the incentives are offered and the city as a whole. 
Goals means the objectives of the city in offering the incentives, which generally are: (a) to promote the construction of new buildings or the rehabilitation of existing buildings within specific areas of the city; (b) to support the establishment of the categories of new businesses within these areas that the council determines will significantly increase the overall commercial activity within specific areas of the city; and (c) to increase employment opportunities within the city. 
Incentive shall mean a grant of any inducement having monetary value by the city that is offered to a person, firm, or corporation to pursue a project that encourages private investment and/or the creation/retention of jobs. The incentive may also include grants from other entities that the city may be able to obtain. 
Job shall mean each new (a) full-time position or (b) each full-time equivalent position that is created as a direct result of the ongoing operation of a project. For the purposes of calculating the number of jobs created by a project, only those employed at businesses located within the project and those who are to permanently be employed within the applicable incentive zone shall be considered. 
Project shall mean the development of real property to the extent of adding value to the tax base through the improvement of real property and the creation of employment opportunities. 
Project sponsor means the private party or parties responsible for the development of a project. 
Recipient means the private party or parties to whom an incentive shall be paid, which, unless otherwise expressly agreed to by the city, shall be the party or parties who paid the fee that is to be refunded or reimbursed. 
(Ord. No. 08132018 , § 1, 8-13-2018)  
Sec. 2-404. - Authorization to enter into incentive agreements. 
(a)  Agreement provisions. The council, at its discretion and on a case-by-case basis, but subject to the eligibility criteria provided for in section 2-406(a) hereof, may enter into an agreement with a project sponsor that intends to develop a project within the city (an "incentive agreement"). Incentives shall only be provided to a recipient after an incentive agreement has been entered into between the city and the project sponsor, which shall set forth the following: (i) the particulars of the project; (ii) the incentives to be provided; and (iii) sufficient assurances that the benefits will accrue to the city and the goals will be advanced by the project. 
(b)  Negotiation and approval. Pending the approval by the council of any incentive agreement and subject to the provisions of section 2-408 hereof, the city manager of the city is authorized to discuss the provisions of this program, aid in the completion of any proposal (as defined herein) and, subject to the final approval by the council, negotiate with the potential project sponsor on behalf of the city. Each incentive agreement shall be approved by the council by ordinance which shall include those findings of the council set forth in section 2-406(a) of this chapter. Council may provide incentives in any amounts and for any period of time within the thresholds provided for herein or within the time periods and thresholds provided for in any applicable statutory authorization. 
(Ord. No. 08132018 , § 1, 8-13-2018)  
Sec. 2-405. - Authorized incentives. 
(a)  Multiple incentives. The council may offer any combination of incentives provided for herein; provided, however, that the total amount of incentives given in connection with an individual project must be in keeping with the goals and the value of the benefits must be greater than the financial value of the incentives. 
(b)  Incentive recipient. Where the project sponsor is the developer of a project, but does not own and/or operate the business or businesses located therein that are responsible for the payment of any fee that is to be refunded or reimbursed as an incentive, the recipient of the incentive shall be the payor of such fee unless otherwise expressly agreed to by the city; provided, however, that with respect to connection fees and permit fees (as each are defined herein) payment of such fees to the city by the contractor of the project shall be considered payment by the project sponsor and any refund or reimbursement of any such fee shall be made to the project sponsor. 
(c)  Incentives of the city. All direct incentives of the city shall be grants which shall be in the form of reimbursements and refunds of fees that have been duly paid to the city. No upfront abatements of fees shall be permitted. Where incentives continue for a period of more than one year, such incentives may be graduated to increase or decrease year-to-year as the council sees fit, but subject to monitoring by the city to ensure compliance with the terms of any incentive agreement. The council may offer incentives in connection with the following fees up to the percentages indicated with respect to each: 
(1)  Up to 50 percent of utility connection fees collected by the city ("connection fees"), to be reimbursed to the recipient 12 months following the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the project; 
(2)  Up to 50 percent of building permit fees collected by the city ("permit fees"), to be reimbursed to the recipient 12 months following the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the project; 
(3)  Up to 50 percent of business license fees collected by the city ("business license fees") for as many as five years, to be reimbursed to the payor of the business license fees at the annual anniversary of the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the project for which a business license has been issued, provided the recipient has continued to operate the business for which the business license fees were paid for the entirety of such year; 
(4)  Such other incentives that the council, at its discretion on a case-by-case basis, determines are appropriate given the amount or type of investment made by the project sponsor. 
(d)  State incentive programs. The council may include within any package of incentives or as a stand-alone incentive for in-city project any incentive authorized by statute ("state incentive programs"). 
(Ord. No. 08132018 , § 1, 8-13-2018)  
Sec. 2-406. - Eligibility criteria. 
(a)  General eligibility criteria. Except for those incentives authorized under a state incentive program, in order for a project to be eligible to receive incentives, the council shall determine and make specific findings in the ordinance approving any incentive agreement that the project meets, or upon completion will meet, each of the following criteria: 
(1)  The project is consistent with the city of Aiken Comprehensive Plan (as it may be amended and updated from time to time, the "comprehensive plan"); 
(2)  The manner in which the project will advance the goals of the city; 
(3)  The project, upon completion and continued operation for the term of the incentives authorized, will result in the realization of benefits to the city and its citizens that exceed the value of the incentives provided, including a description of the tangible and intangible benefits that are expected to accrue to the city and its citizens as a result of a project; 
(4)  Absent the provision of incentives, the project would be unlikely to occur or unlikely to occur at the level or scale contemplated by the proposed project sponsor; and 
(5)  The project consists of a business or businesses that are substantially devoted to one or more of the following uses: (1) retail uses; (2) tourism-related business or activities; (3) corporate headquarters; (4) research and development; (5) high technology growth businesses; and (6) other uses, as may be determined by the council, that are consistent with the goals and the comprehensive plan. Where the project includes multiple businesses or uses, at least 50 percent of the commercial space comprising the project must be occupied by one or more of the above listed uses. 
(b)  Additional criteria. The council may, in its discretion and on a case-by-case basis, include within an incentive agreement any other eligibility criteria, including, without limitation, capital investment and job creation benchmarks, that must be met upon completion of a project in order to ensure that the goals are met and that the project provides benefits to the city and its citizens that exceed the value of the incentives provided. 
(Ord. No. 08132018 , § 1, 8-13-2018)  
Sec. 2-407. - Administration and terms of delivery. 
(a)  Incentive proposal. A proposed project sponsor must submit to the city manager a proposal (a "proposal"). A form of the proposal is attached hereto as exhibit A. The proposal must include a sufficient description of the project, to include, without limitation, the following information: 
(1)  Identification of the property or properties on which the project is to be located (the "subject property"), any acquisition costs of the subject property, and the then-current value of the subject property; 
(2)  A general description of the improvements that are to be made to the subject property as part of the project, including a good-faith estimate of the costs of such improvements, the estimated start date and completion date for any improvements to the subject property, and a good-faith estimate of the value of the subject property upon completion of such improvements; 
(3)  A good-faith estimate of the number of jobs that are to be created in connection with the project, including a projected date or dates upon which the estimated number of jobs will have been created; 
(4)  A good-faith estimate of the property taxes and new revenue from other sources that will be generated for the city as a direct result of the project; and 
(5)  Any other additional information that the project sponsor or the city manager deems may be necessary and helpful for the council to evaluate and give due consideration to the proposal. 
(b)  Determination of incentive amounts. The amount of incentives granted to a project shall be based upon the amount of the capital investment in the project, the amount of new revenue for the city directly created by the project, and the number of new jobs that will be directly created by the project.
