(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in, advertise, promote, organize, conduct, control, manage, solicit, or induce participation in conducting a block party or similar event, close a street, or use a parkway for such purpose, unless a permit has first been obtained from the director of public safety or his designee. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the terms or conditions of a permit issued pursuant to this article or any other provisions of this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to continue to conduct a party or gathering on premises he owns, rents, occupies, resides in or has control of after having been notified by a city public safety officer to terminate the party, because activities relating to or arising from the party on or off such premises are creating or resulting in disturbance of the peace, a public nuisance, public safety hazards, or the consumption of alcoholic liquors, beer or wine in a public place or places. 
(Code 1980, § 14-41)  
Sec. 24-63. - Permit application. 
An application for a permit for temporary street closure or use of a street or parkway for the purpose of conducting a block party or similar event shall be made upon a form provided by the city and shall be prepared by the applicant and submitted to the director of the department of public safety or his designee setting forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, residence, and home and business telephone numbers of each person sponsoring the event; 
(2)  The location, date, beginning and ending hours and purpose of such temporary street closure; 
(3)  A brief explanation of the activities which will occur during the event; and 
(4)  Such other information as the director of the department of public safety deems reasonably necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 14-42)  
Sec. 24-64. - Time of filing. 
The application for the permit required by this article shall be filed with the director of the department of public safety or his designee not less than seven days prior to the scheduled date of such event. The failure to file an application within such period may be grounds for denial of a permit. 
(Code 1980, § 14-43)  
Sec. 24-65. - Permit conditions. 
Any permit granted under this article shall contain such terms and conditions as the director of the department of public safety or his designee determines are reasonably necessary to reduce or minimize the dangers and hazards to vehicular or pedestrian traffic or public health, safety, tranquility, morals or welfare, including, but not limited to, changes or limitations in time, duration, numbers of participants, noise, sound, or any other relevant matter. 
(Code 1980, § 14-44)  
Sec. 24-66. - Standards for issuance of permit. 
A permit authorized by this article shall be issued by the director of the department of public safety or his designee, when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he concludes that the following circumstances exist: 
(1)  The time, duration, size and nature of the temporary street closure, the block party or other event will not substantially disrupt the orderly and safe movement of vehicular or pedestrian traffic; 
(2)  The concentration of persons will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection or ambulance service or the operation of any established commercial, business, government or public operations or institutions in the area; and 
(3)  The nature and time of the event will not unduly interfere with or disturb the reasonable tranquility of adjoining residential areas. 
(Code 1980, § 14-45)  
Sec. 24-67. - Revocation of permit. 
Any permit for a temporary street closure, block party or other event issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the director of the department of public safety or his designee at any time when by reason of emergency, disaster, disorder, riot, traffic conditions, violation of this article or any permit conditions, violations of any other laws or ordinances, or undue burden on public services, he determines that the health, safety, tranquility, morals or welfare of the public requires such revocation. The determination of such revocation may be delivered to the applicant, if the applicant can be reasonably located, orally or in writing by personal contact, personal service, or telephone. 
(Code 1980, § 14-46)  
Sec. 24-68. - Appeal from denial of permit. 
Any person aggrieved by the denial of a block party permit shall have the right to appeal to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within five days after the denial of the permit. The city council shall act upon the appeal within 15 days after its receipt.  
Sec. 24-69. - Other temporary street closures. 
Nothing contained in this article shall limit the authority of city council to close temporarily any street within the city for any purpose it determines is proper. 
(Code 1980, § 14-47) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Chapter 26 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Department of parks and recreation, § 2-260; recreational vehicles and campers, ch. 30; littering parks, § 32-33; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Municipal parks and recreational systems, S.C. Code 1976, § 51-15-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Closing hours for parks and recreation areas. 
(a)  Unless otherwise posted all public parks, ball fields and other recreation areas of the city shall be closed between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. 
(b)  The parks and recreation director of the city is hereby granted authority to extend the closing hours for any public park, ball field or other recreation area of the city, or for a specific area thereof, for a particular event, taking into account the type of event or activity and the number of persons involved and other circumstances affecting such use. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an employee of the city while in the course of his official duties, to enter or remain in any public park, ball field or other recreation area of the city between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., or other hours as posted, or the later closing hour set be the parks and recreation director, if the posted closed hours, or other closing hours, have been extended or modified under the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section. 
(d)  Any person failing to abide by these closing hours by entering the premises during closing hours shall be guilty of an offense, and upon a plea of guilty, nolo contendere, or other plea; forfeiture of bond; or conviction in the municipal court shall be punished as provided in section 1-13. The violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense, and each violation of this article shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 15-1)  
Sec. 26-2. - Closing of parks and recreation areas in emergencies. 
The parks and recreation director of the city or his authorized assistant in charge of a recreation area of the city is hereby granted authority and power to declare any public park, ball field or other recreation area of the city, or a portion thereof, to be closed immediately when there reasonably appears to be immediate danger of injury or damage to persons or property, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail to leave the area so declared closed or having left, to return thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 15-2)  
Sec. 26-3. - Riding, driving or parking vehicles or animals in parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to ride, drive, operate or park any vehicle or animal on or over any portion of a city park, either public or private, except on paths, roads, thoroughfares or areas specifically posted or marked out for such purposes or when special permission is granted in writing by the director of the department of public safety. As used in this section, a "city park" includes, but is not limited to, all premises and facilities owned, leased or used by the city or its recreation department for recreational purposes and all improved and unimproved areas located in a block between streets having the same name and owned by the city or over which the city has obtained a right-of-way or other right of possession and use. 
(b)  A vehicle parked in a city park in violation of this section may be towed or otherwise removed pursuant to the provisions set forth in subsection 42-75(c). 
(Code 1980, § 15-3) 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 8; traffic, ch. 42.  
Sec. 26-4. - Damaging park property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to mutilate, injure, pluck, break, move, tear up or carry off any plant, shrub, flower, tree, fence or other improvement growing or erected in or around any of the parks of the city, or to in any manner injure any of the walks, ways or roads thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 15-4)  
Sec. 26-5. - Rules and regulations for public parks and public facilities—Trespassing. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby authorized to promulgate necessary rules and regulations for the preservation of health, peace and order in all public parks and public facilities owned or maintained by the City of Aiken. 
(b)  Such rules and regulations shall be conspicuously posted in such public parks and public facilities and shall be deemed sufficient notice forbidding certain conduct for the purposes of this section. Any person in violation of such rules and regulations shall be subject to immediate removal from the premises and to being placed on trespass notice. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  Having violated rules or regulations promulgated pursuant to this section to, without good cause or good excuse, refuse to leave immediately from the premises of a public park or public facility, after being ordered or requested to leave by any official, officer, employee or representative of the city. 
(2)  After having been previously placed on trespass notice for violation of rules or regulations promulgated pursuant to this section to, without good cause or good excuse, enter upon the premises of a public park or public facility. 
(Ord. No. 07122010B, § 1, 7-12-2010) 
State Law reference— S.C. Code of 1976, §§ 5-7-30, 51-15-20  
Chapter 28 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Peddlers and hawkers, S.C. Code 1976, § 40-41-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 28-1. - Peddling and soliciting without registering and other unlawful activities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, not having an established place of business in the city, to go upon private property in the city for the purpose of peddling or selling goods, wares, merchandise, or services or soliciting donations for any purpose, who has not been requested or invited to do so by the owners or occupants of such property, without first having registered with the director of public safety pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person not having an established place of business in the city, to peddle or sell any goods, wares, merchandise, or services or to solicit donations for any purpose upon the public streets, rights-of-way, or sidewalks located in the city without first having registered with the director of public safety pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Except as authorized by section 28-3, it shall be unlawful for any person to stand on or adjacent to a street or enter a street for the purpose of soliciting employment, business, or donations from the occupants of vehicles. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit donations in any form from occupants of vehicles in violation of a permit issued by the director of the department of public safety, or to set up road blocks or in any way unreasonably impede traffic while conducting such solicitations, or to conduct such solicitations from any area other than the sidewalk, street shoulder, or other public area designated in the permit. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether or not he has an established place of business in the city, to engage in soliciting or peddling as described in this section any time other than between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. when eastern standard time is in effect in this state and 9:00 p.m. when daylight savings time is in effect in this state. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether or not he has an established place of business in the city, to engage in peddling or soliciting as described in this section by entering on any property on which a sign is displayed stating "no soliciting" or words of similar effect or by refusing to leave any property after having been requested to do so by the owner or any occupant. 
(Code 1980, § 16-1)  
Sec. 28-2. - Registration. 
An informational registration for the activities described in subsection 28-1(a) or (b) of this Code shall be made with the director of the department of public safety by the persons prior to engaging in such activities and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number, date of birth, Social Security Number, and driver's license number of each person involved in activities regulated by this chapter. 
(2)  A complete description of all vehicles used by persons involved in any such activities, including the owner, registration information, license tag number, model, year, and color of all such vehicles. 
(3)  The complete name of the company, firm, or organization on behalf of which such activities are conducted, including the complete mailing address, location address, and telephone number of the company, firm or organization, and the name of the person or persons there with whom may be contacted by the city about any such activities. 
(4)  The name and location of the person in the city or immediate vicinity in charge of all persons conducting such activities for the company, firm, or organization. 
(5)  The date or dates for which such activities are to be conducted in the city and the location and schedule of such activities. 
(6)  A copy of a current city business license, if required, for the company, firm or organization on behalf of which such activities are conducted, or if a nonprofit organization, some documentation of that status from the South Carolina Secretary of State or similar regulatory agency. 
(7)  For such activities to be conducted on the premises of a place of business, a letter from the owner or owner's designee granting permission to engage in such activities. 
(8)  Upon completion of the registration process, the director of public safety or his or her designee shall issue a permit specifying the time period the individual listed may peddle or solicit. This time period shall not be for more than six months. 
(9)  Activities described in subsection 28-1(a) or (b) of this Code shall not be permitted until after a check of the criminal history of each person listed on the registration form has been completed. 
(10)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or allow another to engage in activities described in subsection 28-1(a) or (b) of this Code prior to a criminal background check being completed. 
(11)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or allow another to conduct activities described in subsection 28-1(a) or (b) of this Code if the person has been previously convicted of a felony or violation of a law or ordinance involving dishonesty. A felony is defined as a conviction for an offense considered a felony under South Carolina law. Any person that has a pending charge(s) of the same shall be prohibited from engaging in the above activities prior to the final disposition of said charges(s). For the purposes of this chapter, where there is a federal conviction or a conviction from another state, that conviction will be considered a felony if the equivalent South Carolina offense is classified as a felony. 
(Code 1980, § 16-2; Ord. No. 04112011A, § 1(Exh. A), 4-11-2011)  
Sec. 28-3. - Solicitations from occupants of vehicles, permit required. 
Any solicitations from occupants of vehicles for charitable donations as described in S.C. Code 1976, § 5-27-910 may be conducted only if the director of public safety issues a permit for such activity after receiving the information set forth in section 28-2. The director may include in the permit all such limitations and conditions as he determines are necessary to protect the health and safety of motorists, pedestrians, and those soliciting and to ensure that such solicitation does not unreasonably impede the flow of traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 16-3) 
Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 42.  
Sec. 28-4. - Designation of other officers by director. 
The director of public safety may designate another officer or officers in the department of public safety to discharge the duties delegated to the director in this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 16-4)  
Sec. 28-5. - Other ordinances. 
Nothing contained in this chapter relieves any person of complying with or being subject to the business license ordinance or any other city ordinances, codes or regulations. 
(Code 1980, § 16-5)  
Chapter 32 - SOLID WASTE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) ---

No. 06112007C, § 1, adopted June 11, 2007; Ord. No. 06112007D, § 1, adopted June 11, 2007; Ord. No. 06162008B, § 1, adopted June 16, 2008 and Ord. No. 03222010, § 1, adopted March 22, 2010. 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Solid waste in general. 
(a)  The city, through its public services department, shall collect and dispose of residential garbage as set forth in section 32-2, residential yard trash as set forth in section 32-3, residential recycling as set forth in section 32-4, and weekend use of roll-off containers and trash trailers as set forth in section 32-5. 
(b)  The city shall provide residential garbage services and yard trash services one time per week for each residence throughout the city upon a schedule determined by the public works director. The city shall provide residential recycling services one time every two weeks for each residence throughout the city upon a schedule determined by the public works director. 
(c)  The city will charge a user fee per residence as set by city council in the annual budget process for these residential solid waste services. 
(d)  This fee will appear on the monthly city water bill. 
(e)  All residences in the city limits with an active water or sewer account must be charged the solid waste user fee. 
(f)  The city, through its public works department, shall collect and dispose of small business garbage as set forth in section 32-6 and small business recycling as set forth in section 32-7. 
(g)  The city will charge a user fee per small business as set by city council in the annual budget process and will appear on the business's monthly water bill. 
(h)  The city, through its public works department, shall contract with a private company for the collection and disposal of dumpster garbage set forth in section 32-8 and dumpster cardboard recycling set forth in section 32-9 in the historic downtown business district. The historic downtown business district, as it pertains to this solid waste ordinance, will be defined as those businesses located within the city block bound by Laurens Street, Richland Avenue, Newberry Street and Park Avenue. 
(Ord. No. 11142011A, § 1(Exh. A), 11-14-2011; Ord. No. 06242013B , § 1, 6-24-2013; Ord. No. 01122015E , § 1, 1-12-2015; Ord. No. 11142016A , §§ 1—3, 11-14-2016; Ord. No. 06102019B , § 1, 6-10-2019)  
Sec. 32-2. - Residential garbage. 
(a)  All residents must use the green roll cart that is provided by the city. No other garbage containers can be used. 
(b)  All newly constructed residences are required to obtain a green roll cart from the city for a cart fee that shall be set by city council in the annual budget process. The roll cart fee shall be paid before the residential building permit is issued. This cart will be delivered when the public services department is notified that a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(c)  All items may be disposed of in the green roll carts with the exception of yard trash pursuant to section 32-3, recyclable items pursuant to section 32-4, poisons, acids, caustics, medical waste, dead animals, explosives, automotive fluids, paints, pesticides, fertilizer, ewaste, or any item that may contain hot live coals or fire. 
(d)  If residents have more garbage than will fit into the city roll cart, it must be bagged and placed beside the roll cart at the street. 
(e)  The public services director may require residents, who consistently have extra bags outside roll carts, to purchase additional roll cart(s). 
(f)  Additional roll carts will be provided at a fee that shall be set by city council in the annual budget process. 
(g)  Additional carts will also incur an additional $5.00 user fee for each additional cart per month as follows: 
One roll cart 	Curbside service 	Included in user fee 
Two roll carts 	Curbside service 	User fee + $5.00/month 
Three roll carts 	Curbside service 	User fee + $10.00/month 
Four roll carts 	Curbside service 	User fee + $15.00/month 
 
(h)  No residence may have more than four roll carts without the permission of the public services director. 
(i)  At the discretion of the public services director, carts that become damaged, through no fault of the city, may be required to be replaced at a fee as set forth by city council in the annual budget process, which will be added to the residential monthly city water bill. 
(j)  Lost or stolen carts must be replaced at a fee that shall be set by city council in the annual budget process. If available, a refurbished cart may be provided for free. 
(k)  Carts remain the property of the city. If a resident moves, the cart is to be left at the residence. The resident is to clean the cart and leave it in the backyard for the next resident. 
(l)  Carts may be placed for pickup the night before pickup day and must be removed within 24 hours after pickup. If roll carts are out prior to, or not put back within 24 hours of pickup, city crews will return the roll cart to the house for a fee of $5.00 per incident. This fee will be billed on the monthly water bill. 
(m)  Collection routes begin at 7:00 a.m. each morning. All roll carts and other refuse must be ready for collection at that time. 
(n)  Carts must not be placed within three feet of mailboxes. 
(o)  Carts must not be placed within three feet of yard trash piles. 
(p)  The roll cart lid must be closed and latched when it is placed at the street. 
(q)  Optional backyard service (i.e. a city employee will roll the roll cart out to the collection truck, dump it, and return it back to the residence) is no longer offered. Residents currently signed up for this additional service may be allowed to continue with the following restrictions until the water account is closed or assigned to a new resident: 
One roll cart 	Backyard service 	Additional $5.00/month 
Two roll carts 	Backyard service 	Additional $15.00/month 
Three roll carts 	Backyard service 	Additional $25.00/month 
Four roll carts 	Backyard service 	Additional $35.00/month 
 
(1)  No roll cart can be serviced by city personnel if service requires opening a door, gate, or similar obstacle. City collection personnel will not enter enclosures, fences, carports, or garages in order to service any roll cart. 
(2)  City collection personnel will not enter yards when dogs are present. 
(3)  City personnel will only retrieve a backyard service cart if the cart is not overfilled. The resident will be responsible for removing the garbage to a level that the cart can be rolled without spillage. 
(4)  If a resident with backyard service has more garbage than will fit in the city roll cart they must place all additional bags at the street for collection themselves. City collection personnel will not carry any item from residents' backyard to the truck. Residents may put roll cart(s) and extra bags at the curb for regular pickup as long as they adhere to any time restrictions for placing garbage at the public right-of-way. No backyard fees will be discarded as a result. 
(5)  The city is not responsible for any broken or missing items on residents' property. 
(6)  The public services director may cancel customers' backyard service if there is any safety hazard to the city personnel present. 
(7)  Due to medical necessity or hardship, backyard service may be available and the additional backyard service fee waived if approved by the public services director, or his designee, in their sole discretion, subject to review by the city manager who shall have final authority in this decision. 
(Ord. No. 11142011A, § 1(Exh. A), 11-14-2011)  
Sec. 32-3. - Residential yard trash. 
Residential yard trash is defined as the collection of vegetative materials from residential property. This type trash may include, but is not limited to, trimmings, tree branches, pine straw, leaves, and grass clippings. These items, created through normal and routine residential property maintenance, may be placed by residents beside the road right-of-way in front of the property they own for curb collection provided that: 
(1)  Yard trash must be placed on or beside the paved portion of the right-of-way. In no event can this trash block the paved portion of the right-of-way. In no event can this trash be placed under utility lines or tree limbs with less than 20 feet of overhead clearance. 
(2)  On an unpaved street, yard trash must be placed beside the traveled portion of the right-of-way, but not in it. 
(3)  All yard trash must be placed either on owners' or tenants' property, or directly in front of and on the same side of the street as owners' or tenants' property. The City of Aiken is not responsible for the normal wear and tear to property associated with the collection of yard trash. No person shall place yard trash in front of, or on, property they do not own or lease from an owner. It shall be unlawful to place yard trash on, or within three feet of, the water meter, fire hydrant, or any other obstacle. Any damages to city equipment or infrastructure due to improper placement of yard debris may be charged to the customers' water account. When there is no active water account the charges may be levied on the owners' property taxes. 
(4)  No person shall place yard trash in, or adjacent to, any public or private park, or parkway, in the city. 
(5)  No person shall place yard trash in any location where it will cause a traffic hazard. If the trash as placed is deemed to be causing an unsafe condition by the public safety director, or his department designee, it may be removed by public services personnel and the resident may be charged in accordance with the prohibited material fee schedule in subsection (10). 
(6)  Where utility lines, tree limbs, road configuration, or any other safety concern makes it impracticable to locate the yard trash pile either on owners' or tenants' property, or directly in front of and on the same side of the street as owners' or tenants' property, at the public services director's discretion, the City of Aiken may identify an alternate location. Such alternate locations may include, but are not limited to, community piles with neighboring property owners. 
(7)  All limbs or other vegetative debris must be cut in lengths of six feet or less. 
(8)  Yard trash piles are limited to one pile per property. The maximum length of a yard trash pile is 12 feet. Yard trash piles are required to be built into compact mounds that can be efficiently collected. The public services director, or his department designee, may determine if a yard trash pile requires modification by the property owner or tenant before being collected. During leaf season, yard trash piles, consisting of predominately leaves, may exceed the 12-foot maximum length. The public services director, or his department designee, will determine when leaf season begins and ends each year. 
(9)  Yard trash piles that exceed either the maximum number per property or 12 feet in length are subject to additional fees in accordance with the special collections fee schedule. Special collection fees shall be set by city council in the annual budget process. The fees may be charged to the customers' water account. When there is no active water account the charges may be levied on the owners' property taxes. 
(10)  Following a recognized weather event or natural disaster, at the public services director's discretion, the City of Aiken may allow for oversized piles with no additional charges. During such events the City of Aiken may not be able to maintain a regular collection schedule. 
(11)  Collection begins at 7:00 a.m. and all yard trash must be placed at the curb before that time. 
(12)  Furniture, including, but not limited to, box springs, chairs, tables, white goods (i.e., appliances), and metal goods shall be considered a special collection. These special collections must be scheduled with the public services department. Special collection fees shall be added to the monthly city water bill. When there is no active water account the charges may be levied on the owners' property taxes. Special collection fees shall be set by city council in the annual budget process. The cost to pick up unscheduled special collections shall be double the normal special collection fee. 
(13)  No other materials, refuse, garbage, or waste may be mixed with residential yard trash for pickup. Railroad ties, landscaping timbers, treated lumber, any construction debris, building materials, lumber, brick, dirt, shingles, or any other similar materials shall be removed by the property owner. Tenants and property owners must ensure that debris left by any contractor is removed and properly disposed, whether by contractors, property owners, or tenants. 
(14)  If prohibited items, or vegetative materials mixed with prohibited items, are placed at the curb, tenants or property owners will be charged double the special collection fees through the customers' water account. When there is no active water account the charges may be levied on the owners' property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 11142011A, § 1(Exh. A), 11-14-2011; Ord. No. 02102020 , § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2020)  
Sec. 32-4. - Residential recycling. 
(a)  The city residential recycling program is voluntary. 
(b)  Recycling collection begins at 7:00 a.m. All recyclable materials must be placed at the public right-of-way before that time. 
(c)  The city will provide the residents with a blue recycling roll cart for the collection of the recyclable materials. 
(d)  This blue roll cart must be placed at the curb for pickup. If there is no curb, the roll cart must be placed at the edge of the roadway in front of owners' own property. 
(e)  These blue roll carts remain city property. If a property owner sells the property, the recycling roll cart is to be left at the property. The owner must clean the roll cart and secure it inside the garage, or inside the residence if no garage is constructed on the property. 
(f)  Roll carts can only be put out the night before pickup and must be removed within 24 hours of pickup. If roll carts are out prior to, or not put back within, 24 hours of pickup, city crews will return the roll cart to the house for a fee of $5.00 per incident, and billed on the monthly water bill. 
(g)  Only these items can be placed in the blue recycling roll carts: 
(1)  Steel cans. 
(2)  Aluminum cans. 
(3)  Glass jars and bottles. 
(4)  #1 plastic—PET plastic (e.g., drink bottles). 
(5)  #2 plastic—HDPE plastic (e.g., milk jugs, laundry detergent jugs). 
(6)  Newspapers. 
(7)  Magazines. 
(8)  Cardboard. 
(9)  White paper. 
(h)  No other material may be placed in the recycling roll cart for city collection, except for additional materials or objects that are approved for city-wide recycling by the public services director. 
(i)  If recyclable roll carts contain other materials not on the accepted items list, none may be collected until the property owner or tenant removes the unapproved materials. 
(Ord. No. 11142011A, § 1(Exh. A), 11-14-2011)  
Sec. 32-5. - Weekend use of roll-off containers and trash trailers by city residents with existing residential city utility accounts. 
The city, from time to time, may make roll-off containers or trash trailers used during the week in the solid waste operation available on weekends. These items will not be available during the week. These trailers or containers may be used by the residents provided that: 
(1)  The use is scheduled at least two weeks in advance. 
(2)  They are not used for any commercial purpose. 
(3)  The resident is charged according to the special collection fee schedule in subsection 32-3(8). Residents that only put yard trash in the trailer will not be charged the user fee. 
(4)  The special user fee will be added to the resident's water bill. 
(5)  The resident will be given a list of use instructions and permitted materials that can be put into the trailer. 
(6)  The resident is responsible for any tipping fee incurred due to prohibited material being put in the container or trailer. 
(7)  The container or trailer must be placed on the resident's property or on the edge of the roadway in such fashion that does not cause a traffic problem. 
(8)  The container or trailer will be delivered by 5:00 p.m. on Friday. 
(9)  The container or trailer may be removed as early as 6:00 a.m. on Monday. 
(10)  Residents will not be allowed to move the container or trailer. 
(Ord. No. 11142011A, § 1(Exh. A), 11-14-2011)  
Sec. 32-6. - Small business garbage. 
Small businesses using roll carts will pay a solid waste user fee per month as set forth by city council in the annual budget process. This fee pays for one curbside collection of garbage per week pursuant to this section. Included in this user fee is one collection of yard trash and recyclables per week. Businesses may use 90-gallon roll carts provided that: 
(1)  All small businesses must use a city-provided roll cart. No other garbage carts may be used. 
(2)  All items may be disposed of in the roll carts with the exception of yard trash pursuant to section 32-3, recyclable items pursuant to section 32-7, poisons, acids, caustics, medical waste, dead animals, explosives, automotive fluids, paints, pesticides, fertilizer, ewaste, or any item that may contain hot live coals or fire. 
(3)  If the small business has more garbage than will fit into their roll carts it must be bagged and placed beside the roll cart at the street. 
(4)  The public services director may require small businesses that consistently have extra bags beside their roll cart(s) to use additional carts or contract collection services other than the city for the use of a commercial garbage dumpster instead of the 90-gallon roll carts. 
(5)  Additional roll carts will be provided at a fee as set forth by city council in the annual budget process per cart. Additional carts will also incur a $5.00 user fee for each additional cart each month as follows: 
One roll cart 	Curbside service 	Included in user fee 
Two roll carts 	Curbside service 	User fee + $5.00/month 
Three roll carts 	Curbside service 	User fee + $10.00/month 
Four roll carts 	Curbside service 	User fee + $15.00/month 
 
(6)  No small business will have more than four roll carts without the permission of the public services director. 
(7)  At the discretion of the public services director, carts that are damaged by the small business will be replaced by the city at a fee as set forth by city council in the annual budget process per roll cart replaced. This cost will be added to the small business monthly city water bill. 
(8)  Lost or stolen carts must be replaced at a fee as set forth by city council in the annual budget process per cart. If available, a refurbished cart may be provided for free. 
(9)  These roll carts remain city property. If a business closes or moves, the cart must be left at this location. The owner must clean the cart and leave it behind the building on the premises. 
(10)  Carts may only be put out the night before pickup and must be removed within 24 hours after pickup. If these roll carts are out prior to, or not put back within 24 hours of pickup, city crews will return the cart to the business for a fee of $5.00 per incident, and billed on the monthly water bill. 
(11)  Collection routes begin at 7:00 a.m. each morning. All roll carts and other refuse must be ready for collection at that time. 
(12)  Carts must not be placed within three feet of mailboxes. 
(13)  Carts must not be placed within three feet of yard trash accumulations. 
(14)  The lid on the cart must be closed and latched while it is at the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 11142011A, § 1(Exh. A), 11-14-2011; Ord. No. 01122015E , § 1, 1-12-2015; Ord. No. 06102019B , § 1, 6-10-2019)  
Sec. 32-7. - Small business recycling. 
(a)  The city commercial recycling program is voluntary. 
(b)  Recycling collection begins at 7:00 a.m. All recyclable materials must be placed at the public right-of-way before that time. 
(c)  The city will provide the businesses with a blue recycling roll cart for the collection of the recyclable materials. 
(d)  This blue roll cart must be placed at the curb for pickup. If there is no curb, the bin must be placed at the edge of the roadway in front of owners' own property. 
(e)  These blue roll carts remain city property. If a business owner sells the property, the recycling roll cart is to be left at the property. The owner must clean the roll cart and secure it inside the business or behind the business. 
(f)  Roll carts can only be put out the night before pickup and must be removed within 24 hours of pickup. If roll carts are out prior to, or not put back within, 24 hours of pickup, city crews will return the roll cart to the business for a fee of $5.00 per incident, and billed on the monthly water bill. 
(g)  Only these items can be placed in the blue recycling roll carts: 
(1)  Steel cans. 
(2)  Aluminum cans. 
(3)  Glass jars and bottles. 
(4)  #1 plastic—PET plastic (e.g., drink bottles). 
(5)  #2 plastic—HDPE plastic (e.g., milk jugs, laundry detergent jugs). 
(6)  Newspapers. 
(7)  Magazines. 
(8)  Cardboard. 
(9)  White paper. 
(h)  No other material may be placed in the recycling roll cart for city collection, except for additional materials or objects that are approved for city-wide recycling by the public services director. 
(i)  If recyclable roll carts contain other materials not on the accepted items list, none may be collected until the business owner or tenant removes the unapproved materials. 
(Ord. No. 11142011A, § 1(Exh. A), 11-14-2011)  
Sec. 32-8. - Historic downtown business district dumpster garbage collection. 
(a)  All businesses located in the historic downtown business district as defined in section 32-1(h) who are not covered as a small business garbage customer as defined in section 32-6 will pay a solid waste fee per month as set forth by city council in the annual budget process. This fee pays for the shared use of a garbage dumpster owned and maintained by the city which will be emptied on a regular basis by a private contractor. 
(b)  The fee for this service shall be determined by the public services director based upon the usage rates for each business pursuant to the fees set forth by city council in the annual budget process. Any appeals regarding the fees charged may be submitted to the city manager for review. The dumpster fees shall be included in the business's monthly water bill. 
(c)  All businesses needing garbage dumpster service in the historic downtown business district as defined in section 32-1(h) shall be required to use the garbage dumpsters owned and maintained by the city. 
(d)  All items may be disposed in the garbage dumpsters provided with the exception of cardboard pursuant to section 32-9, poisons, acids, caustics, medical waste, dead animals, explosives, automotive fluids, paints, pesticides, fertilizer, e-waste, any item that may contain hot live coals or fire, or any item that is prohibited by the public services director. 
(Ord. No. 06242013B , § 1, 6-24-2013)  
Sec. 32-9. - Downtown district cardboard dumpster recycling. 
(a)  All businesses located in the downtown district as defined in section 32-1(h), that are not covered as a small business recycling customer in section 32-7, will pay a cardboard dumpster recycling fee per month. This fee pays for the business's shared use of a cardboard dumpster that is owned and maintained by the city and which will be emptied by a private contractor. 
(b)  The fee for this cardboard dumpster service will be determined by the public services director and will be based on the frequency of use. Any appeals regarding this frequency of use may be submitted to the city manager for review. The cardboard dumpster fee will be charged on the business's monthly water bill. 
(c)  All businesses needing cardboard dumpster service in the downtown district, as defined in section 32-1(h), shall use the city provided dumpsters. No other dumpsters may be used. 
(d)  Cardboard is the only item that can be placed in the recycling dumpster. No other material may be placed in the recycling dumpster for collection, except for additional materials or objects that are approved by the public services director. 
(Ord. No. 06242013B , § 1, 6-24-2013)  
Secs. 32-10—32-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LITTER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Littering, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-11-700; Litter Control Act, S.C. Code 1976, § 44-67-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 32-31. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning ascribed to them by this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Aircraft means any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
Authorized private receptacle means a litter storage and collection receptacle as required and authorized in article I of this chapter. 
Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Litter means garbage, refuse and rubbish, as defined in this chapter, and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited, as prohibited in this article, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
Park means a park, reservation, playground, beach or recreation area set aside for use by the public. 
Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes. 
Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1980, § 18-18) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 32-32. - Littering public places generally. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city, except in public receptacles, authorized private receptacles for collection, or in official city dumps. 
(Code 1980, § 18-19) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 32-33. - Littering parks. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city, except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Code 1980, § 18-20) 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, ch. 26.  
Sec. 32-34. - Littering fountains, ponds, lakes, etc. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 18-21)  
Sec. 32-35. - Littering occupied private property. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1980, § 18-22)  
Sec. 32-36. - Littering vacant lots. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not. 
(Code 1980, § 18-23)  
Sec. 32-37. - Removal of litter when premises vacated. 
It shall be unlawful for any person upon vacating or removing from any dwelling, storeroom or any other building to fail to remove all litter refuse from such buildings and the grounds appurtenant thereto or to fail to place the buildings and the grounds appurtenant thereto in a thoroughly sanitary condition within 24 hours after the premises have been vacated. 
(Code 1980, § 18-24)  
Sec. 32-38. - Throwing litter from vehicles. 
No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property. It shall be presumed that the driver of a motor vehicle from which litter is thrown or deposited upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property within the city, is the person who did such wrongful act. Such presumption is a rebuttable presumption which the driver may overcome by evidence showing that he was not, in fact, the person who threw or deposited such litter as provided in this section. 
(Code 1980, § 18-25) 
Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 42.  
Sec. 32-39. - Vehicle or vehicle loads causing litter. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transport by vehicle within the corporate limits of the city any loose material, unless the material is covered or secured so that it will not be blown or otherwise fall from the vehicle onto streets, public places or private property. The lack of a covering for and the securing of such loose material while the vehicle is in motion shall itself constitute a violation of this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move within the corporate limits of the city any vehicle with wheels or tires which carry onto and deposit onto any street or other public place litter or a foreign matter or substance which defaces the street or public place. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to city vehicles while collecting garbage, trash or refuse but shall apply while such vehicles are in transit to dispose of garbage, trash or refuse. 
(Code 1980, § 18-26) 
Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 42.  
Sec. 32-40. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(Code 1980, § 18-27)  
Sec. 32-41. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1980, § 18-28)  
Sec. 32-42. - Litter from business establishments not to be placed in sidewalk trash receptacles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place any litter from any business establishment in the sidewalk trash receptacles provided for the convenience of pedestrians in preventing the littering of public sidewalks. 
(Code 1980, § 18-29) 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 32-43. - Sweeping litter into public places. 
(a)  No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any place or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit floor sweepings from any business establishment on the public sidewalk, in the gutter or anywhere else within the public street right-of-way. 
(Code 1980, § 18-30) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 32-44. - Duty of owners or occupants of abutting property to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Code 1980, § 18-31)  
Chapter 34 - SPECIAL SALES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 34-1—34-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - GARAGE SALES 
 
Sec. 34-31. - Defined. 
For the purposes of this article, the term "garage sale" means the sale of any new or used personal property, which sale is conducted on or about the premises of a private residence or in any residential zoning area that permits single-family residential use, by the owner or occupant and which sale is open to the public. 
(Code 1980, § 19-11) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-32. - Permit required; duration of sale; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale, without first obtaining a permit from the city for each sale and such permit shall be posted at the site of the sale. The maximum period of each permit shall be two consecutive days and the maximum number of permits allowed per year shall be two for any one-family unit, location, lot or premises. 
(b)  The fee for a permit required by this section shall be as prescribed by ordinance and all such ordinances shall continue in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1980, § 19-12)  
Sec. 34-33. - Parking requirements. 
Parking shall be provided for all persons attending a garage sale in a manner that will not affect the free flow of traffic on a public street near such sale. 
(Code 1980, § 19-13) 
Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 42.  
Sec. 34-34. - Signs. 
Only one nonilluminated sign, not to exceed two square feet, may be posted advertising a garage sale and such sign may only be placed on the property where the sale is being conducted. 
(Code 1980, § 19-14) 
Cross reference— Advertising, ch. 4.  
Sec. 34-35. - Merchandise not to be purchased or brought on premises for sale. 
No new or used merchandise shall be purchased or brought on the premises for the purpose of selling such new or used merchandise at a garage sale. 
(Code 1980, § 19-15)  
Sec. 34-36. - Display of goods for sale. 
Goods for sale at a garage sale shall not be displayed on public property, nor shall such goods be displayed on private property in a manner which will materially impede visibility of pedestrian or vehicular traffic on or off the premises. 
(Code 1980, § 19-16)  
Sec. 34-37. - Hours of sale; Sunday operation prohibited. 
A garage sale shall be limited to the hours between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. No garage sale shall be conducted on Sunday. 
(Code 1980, § 19-17)  
Sec. 34-38. - Use of public address system prohibited. 
The use of a public address system is prohibited at garage sales. 
(Code 1980, § 19-18)  
Sec. 34-39. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
No alcoholic beverages of any type shall be served or given away on or near the premises where a garage sale is held. 
(Code 1980, § 19-19) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
State Law reference— Alcohol and alcoholic beverages, S.C. Code 1976, title 61.  
Sec. 34-40. - Inspections to enforce article. 
For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article, duly authorized representatives and employees of the city shall have the right of entry to any premise showing evidence of a garage sale and may close the premise from such a sale where any provision of this article is being violated. 
(Code 1980, § 19-20)  
Chapter 36 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any public improvement saved from repeal, § 1-5(6); any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the city or establishing and prescribing street grades saved from repeal, § 1-5(9); banners extending across streets or parks, § 4-2; deposit or distribution of handbills on or in public places, § 4-32; drinking of beer or wine in public places, § 6-4; buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; parades and other assemblies, ch. 24; permit for use of streets, etc., for demonstrations or picketing, § 24-2; other temporary street closures for block parties, § 24-69; parks and recreation, ch. 26; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 28; recreational vehicles and campers, ch. 30; littering public places generally, § 32-32; litter from business establishments not to be placed in sidewalk trash receptacles, § 32-42; sweeping litter into public places, § 32-43; special sales, ch. 34; telecommunications, ch. 40; conditions on street occupancy for telecommunications, § 40-13; traffic, ch. 42; driving on one-way streets, § 42-36; driving on play streets, § 42-37; driving on sidewalk, § 42-38; regulations for specific streets, § 42-64; riding bicycles on certain sidewalks prohibited, § 42-102; trains blocking street, § 42-152; utilities, ch. 44; vehicles for hire, ch. 46. 
State Law reference— Streets and sidewalks, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-27-10 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 36-1. - Injuring streets or removing materials therefrom. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or plow up any street or to dig, or to cause any digging to be done, in any of the streets, roads, walks, paths or pavements within the corporate limits of the city, or to remove or cause to be removed therefrom any sand, clay, dirt or other earth, without the written permission of the director of public works. This section shall not apply to such work as may be done under the lawful direction of the city authorities. 
(Code 1980, § 20-2)  
Sec. 36-2. - Permit to build sidewalk or coping. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to build any concrete or other permanent sidewalk or coping in the streets of the city without first getting permission from the director of public works, whose duty it will be to designate the proper lines, width, levels, etc., to be followed in constructing such sidewalks or coping. 
(Code 1980, § 20-5)  
Sec. 36-3. - Cutting or removing curb or sidewalk—Permit and bond. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cut away or remove any curb or sidewalk, or any part thereof, in the city, unless and until a permit therefor has been granted by the director of public works. 
(b)  Before any permit shall be granted for the opening of or cutting of any curb or sidewalk in the city, the person making application for such permit may be required by the director of public works to deposit with the city a cash bond in such sum as may be estimated by the director of public works to insure the maintenance of lights and barricades during the period of construction work, the refilling of such opening and the repaving thereof, as is provided in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 20-6)  
Sec. 36-4. - Same—Maintenance of barricades and lights. 
Any person cutting or removing any sidewalk or curb in the city shall protect such opening by means of proper barricades and lights and maintain such barricades and lights during the period of the construction work. Any opening found not properly protected shall immediately be closed by the director of public works and the cost thereof charged against the owner of the abutting property. 
(Code 1980, § 20-7)  
Sec. 36-5. - Same—Refilling opening and replacing pavement. 
After the opening or cut has been made pursuant to a permit issued under section 36-3, the person receiving the permit shall refill the opening or cut and shall repave the filled opening with the same type of material as the surrounding surface or the same type of material as cut or excavated. Such work of refilling and repaving shall be done in such manner as is prescribed by the director of public works and, upon failure so to do, the city may cause such work to be done and the cost thereof shall be charged against the owner of the abutting property. 
(Code 1980, § 20-8)  
Sec. 36-6. - Rights-of-way generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon any public pavement, walk, sidewalk, street, or bicycle path in the city any open gate or to swing upon, it, or to place it or allow it to remain on any public right-of-way, or to allow any motor vehicle, bicycle, or other wheeled vehicle, horse, or other animal to remain upon any public right-of-way, pavement, walk, sidewalk, street, or bicycle path other than in a designated parking space or rack. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or place upon any public right-of-way, street, highway, public road, or traveled place, or any part thereof within the corporate limits of the city, by placing or allowing to remain thereon any object, item, or wheeled vehicle not in actual and immediate use, or any other article; provided, that nothing contained in this section shall deprive any person who may be undertaking a city-permitted construction project, of the use of such number of feet, not to exceed 20 feet, from the pavement and the sidewalk as may be allowed by the director of public safety, for the temporary convenience of placing timber, brick, or such other building material as the public safety director may deem proper. 
(Code 1980, § 20-10; Ord. No. 04092007E, § 1, 4-9-2007)  
Sec. 36-7. - Display of merchandise. 
It shall be unlawful in the Downtown Business [DB]-zoned area of the city for any merchant or other person to place upon any public right-of-way, street, or sidewalk within the corporate limits of the city articles of merchandise or other things for display or sale of any kind further than two feet from the store front. This section shall not prevent any person from engaging in any business upon private property adjacent to, but not forming a part of such public street, sidewalk, or right-of-way; nor shall this section prohibit organized nonprofit groups from conducting, upon a public safety director-approved specified day or days, an annual sale of T.B. Christmas seals, buddy poppies or other like articles, for charitable or eleemosynary purposes and not for profit, upon such public sidewalks rights-of-way as may be designated by the director of public safety, upon application to him, at such points as will cause the least obstruction to the regular flow of traffic. The director may also approve seasonal sidewalk sales, not to exceed four in any given calendar year. Furthermore, nothing in this article shall prohibit other uses of public rights-of-way, including, but not limited to, sidewalk cafes, preapproved streetscaping objects, park benches, and any temporary directional commercial sign boards preapproved by the public safety director, in consultation with the planning department director. 
(Code 1980, § 20-11; Ord. No. 04092007E, § 1, 4-9-2007)  
Sec. 36-8. - Sale of food prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any merchant or other person to sell food from vehicles on the public streets of the city, or to sell food from vending machines on streets or sidewalks within the corporate limits of the city, unless otherwise permitted pursuant to section 3.5.7 of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 20-12; Ord. No. 07102017A , § 1(Exh. A), 7-10-2017)  
Sec. 36-9. - Deposit of injurious substances on street; removal. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit upon any street any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans or any other substance likely to injure any person, animal or vehicle upon such street. 
(b)  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any street any destructive or injurious material shall immediately remove such material or cause it to be removed. Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street from such vehicle. 
(Code 1980, § 20-13)  
Sec. 36-10. - Use of public streets, alleys, ways and places by utilities. 
(a)  Permission to use streets required. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, erect, install, maintain or operate electric, gas, telephone, cablevision or other utility lines, poles, wires, equipment or facilities in, on, over, under, upon or across any public street, alley, way or place in the city without first obtaining a franchise or permit from the city council consenting to such use of the public streets, alleys, ways and places. A franchise or permit consenting to such use may be granted by the city council only through the adoption of an ordinance which prescribes the term, fees and conditions for use. 
(b)  Undergrounding of utilities. Where economically feasible, all electric, gas, telephone, cablevision and utility lines, wires, equipment and facilities crossing public streets, alleys, ways and places in the city shall be placed underground. 
(c)  Trimming of trees. No trees located in public streets, alleys, ways or places in the city shall be cut, destroyed or trimmed by any person except upon prior notice to and approval by the city horticulturist. 
(d)  Application to franchises. Subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall apply to and be a provision in all franchises and permits granted by the city council at any time authorizing the use of the public streets, alleys, ways and places as described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(e)  Consent, franchise or business license fee required. The annual fee for use of streets or public places authorized by a consent agreement or franchise agreement shall be set by the ordinance approving the agreement and shall be based on gross revenues derived from activities in the municipality, the length of lines installed in streets and public places, or other formula deemed appropriate by council. No consent fee or franchise fee shall be construed to be in lieu of a business license tax based on gross revenue unless specifically provided by ordinance. Credits for business license taxes paid may be applied to fees set by ordinance granting consent or a franchise when specifically authorized by the ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 20-14) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 44.  
Sec. 36-11. - Outdoor displays and cafes. 
(a)  Purpose and applicability of section. The provisions of this section shall apply to the establishment, operation and maintenance of outdoor cafes within the central business district. The purpose of this section is to promote the general economic development and atmosphere of the central business district for the benefit of all businesses and citizens located there, and no rights of individuals or individual businesses are created in this section. The city manager shall have broad discretion to grant, modify or revoke permits issued pursuant to this section in the interests of improving the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrator means the zoning official or other person authorized by the city manager to enforce this section. 
Design requirements means the standards adopted for the central business district with this section that guide design and materials in encroachment areas. 
Encroachment means stands, tables, umbrellas, chairs, displays, objects related to the business, or other items for sale on the public right-of-way, sidewalk or common area on public property. 
Outdoor cafe means the placing, locating or permitting of the placing or locating of chairs and tables on the right-of-way, such as sidewalks, adjacent to a business licensed to operate as an eating establishment where food and/or other refreshments are served, or upon public property within designated areas. 
Sidewalk means that area of the public right-of-way between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines reserved for pedestrian traffic, not including street crossings. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13. Each day any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  Permit required. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to create, establish, operate, maintain or otherwise be engaged in the business of running an outdoor cafe, or place any items upon the sidewalks or public property, in the central business district in the city unless he shall hold a currently valid permit issued under the terms of this section. 
(2)  Permits shall be issued only to validly licensed businesses that wish to provide tables and chairs related to their business on the public property adjacent to their businesses for use by the general public. 
(e)  Application for permit; fee. 
(1)  Application for the permit required by this section shall be made at the department of public safety on a form deemed appropriate by the zoning official. Such application shall include but not be limited to the following information: 
a.  Name, home and business address and telephone number of the applicant, and the name and address of the owner of the business if other than the applicant. 
b.  Name, home address and telephone number of a responsible person whom the city may notify or contact at any time concerning the applicant's encroachment. 
c.  A copy of a valid business license to operate a business establishment adjacent to the public property which is the subject of the application. 
d.  Proof of current liability insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, protecting the licensee and the city from all claims for damage to property and bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operation under or in connection with the encroachment permit. Such insurance shall name the city as an additional insured and shall provide that the policy shall not terminate or be cancelled prior to the expiration date without 30 days' advance written notice to the city. The policy shall be a minimum required amount, or higher if deemed necessary by the city's risk management division. 
e.  Proof of any required ABC license, health permits or other state permits for the business involved. 
(2)  Not later than 15 days after the filing of a completed application for a temporary encroachment permit, the applicant shall be notified by the zoning administrator of the decision on the issuance or denial of the permit. Upon issuance of the permit, an annual fee set by the city manager shall be due and payable. This fee is in addition to the business license fee required for operation within the city. 
(3)  Application for a permit shall be made at the department of public safety within 48 hours of written notice for failure to obtain a permit. Where the same owner, occupant or person responsible has been given notice for the same violation at the same location within the previous 180 days, such requirements of written notice may be waived and legal proceedings commenced immediately. 
(f)  Prohibited acts. 
(1)  No merchant, vendor, business or property owner shall: 
a.  Place any items for sale or other equipment, tables or chairs on any portion of the public property other than that directly adjacent to the existing place of business without the written consent of adjacent landowners and businesses. In no event shall such items be placed in the landscaped areas or extend beyond the authorized 25 feet from each side of the applicant's business. 
b.  Block or restrict the passageway to less than four feet in width, or block ingress or egress to or from any building. In areas of congested pedestrian activity, the zoning administrator is authorized to require a wider pedestrian path, as circumstances dictate. 
c.  Sublicense the encroachment separately to nonoccupants of the premises. 
d.  Place objects around the perimeter of an area occupied by tables and chairs which would have the effect of forming a physical or visual barrier. 
e.  Use tables, chairs, umbrellas and any other objects of such quality, design, materials and workmanship which are not authorized by the administrator. 
f.  Use umbrellas or other decorative materials which are not fire-retardant, pressure-treated or manufactured of fire resistive material. 
g.  Fail to secure permission of the landlord where a building has multiple occupants. 
h.  Sound or permit the sounding of any device on the public property which produces a loud noise, or use or operate any loudspeaker, public address system, radio, sound amplifier or similar device in violation of the noise regulations of the city. 
i.  Fail to pick up, remove and dispose of all trash or refuse left by the business on the public right-of-way. 
j.  Store, park or leave any vehicle, truck or trailer within the encroachment area. 
(2)  The encroachment permit is a temporary license which may be denied, suspended or revoked for any conduct which is contrary to the provisions of this section or for conduct of the business in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute a danger to the operator's or the public's health, safety or welfare. No property right is created by this section, and the decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(g)  Form and conditions of permits. The permit required by this section shall be issued on a form deemed suitable by the zoning administrator. In addition to naming the permittee and any other information deemed appropriate by the administrator, the permit shall contain the following conditions: 
(1)  Each permit shall be effective for one year, from July 1 to June 30, subject to annual renewal, unless revoked or suspended prior to expiration. 
(2)  The permit issued shall be personal to the permittee only and shall not be transferable in any manner. 
(3)  The permit may be suspended by the administrator when necessary to clear the public property for public safety for a community or special event authorized by a permit issued by the city. 
(4)  The city manager may require the temporary removal of items within the encroachment area when street, sidewalk, common area or utility repairs necessitate such action. 
(5)  The permit shall be specifically limited to the area shown on the plat diagram attached to the permit application. As a condition of approval, the city may reduce and otherwise reconfigure the proposed area and the number of requested chairs, tables, and items within the encroachment area. 
(6)  The encroachment area covered by the permit shall be maintained in a neat and orderly appearance at all times, and the area shall be cleared of all debris on a periodic basis during the day, and again at the close of each business day. 
(7)  No tables or chairs or any other parts of the business shall be attached, chained or in any manner affixed to any tree, post, sign or other fixtures, curb or sidewalk within or near the permitted area. No additional outdoor seating authorized under this section shall be used for calculating seating requirements pertaining to location of, application for or issuance of an ABC license for any establishment, or be used as the basis for computing required seating for restaurants and dining rooms, or as grounds for claiming exemption from such requirements under the provisions of any city ordinance or state law. 
(8)  The issuance of a permit does not grant or infer vested rights to use of the area by the permittee. The city retains the right to deny the issuance of a permit or the renewal of a permit for any reason. 
(9)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas and any other objects provided shall be maintained in a clean and attractive appearance and shall be kept safe and in good repair at all times. 
(10)  The city retains the right to suspend the privilege of using glass containers within the encroachment area during major festivals and events and when streets are closed. The use of glass containers will be revoked if an incident jeopardizes the health, safety and welfare of customers or the general public. Any violation of state or local laws will also result in a revocation of this privilege. Repeated offenses may result in revocation or denial of the encroachment permit. 
(11)  The serving and consumption of alcoholic beverages on city sidewalks and public property must be in compliance with applicable regulations of the state alcoholic beverage control commission and with applicable provisions of the South Carolina Code. The serving and consumption of alcoholic beverages in sidewalk encroachments is limited to patrons seated at tables. The serving and consumption of alcoholic beverages on other public property is not restricted to patrons seated at tables, provided the configuration and use of the encroachment does not result in undue interference with the public's safe access and use of the surrounding space. 
(12)  The city may require the posting or placement of the permit and relevant notices to facilitate the administration and enforcement of this section. 
(h)  Denial, suspension or revocation of permit; removal of property by city. 
(1)  Grounds for denial, suspension or revocation; removal of property by city. The administrator or his designee may deny, revoke or suspend a permit issued under this section at any time for any business authorized in the city if it is found that: 
a.  Any necessary business or health permit has been suspended, revoked or canceled. 
b.  The permittee does not have insurance in force which is correct and effective in the minimum required amount. 
c.  Changing conditions of pedestrian or vehicular traffic cause congestion necessitating removal of the encroachment. Such decision shall be based upon findings of the administrator that the minimum four-foot pedestrian path is insufficient under existing circumstances and represents a danger to the health, safety or general welfare of pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
d.  The permittee has failed to correct violations of this section or conditions of his permit upon receipt of the administrator's notice of the violation delivered in writing to the permittee. 
e.  The permittee has failed to take positive actions to prohibit violations from reoccurring. 
f.  The permittee has failed to make modifications upon receipt of the administrator's notice to make such modifications delivered in writing to the permittee. Tables, chairs and other vestiges of the business may be removed by the department of public works, and a reasonable fee charged for labor, transportation and storage, should the permittee fail to remove the items within 36 hours of receipt of the zoning administrator's final notice to do so for any reason provided for under this section. If the action is taken based on subsection (h)(1)b or c of this section, the action shall become effective upon the receipt of such notice and the permittee shall have four hours to remove the items. 
(2)  Notice of denial or revocation. Upon denial or revocation, the zoning administrator shall give notice of such action to the applicant or the permittee, in writing, stating the action which has been taken and the reason therefore. The action shall be effective upon giving such notice to the permittee. 
(3)  Appeals. The permittee shall have the right to appeal the decision of the city official to the city manager within five working days from receipt of notice. An appeal does not stay the denial or revocation of the encroachment permit. The hearing shall be held within two working days from the date of notice of the request. The permittee or applicant may be represented by an attorney and may present witnesses, affidavits and any relevant documentary evidence. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply. The city manager or his designee shall notify the permittee or applicant of his determination in writing, and such determination shall constitute the final decision by the city in the matter. 
(Code 1980, § 20-15)  
Sec. 36-12. - Newsracks in the central business district. 
(a)  Purpose and applicability of section. The provisions of this section shall apply to the placement and maintenance of newsracks and modular newsracks within the central business district. The purpose of this section is to promote the general economic development and atmosphere of the central business district for the benefit of all businesses and citizens located there, and no rights of individuals or individual businesses are created in this section. The city manager shall have discretion, consistent with the provisions in this section, to grant, modify or revoke permits issued pursuant to this section in the interests of improving the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  Location requirements. The city manager shall determine where newsracks and modular newsracks shall be located in the central business district. Initially, there shall be 11 modular newsracks locations [may be more than one modular newsrack] placed at or near the locations set forth on the map which is attached hereto as Exhibit "A" and incorporated herein by reference. These modular newsracks shall be installed within six months of council's adoption of this ordinance. In determining future location requirements, the city manager shall establish objective criteria relating to the following: surrounding uses likely to generate a demand for periodicals and other material customarily supplied through newsracks, distances between locations, and the visual compatibility of newsracks and modular newsracks with surrounding facades and streetscape improvements. 
(c)  Design requirements. No person other than the city shall place or use for distribution of material any newsrack or modular newsrack on any public sidewalk, public park, or other public space owned by the city in the central business district. In determining design requirements, the city manager shall consider compatibility of design features with prevailing facade treatments and with streetscape improvements to the full extent modular newsracks having such features are reasonably available on the market. 
(d)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
