Central business district. The district bounded on the south by Colleton Avenue, then turning north on Laurens Street, then turning west on Park Avenue, then turning north on Hayne Avenue, then turning west on Hayne Avenue, then turning north on Greenville Street, then turning east on Abbeville Avenue, then turning south on Union Street and returning to Colleton Avenue. The district shall include all properties within the above described and all properties on both sides of the streets and avenues that comprise the central business district. This definition shall apply for purposes of this section only and is not to be confused with the downtown business district referred to in the City of Aiken Zoning Ordinance. 
Newsrack. Any industry standard self-service or coin operated machine which dispenses newspapers, periodicals, brochures, pamphlets and like material to the general public. 
Modular newsrack. One industry standard structure composed of a group of individual publication dispensing cabinets mounted as single cabinets or as cabinets in multiple cabinet configurations. 
Publisher. A person or corporation, or other legal entity, who engages in the business of publishing newspapers, periodicals, brochures, pamphlets and like material. 
(e)  Delegation of duties. The city manager may delegate, in whole or in part, the city manager's duties under this section to one or more city employees. 
(f)  Ownership of modular newsracks. The city shall own all of the modular newsracks authorized by the city manager under this section. The city shall be responsible for the upkeep, repair, and replacement of modular newsracks. 
(g)  Allocation of locations. The city manager shall develop written criteria to allocate the limited modular newsracks locations available for periodicals and other material. The criteria shall be non discriminatory among publishers, but may make reasonable limitations on the number of publications that any one publisher, or its affiliates, may have at any one location when spaces at that location are limited in number. The city manager may also implement reasonable regulations to promote the full utilization of modular newsrack spaces and to require the forfeiture of modular newsrack spaces when they are not fully utilized. The city manager may make limitations on the lettering, logos, and graphics that appear on the modular newsracks, but shall allow a reasonable basis for publications contained within spaces to be readily identified. The initial draft of these regulations is attached hereto as Exhibit "B" and is set out following this section. 
(h)  Permit not a property right. The permits for the use of public modular newsrack space as provided for under this section are not property rights or entitlements of any distributor of material found in the modular newsracks. 
(Ord. No. 01282008C, § 1, 1-28-2008) 
Exhibit A 
 
Exhibit B 
NEWSRACK UNIT REGULATIONS: 
ALLOCATION OF NEWSRACK UNIT SPACES 
The total number of public spaces on the right of way or other city-owned property to be made available for modular newsracks in the central business district [as defined in section 36-12 of the Aiken City Code] shall be allocated by the following criteria: 
(1)  The City of Aiken will purchase and install modular newsracks for the locations originally approved by city council. The city will lease space on a bi-annual basis to publications originally approved by city council. There will be a minimum of 400 feet between each modular newsrack location which may be comprised of more than one modular newsrack. 
(2)  No later than May 15 of each year following the initial allocation of spaces, all publishers interested in leasing unoccupied modular newsrack space shall submit to the city manager a request identifying the number of spaces and locations requested. No later than June 1 of each year, the city manager shall designate the number of spaces, if any, a requesting publisher shall have at any location, effective July 1. The space so allocated, subject to the terms and conditions of these regulations, shall be held by the permittee for two consecutive fiscal years at a cost per year to be determined and based upon the actual cost to the city amortized over a five-year period. 
(3)  If all spaces at all locations are available to meet all publishers' requests as submitted, then the city manager's office shall issue space permits as requested. Before newsrack spaces are allocated, the publisher will agree to remove all of its personal newsracks from the central business district within ten days of receiving its space from the city. If the publisher does not remove its racks within this time, the city will be authorized to remove the racks. 
(4)  If there are insufficient spaces at a location to meet all new requests for available spaces as submitted, then the city manager's office shall allocate by lottery for the locations where there are insufficient spaces. 
(5)  All publishers failing to receive a space at a particular location shall be put on a waiting list for that location for the applicable year in the sequence their names were drawn for that location. If spaces at the location become available during the year, then they shall be made available to publishers in the sequence their names appear on the waiting list for the location. 
(6)  No publisher may utilize more than 50 percent of the available modular newsrack space at any one location unless there is a space not being utilized at the location, but each publisher may offer more than one publication in the spaces provided. 
(7)  Publishers not participating in the May 15 application, may be placed on the waiting list behind those already on the list and they shall be placed in the order their requests are received. 
(8)  A publication's permit for a modular newsrack space is not transferable. 
(9)  All publishers must keep stocked the modular newsrack spaces allocated to them. If the city checks randomly and finds a space not stocked two out of four times over a four week period, the occupancy can be terminated, provided there is a publisher on the waiting list for the location. The city must keep the modular newsracks in good working order and good appearance. 
(10)  In the event a publisher desires to utilize a coin operated device for the purpose of collecting money for their publication, the publisher will be responsible for procuring the coin operated device and will be responsible for the upkeep, maintenance and repair of these coin operated devices. 
(11)  The city manager shall have the ability to amend these regulations from time to time with a minimum of 15 days written notice to all tenants. 
(Ord. No. 01282008C, § 1, 1-28-2008)  
Secs. 36-13—36-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - STREET NAMES 
 
Sec. 36-31. - Naming system established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a uniform system of street naming in the city, and all streets, avenues and other dedicated public ways shall be named in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  All streets and other public ways running in the same direction and having a deviation of not more than 125 feet from the nearest parallel street shall carry the same name unless special circumstances make such a plan impracticable or not feasible. 
(c)  All through east and west streets shall carry the designation "Avenue," and all through north and south streets shall carry the designation "Street." 
(d)  That part of any street ending in a dead-end or cul-de-sac shall carry the designation "Place." 
(e)  The name "Terrace" shall be used in any residential or business development for any north and south alley street which bisects or crosses a nominal block or series of blocks, and the name "Lane" shall be used for any such east and west alley street. 
(f)  No street established or named shall bear a name in conflict with the general directions set out in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 20-23)  
Sec. 36-32. - Preparation of naming plan by planning commission. 
(a)  For the purpose of clarifying and systematizing the street naming pattern in the city and to implement the application of the provisions set forth in section 36-31, the planning commission is hereby authorized to prepare and present to the city council a complete plan for the naming of all streets, avenues and public ways within the city which shall be adhered to, except where a conflict or duplication exists. The planning commission shall follow the general plan set forth in section 36-31 and such other rules as are set forth in this article. 
(b)  In preparing the plan under this section, if the planning commission shall find an existing street now carrying more than one name, it shall recommend that such street shall bear the name under which it currently travels the longest distance, both inside and outside of the city limits, unless circumstances indicate that another and different name would be desirable. The planning commission may hold public hearings at which interested property owners may express their views concerning the changing of the name or names of any street. 
(Code 1980, § 20-24) 
State Law reference— Approval of street names, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-29-1200.  
Sec. 36-33. - Subdivision plats to bear report of planning commission as to street names. 
Every subdivision plat submitted to the city council for its approval shall bear upon its face the report of the planning commission of the proper names of any and all streets, avenues and public ways dedicated to public use within the jurisdiction of the city council and shall first be checked by the planning commission as to their names under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 20-25)  
Sec. 36-34. - Street naming and renaming recommendations of planning commission. 
The planning commission shall recommend to the city council any change in the name or the naming of existing or newly established streets within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 20-26)  
Secs. 36-35—36-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STREET NUMBERS FOR LOTS AND BUILDINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10. 
 
Sec. 36-61. - System established; compliance with article. 
There is hereby established a uniform system for numbering parcels of land fronting on all streets, avenues and public ways in the city, and all houses and other buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 20-37)  
Sec. 36-62. - Baselines designated. 
(a)  Richland Avenue shall constitute the baseline for numbering parcels along all streets running northerly and southerly; and Chesterfield Street and Whiskey Road, as hereinafter named and established, shall constitute the base line for numbering parcels along all streets running easterly and westerly. 
(b)  Each parcel north of Richland Avenue and facing a street running in a northerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location north of such base street. 
(c)  Each parcel south of Richland Avenue and facing a street running in a southerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location south of such base street. 
(d)  Each parcel east of Chesterfield Street and Whiskey Road and facing a street running in an easterly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location east of such base street. 
(e)  Each parcel east of Chesterfield Street and Whiskey Road and facing a street running in a westerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location west of such base street. 
(f)  All parcels on diagonal streets shall be numbered the same as parcels on northerly and southerly streets if the diagonal street runs more from the north to the south, and the same rule shall apply on easterly and westerly streets if the diagonal street runs more from the east to the west. All parcels on diagonal streets having a deviation of exactly 45 degrees shall be numbered the same as parcels on northerly and southerly streets. 
(Code 1980, § 20-38)  
Sec. 36-63. - Lot numbering to begin at baseline; one number for each 20 feet. 
The numbering of parcels on each street shall begin at the baseline. All numbers shall be assigned on the basis of one number for every 20 feet of street frontage. 
(Code 1980, § 20-39)  
Sec. 36-64. - Odd and even numbers. 
All parcels on the north and east side of each street running from the base street shall bear even numbers. All parcels on the south and west side of each street running from the base street shall bear odd numbers. 
(Code 1980, § 20-40)  
Sec. 36-65. - Numbering of lots facing streets not extending to baseline. 
All parcels facing streets not extending through to the baseline shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the street had extended to the baseline. 
(Code 1980, § 20-41)  
Sec. 36-66. - Numbers and directional symbols for streets, avenues, etc., in addition to lot numbers. 
(a)  In addition to the numbers placed on each parcel as heretofore provided, all streets, avenues and other public ways within the city are hereby given numbers and directional symbols according to their distance and direction from the two base streets set forth in section 36-62. 
(b)  All streets east of Chesterfield Street and Whiskey Road and north of Richland Avenue shall carry the designation "Northeast" (N.E.). 
(c)  All streets west of Chesterfield Street and Whiskey Road and north of Richland Avenue shall carry the designation "Northwest" (N.W.). 
(d)  All streets east of Chesterfield Street and Whiskey Road and south of Richland Avenue shall carry the designation "Southeast" (S.E.). 
(e)  All streets west of Chesterfield Street and Whiskey Road and south of Richland Avenue shall carry the designation "Southwest" (S.W.). 
(f)  Each block shall bear a number or numbers corresponding to the distance of the block from the base street. Each block parallel to the base street shall carry the same block number between terminating streets. If the block is not parallel with either base Street, then its number shall vary according to the distance the block is from both base streets. 
(g)  Each house or other building, in addition to the number or numbers given it under other sections of this article, shall also bear the number and direction of the street on which it is located. 
(Code 1980, § 20-42)  
Sec. 36-67. - Numbering building entrances serving separate occupants. 
(a)  Where any building has more than one entrance serving separate occupants, a separate number shall be assigned to each entrance serving a separate occupant. If the building is not located on a lot, parcel or tract which would permit the assignment of one number to each such entrance, numerals and letters shall be used, as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Where only one number can be assigned to any building, the owner, occupant or agent of such building, who shall desire distinctive numbers for the upper and lower portion of the building, or for any part of such building fronting on any street, may use the suffix (A), (B), (C) and so on through the alphabet as may be required. 
(Code 1980, § 20-43)  
Sec. 36-68. - Assignment of numbers generally. 
It shall be the duty of the county E-911, in conjunction with the public works department, to inform any party applying therefor of the number or numbers belonging to or embraced within the limits of any parcel, as provided in this article. In case of conflict as to the proper number to be assigned to any building, the building official shall determine the number of such building in accordance with the plats referred to in section 36-70. 
(Code 1980, § 20-44)  
Sec. 36-69. - Duty to procure and display number. 
(a)  Whenever any house, building or structure shall be erected or located in the city, it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the correct number or numbers, as designated on the plats referred to in section 36-70, from the building official. No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has procured from the building official the official number of the premises. Final approval of any structure erected, repaired, altered or modified shall be withheld by the building official until durable and proper numbers have been affixed to the structure in accord with this section. 
(b)  The owner, occupant or agent shall place or cause to be placed upon each house or building controlled by him the number or numbers assigned under the uniform system as provided in this article. The cost of the number or numbers shall be paid for by the property owner or occupant. Replacement of numbers shall be procured and paid for by the owner or occupant. The numbers used shall be not less than 2½ inches in height and shall be painted or made of a durable and clearly visible material. 
(c)  The numbers referred to in this section shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the proper door of each building; or in lieu thereof they shall be placed near the walk, driveway or common entrance to such building and upon a gate post, fence, tree, post or other appropriate place within the lot lines, so as to be easily discernible from the street. 
(Code 1980, § 20-45)  
Sec. 36-70. - Plats showing proper numbers. 
For the purpose of facilitating correct numbering, a plat book of all streets, avenues and public ways within the city, showing the proper numbers of all parcels fronting upon all streets, avenue or public ways shall be kept on file in the office of the director of public works. These plats shall be open to inspection of all persons during the office hours of the department of public works. Duplicate copies of such plats shall be furnished to the city engineer. 
(Code 1980, § 20-46)  
Sec. 36-71. - Painting of addresses on street curbs. 
The director of the department of public safety shall promulgate written regulations for the voluntary painting of street address numbers on street curbs in the city. These regulations shall include requirements providing for the clear visibility of such numbers during all hours of the day, uniform standards for the sizes of the numbers, the color and type of paint or paints which may be used therefor, the written permission of the owner or his agent for the painting and the person or company providing the service notifying the owner or his agent in writing that it or he is not acting on behalf of the city in providing the service and that the painting of such numbers on curbs is not required by the city. The display of the street address numbers as allowed by this section does not relieve the owner of the duty to display those numbers as required by section 36-69. 
(Code 1980, § 20-47)  
Secs. 36-72—36-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - ASSESSMENTS FOR PERMANENT IMPROVEMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Assessments for street and sidewalk improvements, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-27-310 et seq. 
 
Sec. 36-91. - Petition by abutting owners; plans and specifications; assessment roll generally; etc. 
When permanent improvements of any streets or sidewalks in the city are to be made, they shall be done in the following manner: Upon written petition by, and the consent of, two-thirds in number of the owners of the abutting property upon any streets proposed to be improved, the petition to be filed with the city clerk, agreeing to pay in the aggregate not to exceed one-half of the total cost of such improvements of the street, the city council shall, by order, direct the improvement of the street, as follows: The council shall determine the character of material to be used in the improvements to be made and the manner in which the improvements shall be done, shall cause to be prepared accurate plans and specifications therefor, and shall determine the cost of the improvements. Thereupon, the city engineer or other person acting in his capacity shall prepare a plat of the street, or part thereof, showing the name of each owner of property abutting thereon, with the location of the property of each, and shall prepare an assessment roll, showing the amount to be assessed against each particular piece or parcel of property abutting on the proposed improvement in proportion to the frontage of such property on the street; provided, however, that the assessments so made shall not exceed, in the aggregate, one-half of the total cost of the improvement. The assessment roll so prepared shall be filed with the city clerk, whose duty it shall be, upon receipt of such assessment roll, to give notice by publication in a newspaper published in the city, to all parties interested that the assessment roll is in his office and will there remain for a period of one week from the date of the publication of the notice. All persons concerned, during such period of one week, may file in writing with the city clerk such exceptions or objections to the assessment as they may desire. 
(Code 1980, § 20-57)  
Sec. 36-92. - Rejection or ratification of assessment roll by council. 
At the expiration of one week from the date of the notice of the completion of the assessment roll, the city clerk shall refer the assessment roll to the city council, together with such exceptions or objections as may have been filed thereto, and the city council, at its next regular meeting or at an adjourned or called meeting, shall review the assessment roll, together with any exceptions, and shall have authority to make any correction therein deemed proper, and, in its discretion, to reject or ratify the assessment roll. Upon the ratification of the assessment roll, the city council shall provide for the payment out of the city treasury of one-half of the cost of the proposed improvement. 
(Code 1980, § 20-58)  
Sec. 36-93. - Lien. 
(a)  Upon the ratification of the assessment roll by the city council, the amount, as shown in the assessment roll, assessed against each piece or parcel of property shall constitute a lien thereon from the time of the ratification by the city council, and the payment thereof may be enforced by the city in the same manner as is the payment of city taxes; provided, that such assessment shall be entered in a book to be kept for that purpose by the city clerk, to be entitled "Assessment Liens," stating the name of the owner, the location of the property, the amount of the assessment and the time of payment. Such lien shall continue from the date of the entry of the lien on such assessment lien book until the expiration of five years from the date when the final payment is due and payable, unless sooner paid. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk, when full payment is made by the owners of the abutting property of the assessments provided for in this article, to make entry of satisfaction on the assessment lien book, and thereupon such lien shall be extinguished. 
(Code 1980, § 20-59)  
Sec. 36-94. - Terms of payment; interest. 
(a)  When the assessment roll has been ratified in the manner prescribed by section 36-92, each owner of property so assessed may, within 30 days after such ratification, pay into the city treasury the full amount of the assessment, or shall have the right to have such assessment divided into five equal payments, the first installment thereof to be due 30 days after the date of the ratification of the assessment roll by the city council, and the remaining installments to be due in equal amounts, respectively in one, two, three and four years from the date of the first installment, with interest on unpaid installments at the rate of six percent per annum, payable annually from date until paid in full. 
(b)  Where the permanent improvement of any of the streets in the city is of the type commonly known as "surface treatment," the property owner shall have the right to have such assessment divided into four equal payments, the first installment of which shall be due and payable 30 days after the date of the ratification of the assessment roll by the city council and the remaining installments to be due in equal amounts, one, two and three years from the date of the first installment, with interest on unpaid installments at the rate of six percent per annum, payable annually from date until paid. 
(Code 1980, § 20-60)  
Sec. 36-95. - Application of payments. 
All appropriations made by the city for permanent improvements under the authority of this article, together with the amounts of such assessment as may be paid in cash by the owners of abutting property within the time provided for in this article for the payment of assessments in full, shall be applied to the payment of the contractor or other person making the improvements, under contract with the city, on monthly estimates to be approved by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 20-61)  
Sec. 36-96. - Assessment certificates. 
(a)  For assessments made in compliance with this article, remaining unpaid at the expiration of the time limit for the payment of assessments in full, the mayor and city clerk are authorized and required to issue assessment certificates, in the name of the city council, in the amount of such assessments unpaid. Such certificates shall be known as "Paving Assessment Certificates of the City of Aiken," and shall be substantially the following form: 
"PAVING ASSESSMENT CERTIFICATE OF THE CITY OF AIKEN, S.C. 
"All requirements of an Act of the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina having been complied with, the City of Aiken, S.C., agrees to collect from the property owners abutting on the improvement of _______ Street, which property is, for value received, bound unto the holder of this certificate in the sum of _______ Dollars with interest thereon at the rate of six percent per annum, payable annually from this date until paid, payable at the city clerk's office in the City of Aiken, S.C., with exchange and collection charges on the ________ day of ________, 20___. 
"This certifies that the improvements for which this assessment was levied has been ordered by the City Council of Aiken, S.C., the same being in compliance with the law and all ordinances pertaining thereto, and owners of the property abutting improvements have acknowledged their indebtedness to the city by payment in cash of one-fifth of the total assessment against their property, as required by law, and will accept from the City Council of Aiken, S.C., as provided by an Act of the Legislature of said state, the privilege of paying the amount still due in four equal annual installments, with interest at the rate of six percent per annum from _______ payable annually to the City of Aiken, S.C., in accordance with the assessment made and approved on the ________ day of ________, 20___, fully described and set forth in a record kept by the city clerk, entitled "Assessment Liens," stating the name of the owner, the location of the property, and the time of payments. 
"The City of Aiken agrees to collect the annual installment which this certificate represents, and to pay, when collected, the amount to the holder thereof." 
(b)  There shall be four assessment certificates issued for each separate piece of permanent street improvement, each covering the assessment for one of the years in which the assessment may be due and payable, each for one-fourth of the total amount of the assessment remaining unpaid at the time limited for the payment of assessments in full or in cash, as prescribed by this article, or in such a manner and in such amounts as may be prescribed by the city council, and the certificates may be sold at or above par or may be delivered to the contractor on account of the contract price of the work. 
(Code 1980, § 20-62)  
Sec. 36-97. - Segregation of assessment funds. 
The amount raised by the assessments provided for by this article, together with the appropriation added thereto out of the city treasury, shall be kept as a separate fund, to be used only for the purpose for which it was contributed and appropriated. 
(Code 1980, § 20-63)  
Sec. 36-98. - Authority to borrow and loan funds. 
The city council shall have the right to borrow the amount of money necessary to make the improvements provided for in this article and to loan to the party owning the abutting property on the improved streets an amount not exceeding one-half the cost of the improvement, such loan to be secured according to law, and to be a lien on the abutting property. 
(Code 1980, § 20-64)  
Secs. 36-99—36-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLES AND OTHER PROPERTY ABANDONED ON STREETS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 42. 
 
Sec. 36-121. - When vehicle or property considered abandoned. 
Any vehicle or other personal property which is left on any right-of-way of any street, avenue, road or other public way in the city for a period of over 48 hours, is hereby declared to be abandoned property. 
(Code 1980, § 20-75)  
Sec. 36-122. - Impoundment generally. 
It shall be the duty of the director of public safety and public safety officers designated by him, having knowledge of any abandoned property referred to in section 36-121 to seize it and have it removed for safekeeping to such place as may be designated by the director of public safety, who shall thereupon be charged with its custody and disposition as provided in this article. 
(Code 1980, § 20-76)  
Sec. 36-123. - Notice of impoundment. 
The officer having custody of any abandoned property under this article shall forthwith: 
(1)  Post, in three public places within the city, a notice, setting forth the fact of his possession, a full description of such property, the place at which it was found, the place at which it is being held, the amount of any charges connected with his possession of it, and that, unless the property shall be reclaimed within 30 days after the posting of such notice, it will be advertised for sale and sold as provided in this article; and 
(2)  Mail such notice by certified mail to the owner of such abandoned property, and to the holder or holders of any liens upon the property, if the names and addresses of such owner and lien holders can be ascertained by reasonable inquiry. 
(Code 1980, § 20-77)  
Sec. 36-124. - Notice of proposed sale. 
If 30 days shall elapse after notice by mail or posting, as required in section 36-123, is given, and the property has not been reclaimed, the director of public safety shall advertise such property for sale for cash at public auction, giving such information as is required in subsection 36-123(1) for a posted notice, along with the time, date and place of proposed sale. Such advertisement shall be published at least once a week for three succeeding weeks prior to the proposed sale, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1980, § 20-78)  
Sec. 36-125. - Reclamation of property before sale. 
Any owner or lien holder having an interest in property seized under this article may reclaim the property at any time before its public sale, by presenting evidence of right to possession, satisfactory to the director of public safety and tendering payment of all charges and fees incurred by the latter or the city while in possession of such property. 
(Code 1980, § 20-79)  
Sec. 36-126. - Lien for towing or storage charges. 
Any person authorized by the director of public safety to tow, haul or store any abandoned property shall have a lien against such property for the reasonable value of such services, which shall be prior to all other liens. 
(Code 1980, § 20-80)  
Sec. 36-127. - Sale of unreclaimed property. 
If abandoned property is not reclaimed prior to the time of any advertised sale thereof, the director of public safety shall sell it and pay from the proceeds all costs and charges incurred in handling, in advertising the sale of, and in selling such property, and any balance remaining shall be paid to the city treasurer for credit to the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 20-81)  
Sec. 36-128. - Payment of claims of owners and lien holders after sale. 
For a period of not in excess of two years after the payment of any sum into the general fund of the city, on account of the sale of any abandoned property pursuant to this article, the city council shall hear and allow claims of any persons claiming to be damaged by the sale of such property, and make awards to owners or lien holders as their interest may appear, but in no event shall such award be in excess of the amount received by the city on account of the sale of the property which is the subject of any such claim. The decision of the council in connection with any such claim shall be final. 
(Code 1980, § 20-82)  
Secs. 36-129—36-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - ROAD AND DRAINAGE IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06202016 , § 1(Exh. A), adopted June 20, 2016, added provisions designated as Art. V, §§ 36-1—36-4. Inasmuch as such designations already existed in the Code, the new provisions have been redesignated, at the discretion of the editor, as Art. VI, §§ 36-141—36-144. 
 
Sec. 36-141. - Effective date; purpose; exemption. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 2017, a mandatory road maintenance fee as established in the annual City Operating Budget Ordinance on each motorized vehicle licensed in the city is to be included on motor vehicle tax notices with the proceeds going into a separate fund for accounting purposes specifically to be used for maintenance and improvements of the city road system, to include road signs and correction of drainage problems impacting the city road system. 
(b)  Motor vehicles registered with the state as antique cars are exempt from payment of the road maintenance fee. 
(c)  A wartime disabled veteran who is entitled to compensation for the loss, or loss of use of one or both legs or arms, or the permanent impairment of vision in both eyes to a degree as to constitute virtual blindness and is also entitled to a special monthly statutory award by reason thereof or any South Carolina veteran classified as totally and permanently disabled due to service-connected disabilities as determined from medical records on file with the veterans administration certifying the disability may present such documentation and certification to the city finance department for review. Upon review and approval by the city finance department, the road maintenance fee then in effect as established by the most recent city operating budget, shall be waived on not more than two vehicles qualified for the exemption from registration fees as defined in section 56-3-1110 of the South Carolina Code of Laws. A veteran who is issued an exemption from the road maintenance fee under the provisions of this section must provide a new certification as prescribed by this subsection at the time a new license plate is issued. A surviving spouse of such a veteran is also eligible to obtain such plate so long as the surviving spouse does not remarry. When a new license plate is issued to a surviving spouse, the spouse must certify on a form prescribed by the department that the spouse has not remarried. 
(Ord. No. 06202016 , § 1(Exh. A), 6-20-2016)  
Sec. 36-142. - Penalty for nonpayment. 
In the event an individual does not pay the assessed road user fee and operates his vehicle on any city road, the individual shall pay a fine of up to $200.00 and/or serve a sentence of 30 days in jail, which offense shall be tried in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 06202016 , § 1(Exh. A), 6-20-2016)  
Sec. 36-143. - Road and drainage improvement projects. 
(a)  General provisions. Roads in the city road system and drainage projects impacting city roads may qualify for improvement under this program. Roads and drainage projects for consideration for inclusion in the project list may be nominated by members of city council, city staff, other governmental units and/or citizens of the city. 
(b)  Roads. 
(1)  Nominated roads must adhere to the following criteria to qualify for consideration: 
a.  The road must be a public road maintained by the city. 
b.  The road must be connected to an existing state or city maintained road. 
c.  The city must possess right-of-way easements from all property owners bordering the nominated road. 
(2)  Upon receipt of roads nominated for improvement, the director of public works and engineering shall complete an evaluation and prioritized ranking of nominated roads according to a procedure approved by the council. This listing shall be reviewed by the city manager and submitted annually to the council for approval and appropriations of required funding. 
(c)  Drainage projects. 
(1)  Nominated drainage project must adhere to the following criteria to qualify for consideration: 
a.  The project must arise from or be related to a drainage problem associated with a city road or significantly impact upon the general welfare of citizens. 
b.  The city must be able to obtain drainage easements from all property owners bordering the drainage project. 
(2)  Upon receipt of drainage projects nominated for project work, the director of public works and engineering shall complete an evaluation and prioritized ranking of nominated drainage projects according to a procedure approved by the council. This listing shall be reviewed by the city manager and submitted annually to the council for approval and appropriation of required funding. 
(Ord. No. 06202016 , § 1(Exh. A), 6-20-2016) 
Editor's note— The city road and drainage procedures and project evaluation and ranking list referenced in this section are not set out herein. Such provisions shall be prepared as part of the annual city operating budget by the director of public works and engineering and shall be on file and available for public inspection in the office of the director of public works and engineering.  
Sec. 36-144. - Annual review. 
An annual review will be made by the city council during a month selected by council. This review will include the following items: 
(1)  An estimate of the total funds available for road and drainage projects during the coming year. 
(2)  A prioritized listing of recommended road and drainage projects with estimated costs and recommendations from city council following a review of those projects. Council shall approve from the recommended list, subject to the availability of funds, the city road and drainage project list to be completed during the next fiscal year. The approved list shall include an additional number of roads and drainage projects totaling ten percent of the estimated available funds in the event higher priority selections cannot be accomplished. 
(Ord. No. 06202016 , § 1(Exh. A), 6-20-2016)  
Chapter 38 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 38-1. - Council as investigating board for tax matters. 
The city council shall constitute a board for investigating all matters relating to the assessment and listing of property for taxation or for the relief of taxpayers, and it shall be the duty of the city council to see that no property in the city escapes proper assessment and taxation. In case it shall be discovered by the city council that there is real or personal property within the city which has not been returned, assessed or listed for taxation, or is listed on the county auditor's books as being outside of the city, or is improperly assessed, or is listed in the name of the wrong person or is a double entry, or is listed through error as being in the city, or in case any other irregularity appears or exists, it shall be the duty of the city council to forthwith report, or cause to be reported, the error or irregularity to the county auditor, or other county or state officials, to the end that no property properly liable for city taxes shall escape taxation by the city, or its proper assessment or listing, or shall be improperly taxed. 
(Code 1980, § 21-1)  
Sec. 38-2. - Annual levy. 
The city council shall impose, by ordinance, an annual tax at such rate, in its discretion, as will yield an amount necessary for the general purposes of the city, not exceeding the limit permitted by law. Such tax shall be levied by the city council on the property within the corporate limits as assessed for taxation for county and state purposes as provided in this chapter. Such tax rate shall remain the same from year to year unless changed by ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 21-2)  
Sec. 38-3. - Use of proceeds of annual levy. 
The proceeds of the annual property tax levy, together with other income of the city, shall be used for general municipal purposes, to pay all current indebtedness and to pay the principal and interest on outstanding bonds or coupons of the city which may become due and payable during the fiscal year. 
(Code 1980, § 21-3) 
State Law reference— Limitation on use of proceeds of tax levied for specific purpose, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-21-130.  
Sec. 38-4. - Basis of property value; amount of assessment. 
The basis of value for taxation of real estate, personal property, stock in trade or other taxable property within the city shall be taken from the books of the auditor of the county and such assessment shall be the same as levied by the county auditor in any particular calendar year. 
(Code 1980, § 21-4)  
Sec. 38-5. - Assessed valuation to be entered on tax books; alterations as directed by county auditor. 
The city treasurer shall enter the assessed valuation, fixed as provided in section 38-4, upon his tax books and thereafter shall make only such alterations on his books as may be directed by a supplemental tax return issued by the county auditor. 
(Code 1980, § 21-5)  
Sec. 38-6. - Duty of treasurer to collect taxes. 
All taxes for the year shall be collected by the city treasurer. 
(Code 1980, § 21-6)  
Sec. 38-7. - Appointment, bond and general duties of tax collector. 
(a)  The city manager shall appoint a tax collector whose duty it shall be to check places of business in the city with reference to the payment of license taxes and to collect all delinquent taxes for which executions have been delivered to him by the city treasurer. Before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office, the tax collector shall enter into a bond payable to the city, in such amount as shall be fixed or approved by the council, and in a bonding company duly authorized and licensed to do business within the state, for the faithful performance of his duties. The city shall pay the premium of such bond. 
(b)  The tax collector shall render daily, to the city treasurer, a complete account of all moneys collected during the preceding day and shall at that time turn over all such moneys to the treasurer. 
(Code 1980, § 21-7)  
Sec. 38-8. - Special real property tax assessments for rehabilitated historic properties. 
A special tax assessment is created for eligible rehabilitated historic properties for ten years equal to the appraised value of the property at the time of preliminary certification. Where there is a conflict between provisions of this section and the enabling state code, the more restrictive provision shall control. 
(1)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to: 
a.  Encourage the restoration of historic properties; 
b.  Promote community development and redevelopment; 
c.  Encourage sound community planning; and 
d.  Promote the general health, safety, and welfare of the community. 
(2)  Eligible properties. 
a.  Certification. In order to be eligible for the special tax assessment, historic properties must receive preliminary and final certification. 
1.  To receive preliminary certification a property must meet the following conditions: 
(i)  The property has received historic designation. 
(ii)  The proposed rehabilitation work receives approval from the design review board (DRB). 
(iii)  Be a project that commenced by or after August 17, 2004 to the date of the adoption of this section and work was permitted to have begun prior to receiving preliminary certification; or 
(iv)  Be a project that commences on or after the date of the adoption of this section. Preliminary certification must be received prior to beginning work. 
2.  To receive final certification, a property must have met the following conditions: 
(i)  The property has received preliminary certification. 
(ii)  The minimum expenditures for rehabilitation were incurred and paid. 
(iii)  The completed rehabilitation receives approval from the DRB as being consistent with the plans approved by DRB as part of preliminary certification. 
b.  Historic designation. As used in this section, "historic designation" means the property maintains one or more of the following: 
1.  The property is listed on the National Register of Historic Places either individually or as a contributing property in a district. 
2.  The property is at least 50 years old and is an individual landmark or a contributing property in a local district as designated by city council and listed as so designated in the city Code. 
(3)  Eligible rehabilitation. 
a.  Standards for rehabilitation work. To be eligible for the special tax assessment, historic rehabilitations must be appropriate for the historic building and the historic district in which it is located. This is achieved through adherence to the following standards: 
1.  The historic character of a property shall be retained and preserved; the removal of historic materials or alterations of features that characterize each property shall be avoided. 
2.  Each property shall be recognized as a physical record of its time, place and use; changes that create a false sense of historical development shall not be undertaken. 
3.  Most properties change over time; those changes that have acquired historic significance in their own right shall be retained and preserved. 
4.  Distinctive features, finishes, and construction techniques or examples of craftsmanship that characterize a property should be preserved. 
5.  Deteriorated historic features shall be repaired rather than replaced; where the severity of deterioration requires replacement of a distinctive feature, the new should match the old in design, color, texture, and other visual qualities and, where possible, materials; replacement of missing features shall be substantiated by documentary, physical, or pictorial evidence. 
6.  Chemical or physical treatments, such as sandblasting, that cause damage to historic materials shall not be used; the surface cleaning of structures, if appropriate, shall be undertaken using the gentlest means possible. 
7.  New additions, exterior alterations, or related new construction shall not destroy historic materials that characterize the property; the new work shall be differentiated from the old and shall be compatible with the massing, size, scale, and architectural features to protect the historic integrity of the historic property and its environment. 
8.  New additions and adjacent or related new construction shall be undertaken in such a manner that if removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the historic property and its environment would be unimpaired. 
b.  Work to be reviewed for preliminary and final certification. The following work will be reviewed according to the standards set forth above: 
1.  Repairs to the exterior of the designated building. 
2.  Alterations to the exterior of the designated building. 
3.  New construction on the property on which the building is located. 
4.  Any remaining work, including interior work, where the expenditures for such work are being used to satisfy the minimum expenditures for rehabilitation. 
c.  Minimum expenditures for rehabilitation means the owner or the owner's estate rehabilitates the building, with expenditures for rehabilitation exceeding 20 percent of the fair market value of the building. Fair market value means the appraised value as certified to the DRB by a real estate appraiser licensed by the state, the sales price as delineated in a bona fide contract of sale within 12 months of the time it is submitted, or the most recent appraised value published by the county tax assessor. 
d.  Expenditures for rehabilitation means the actual cost of rehabilitation relating to one or more of the following: 
1.  Improvements located on or within the historic building as designated. 
2.  Improvements outside of but directly attached to the historic building which make possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions and features of the building(s) that are significant to its historic, architectural, and cultural values. Costs associated with new structures, or the addition of rentable/habitable floor space not attributed to efficient contemporary use of space within an existing historic structure shall not be included in the calculation of eligible costs. 
3.  Architectural and engineering services attributable to the design of the improvements. 
4.  Costs necessary to maintain the historic character or integrity of the building. 
e.  Scope. The special tax assessment may apply to the following: 
1.  Structure(s) rehabilitated. 
2.  Real property on which the building is located. 
f.  Time limits. To be eligible for the special tax assessment, rehabilitation must be completed within two years of the preliminary certification date. If the project is not complete after two years, but the minimum expenditures for rehabilitation have been incurred, the property continues to receive the special assessment until the project is completed or until the end of the special assessment period, whichever shall first occur. 
(4)  Process. 
a.  Fee required. There is a fee of $150.00 required for final certification for each application for review of rehabilitation work of single-family and/or duplex structures and $300.00 for all other structures. Fees are payable to the city, and final certification will not be given without payment of this fee. 
b.  Plan required. Owners of property seeking to receive the special tax assessment must submit an application, provided by the planning department, with all supporting documentation and application fee in order to be considered for preliminary certification. This should be submitted before work is begun. However, work completed within the preceding 12 months may be considered at the discretion of the board. 
c.  Preliminary certification. Upon receipt of the completed application, the proposal shall be placed on the next available agenda of the DRB to determine if the project is consistent with the standards for rehabilitation in subsection 38-8(3)a. above. After the DRB makes its determination, the owner shall be notified in writing. Upon receipt of this determination the owner may: 
1.  If the application is approved, begin rehabilitation; 
2.  If the application is not approved, he may revise such application in accordance with comments provided by the DRB; 
d.  Substantive changes. Once preliminary certification is granted to an application, substantive changes must be approved by the DRB. Unapproved substantive changes are conducted at the risk of the property owner and may disqualify the project from eligibility. Additional expenditures will not qualify the project for an extension on the special assessment. 
e.  Final certification. Upon completion of the project, the project must receive final certification in order to be eligible for the special assessment. The DRB will inspect completed projects to determine if the work is consistent with the approval granted by the DRB pursuant to section 38-8. Final certification will be granted when the completed work meets the standards and verification is made that expenditures have been made in accordance with subsection 38-8(3)c and d. above. Upon receiving final certification, the property will be assessed for the remainder of the special assessment period on the fair market value of the property at the time the preliminary certification was made or the final certification was made, whichever occurred earlier. 
f.  Additional work. Subsection 1 below shall apply to all properties receiving final certification after (date of city council adoption). Properties receiving final certification before this date shall be subject to subsection 2 below. 
1.  All additional work on the exterior of the property shall be subject to design review via the established certificate of appropriateness process and approval matrix. Furthermore, at the time of final certification, the design review board may establish a "preservation zone" to identify critical architectural and historically significant elements that should be preserved. This preservation zone may include interior rooms and elements, as well as exterior elements that would not otherwise be subject to design review through the certificate of appropriateness process. For the remainder of the special assessment period after final certification, any additional work (repair, replacement, modification) to the preservation zone elements identified shall be subject to review by the design review board through the certificate of appropriateness process to ensure that all work is consistent with relevant design and preservation guidelines as adopted per section 5.2.3.J of the zoning ordinance, and the standards for rehabilitation work provided in this section. If the additional work is found to be inconsistent with these guidelines, the property owner may withdraw his request and cancel or revise the proposed additional work. The design review board may designate review and approval authority to the planning director and design review board chair. 
2.  Current owners of participating properties receiving final certification before September 23, 2019 shall, upon adoption of this ordinance by city council, be given by staff the following implementation options applicable for the remainder of their assessment period: 
(i)  For the remainder of the special assessment period after final certification, the property owner shall notify the DRB of any additional work, other than ordinary maintenance. The DRB will review the work at a regularly scheduled hearing and determine whether the overall project is consistent with the standards for rehabilitation. If the additional work is found to be inconsistent the property owner may withdraw his request and cancel or revise the proposed additional work. 
(ii)  Participating properties shall be subject to the policy established in subsection 1 after a site visit and hearing by the board to establish a "preservation zone" for the property. 
g.  Decertification. When the property has received final certification and has been assessed as rehabilitated historic property, it remains so certified and must be granted the special assessment until the property becomes disqualified by any one of the following: 
1.  Written notice from the owner to the DRB and the auditor requesting removal of the preferential assessment; 
2.  Removal of the historic designation by the city council; or 
3.  Rescission of the approval of rehabilitation by the DRB because of alterations or renovation by the owner or the owner's estate which causes the property to no longer possess the qualities and features which made it eligible for final certification. 
Notification of any change affecting eligibility must be given immediately to the county assessor, auditor, and treasurer. Under no circumstances shall the sale or transfer of ownership of real property certified and assessed in accordance with this section and any ordinance in effect at the time disqualify the property from receiving the special property tax assessment under this section. This provision shall be applicable and given full force and effect to any special property tax assessment granted prior to the effective date of this paragraph notwithstanding any ordinance in effect from time to time to the contrary. 
h.  Notification. The city shall, upon final certification of a property, notify the county assessor, auditor and treasurer that such property has been duly certified and is eligible for the special tax assessment. 
i.  Date effective. If an application for preliminary or final certification is filed by May 1 or the preliminary or final certification is approved by August 1, the special assessment authorized herein is effective for that year. Otherwise, it is effective beginning with the following year. 
The special assessment only begins in the current or future tax years as provided for in this section. In no instance may the special assessment be applied retroactively. 
j.  Application. Once the DRB has granted the special property tax assessments authorized herein, the owner of the property shall make application to the county auditor and other appropriate county offices at the directive of county officials for the special assessment provided for herein. 
(Code 1980, § 21-22; Ord. No. 11132000D, § 1, 11-13-2000; Ord. No. 04242017 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-24-2017; Ord. No. 04092018A , § 1(Exh. A), 4-9-2018; Ord. No. 10142019C , § 1(Exh. A), 10-14-2019) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04242017 , § 1(Exh. A), adopted April 24, 2017, amended § 38-8 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Special real property tax assessments for rehabilitated historic properties" to "Special tax assessment created," as set out herein.  
Sec. 38-9. - Special real property tax assessments for qualifying low and moderate income rental properties. 
(a)  Real property within the city which meets the requirements in this section for low or moderate income rental property shall be assessed for property tax purposes as follows: An initial assessment for two years equal to six percent of the appraised value of the property at the time the certification was made, and thereafter an assessment for eight years equal to the greater of 40 percent of six percent of the appraised value of the property after rehabilitation or the original assessment of the uncertified property. 
(b)  The city council hereby designates the city community development committee to perform all functions and duties for the special property tax assessment program for low and moderate income rental property expressly delegated to it by the provisions of this section. 
(c)  To be eligible for the special tax assessment provided by this section, real property must be certified by the community development committee as meeting the requirements set forth in S.C. Code 1976, §§ 4-9-195(C) and 5-21-140, this section, and any successor provisions thereto. To apply for the special tax assessment, an owner of real property must submit an application to the community development committee on such forms as it shall promulgate for that purpose and shall pay such application fee as the community development committee shall establish. The application fee shall be no higher in amount than the actual estimated cost to the city for reviewing such applications. 
(d)  A real property may be disqualified from receiving the special tax assessment provided by this section for any of the reasons set forth in S.C. Code 1976, § 4-9-195(E). 
(e)  Any real property owner aggrieved by a decision of the community development committee with respect to certifying or disqualifying a real property from the special tax assessment provided by this section may request a review of the decision thereon by submitting a written request therefor to the community development committee. Upon receipt of the request, the community development committee shall schedule a hearing thereon and notify the property owner in writing of the date, time and location of the hearing. At such hearing, the property owner may present information concerning whether the community development committee's decision should be reversed or otherwise modified. The community development committee shall advise the property owner in writing of its decision on the review within ten days of the hearing thereon. Any real property owner aggrieved by a final decision of the community development committee with respect to certifying or disqualifying a real property may appeal that decision to city council by filing a letter with the city manager setting forth the grounds of appeal within ten days of the date of the community development committee's decision. Council shall consider that appeal at the next available meeting of council based upon the record of the hearing before the community development committee. Council may affirm, reverse, or otherwise modify the final decision of the community development committee. 
(f)  The community development committee or its designee shall notify the appropriate city and county taxing and assessing authorities of the certification or disqualification of any properties for special tax assessment pursuant to this section. To be eligible for special tax assessment for any year, a property must be certified for such special tax treatment before April 1 of that year. The owner shall annually make an application to the city treasurer and county auditor for special tax assessment. 
(g)  The special tax assessment program authorized by this section shall be administered in conformity with the provisions of this section, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 4-9-195 and 5-21-140, and any successor provisions thereto, and in the event of a conflict between the provisions of this section and the provisions of those state laws, the latter provisions shall control. 
(Code 1980, § 21-23)  
Sec. 38-10. - Local accommodations tax. 
(a)  Authority. This tax is enacted pursuant to the S.C. Code 1976, as amended, §§ 6-1-500—6-1-570, which provides in part that a local governing body may impose, by ordinance, a local accommodations tax, not to exceed three percent. 
(b)  Purpose and intent. This local accommodations tax is enacted to preserve the general health, safety, and welfare of the general public within the city, and to specifically improve and increase tourism-related activities and facilities and to enhance the quality of life in the city for its citizens and its visitors. The revenue generated by the local accommodations tax must be used exclusively for the following purposes: (1) tourism-related buildings, including, but not limited to, civic centers, coliseums, and aquariums; (2) cultural, recreational, or historic facilities; (3) highways, roads, streets, and bridges providing access to tourist destinations; (4) advertisements and promotions related to tourism development; or (5) water and sewer infrastructure to serve tourism-related demand. 
(c)  Imposition of local accommodations tax. A uniform tax equal to three percent is hereby imposed on the gross proceeds derived from the rental or charges for accommodations furnished to transients as provided in S.C. Code 1976, § 12-36-920(A) and is imposed on every person engaged in the business of furnishing accommodations to transients for consideration within the city. Included are gross proceeds derived from the rental or charges for any rooms, campground spaces, lodgings, or sleeping accommodations furnished to transients by any hotel, inn, tourist court, tourist camp, motel, campground, residence, or any place in which rooms, lodgings, or sleeping accommodations are furnished to transients for a consideration. This tax does not apply where the facilities consist of less than six sleeping rooms, contained on the same premises, which is used as the individual's place of abode. The gross proceeds derived from the lease or rental of sleeping accommodations supplied by the same person for a period of ninety continuous days are not considered proceeds from transients. This tax does not apply to additional guest charges as defined in S.C. Code 1976, § 12-36-920(B) as amended. 
(d)  Accounting for local accommodations tax. All proceeds derived from the local accommodations tax must be kept in a separate fund segregated from the city general fund. This fund shall be known as the "capital development fund." All interest generated by the local accommodations tax fund must be credited to the capital development fund. 
(e)  Payment of local accommodations tax. Payment of the local accommodations tax shall be the responsibility of the consumer of the services described in subsection (c). This tax shall be paid at the time of the delivery of the services or items to which the tax applies and shall be collected by the provider or seller of the service(s), or item(s). 
(f)  Remittance to the city. The taxes collected by the seller or provider of the services or items as required in subsection (e) shall be remitted to the city business license administrator as set forth herein along with such return or form as may be established by the business license administrator for such purpose. When the estimated amount of average tax is more than $50.00 per month, that seller or provider shall remit the amount due on a monthly basis. When the estimated amount of average tax is $25.00 to $50.00 per month, that seller or provider shall remit on a quarterly basis. When the estimated amount is less than $25.00 per month, that seller or provider shall remit on an annual basis. 
(g)  Payment due dates. Taxes and required reports shall be submitted to the business license administrator by the 20 th day of the month following the due date of the tax payment and shall cover sales of the previous month, quarter, and/or year depending on the seller's monthly average tax. Any taxes not timely remitted shall be subject to a penalty of five percent of the unpaid tax for each month or portion thereof after the due date until paid. The failure to collect from patrons the tax imposed by this section shall not relieve any establishment subject to this section from making the required remittance. 
(h)  Penalties for violations. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be subject to punishment under section 1-13 of this Code upon conviction. Each day of violation shall be considered a separate offense. Punishment for violation shall not relieve the offender of liability for delinquent taxes, penalties, and costs provided for herein. 
(i)  Expenditure of proceeds. The expenditure of the proceeds generated by this tax shall be approved by city council during its annual budget consideration process. 
(Code 1980, § 21-24; Ord. No. 02122001, § 1, 2-12-2001)  
Sec. 38-11. - Local hospitality tax. 
(a)  Authority. This tax is enacted pursuant to the S.C. Code 1976, as amended, §§ 6-1-700—6-1-770, which provides in part that a local governing body may impose, by ordinance, a local hospitality tax, not to exceed two percent of the charges for food and beverages sold in establishments with the city. 
(b)  Purpose and intent. This local hospitality tax is enacted to preserve the general health, safety, and welfare of the general public within the City of Aiken, South Carolina, and to specifically improve and increase tourism-related activities and facilities and to enhance the quality of life in the city for its citizens and its visitors. The revenue generated by the local accommodations tax must be used exclusively for the following purposes: (1) tourism-related buildings, including, but not limited to, civic centers, coliseums, and aquariums; (2) cultural, recreational, or historic facilities; (3) highways, roads, streets, and bridges providing access to tourist destinations; (4) advertisements and promotions related to tourism development; or (5) water and sewer infrastructure to serve tourism-related demand. Further, an amount not to exceed 50 percent of the revenue in the preceding fiscal year of the local hospitality tax may be used for the operation and maintenance of items (1) through (5) including police, fire protection, emergency medical services, and emergency-preparedness operations directly attendant to those facilities. City council will approve the expenditure of these funds as a part of its annual budget process. 
(c)  Imposition of local hospitality tax. A uniform tax equal to one percent is hereby imposed on the gross proceeds derived from the sale of prepared meals and beverages sold in establishments or sales of prepared meals and beverages sold in establishments licensed for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages, beer or wine, and is imposed on every person engaged in the business of furnishing food and beverage services, whether dine in or take out, within the city. In addition, the local hospitality tax shall be imposed on all food and beverages prepared or modified by convenience stores, fast food service outlets, or grocery stores within the city. 
(d)  Accounting for local hospitality tax. All proceeds derived from the local hospitality tax must be kept in a separate fund segregated from the city general fund. This fund shall be known as the "Hospitality Fund (014)." 
(e)  Payment of local hospitality tax. Payment of the local hospitality tax shall be the responsibility of the consumer of the services described in section 38-11(c). This tax shall be paid at the time of the delivery of the services or items to which the tax applies and shall be collected by the provider or seller of the service(s), or item(s). 
(f)  Remittance to the City of Aiken. The taxes collected by the seller or provider of the services or items as required in section 38-11(e) shall be remitted to the city business license administrator as set forth herein along with such return or form as may be established by the city business license administrator for such purpose. When the estimated amount of average tax is more than $50.00 per month, that seller or provider shall remit the amount due on a monthly basis. When the estimated amount of average tax is $25.00 to $50.00 per month, that seller or provider shall remit on a quarterly basis. When the estimated amount is less than $25.00 per month, that seller or provider shall remit on an annual basis. 
(g)  Payment due dates. Taxes and required reports shall be submitted to the city business license administrator by the 20th day of the month following the due date of the tax payment and shall cover sales of the previous month, quarter, and/ or year depending on the seller's monthly average tax. Any taxes not timely remitted shall be subject to a penalty of five percent of the unpaid tax for each month or portion thereof after the due date until paid. The failure to collect from patrons the tax imposed by this section shall not relieve any establishment subject to this section from making the required remittance. 
(h)  Penalties for violations. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be subject to punishment under section 1-13 of this Code upon conviction. Each day of violation shall be considered a separate offense. Punishment for violation shall not relieve the offender of liability for delinquent taxes, penalties, and costs provided for herein. 
(i)  Expenditure of proceeds. As part of the annual budget process, the city manager shall report to city council regarding the annual revenue received from this tax and the annual expenditures. 
(Ord. No. 05112015 , § 1(Exh. A), 5-11-2015) 
Editor's note— Prior to the reenactment of § 38-11 by Ord. No. 05112015 , § 1(Exh. A), adopted May 11, 2015, said section was repealed by Ord. No. 02122001, § 1, adopted Feb. 12, 2001. The former § 38-11 pertained to the local hospitality tax and derived from Code 1980, § 21-25.  
Secs. 38-12—38-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DELINQUENT TAXES 
 
Sec. 38-31. - Officers invested with powers and duties to collect delinquent taxes. 
The director of public safety, the city finance director, the revenue administrator/tax collector, or their designee, are hereby invested with all the rights, powers and privileges, and they are, as needed, hereby charged with all the duties of the officers designated for the enforcement and collection of delinquent taxes by the Constitution and laws of the state and all amendments thereto. 
(Code 1980, § 21-8; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-32. - Due date; penalty for late payments; when unpaid taxes go into execution. 
(a)  All taxes for the year shall normally be due and payable during the month of October without discourse unless otherwise directed by the city finance director and the city manager for a particular year, as set forth in subsection (b) below. In years where the city's tax books open [i.e. Tax files are loaded into the city tax system, reviewed and balanced and processing of payments is able to begin] before September 15, the following penalties will be applicable: Taxes paid during the month of November shall be subject to a penalty of five percent for late payment; taxes paid during the month of December shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent for late payment; and taxes not paid until on or after January 1 will be subject to a penalty of 15 percent for late payment. On February 15 of each year, all unpaid taxes shall go into execution, subject to a cost of 2½ percent additional charge. 
(b)  In years where the city's tax books open after September 15 [ie. Tax files are loaded into the city tax system, reviewed and balanced and processing of payments is able to begin], the city finance director and the city manager shall establish the tax book open date for the city taxes whereby city residents shall have a minimum of 45 days from the date of the tax book open date to pay their city taxes without penalty. Thereafter, the following penalties shall be applicable: (1) Taxes paid more than 45 days from the date of the tax book open date and less than 75 days late shall be subject to a penalty of five percent for late payment; taxes paid more than 75 days from the date of the tax book open date and less than 105 days late shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent for late payment; and taxes paid more than 105 days from the date of the tax book open date will be subject to a penalty of 15 percent for late payment. If the city taxes are not paid within 135 days from the date of the tax book open date, all unpaid taxes shall go into execution, subject to a cost of 2½ percent additional charge. 
(Code 1980, § 21-9; Ord. No. 10282002, § 1, 10-28-2002)  
Sec. 38-33. - Issuance and contents and form of executions against defaulting taxpayers. 
(a)  Immediately after May 1 of each year, the city finance department director, or a designee, shall issue, in the name of the city, an execution against any defaulting taxpayer. Such warrant or execution shall be signed by the city finance department director, or a designee, directed to the revenue administrator/tax collector, or a designee, requiring and commanding levy of the taxes or assessments by distress and sale of so much of the defaulting taxpayer's estate, real, personal, or both, as may be sufficient to satisfy the taxes or assessments due by such defaulter, and specifying the aggregate amount of all taxes or assessments due the city. 
(b)  Tax executions shall be in substantially the same form as that provided in S.C. Code Annotated §§ 12-51-40 et seq. (and as amended) for the collection of delinquent taxes owed to the state or county. 
(Code 1980, § 21-10; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-34. - Tax liens. 
(a)  The taxes, assessments, license taxes and penalties legally assessed by the city shall constitute a lien on the property upon which the taxes, assessments, license taxes, and penalties were made until paid in full, which lien shall be paramount to all other liens, except liens for county and state taxes. 
(b)  As soon as any property within the city is listed with the auditor of the county for taxation, such tax assessment shall immediately become a lien on such property. 
(Code 1980, § 21-13) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), adopted Feb. 13, 2006, deleted § 38-34 and renumbered former § 38-36 as § 38-34 as set out herein. Former § 38-34 pertained to execution lists and derived from Code 1980, § 21-11.  
Sec. 38-35. - Seizure and sale of property for delinquent taxes generally. 
(a)  Under and by virtue of the execution provided for in this chapter, the revenue administrator/tax collector shall seize, take exclusive possession of, and sell so much of the defaulting taxpayer's estate, real, personal, or both, as may be necessary to raise the sums of money named, and the charges thereon, in the manner provided for in S.C. Code Annotated §§ 12-51-40 et seq. (and as amended). 
(b)  All real property returned delinquent by the city finance department director, or a designee, upon which the taxes shall not be paid by distress or sale of personal property or otherwise, shall be seized and sold as provided by law. The distress and sale of personal property shall not be a condition precedent to seizure and sale of any real property under this article. 
(c)  Whenever any real estate is levied upon for taxes by the revenue administrator/tax collector, or a designee, it shall be a duty, before proceeding to advertise the real estate for sale, to give 20 days' written notice of such levy to the owner of each mortgage contained on the list filed at the city in the manner provided for under S.C. Code Annotated §§ 12-49-220 et seq. (and as amended) and the revenue administrator/tax collector shall follow the procedure set forth in those sections. 
(Code 1980, § 21-14; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), adopted Feb. 13, 2006, deleted § 38-35 and renumbered former § 38-37 as § 38-35 as set out herein. Former § 38-35 pertained to the return of uncollectible executions and derived from Code 1980, § 21-12.  
Sec. 38-36. - Payment by purchase at tax sale; execution and form of title. 
(a)  Purchasers at any tax sale shall pay the amount bid to the revenue administrator/tax collector, or a designee, immediately after the closing of the sale and they shall give to such purchaser a receipt for the purchase money. Title deeds shall not be made until the expiration of at least 12 months from the date of such sale and then only if the property sold is not redeemed as provided in S.C. Code §§ 12-51-40 et seq. (and as amended). 
(b)  The form of the title to real estate given to purchasers at a tax sale shall be substantially the same form as the title deed given to purchasers at tax sales for state or county taxes. 
(Code 1980, § 21-15; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-37. - Purchase of land by city at tax sale. 
In case there is no bid at a tax sale equal in amount to the delinquent taxes, together with all penalties, costs, or charges, named in the execution against the property, the city shall buy the land for the city, as the actual purchaser, for the amount of such taxes, penalties, costs, and charges. The revenue administrator/tax collector shall execute title to the city in the same manner as to any other purchaser, and he shall put the city, or its authorized officers or agents, in possession of the premise s as provided by law. The land so sold to the city shall be treated as an asset of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 21-16; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-38. - Settlement with city after tax sale. 
The revenue administrator/tax collector shall make immediate settlement with the city and pay over all funds collected from the sale of property for taxes due to the city and take the receipt therefor.
