(Code 1980, § 21-17; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-39. - Tax deeds as evidence of title, etc. 
All deeds of conveyance made by the revenue administrator/tax collector under the authority of this chapter, whether executed to the city or to any other person, shall be held and taken as prima facie evidence of a good title in the holder, that all proceedings have been legally conducted, and that all requirements of law have been met. 
(Code 1980, § 21-18; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-40. - Collection of taxes on property about to be moved from city. 
In case any property within the city listed with the county auditor for taxation is about to be taken or removed from the jurisdiction of the city before taxes are due and payable for any year, the revenue administrator/tax collector shall immediately issue an execution on the property and shall proceed to collect the taxes due on the property. 
(Code 1980, § 21-19; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-41. - Ownership or operation of vehicles on which personal property taxes are delinquent. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any resident of the city to own or operate within the corporate limits of the city, or upon the public streets or ways of the city, any motor vehicle on which personal property taxes due to the city are delinquent and unpaid. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, personal property taxes assessed against any motor vehicle owned by any resident of the city shall be delinquent when the personal property taxes assessed against such motor vehicle are past due and unpaid and have gone into execution. 
(Code 1980, § 21-20; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Sec. 38-42. - Location of tax sales. 
All tax sales under the provisions of this chapter must be conducted at such location as shall be set by the city revenue administrator/tax collector, in consultation with the finance department director, as authorized by South Carolina law; provided, however, that the location must be a place duly advertised prior to the date of this tax sale. 
(Code 1980, § 21-21; Ord. No. 02132006D, § 1 (Exh. A), 2-13-2006)  
Chapter 40 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36; utilities, ch. 44. 
State Law reference— Authority to grant franchises for the use of public streets, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-30; requirement to grant, renew or extend franchises by ordinance, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-260(4); Cable System Act, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-12-10 et seq.; franchising cable television systems by municipalities, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-12-30. 
 
Sec. 40-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known as the cable communications ordinance. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-1)  
Sec. 40-2. - Intent and authority. 
This chapter is adopted pursuant to the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 and the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 (codified at 47 USC, 521—559); the applicable regulations of the Federal Communications Commission; S.C. Code 1976, §§ 58-12-10—58-12-130; S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-30; and other applicable laws of the United States and the state to promote public convenience, safety, health and welfare; protect consumers; protect and regulate public rights-of-way and property; and further the public interest. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-2)  
Sec. 40-3. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words and derivations shall have the meaning given herein, unless the context clearly indicates that another meaning is intended. 
Agency means the city manager. 
Auxiliary services means any communications service in addition to regular subscriber services, including, but not limited to, services for which a per-program or per-channel charge is made, pay TV, burglar alarm services, data or other electronic transmission services, facsimile reproduction services, meter reading services, interactive two-way services, and any other service utilizing any facility or equipment of a cable communications system operating pursuant to a franchise under this chapter. 
Cable communications system, cable system, cable television system or CATV system mean any facility that in whole or in part receives, directly or indirectly, over the air, and amplifies or otherwise modifies the signals of television or radio stations and distributes such signals by wire or cable to subscribing members of the public who pay for such services. This also includes any such system's auxiliary services. However, this does not include any portion of any system the primary business of which is to provide telephonic, telegraphic or similar services, except that such system shall be considered a cable system to the extent that such faculty is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers. 
Channel means a band of frequencies six megahertz wide in the electromagnetic spectrum capable of carrying either one audio visual television signal and few nonvideo signals or a large number of nonvideo signals. 
Federal Communications Commission or FCC mean the present federal agency of that name as constituted by the Communications Act of 1934, or any successor agency created by federal laws. 
Franchise means a nonexclusive authorization granted by the franchise authority which permits the construction, operation and maintenance of a cable communications system within the franchise area pursuant to this chapter. 
Franchise area means that portion of the franchise entity for which a franchise is granted under the authority of this chapter. The franchise area may or may not be coterminous with the franchise entity. 
Franchise authority means the city council. 
Franchise entity means all areas within the corporate limits of the city, including any area henceforth added thereto during the terms of any franchise granted hereunder, or the city, a municipal corporation and political subdivision of the state, whichever is applicable to the context in which the term is used. 
Grantee means a holder of a franchise issued by the franchise entity pursuant to this chapter. 
Gross revenues means all cash, credits, compensation, property of any kind or nature, or other consideration directly or indirectly received by a grantee, its affiliates, subsidiaries, parents, and any other person or entity in which the grantee has a financial interest or which has a financial interest in the grantee, including but not limited to: 
(1)  Revenue from all charges for regular subscriber services, premium services, auxiliary services, or other cable services provided to subscribers in the franchise area (including leased access fees), less refunds but including the full amount recovered by any collection agency; 
(2)  Revenue from all charges for programming or the insertion of commercial advertisements upon a cable television system in the franchise area; 
(3)  Revenue from all charges for the leased use of studios or equipment; 
(4)  Revenue from all charges for the sale, installation, connection, and reinstatement of equipment and services for utilization of the cable communications system and the provision of subscriber and other services in the franchise area; 
(5)  The sale, exchange or use or cablecast of any programming developed for community use or institutional users in the franchise area; 
(6)  The value of any goods, services, or other remuneration in nonmonetary form values at retail price levels received by a grantee in consideration for performance by grantee of any advertising, programming or other service in connection with the cable television system; 
(7)  Revenues from any television programming or any other services offered in the franchise area by any means of delivery whatsoever where such programming or services are provided by means of the system or any part thereof; and 
(8)  Revenues from all cable services, cable operations, and cable-related activities within the city, including any and all ancillary and nonsubscriber services, operations or activities related to the cable system. 
The phrase "financial interest" as used in this definition shall include but not be limited to the following, to the extent derived from the operation of the cable system: 
(1)  Any contract in which a grantee or any named owner thereof is to receive a percentage of the gross revenues and/or a percentage of the net or other income of the other party to the transaction by reason of the activities encompassed by such contract; 
(2)  Any debt relationship in which a grantee or any named owner thereof as debtor borrows funds at a rate more advantageous than that generally available to similarly situated entities of similar credit worthiness; 
(3)  Any debt relationship in which a grantee or any named owner thereof as creditor receives a rate of interest exceeding that which would otherwise be paid by a similarly situated debtor of similar credit worthiness; or 
(4)  Any debt relationship which has conversion privileges to a form of equity of the nature described in the preceding subsection. 
Major stockholder means a beneficial owner, directly or indirectly, of ten percent or more of the issues and outstanding voting stock of any corporation. 
Regular subscriber service is that service regularly provided to all subscribers. It includes all broadcast signal carriage and all FCC required access channel carriage, including origination programming. It does not include specialized programming for which a per-program or per-channel charge is made. 
Street means the surface of and space above and below any public street, avenue, highway, boulevard, concourse, driveway, bridge, tunnel, park, parkway, waterway, dock, bulkhead, wharf, pier, alley, right-of-way, public utility easement, or any other public ground or water now or hereafter within or located in the franchise entity. 
Subscriber means any person receiving regular subscriber service. 
Usable activated channels means channels engineered at the headend of the cable television system for the provision of services generally available to subscribers of the cable television system, regardless of whether services actually are provided, including any channel designated for public, educational, or governmental use, but excluding channels whose use for the distribution of signals would not meet the technical and safety standards of FCC rules, 47 CFR, 76.601 et seq. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-3) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 40-4. - Franchise to operate necessary. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commence or engage in the construction, operation or maintenance of a cable communications system without a franchise issued under this chapter. The franchise authority may, by ordinance, award a franchise to construct, operate and maintain a cable communications system within all or any portion of the franchise entity to any person, whether operating under an existing franchise or not, who makes application for authority to furnish a cable communications system which complies with the terms and conditions of this chapter and applicable laws, regulations and ordinances. Provided that no franchise shall be awarded to an applicant if the proposed franchise service area is drawn in such a way as to deny access to cable service to any group of potential residential cable subscribers because of the income of the residents of the local area in which such group resides. Provided further, that this section and chapter shall not be deemed to require the grant of a franchise to any particular person or to prohibit the franchise authority from restricting the number of grantees should it determine such action or restriction would be in the public interest. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this section, and upon conviction therefor, any such person shall be punished as provided by section 1-13. Each day that any such violation continues or is permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-4)  
Sec. 40-5. - Term of franchise; revocation. 
(a)  Any franchise granted by the franchise authority shall be for a term of up to seven years following the date such franchise is accepted by the grantee, and, upon application of the grantee and review of the performance of the grantee in a public proceeding undertaken pursuant to the provisions of section 40-23, the franchise authority may renew the franchise for successive seven-year periods, with such modification of terms as the franchise authority may determine to be necessary to meet the present and future needs and interests of the franchise entity and its citizens. Provided, however, that the franchise authority may grant franchises or franchise renewals exceeding seven years but not exceeding 15 years pursuant to the provisions of section 40-30. 
(b)  The franchise authority may revoke any franchise granted under this chapter in the event the grantee shall refuse or neglect to comply with any material requirement or limitation contained in this chapter or applicable laws, regulations or ordinances. 
(c)  Should the franchise authority or agency determine that the grantee of a franchise issued under this chapter is in violation of any requirement or limitation of either this chapter or the franchise issued thereunder, it shall so notify the grantee, and the grantee shall, within 30 days, bring the franchise system into compliance, reporting any corrective action taken to the franchise authority in writing. 
(d)  If the franchise authority or agency finds that compliance has not been achieved within 30 days of the notice of violation and that no substantial good faith progress is being made toward compliance, it may schedule a public hearing to determine whether the franchise should be revoked. The grantee and the public shall be given at least 30 days notice of such a hearing, and all interested persons shall be heard in open hearing. 
(e)  At the conclusion of the public hearing, the franchise authority shall determine whether the franchise should be revoked and shall put forth, in writing, the facts and reasons upon which its decision is based. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-5)  
Sec. 40-6. - Cable television system agency. 
The franchise authority hereby designates and empowers the city manager or his designee to act for it in administrative matters relating to cable communications, cable communications systems, this chapter, and any franchise granted pursuant to this chapter. This is cumulative to the other powers granted to the agency pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-6)  
Sec. 40-7. - Limitations of franchise. 
(a)  A grantee shall, at all times during the term of its franchise, be subject to the lawful exercise of the franchise entity's police power and such reasonable regulations as the franchise authority may subsequently promulgate thereunder. Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit in any way the right of the franchise entity to levy nondiscriminatory charges, assessments fees, or taxes on any activity conducted by a grantee. 
(b)  All privileges prescribed by a franchise shall be subordinate to any prior lawful occupancy of the streets, and the franchise authority reserves the right reasonably to designate where a grantee's facilities are to be placed within the streets. 
(c)  A franchise shall be a privilege which is personal to the original grantee. It shall not be sold, transferred, leased, assigned, or disposed of, in all or in part, either by sale, merger, consolidation, sale of stock, transfer of control or otherwise, without the prior consent of the franchise authority expressed by ordinance, and then only under such reasonable conditions as may be prescribed therein and pursuant to the following: 
(1)  Any such transfer or assignment shall be made only by an instrument in writing, which shall include an acceptance of all terms and conditions of the franchise by the person acquiring the franchise or control thereof, a duly executed copy of which shall be filed with the agency within 30 days after any such proposed transfer or assignment is executed. Any written request for transfer or assignment shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $3,500.00. 
(2)  Consent of the franchise authority shall not be granted until the franchise authority, in its discretion, has examined the legal, financial, technical, character and other qualifications of the person proposing to acquire the franchise or control thereof to construct, operate and maintain a cable communications system in the franchise entity and has afforded all interested persons notice and an opportunity to be heard. The person proposing to acquire the franchise shall promptly provide all information and documents requested by the franchise authority. 
(3)  Consent of the franchise authority shall not be arbitrarily refused provided that the person proposing to acquire the franchise or control thereof possesses the requisite qualifications and agrees, in writing, to comply with all provisions of the franchise, any reasonable conditions prescribed by the franchise authority, and this chapter. 
(4)  The transfer of 20 percent or more of the voting securities of a corporate grantee to a person not presently a stockholder or a group of persons acting in concert, none of whom already own 20 percent or more of the voting stock, singly or collectively, shall be deemed to be a transfer of control subject to this section. 
(5)  A change in the identity of the sole general partner or in the membership of a majority of the general partners of a limited partnership shall be deemed to be a transfer of control subject to this section. 
(6)  No such consent shall be required for a transfer: 
a.  In trust, of system assets by mortgage or by other hypothecation, to secure an indebtedness related to operations under the franchise. 
b.  To a parent or subsidiary of a corporate grantee. 
c.  To a corporation whose stock is held by the same stockholder as grantee. 
d.  Of less than 20 percent of the voting securities of a corporate grantee unless such transfer also results in a transfer of voting control. 
e.  Of stock from one present stockholder to another present stockholder unless such transfer also results in a transfer of voting control. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to in any way impair or affect the right of the franchise entity to acquire the property of the grantee, either by purchase or through the exercise of the franchise entity's power of eminent domain, at a price reflective of its fair market value as an ongoing concern, and nothing in this section shall be construed to constitute a waiver of, or bar to, the exercise of any governmental power of the franchise entity. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-7)  
Sec. 40-8. - Indemnification; defense of litigation; insurance. 
(a)  Grantee shall indemnify and hold harmless the franchise entity, its officers, boards, commission, agents, and employees, against and from, regardless of the merits, any and all claims, demands, causes of actions, actions, suits, proceedings, fines, damages (including, but not limited to, damages to franchise entity property, damages arising out of copyright infringements, and damages arising out of any failure by grantee to secure consents from the owners, authorized distributors, or licensors of programs to be delivered by grantee's cable television system), and costs or liabilities (including costs or liabilities of the franchise entity with respect to its employees) of every kind and nature whatsoever, including, but not limited to, damages for bodily injury or death or damage to person or property; against and from all liability to others; and against and from any loss, cost, or expense resulting or arising out of any of the foregoing, including, but not limited to any attorney fees, accountant fees, expert witnesses or consultant fees, court costs, per diem expense, traveling and transportation expense, or other costs or expense, arising out of or pertaining in any way to the exercise or enjoyment of any franchise under this chapter by any grantee or the granting thereof by the franchise entity. 
(b)  Grantee shall at the sole risk and expense of grantee, upon demand of the franchise entity, made by and through the franchise entity's attorney, appear in and defend any and all suits, actions, or other legal proceedings, whether judicial, quasi-judicial, administrative, legislative, or otherwise, brought or instituted or had by third persons or duly constituted authorities against or affecting the franchise entity, its officers, boards, commissions, agents or employees, and arising out of or pertaining to the exercise or enjoyment of such franchise or the granting thereof by the franchise entity. 
(c)  Grantee shall pay and satisfy and shall cause to be paid and satisfied any judgment, decree, order, directive, fine, or demand rendered, made or issued against grantee, the franchise entity, its officers, boards, commissions, agents, or employees in any of these matters; and such indemnity shall exist and continue without reference to or limitation by the amount of bond, policy of insurance, deposit, undertaking or other assurance required hereunder, or otherwise; provided, that neither grantee, nor the franchise entity shall make or enter into any compromise or settlement of any claim, demand, cause of action, action, suit, or other proceeding asserted against both grantee and the franchise entity or to which grantee and the franchise entity are both parties, without first obtaining the written consent of the other, which written consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(d)  Upon acceptance of the franchise the grantee shall file with the agency and shall thereafter during the entire term of such franchise maintain in full force and effect: 
(1)  Workers' compensation insurance as provided by the laws of the state. 
(2)  Comprehensive liability insurance with limits of not less than: 
a.  For personal injury, bodily injury, or death to any person, $1,000,000.00; 
b.  For personal injury, bodily injury, death or other liability resulting from any one accident or occurrence, $1,000,000.00; and 
c.  For property damage resulting from any one accident, $1,000,000.00. 
The insurance policies obtained by a grantee in compliance with this section shall be issued by a company or companies licensed to do business in this state and are subject to approval by the franchise entity's attorney, and a current certificate or certificates of insurance, along with written evidence or payment of all required premiums, shall be filed by the grantee with the agency and maintained with the agency during the term of the franchise. The policies shall name the franchise entity as an additional insured and shall contain a provision that a written notice of cancellation or reduction in coverage of the policy shall be delivered to the agency 30 days in advance of the effective date thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-8)  
Sec. 40-9. - Technical requirements; channel capacity. 
(a)  The cable communications system to be constructed by grantee shall be, at a minimum, installed, maintained, and operated at all times in full compliance with the technical and channel capacity standards of the FCC, as they exist on the effective date of this chapter, or as they may hereafter be amended to be more stringent, and all other applicable laws, ordinances, codes and regulations. Signal quality for all cable channels, including broadcast, encoded and noncoded cablecast, and two-way transmission channels, shall comply with the technical standards of the FCC for broadcast channels, presently codified at 47 CFR, 76.605, or successor provisions thereto, as they exist on the effective date of this chapter, or as they may hereafter be amended or recodified under a different section or sections. The results of annual performance tests conducted in accordance with 47 CFR, 76.601(c) of the FCC's rules (or such other section of the rules as shall incorporate its substance) or successor provisions thereto shall be retained for at least five years by a grantee and shall be available during business hours at the grantee's local business office for inspection by the franchise entity. 
(b)  Additionally, the cable communications system to be constructed or operated by the grantee shall have the capacity for return communication on at least a digital basis, distribution of color television signals, at least 21 usable activated channels, and a minimum of 40 channels of capacity. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-9)  
Sec. 40-10. - Safety requirements. 
A grantee shall at all times: 
(1)  Install and maintain its wires, cables, fixtures and other equipment in accordance with the requirements of the franchise entity's building codes and safety ordinances and all other applicable laws, codes, regulations and standards, and in such a manner that will not interfere with any installations or operations of the franchise entity. 
(2)  Keep and maintain in a safe, suitable, and substantial condition, and in good order and repair, all structures, lines, equipment, and connections in, over, under, and upon the streets and other public places of the franchise entity, wherever situated or located. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-10)  
Sec. 40-11. - Service standards; business office; resolution of complaints. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of subsection 40-14(a)(5), no person within the franchise area of a grantee shall be refused service; provided, however, that a grantee shall not be required to provide service to any subscriber who does not pay the applicable connection fee or service charges. 
(b)  Throughout the term of its franchise, a grantee shall at a minimum: 
(1)  Maintain all parts of its system in good condition and in accordance with standards generally observed by the cable television industry so as to provide reliable quality services to subscribers. Sufficient employees shall be retained to provide safe, adequate and prompt service for all grantee's facilities. 
(2)  Maintain a local business office and service center which subscribers may reach by telephone without incurring long distance charges. The franchise authority may require the office to be located in the corporate limits of the franchise entity. The office shall be open to the public during regular business hours, Monday through Friday, except national holidays. Office hours shall be posted at the office location, and notice of such hours of operation shall be given to the agency. In addition, a grantee's local business office and service center shall have the capability of receiving service calls 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 
(3)  Provide service response 24 hours a day, seven days a week, for all complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments. Calls involving loss of reception on all channels shall be responded to immediately. Calls concerning degraded reception, including channel outages, shall be responded to within 24 hours on weekdays, and 48 hours on weekends, and shall be resolved as promptly as possible. 
(4)  Maintain a daily record or log listing the date and time of customer complaints or requests for service, describing the nature of the complaint or request for service, and when and what action was taken by the grantee in response thereto, including the time it was resolved. Such records shall be kept in the grantee's local business office for a period of at least three years, and shall be available for inspection and copying by the franchise entity during regular business hours without special or advance notice or demand. 
(5)  Specify a four-hour time period for all installation or service appointments. If a grantee's service technician is unable to keep an appointment concerning installation or for other service, the grantee shall call and advise the subscriber in advance and reschedule the appointment for a specific time. 
(c)  In the event that a subscriber complaint or service problem is not resolved to the mutual satisfaction of the subscriber and the grantee, either the subscriber or the grantee may request, through the agency, that the matter be presented to an arbitration panel which shall meet in the franchise entity for hearing and resolution. The panel shall consist of three individuals, one selected by the franchise authority, one by the grantee, and one neutral individual selected by the other two arbitrators acting jointly. Notice regarding the hearing shall be given to all interested persons by the franchise authority. All costs of the arbitration shall be borne by the grantee unless the arbitration panel finds the subscriber's complaint to be groundless, frivolous or meritless, in which case the subscriber shall bear the costs of the arbitration. The decision of the arbitration panel, which shall be by majority vote of the three arbitrators, shall be final and binding on all parties. 
(d)  When, in the exercise of a reasonable judgment and discretion, and on the basis of subscriber complaints, service problems or other substantial evidence casting doubt on the reliability or quality of the cable service being provided, the franchise authority or agency finds there are reasonable grounds to believe that a grantee is providing substandard cable service, the franchise authority or agency shall have the authority to compel the grantee to test, review, analyze and report on the performance of the parts of the system, including customer service, which appear to be involved in the problems or the source of the complaints. The agency shall notify the grantee in writing of the need to test the system. Such tests may be conducted by the grantee, but the franchise entity reserves the right to direct that such tests be made by an independent consultant retained by the franchise entity, but paid for by the grantee. Tests shall be conducted consistent with the standards set forth in the franchise agreement and this chapter. The investigation of the problems shall be completed within 30 days of the date of formal notification. Reports on the investigation shall be delivered to the agency no later than 15 days after completion of testing. The reports shall include at a minimum the following information: 
(1)  Nature of the complaints or service problems which precipitated the special tests or review; 
(2)  System components or services tested; 
(3)  Equipment used and procedures employed in such testing or review; 
(4)  Test or review results; 
(5)  Method by which complaints or service problems were resolved; and 
(6)  Any other information pertinent to the special testing or review also shall be recorded. 
The franchise authority's rights under this provision shall be limited to requiring reviews, tests, analysis and reports covering specific subjects and characteristics based on complaints, service problems, or other evidence which provide the franchise entity with reasonable grounds to believe testing is necessary to protect the public against substandard service. 
(e)  Planned interruptions of service, excluding routine repair work, shall be only for good cause. Insofar as possible, planned interruptions of service shall be preceded by notice given to subscribers at least 24 hours in advance and shall occur during minimum viewing hours. 
(f)  The following remedies for inadequate service or for interruption of service are hereby established: 
(1)  In the event that service to any subscriber is interrupted, except for natural disasters, and except in circumstances for which approval of the interruption is obtained from the agency, a grantee shall provide credit on or reimbursement of the monthly fees (basic, special, or premium service) to the subscriber on a pro rata basis for any interruption in cable services if the subscriber has made a complaint to the grantee or requested credit or reimbursement. If the service interruption continues for more than 12 hours and less than 24 hours on any day or portion of a day, then the customer shall be entitled to a full day credit for each such 12- to 24-hour period. 
(2)  In the event that degraded reception, i.e. poor quality reception, is the result of technical deficiency of the system and not caused by the equipment of the subscriber or user, or abuse of the grantee's equipment by the subscriber or user, the grantee shall credit the subscriber for the monthly fees (basic, special, or premium service) on a pro rata basis for any degraded reception quality if the subscriber has made a complaint to the grantee or requested a credit. If degraded reception quality continues for more than 12 hours and less than 24 hours on any day or portion of a day, then the customer shall be entitled to a full day credit for each such 12- to 24-hour period. 
(3)  In the event that the grantee's system fails to meet one or more of the operational standards detailed in the franchise agreement of this chapter, and for which a performance test has been requested pursuant to subsection (d) of this section, for a full three-month period, grantee shall reduce fees to all subscribers by 25 percent until all operational standards are met. The agency's notification to conduct performance tests pursuant to subsection (d) of this section shall be the date upon which the three-month period commences. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-11)  
Sec. 40-12. - Inspection of property and records. 
(a)  Grantee shall at all reasonable times, and to the extent necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter, permit any duly authorized agent or representative of the franchise entity to examine all franchise property of grantee, together with any appurtenant property of grantee situated within or without the franchise entity, and to examine and transcribe any and all maps and other records kept or maintained by grantee or under the control or direction or at the request of grantee which pertain in any way to the franchise operations, affairs, transactions, or property of grantee. 
(b)  Any of such map or other records which are not situated within the franchise entity and which are not made available in the franchise entity within a reasonable time after written request therefor by the agency or the franchise entity's attorney, shall be produced for examination wherever the map or other records shall be situated, and grantee shall pay all travel and other expenses necessarily or reasonably incurred by the franchise entity, its agents, and representatives in making such examination. 
(c)  Grantee shall prepare and furnish to the agency, at such times and in such form as prescribed by the agency, references, and materials relating to the operations, affairs, transactions, or property of grantee as may be reasonably necessary or appropriate to the performance of any of the duties of the agency or franchise authority. All annual financial reports submitted by the grantee to any state or federal regulatory agency shall be simultaneously submitted to the agency. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-12)  
Sec. 40-13. - Conditions on street occupancy. 
(a)  Any pavements, sidewalks, curbing or other area taken up or disturbed or any excavations made by a grantee shall be done under the supervision or direction of the authority responsible for the maintenance of the street or public place or facilities involved and shall be done in such a manner the least inconvenient to the inhabitants of the franchise entity, users of the streets, places, and facilities and adjoining property owners. A grantee shall, at its own cost and expense, and in a manner approved by the agency or other authority, replace, repair, and restore any such pavements, sidewalks, curbing or other paved areas in as good a condition as before the work involving such disturbance was done, and shall also make and keep full and complete plats, maps, and records showing the exact locations of its facilities located within the streets, public places, and easements of the franchise entity. These maps shall be available for inspection at any time during business hours by the agency. 
(b)  A grantee shall at its expense, protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate, or remove, any of its property located in, under, on or over the streets and other public places or facilities of the franchise entity when required by the franchise authority or agency by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, road construction, change of street grade, installation of sewers, drains, water pipes, power lines, signal lines, tracks, or any other type of municipal improvements or operations; provided, however, that the grantee shall, in all cases, have the privilege of abandoning any property in place. 
(c)  A grantee shall, on the request of any person holding a building moving permit issued by the franchise entity, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of buildings. The expense of such temporary removal or raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting the temporary removal or raising or lowering of wires, and the grantee shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. The grantee shall be given not less than 96 hours advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(d)  Grantee shall make use of existing poles and other facilities available to it to the maximum extent feasible. 
(e)  Subject to prior approval by the city horticulturist, a grantee shall have the authority to trim trees upon and overhanging streets, but only to the minimum extent feasible to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the grantee, except that, at the option of the city horticulturist, such trimming may be done by it or under its supervision and direction at the expense of the grantee. In case of an emergency, prior approval of the city horticulturist is not required. 
(f)  In all sections of the franchise area where cable, wires or other similar facilities of public utilities are placed underground, the grantee shall place its cables, wires or other like facilities, whether existing or not, underground to the maximum extent that existing technology reasonably permits the grantee to do so. To the extent existing technology does not permit underground placement, the facilities may be placed above ground but must be of such size, design and location as not to be unsightly or unsafe. 
(g)  Notwithstanding the grant to use streets, no street shall be used by grantee if the franchise authority determines that such use is inconsistent with the terms, conditions or provisions by which such street was created, or dedicated, is inconsistent with how the street is properly used by the franchise entity or public, or creates a public safety hazard. 
(h)  Nothing in a franchise agreement or this chapter shall be deemed to compel the franchise entity to maintain or retain any of its property any longer than or in any fashion other than, in its discretion, its own operations or needs may require. 
(i)  The franchise entity shall not be required to assume any responsibility for securing any rights-of-way or easements for grantee, nor shall it be responsible for securing for grantee any permits or agreements with other persons or utilities. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-13) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 40-14. - Construction. 
(a)  A grantee shall extend the installation of cables, amplifiers, and related equipment and facilities throughout the area covered by its franchise as rapidly as practicable, but, in any event, shall: 
(1)  Begin engineering studies within 30 days after accepting its franchise. 
(2)  Begin awarding contracts within 90 days after receiving certification from the FCC. 
(3)  Begin construction of its proposed system within six months after receiving certification from the FCC. 
(4)  Begin rendering service to subscribers within one year of franchise award from the franchise entity. 
(5)  Complete construction of 50 percent of its proposed system (measured in terms of total linear strand miles) within two years after receiving certification from the FCC and complete an additional 25 percent each year thereafter so that after four years the entire system shall be constructed and the grantee capable of providing service no more than 60 days after receiving an application for service to every household within the franchise area. 
(6)  File a map and progress report with the agency at the close of each calendar year showing the exact areas of the franchise entity being services by the cable television system and lines. 
(b)  Failure on the part of a grantee to commence and diligently pursue each of the requirements of this section and to complete each of the matters set forth in this section shall be grounds for revocation of its franchise pursuant to the terms of section 40-5, provided, however, that the franchise authority may in its discretion extend the time for the commencement and completion of construction and installation for additional periods in the event that grantee, acting in good faith, experiences delays by reasons of circumstances beyond its control. 
(c)  In the event the operation of any part of a cable television system is discontinued for a continuous period of 12 months, or in the event a system has been installed in any public street without complying with requirements of the grantee's franchise, the grantee shall promptly, upon being given ten days' notice by the franchise authority or agency, remove from the streets or public places at its own expense all such property and poles of such system. Any property which the grantee allows to remain in place 60 days after having been notified by the franchise authority or agency that it must be removed shall be considered permanently abandoned and shall become the property of the franchise entity subject to the provisions of any utility joint use attachment agreement. 
(d)  Upon the failure of grantee to satisfactorily complete any work upon the public streets as may be required by this chapter or the terms of its franchise agreement within the time prescribed, the franchise authority or agency, at its option, may cause such work to be done and the grantee shall pay the franchise entity the cost thereof within 30 days after receipt of any itemized statement therefor. 
(e)  In the case of a franchise renewal, the franchise agreement or other document containing the terms of the renewal shall set forth the obligations of the grantee to extend, improve, or upgrade its services, equipment, and facilities. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-14) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10.  
Sec. 40-15. - Performance and construction bond. 
(a)  Concurrently with the acceptance of its franchise, a grantee shall file with the agency a permanent payment and performance bond, with surety acceptable to the franchise authority, in an amount determined by section 40-16 to indemnify the franchise entity against any losses it may suffer if the grantee fails to comply with one or more of the provisions of this chapter or its franchise. The bond shall be obtained at the sole expense of the grantee and shall be upgraded in the event the number of subscribers increase such that it would place the cable television system in a higher subscriber range and would therefore increase the amount of the bond. A bond set as prescribed in this section shall remain in effect for the full term of the franchise or any renewal thereof plus an additional six months thereafter. For an existing cable television system operating satisfactorily under a current franchise within the franchise entity for a period of three or more years, the franchise authority may modify or waive the performance bond in its discretion by resolution. The grantee and its surety shall be jointly and severally liable under the terms of the bond for any damage or loss suffered by the franchise entity as a result of the grantee's nonperformance, including default, plus a reasonable allowance for attorney's fees and costs, up to the full amount of the bond. The bond shall provide for 30 days prior written notice to the agency of any intention on the part of the grantee or surety to cancel, fail to renew, or otherwise materially alter its terms. Neither the filing of an indemnity bond with the agency, nor the receipt of any damages recovered by the franchise authority thereunder shall be construed to excuse faithful performance by the grantee or limit the liability of the grantee under the terms of this chapter or its franchise for damages either to the full amount of the bond or otherwise. 
(b)  Within 30 days after the award of a franchise, grantee shall file with the agency a construction bond with a surety acceptable to the franchise authority or agency, or cash in lieu of a bond, in an amount equal to 110 percent of the estimated system construction cost, to indemnify the franchise entity against any losses it may suffer in the event the grantee fails to complete on time each construction phase of the system. The bond shall be obtained at the sole expense of the grantee and remain in effect for the time of construction. The bond shall be reduced by the franchise authority or agency in increments to be based upon the timely completion of each phase of system following approval by the agency. A grantee that has completed primary construction and is extending the system into new service areas of the franchise entity shall provide a construction bond each year in an amount equal to 110 percent of the estimated cost of all proposed cable system construction by the grantee during such year. The grantee shall provide a certificate to the agency by January 1 of each year estimating the costs of all projected construction during such year and shall provide the construction bond within 30 days after submitting the certificate. The franchise authority agrees to sign any documentation required by the grantee in order to release any construction bond, provided that an appropriate replacement bond, if required, will be provided to the franchise entity. The grantee and its surety shall be jointly and severally liable under the terms of the bond for any damages suffered by the franchise entity as a result of the grantee's nonperformance, including the full amount of any compensation, indemnification, or cost to cure, plus a reasonable allowance for attorney's fees and costs, up to the full amount of the bond. The bond shall provide for 30 days' prior written notice to the agency of any intention on the part of the grantee or surety to cancel, fail to renew, or otherwise materially alter its terms. Neither the filing of any indemnity bond with the agency, nor the receipt of any damages by the franchise authority thereunder shall be construed to excuse faithful performance and timely construction by the grantee, or limit the liability of the grantee under the terms of this chapter or its franchise for damages, either to the full amount of the bond or otherwise. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-15)  
Sec. 40-16. - Performance and payment bond schedule. 
The performance and payment bond schedule for franchise owners shall be as follows: 
Number of Subscribers 	Amount for Performance 
and Payment Bond 
0 to 1,000 ..... 	$ 10,000.00 
1,001 to 5,000 ..... 	  50,000.00 
5,001 to 10,000 ..... 	 100,000.00 
10,001 to 20,000 ..... 	 200,000.00 
 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-16)  
Sec. 40-17. - Franchise fee payments. 
(a)  Any person awarded a franchise under this chapter shall pay the franchise entity each year during the term of the franchise a franchise fee in a percentage amount, which shall not exceed the maximum permitted by applicable federal and state laws and which shall be specified in the franchise agreement between the franchise entity and the grantee, of its annual gross revenues derived from its operation of the cable communications system within the franchise area. The fee shall be paid to the franchise entity on a quarterly basis by the grantee pursuant to terms specified in the franchise agreement. 
(b)  A grantee shall file with the agency, within 90 days after expiration of any calendar year or portion thereof during which its franchise is in force, a financial statement certified by a responsible officer of the grantee, reporting in detail the gross revenues, as defined in this chapter, of the grantee during the preceding calendar year or portion thereof. It shall be the duty of the grantee to pay the franchise entity within 15 days after the time for filing such statement any unpaid balance thereof for the calendar year covered by such statement. If an overpayment has been made, it shall be credited against the franchise fee for the succeeding year. 
(c)  The franchise entity shall have the right to inspect the grantee's records showing the gross revenues from which its franchise payments are computed and shall also have the right of audit and recomputation of any and all amounts paid or due under this chapter or the franchise agreement. No acceptance of payment shall be construed as a release or as an accord and satisfaction of any claim the franchise entity may have for further or additional sums payable under this chapter or for the performance of any other obligation under this chapter. However, an accounting rendered to the franchise entity and to which no exception is made within three years after receipt by the franchise entity shall be deemed to be accurate and shall not thereafter be subject to question or made the basis of any claim by the franchise entity against grantee. 
(d)  Interest to be charged the grantee for late payment of franchise fees shall be specified in the franchise agreement. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-17)  
Sec. 40-18. - Rates charged to subscribers. 
(a)  A grantee's rate structure must be uniform throughout the franchise area. No rate established by a grantee shall afford any undue preference or advantage among subscribers. 
(b)  Grantee shall, at all times, keep on file and maintain with the agency and in its local business office a complete information tariff containing schedules of all charges, rates, and fees charged by grantee to all classes of its subscribers, together with any amendments thereto. 
(c)  No rate shall be increased unless a grantee provides notice thereof to subscribers 45 days prior to the effective date of the increase. 
(d)  The franchise authority expressly reserves the right at its discretion to review, regulate and/or approve the rates which a grantee charges its subscribers for such services as it may be permitted to regulate by existing or subsequent federal or state laws or regulations; provided, however, that such right of the franchise authority may be exercised only by affirmative action of the franchise authority after a duly noticed public hearing. A grantee shall not deny, delay, interrupt, or terminate cable service or the use of community communications facilities to subscribers because the franchise authority denies a request for a rate increase; provided, however, that nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit a grantee's right to seek judicial review of the reasonableness of any such action. 
(e)  No rate, fee or charge of any kind, which is within the approval authority of the franchise entity as set forth in subsection (d) of this section, shall be charged or collected from subscribers by the grantee without authorization by the franchise authority. 
(f)  A grantee may request rate increases or decreases at any time in accordance with this section; provided, however, that initial rates to be charged and collected by a new grantee from subscribers shall be established in the agreement granting a franchise; provided further, that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to the first renewal of a franchise in existence on the effective date of this chapter. 
(g)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit a grantee from reducing or waiving charges in conjunction with bona fide promotional campaigns for the purpose of attracting subscribers or users. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-18)  
Sec. 40-19. - Termination of service. 
(a)  Upon termination of service to any subscriber, a grantee shall promptly remove all its facilities and equipment from the subscriber's premises upon the subscriber's request. 
(b)  If a grantee terminates services to a subscriber of less than the three years without good cause or because the grantee ceases to operate a system authorized hereunder for any reason, except expiration of a franchise granted hereunder, the grantee shall refund to such subscriber that portion of the initial tap-in and connection charge paid by the subscriber representing the unused remainder of the three-year period, determined by prorating the date of notice of terminate on a month-unit basis. 
(c)  No subscriber's service may be terminated for nonpayment of charges unless the subscriber is provided ten days' written notice prior to such termination. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-19)  
Sec. 40-20. - Public service requirements. 
A grantee shall: 
(1)  Provide at least one service outlet to all franchise entity facilities and all public schools within its franchise area which are located within 300 feet of grantee's lines at no cost to the franchise entity or school involved, and shall charge only its time and material costs for any other service outlets to such facilities. There shall be no charge for basic cable service for one outlet for each such location. 
(2)  Provide at least one channel, without charges or restrictions, for use by the franchise entity. 
(3)  Provide at least one channel for educational and public access uses. 
(4)  Make its facilities immediately available to the franchise entity upon request during the course of any emergency or disaster. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-20)  
Sec. 40-21. - Amendment of any franchise. 
The franchise authority may amend this chapter, and any franchise issued hereunder, upon its own motion or the application of a grantee whenever amendment is necessary to enable the grantee to utilize new development in television or radio signal transmission which would improve and update cable television service in the franchise area. No amendment shall be adopted except after a public hearing, and no amendment substantially amending the existing rights and obligations of the grantee or franchise entity shall be adopted without its consent, unless otherwise required by federal or state laws or regulations. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-21)  
Sec. 40-22. - Application procedures. 
(a)  This chapter itself grants no authority to operate a cable television system to any person. Such grants are only made by the adoption of separate ordinances awarding a specific franchise to an applicant who has complied with the provisions of this chapter and accepted a franchise agreement. 
(b)  Any person interested in obtaining a franchise to operate a cable communication system in the franchise area shall submit a written application to the franchise authority, together with a nonrefundable application fee of $3,500.00, which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and form of business of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, it shall also state the names, addresses and occupation of its officers, directors and major stockholders, and the names and addresses of any parent or subsidiary companies. If the applicant is a corporation controlled by another corporation, the names, addresses and occupations of the officers, directors and major stockholders of the controlling corporation also shall be stated. If the applicant is a partnership or other unincorporated association, the name and address of each member, whether active or inactive, shall be set forth, and if one or more partners are corporations, the names, addresses and occupations of such corporations' officers, directors and major stockholders also shall be stated. 
(2)  A list of all other cable television systems, if any, in which the applicant (or any partner or major stockholder of applicant) has a substantial interest, stating the location, approximate number of homes served, and the name and address of the franchising body. 
(3)  A thorough description of the proposed cable communications system to be installed and operated; the manner in which the applicant purposes to construct, install, maintain and operate the cable communications system; and the extent and manner in which existing or future poles or other facilities of public utility companies will be used in the proposed system, together with a legible map or maps delineating proposed service areas if the applicant proposes to serve less than the entire franchise entity. 
(4)  A schedule of all proposed rates and charges to all classes of subscribers for both installation and monthly service, and a copy of the proposed service agreement between the applicant and its proposed subscribers. 
(5)  A copy of each existing or proposed contracts between the applicant and any public utility providing for the use of such utility's facilities, such as poles, lines, or conduits. 
(6)  A statement setting forth all agreements and understandings, whether written, oral, or implied, between the applicant and any other person with respect to the proposed cable communication system or operation. If a franchise shall be granted to a person posing as a front or representative of another person, such franchise shall be deemed void and of no force and effect whatsoever. 
(7)  An estimate of the cost of constructing the applicant's proposed system and a financial statement prepared in form satisfactory to the franchise authority or agency showing applicant's financial status and its financial ability to meet those proposed costs. 
(8)  A sworn statement acknowledging the applicant's familiarity with and eligibility under the provisions of this chapter and FCC regulations and rules and its intention to abide by such provisions and regulations. 
(9)  Any supplementary information as the franchise authority or agency shall at any time demand in order reasonably to determine whether the requested franchise should be granted. 
(c)  No application for a new franchise shall be accepted by the franchise authority until it has announced its intention to award such a franchise or franchises. Written comments shall then be accepted from all interested persons for a period of 30 days. 
(d)  The franchise entity shall then: 
(1)  Specify a date, not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days following receipt of a complete application with all required information, for a public hearing before the franchise authority. 
(2)  Specify a public place where interested persons may inspect the applications and accompanying information. 
(e)  Prior to the hearing, the applicant and franchise entity shall develop a proposed franchise agreement. 
(f)  After hearing the presentations of all interested persons, including members of the public, the franchise authority shall render a decision on awarding the franchise based upon its findings, among other things, on whether the application demonstrates the applicant's compliance with this chapter and applicable state and federal laws and regulations and adequate financial, technical and legal qualifications to provide satisfactory cable service. The franchise authority's decision on all applications shall be final and conclusive. 
(g)  The public hearing also shall serve as the public hearing on the proposed ordinance adopting the franchise agreement between the applicant and franchise entity. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-22)  
Sec. 40-23. - Renewal procedure. 
Renewals of franchises granted pursuant to this chapter shall be governed by the provisions of 47 USC, 546, as amended, and any successor provisions thereto, all of which are incorporated in this section by reference, mutatis mutandis. The franchise authority may require a renewal application fee not to exceed that for a new franchise. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-23)  
Sec. 40-24. - Grantee may promulgate rules. 
A grantee may promulgate such rules, regulations, terms and conditions of its business as shall be reasonably necessary to enable it to exercise its rights and perform its services under this chapter, its franchise agreement, federal and state laws, and the regulations and rules of the FCC, and to assure uninterrupted service to its subscribers. Such rules and regulations shall not be deemed to have the force of law. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-24)  
Sec. 40-25. - Notice. 
Every direction, notice, or order to be served upon a grantee shall be sent to the local office described in subsection 40-11(b)(2). Every notice to be served upon the franchise entity or authority shall be delivered or sent by certified mail to the agency to the attention of the city manager, 214 Park Avenue S.W., Aiken, South Carolina, 29801. The delivery of such notice shall be deemed to have been at the time of receipt. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-25)  
Sec. 40-26. - Rights and remedies are cumulative. 
The rights and remedies reserved to the franchise entity, a grantee or any other person by this chapter are cumulative and shall not subtract from any other rights or remedies which they may have with respect to the subject matter of this chapter, and a waiver thereof at any time shall not affect their assertion at any other time. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-26)  
Sec. 40-27. - Right of franchise entity to intervene. 
The franchise entity reserves to itself the right to intervene in any suit, action, or proceeding involving any provision of this chapter or any franchise agreement granted pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-27)  
Sec. 40-28. - Right of first refusal. 
If a grantee enters into a bona fide agreement to sell its cable system to another person, it shall notify the agency of the agreement within ten days of reaching the agreement and provide the agency with a copy of the agreement. The franchise entity shall treat the agreement as a nonpublic document to the extent permitted by law. The franchise authority shall have 30 days from receipt of the agreement to notify the grantee in writing that it will purchase the system on the same terms. If it does not so notify the grantee, the first right of refusal shall terminate. This section does not apply to a transfer or sale of the cable system to a subsidiary of the grantee or to a partnership which has the same general partner as the grantee. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-28)  
Sec. 40-29. - Municipal ownership. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall or shall be construed to prohibit or prevent the franchise entity from constructing, purchasing or operating a cable communications system within any franchise area or anywhere else. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-29)  
Sec. 40-30. - Variances. 
The franchise authority in its discretion may be resolution vary or modify the application of a provision of this chapter to a grantee where it determines, in its sole discretion, one of the following: 
(1)  The matter is pre-empted by federal or state laws or regulations; 
(2)  The grantee has a policy that is comparable to or exceeds the requirements of this chapter; 
(3)  Enforcement would jeopardize the financial solvency of the grantee; or 
(4)  To do so would be beneficial to the public, subscribers and the grantee. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-30)  
Sec. 40-31. - Annexed areas. 
(a)  If the franchise authority annexes an area, and if a grantee has an existing franchise for the entire corporate limits of the franchise entity, the grantee on its own initiative may submit, or after receiving a written request from the franchise authority 60 days prior thereto shall submit a plan and schedule for providing cable communications service to the annexed area as soon as practical. Upon approval by the franchise authority, the grantee shall implement the plan. 
(b)  If the franchise authority annexes an area, and if a grantee does not have a franchise to serve the entire corporate limits of the franchise entity, the grantee may apply to the franchise authority for its franchise to be amended to add any such annexed area to its franchise area. The franchise authority shall review the request to determine if the grantee meets the criteria in subsection 40-22(f) for providing service to the annexed area. 
(c)  If a grantee already is serving an area annexed by the franchise authority, it may continue to serve the area after annexation subject to approval by the franchise authority and amendment of the franchise agreement to include the annexed area, if necessary. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-32)  
Sec. 40-32. - Liquidated damages. 
The franchise agreement may contain provisions requiring the payment of liquidated damages to the franchise authority for a grantee's failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter or the franchise agreement. 
(Code 1980, § 6.5-33)  
Chapter 42 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Use of vehicle for advertising purposes, § 4-3; municipal court, ch. 20; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 22; noise from vehicles, § 22-36; use of vehicle horn in quiet zone, § 22-37; racing vehicle motor, § 22-38; driving vehicle through parade, § 24-10; parking vehicle on parade route, § 24-11; riding, driving or parking vehicles or animals in parks, § 26-3; solicitations from occupants of vehicles, § 28-3; throwing litter from vehicles, § 32-38; vehicle or vehicle loads causing litter, § 32-39; parking requirements for garage sales, § 34-33; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36; vehicles and other property abandoned on streets, § 36-121 et seq.; vehicles for hire, ch. 46. 
State Law reference— Uniform Traffic Act, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-10 et seq.; general authority of city to regulate traffic, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-5-30, 56-5-710. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 42-1. - State law adopted. 
(a)  All of the provisions and requirements of S.C. Code 1976, § 56-1-10 et seq., S.C. Code 1976, § 56-3-10 et seq., S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-10 et seq. and S.C. Code 1976, § 56-9-10 et seq., as now in force or as hereafter amended, insofar as such provisions can have application within the city, are hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter as fully as though set out at length in this section. All persons within the city shall strictly comply with all regulations imposed thereby, when so applicable. 
(b)  Words and phrases defined in the state law adopted by this section when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them by such state law. 
(c)  Whenever the words "public highways of the state" are used in the state law adopted by this section, they shall be construed to mean and include the streets and other public ways of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 22-1)  
Sec. 42-2. - Compliance with chapter. 
lt shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden, or fail to perform any act required, in this chapter. 
(Code 1980, § 22-2)  
Sec. 42-3. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
Any person violating any section of this chapter in which a penalty is not specified shall be punished as provided in section 1-13; provided that, in cases where the state, by statute, provides a lesser penalty for a similar offense, the penalty imposed by the state shall govern. 
(Code 1980, § 22-3)  
Sec. 42-4. - Disposition of fines and forfeitures. 
All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be paid into the city treasury and deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 22-4)  
Sec. 42-5. - General powers and duties of director of public safety relative to traffic. 
The director of public safety, upon approval of his recommendations therefor by resolution of the city council, shall have power to designate, lay off and indicate, by appropriate signs and markings: parking spaces and zones, no parking zones, limited parking zones, loading zones, safety zones, school zones, hospital zones, quiet zones, no passing zones, traffic zones other than the above, pedestrian crosswalks, through streets, stop streets, one-way streets, three- and four-lane streets, play streets, bus stops and taxicab stands, and shall erect and install such traffic control devices, signs and markings as he may deem necessary. It shall be unlawful for any person to disregard or fail to obey the directions of any such device, sign or marking. 
(Code 1980, § 22-5)  
Sec. 42-6. - Boarding or alighting from moving vehicle. 
No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1980, § 22-6)  
Sec. 42-7. - Riding on portion of vehicle not intended for passengers. 
No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designated or intended for the use of passengers. This section shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1980, § 22-7)  
Sec. 42-8. - Use of skates, coasters, etc., on roadway. 
No person upon roller skates, in-line skates or other wheeled device or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway, except while crossing a street on a crosswalk and except upon streets set aside as play streets. 
(Code 1980, § 22-8)  
Sec. 42-9. - Towing coasters, sleds, etc. 
The operator of a vehicle shall not tow or draw any coaster, sled, person on roller skates, in-line skate, skis, toy vehicle or other similar vehicle on a roadway. 
(Code 1980, § 22-9)  
Sec. 42-10. - Required use of crosswalks by pedestrians. 
(a)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation, and between intersections or at locations where appropriate authorized traffic control signs have been erected so requiring, pedestrians shall not cross any roadway at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway, and shall give warning, by sounding the horn, when necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1980, § 22-10) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3120.  
Sec. 42-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05092011, § 3, adopted May 9, 2011, repealed § 42-11, which pertained to rules and regulations for rotation list wreckers and derived from Ord. No. 09082003, § 1, adopted Sept. 8, 2003; Ord. No. 06132005, § 1, adopted June 13, 2005; Ord. No. 12102007A, § 1, adopted Dec. 10, 2007 and Ord. No. 09082008E, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Sept. 8, 2008.  
Sec. 42-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05092011, § 3, adopted May 9, 2011, repealed § 42-12, which pertained to rules and regulations for rotation list wreckers (for larger vehicles) and derived from Ord. No. 09082003, § 1, adopted Sept. 8, 2003 and Ord. No. 10102005B, § 1, adopted Oct. 10, 2005.  
Secs. 42-13—42-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Uniform Act regulating traffic on highways, South Carolina Code 1976, § 56-5-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 42-31. - Obstructing intersections or crosswalks. 
No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk, unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1980, § 22-21)  
Sec. 42-32. - "U" turns generally. 
The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in the business district of the city and shall not, upon any other street, so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 22-22) 
State Law reference— Limitation on "U" turns, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2140.  
Sec. 42-33. - Obedience to signs, markers, etc., regulating turning. 
Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left or "U" turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such signs, and when authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Code 1980, § 22-23) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate or prohibit turning at intersections, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(9).  
Sec. 42-34. - Driving in processions. 
Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1980, § 22-24) 
Cross reference— Parades and other assemblies, ch. 24.  
Sec. 42-35. - Driving through processions. 
No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion, except as otherwise directed by police officers. 
(Code 1980, § 22-25) 
Cross reference— Parades and other assemblies, ch. 24.  
Sec. 42-36. - Driving on one-way streets. 
Upon those streets and parts of streets as designated by official signs, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1980, § 22-26) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Authority to designate one-way streets, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(4).  
Sec. 42-37. - Driving on play streets. 
Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon such street or portion thereof, except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1980, § 22-27) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 42-38. - Driving on sidewalk. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area, except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1980, § 22-28) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 42-39. - Driving through or across private driveway, etc., to avoid traffic control device. 
No person shall drive any vehicle through or across any private driveway or filling station premises for the purpose of avoiding any traffic control device. 
(Code 1980, § 22-29)  
Sec. 42-40. - Careless driving. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in a careless manner in disregard of the safety of persons or property upon any street, sidewalk, alley or parking area, public or private, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 22-30)  
Sec. 42-41. - Truck routes. 
(a)  Any trucks, tractor-trailer units or similar vehicles entering the city and not taking on or delivering any goods, wares or merchandise within the city shall be driven exclusively on the truck routes established in subsection (c) of this section or on the portions of such truck routes as shall constitute the most direct route from the point of entrance into the city to the point of departure from the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any truck, tractor-trailer unit or similar vehicle transporting freight, goods, wares or merchandise or used for such purposes when neither its origin nor its destination is within the city, on or over any street within the city not designated as a truck route or on or over any street where prohibited by signs erected by the city or state. 
(c)  The truck routes which may be lawfully traveled pursuant to this section are as follows: Along South Carolina Highway 118 (also known along portions thereof as Rutland Drive or Beaufort Street) from S.C. Highway 19 North to U.S. Highway 1 North and from U.S. Highway 1 North to U.S. Highway 78 East; along U.S. Highway 78 East to S.C. Highway 302; along S.C. Highway 302 (also known as Pine Log Road) from U.S. Highway 78 East to S.C. Highway 19 South (also known as Whiskey Road); along S.C. Highway 478 (also known as Hitchcock Parkway) from S.C. Highway 19 South to U.S. 1 South; and along S.C. Highway 118 (also known along portions thereof as the Robert M. Bell Parkway or University Parkway) from U.S. Highway 1 South to S.C. Highway 19 North. The foregoing routes shall include any streets constructed to replace or succeed the foregoing routes as bypasses around the city. 
(Code 1980, § 22-31)  
Sec. 42-42. - Speed limits upon unpaved roadways. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle upon any unpaved roadway within the city limits at speeds in excess of 15 miles per hour, or as may be otherwise posted. 
(b)  Violations of this section shall be unlawful and subject to the penalties set forth under section 1-13, Code of the City of Aiken. 
(Ord. No. 03282005D, § 1, Exh. A, 3-28-2005)  
Secs. 42-43—42-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate standing and parking of vehicles, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(1); stopping, standing and parking generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2510 et seq. 
 
Sec. 42-61. - Prohibited between curblines and adjacent property lines. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle upon that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines. 
(Code 1980, § 22-42)  
Sec. 42-62. - Prohibited for certain purposes. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying it for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1980, § 22-43)  
Sec. 42-63. - Width of roadway available for traffic. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, except that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals or a public safety officer. 
(b)  No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1980, § 22-44)  
Sec. 42-64. - Regulations for specific streets. 
When a sign is in place giving notice that the parking, stopping or standing of vehicles is prohibited, limited or restricted on any street or portion thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any vehicle in violation of the directions of such sign. 
(Code 1980, § 22-45) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 42-65. - Method of parking.
