No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the edge of the roadway, except that, upon those streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such mark or signs. 
(Code 1980, § 22-46) 
State Law reference— Authority to permit angle parking, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2550.  
Sec. 42-66. - Parking of vehicles exceeding twenty feet in length restricted to certain hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any truck, van, bus or other vehicle exceeding 20 feet in length to park on any street in the city which has been officially marked or indicated by the city for angle or parallel parking, except from 10:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 1980, § 22-47)  
Sec. 42-67. - Backing to curb to load or unload. 
In places where and at hours when stopping for the loading or unloading of merchandise or materials is permitted, vehicles used for the transportation of merchandise or materials may be backed to the curb to take on or discharge loads, when the owner of such vehicle holds a special permit issued in the discretion of the director of public safety granting him such privilege, and such permit shall be either in the possession of the driver or on the vehicle at the time such vehicle is backed to the curb to take on or discharge a load. It shall be unlawful for any owner or driver to violate any of the terms or conditions of any such special permit. 
(Code 1980, § 22-48)  
Sec. 42-68. - Loading and unloading at rear or side of certain business houses required. 
All persons loading or unloading goods at any business house or establishment in a business district having accessible back or side entrances shall use such back or side entrances for the purpose of loading or unloading goods, and in all cases where there exists an accessible back or side entrance, it shall be unlawful to load or unload goods across any sidewalk of the principal business streets of the city, unless otherwise authorized by a special permit issued in the discretion of the director of public safety. 
(Code 1980, § 22-49)  
Sec. 42-69. - Restrictions on loading or unloading on Laurens Street. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle for the purpose of loading or unloading on Laurens Street, between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on any day, except in a designated loading and unloading zone indicated by official signs or markings. 
(Code 1980, § 22-50)  
Sec. 42-70. - General restrictions on use of passenger zones and loading zones. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time, other than for the expeditious loading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger zone, during hours when the regulations applicable to such passenger zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time, other than for the expeditious unloading or delivery or pick-up and loading of materials, in any place marked as a loading zone, during hours when the provisions applicable to loading zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(Code 1980, § 22-51)  
Sec. 42-71. - Restrictions on parking or standing of buses and taxicabs and use of bus stops and taxicab stands. 
The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any taxicab from temporarily stopping, in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations, at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, other than a bus, in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab, in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers, when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1980, § 22-52)  
Sec. 42-72. - Owner of vehicle not to permit parking violations. 
(a)  No person shall allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to be parked or left standing in any street in the city in violation of any provision of this article or any other ordinance regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(b)  The person in whose name the vehicle is registered shall be absolutely responsible for violations of state law or city ordinances. It shall be no defense that the vehicle was illegally parked by someone other than the registered owner unless it is shown that at the time of the violation the vehicle was stolen and was not in possession of the registered owner. 
(c)  An owner of a vehicle who is engaged in the business of renting or leasing vehicles under written rental or leasing agreements shall not be liable for parking fines and penalties imposed under this section on such rented or leased vehicles, if, within 15 days after receiving notice of the parking violation, the lessor provides to the department of public safety the true name, address, and driver's license number of the person in possession of the vehicle at the time of the issuance of the citation. A lessor who fails to comply shall be treated as any other owner. Upon provision of this information, the department of public safety, in its discretion, may issue a parking citation against the lessee of the vehicle as established by the lessor under this section. 
(Code 1980, § 22-53; Ord. No. 10222001A, § 1, 10-22-2001)  
Sec. 42-73. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 01122009A, § 2(Exh. B), adopted Jan. 12, 2009, repealed § 42-73, which pertained to removal of illegally stopped vehicles. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 42-74. - Handicapped parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle in a parking place clearly designated for handicapped persons as defined by S.C. Code 1976, § 56-3-1950, or any successor provisions thereto, unless the vehicle bears a handicapped designated license plate or handicapped placard as provided by S.C. Code 1976, § 56-3-1960, or any successor provisions thereto. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person who is not handicapped or who is not transporting a handicapped person to park any vehicle in a parking place clearly designated for handicapped persons whether or not the motor vehicle has the license or placard described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $200.00 or imprisoned for not more than 30 days for each separate offense. 
(Code 1980, § 22-55)  
Sec. 42-75. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 01122009A, § 2(Exh. B), adopted Jan. 12, 2009, repealed § 42-75, which pertained to parking of vehicles in excess of 72 hours prohibited. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 42-76. - Unlawful to park vehicle so as to block refuse containers. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any manner so as to block a refuse container. The refuse containers referred to in this section are those provided for in section 32-6. Any vehicle found in violation of this section may be towed or otherwise removed by or at the direction of the department of public safety, and the owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for all towing, removal and storage costs arising therefrom. 
(Code 1980, § 22-57)  
Sec. 42-77. - City parking ticket. 
The director of the department of public safety, with the approval of the city manager, shall develop a uniform parking ticket for the purpose of vesting the municipal court with jurisdiction to hear and to dispose of violations of ordinances regulating parking within the city. The director shall design the ticket so that all of the necessary information concerning the identification of the motor vehicle involved and its owner are contained on the ticket as well as information concerning the location and date of the violation. All public safety officers and other authorized enforcement officers shall use only the uniform parking ticket authorized by this section in charging the persons with violations of parking ordinances in the city. The uniform parking ticket may not be used for and does not authorize the arrest of persons for any offense. 
(Code 1980, § 22-58)  
Sec. 42-78. - Parking of certain commercial vehicles in residential districts prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall park or leave standing between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., on any street, portion of a street, or on a public right-of-way in city residential districts, as defined by the city zoning ordinance, any truck, trailer, truck and trailer, or other commercial vehicle exceeding 10,000 pounds gross weight, or 20 feet in length. 
(b)  Additionally, no person shall park or leave standing, regardless of the time of day, for more than two continuous hours, on any street, portion of a street, or on a public right-of-way in city residential districts, as defined by the city zoning ordinance, any truck, trailer, truck and trailer, or other commercial vehicle exceeding 10,000 pounds gross weight, or 20 feet in length. 
(c)  These prohibitions shall not apply to trucks or commercial vehicles being used for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise, from or to any building or structure located within city residential districts, or for the purpose of delivering materials to be used in the repair, alteration, remodeling or construction of any such building or structure for which a building permit has been obtained, or when such vehicle has an emergency breakdown. In the event of such an emergency breakdown, the vehicle must be moved within 14 hours. 
(d)  Violations of this section shall be unlawful and subject to the penalties set forth under section 1-13. 
(Code 1980, § 22-59; Ord. No. 11122001, § 1, Exh. A, 11-12-2001)  
Sec. 42-79. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned vehicles means motor vehicles required to be registered in the state if operated on a public highway in the state that are left unattended on a right-of-way for more than 48 hours, or vehicles that have remained on private or other public property for a period of more than seven days without the consent of the owners or persons in control of the property. 
Derelict vehicles mean motor vehicles required to be registered in the state if operated on a public highway in the state: 
(1)  Whose motor or other major parts are in a state of disrepair, are partially dismantled, discarded, wrecked, or have been removed so as either to render the vehicle inoperable or incapable of operation in the manner for which it was originally intended, or if they were operated they would violate S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-4410 et seq.; or 
(2)  Whose manufacturer's serial plates, motor vehicle identification number, or any other means of identification have been removed so as to nullify efforts to locate or identify the registered owners; or 
(3)  Whose registered owners disclaim ownership or release all ownership rights; or 
(4)  That are left on property owned, or operated by, the City of Aiken for more than 48 hours; or 
(5)  That are left on private property for more than 48 hours without the property owner's, or person's in control, consent; or 
(6)  That are left on any public right-of-way in the city limits of Aiken for more than 48 hours; or 
(7)  That are incapable of self-propulsion or being moved in the manner for which they were originally intended, or their condition is wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled, inoperative or discarded, or which cannot safely or legally be operated. Junk motor vehicles do not include those vehicles completely enclosed in a building in a lawful manner or completely covered by a car sized tarp or covered by a vehicle-sized tarp where they are not visible from the public right-of-way or adjacent private properties. 
Motor vehicles means self-propelled land, water, or air vehicles which can be used for towing or transporting people or materials, including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, buses, motor homes, motorized campers, boats, airplanes, motorcycles, motor scooters, mopeds, golf carts, four wheelers, motorized transport vehicles, tractors, snowmobiles, dune buggies, hot rods, or other on the road, or off the road, vehicles. 
Motor vehicle accessories means any part or parts of any motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 42-80. - Abandonment prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon motor vehicles, including derelict motor vehicles, on any private or public right-of-way, private or public street, or private or public real estate. It shall also be unlawful for any person, including owners or occupants controlling publicly or privately owned property, to abandon, or to permit the abandonment of, motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 42-81. - Removal of abandoned vehicles. 
The persons responsible, or the registered owners of any such vehicles, if such can be determined after a reasonable search, or the owners of the premises on which such vehicles are located, or as many of them as may be as reasonably as possible, should be given notice to remove and dispose of abandoned vehicles, or they shall be in violation of the City Code. 
(1)  Vehicles on public property. If such persons, or owners, cannot be determined, or have not complied within the time prescribed by the notice, these vehicles, if located on public property, and in the discretion of the city, may be removed to a storage area for safekeeping at the direction of the city. Written notice of such removal should be promptly given to the registered owners of the vehicle and to any holders of any lien on record in the office of the state department of motor vehicles, as set forth below, if they can be determined after a reasonable search. The city may remove these vehicles without prior notice when these vehicles constitute a safety hazard or other public nuisance. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to park vehicles, or cause to allow vehicles to be parked, left, or to remain in public parking areas, streets, or public rights-of-way for a period of time exceeding 48 consecutive hours. When a vehicle has been so parked for a period of 24 consecutive hours, the department of public safety, or other city employee authorized to issue ordinance summonses, shall cause a colored tag to be placed upon these vehicles, notifying the owner of the provisions of this subsection. 
b.  The fact that vehicles found in violation of this section are registered in the name of a person shall be prima facie proof that such person was in control of the vehicle at the time of the violation. 
c.  Any vehicles found in violation of this section may be towed, or otherwise removed, by order of either the director of the department of public safety or a city official authorized to issue ordinance summonses. When any of them authorize the towing or removal of a vehicle under this section, the owner shall be responsible for all towing, removal, and storage costs. When a vehicle has been taken into custody pursuant to this section, they should notify, within seven days of the tow, by registered mail, return receipt requested, the last known registered owner of the vehicle that the vehicle has been taken into custody. The notice shall describe the vehicle, set forth its location, and advise the owner how to reclaim the vehicle upon payment of all towing, removal, and storage costs. 
(2)  Motor vehicles on private property. If located on private property, no such motor vehicles should be so removed from the premises by the city without the written authorization of the owners of the vehicle, if known, or the owners, lessees, or occupants of the premises, unless the vehicle has been declared by order of any authorized official, after due notice and opportunity for a hearing, to be a safety hazard or other public nuisance. Upon the issuance of such order, the costs of removal and disposal may be assessed against the persons responsible for the nuisance and such costs may be placed as a lien against their properties, and such lien shall be collectible in the same manner as municipal taxes. Vehicles on private property does not include those vehicles, regardless of condition, that are completely enclosed in a building or covered by an appropriate vehicle-sized tarp and not visible from the right-of-way or any adjoining property. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 42-82. - Payment of costs of removal and storage; disposition of unclaimed motor vehicles. 
(a)  The owners of any vehicles removed pursuant to this division, before obtaining possession thereof, shall pay to the city all reasonable costs incidental to its removal or storage or the locating of the owners. 
(b)  Should the owners fail or refuse to pay these costs within 30 days after receipt of the notice, or should their identities or whereabouts be unknown or unascertainable after a reasonable search and after notice as prescribed in section 42-81, the stored vehicle may be sold after 30 days' notice has been given to the state department of motor vehicles before the date of the sale and after the vehicle has been held for not less than 30 days; provided that section 42-83 shall govern disposition of any junk motor vehicles. 
(c)  These vehicles may be sold by public sale, after one public notice published in a newspaper of general circulation, but no vehicles may be sold or disposed of until their value has been determined in writing. 
(d)  Vehicles appraised at a value of less than $50.00 may be disposed of by any means in the discretion of the city or a storing agent of the city. 
(e)  The proceeds of any sale shall be forwarded to the finance director, who shall pay from the proceeds the costs of removal, storage, investigation as to ownership and sale and other liens, in that order. If after the sale the ownership at the time of removal is established satisfactorily to the finance director, the owners may be paid so much of the proceeds as remains after payment of the costs and liens described in this subsection; otherwise, any remaining proceeds shall be deposited after 30 days in the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 42-83. - Removal of derelict motor vehicles and parts. 
(a)  The persons responsible, or the owners of the premises on which vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories are located, or the registered owners of any such vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories if they can be determined after reasonable search, or as many as possible, shall be given notice as prescribed in this division to remove and dispose of derelict motor vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories at their own expense, or they shall be in violation of this division. If such persons or owners cannot be determined or have not complied within the time prescribed by the notice, any such vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories, at the discretion of the city, may be removed from public property to a storage area for safekeeping at the direction of the city. None of these vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories shall be so removed from privately owned premises without the written authorization of the registered owners of the vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories, if known, or the owners, lessees, or occupants of the premises, unless the vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories have been declared by order of the authorized official, after due notice and hearing, to be a safety hazard or other public nuisance. Upon the issuance of such order, the costs of its removal and disposal may be assessed against the persons responsible for the nuisance, and such costs may be placed as a lien against their properties and collectible in the same manner as municipal taxes. 
(b)  Derelict motor vehicles and/or vehicle accessories may be removed to a designated place, and their owners may reclaim it by exhibiting reasonable proof of ownership and paying all reasonable costs incident to its removal and storage and administrative expenses. Unclaimed junk motor vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories may be destroyed, or otherwise disposed of, in summary manner after 30 days following possession of these vehicles and/or accessories under the provisions of this division. Notice should be promptly given after final disposition to the state department of motor vehicles, on such forms as it supplies, that they were deemed junk motor vehicles and have been disposed under this Code. This notice should fully and accurately describe these vehicles. Any proceeds derived from such disposition of motor vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any persons, after notifications have been given, to remove any motor vehicle or motor vehicle accessories from any private property to any other private property upon which such storage is not permitted or onto any public highway or other public property for purposes of storage. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to motor vehicles or motor vehicle accessories either completely covered by a car sized tarp or completely screened by legally installed and maintained buildings. No vehicles or accessories shall be visible from any public places, rights-of-way, or from any surrounding private property. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 42-84. - Disposition with owner's consent. 
With motor vehicles owners' written consent, the city at its own discretion may remove and immediately dispose of these vehicles as derelict motor vehicles regardless of value or condition of these vehicles, and without waiting the periods required by this division. 
As an incentive for voluntary removal of these motor vehicles, the owners of them will be paid $75.00 as an incentive deemed appropriate by city council. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 42-85. - Entry upon private property for abatement or removal is authorized. 
Any public safety, code enforcement, or other city officer, or official, designated as able to issue ordinance summonses by the city manager, is authorized to enter upon private property for the purposes of enforcing the provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful to interfere with, hinder, or refuse to allow a city officer or official to enter upon private property for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this, or any related, chapter. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 42-86. - Appeal. 
Appeal of any administrative decision under the terms of this article shall be made to the building code board of appeals pursuant to any applicable provisions of the most recent version of the International Property Maintenance Code adopted by the Aiken City Council, the provisions of this article, or the South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act, whichever provision provides the most meaningful opportunity for an interested party under this section to be heard. 
(Ord. No. 01122009A, § 1(Exh. A), 1-12-2009)  
Secs. 42-87—42-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - BICYCLES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate operation of bicycles, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(8); provisions of state law adopted by section 42-1 regulating bicyclists, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3410 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 42-101. - Tires. 
Every bicycle used on the streets and other public places of the city shall have a sufficient tread upon its tires to prevent unnecessary skidding and assist in control of the bicycle when stopping and turning. 
(Code 1980, § 22-65)  
Sec. 42-102. - Riding on certain sidewalks prohibited. 
No person shall ride a bicycle, skateboard or similar device or use roller skates on any sidewalk within the city, except where the posted speed limit is in excess of 25 miles per hour on the adjacent street. In no event, shall any person ride a bicycle, skateboard or similar device or use roller skates on any sidewalk located within the following districts as designated upon the comprehensive zoning map of the city: Central business district (CBD); planned shopping center (PSC); and shopping centers located in neighborhood business districts (NB). 
(Code 1980, § 22-66) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 36.  
Sec. 42-103. - Parking. 
Bicycles shall be parked in a position which least obstructs pedestrian traffic between the curbing and the sidewalk. In locations where bicycle racks are provided, they shall be utilized. Where there is no curbing or no sidewalk, bicycles shall be parked off any roadway, street or path in a manner that will not obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic. In the downtown area and where there is no space between the curbing and the sidewalk, bicycles shall be parked on the sidewalk and as close to the curb as possible. 
(Code 1980, § 22-67)  
Secs. 42-104—42-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate licensing of bicycles, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(8). 
 
Sec. 42-121. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the limits of the city, except a transient, to ride or propel a bicycle on any street or other public way, unless the bicycle is currently licensed pursuant to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1980, § 22-73)  
Sec. 42-122. - Application. 
Application for a bicycle license shall be made upon a form provided by the city and shall be made to the director of public safety. 
(Code 1980, § 22-74)  
Sec. 42-123. - Inspection prerequisite to issuance. 
The director of public safety, or a public safety officer assigned such responsibility by such director, shall inspect each bicycle before licensing the bicycle and shall refuse a license for any bicycle which he determines is in unsafe mechanical condition. 
(Code 1980, § 22-75)  
Sec. 42-124. - Fee. 
A fee, in such amount as is prescribed by ordinance, shall be paid to the city before a bicycle license or renewal thereof is granted. Any ordinance prescribing such fee is hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1980, § 22-76)  
Sec. 42-125. - Issuance; display of plate. 
The director of public safety, upon receiving proper application therefor and subject to the other provisions of this division, is authorized to issue a bicycle license and license plate. It shall be unlawful for any person, except a transient, to ride a bicycle on any street in the city, unless such license plate is displayed thereon in a manner prescribed by the director of public safety. 
(Code 1980, § 22-77)  
Sec. 42-126. - Removal of plate generally. 
No person shall remove a license plate from a bicycle during the period for which issued except upon a transfer of ownership, or in the event the bicycle is dismantled and no longer operated upon any street in the city. 
(Code 1980, § 22-78)  
Sec. 42-127. - Removal of plate upon transfer of ownership. 
Upon the sale or other transfer of ownership of a licensed bicycle, the licensee shall remove the license plate and shall notify the director of public safety. 
(Code 1980, § 22-79)  
Sec. 42-128. - Expiration and renewal. 
A bicycle license shall expire on July 1 of the third year following its issuance. Upon the expiration of such license, the license may be renewed upon application and payment of the same fee as for an original application. 
(Code 1980, § 22-80)  
Sec. 42-129. - Records to be kept. 
The director of public safety shall keep a record of the number of each bicycle license issued, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom issued and the number on the frame of the bicycle for which issued, and a record of all bicycle license fees collected by him. 
(Code 1980, § 22-81)  
Secs. 42-130—42-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Railroads generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-17-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 42-151. - Speed of trains restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to operate or run any railroad train at a rate of speed exceeding 15 miles per hour, between the eastern boundary of Williamsburg Street and the eastern boundary of Union Street, and between the northern boundary of the city limits and the northern boundary of Park Avenue, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 17-1)  
Sec. 42-152. - Trains blocking street. 
It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the railroad train in such a manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than five minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains or cars in motion, other than those engaged in switching. It shall be unlawful for any such person to stop a railroad train within an intersection or on a crosswalk for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1980, § 17-2)  
Secs. 42-153—42-175. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10252004A, § 1, adopted Oct. 25, 2004, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 11-1—11-6. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as §§ 42-176—42-181. 
 
Sec. 42-176. - Purpose and administration. 
(a)  The purpose of this article shall be to maintain at least a level of service D at roadway intersections or to maintain operations at a level of service and delay better than or equivalent to current conditions if the intersection operates at level of service E or F today, by requiring the preparation of a traffic impact analysis study to determine the impact and improvements necessary to the transportation system in conjunction with certain development requests. Where required by section 42-178, a traffic impact analysis study shall be submitted as part of any request for approval of a site plan change, an annexation, a rezoning to a category that allows more intense uses than currently allowed on the site, a major subdivision, a concept plan for a tract zoned commercial or planned unit development, or a request for city services except where the subject property is already developed and no redevelopment is proposed. This article shall apply to any new development or change to an existing site. 
(b)  The planning director shall administer this article. 
(Ord. No. 10252004A, § 1, Exh. A, 10-25-2004; Ord. No. 02102020 B, § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2020)  
Sec. 42-177. - Standards. 
(a)  For the purpose of monitoring the operations of the significant intersections of the transportation network, the planning director shall prepare and update at least every two years by November 1 an official AM and PM peak hour transportation analysis and associated map listing current intersection levels of service. The significant intersections in the city limits and in the utility service area outside of the city limits will be determined prior to the commencement of the traffic analysis. 
(b)  Except as stated below, the level of service for a particular intersection shall be determined using a.m. and p.m. peak hour traffic volumes and capacity analysis methodologies based on the Transportation Research Board's 2010 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) or latest edition. 
(Ord. No. 10252004A, § 1, Exh. A, 10-25-2004; Ord. No. 11122007A, § 1, 11-12-2007; Ord. No. 02102020 B, § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2020)  
Sec. 42-178. - Criteria for determining when a traffic impact analysis study is required. 
(a)  A traffic impact analysis study will be required for new developments when the proposed development is projected to generate 100 or more trips during the peak hour of the traffic generator or the peak hour of the adjacent street traffic (7:00—9:00 a.m. or 4:00—6:00 p.m.). Proposed developments that do not meet this threshold may also be required to complete a traffic study as determined by the planning director. 
(b)  A study will be required for a change or expansion at an existing site that results in an expected increase of 100 or more trips during the peak hour of the traffic generator or the peak hour of the adjacent street traffic (7:00—9:00 a.m. or 4:00—6:00 p.m.), or if the planning director determines that the change or expansion of the existing site will have significant impact at the existing access points, proposed access points, or surrounding intersections. 
(c)  The estimate of the number of trips generated by proposed developments will be based on the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation, 10 th Edition, or latest edition. Other trip generation data collected locally may be used where approved by the planning director. 
(Ord. No. 10252004, § 1, Exh. A, 10-25-2004; Ord. No. 11122007A, § 1, 11-12-2007; Ord. No. 02102020 B, § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2020)  
Sec. 42-179. - Traffic impact analysis study requirements. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  A traffic impact analysis study must be prepared, signed, and sealed by a qualified traffic engineering consultant registered in the State of South Carolina. The planning director shall maintain a list of consultants preapproved to prepare a study and shall develop, publish, and maintain a policy for the selection of firms to be on the list. A qualified firm may be added to the list of approved consultants by submitting a qualifications package for approval by the planning director. 
(2)  The planning director will establish the scope of the traffic impact analysis study based on the intensity of the proposed use and the location of the project. At a minimum, the proposed site access points will be studied, and signalized intersection(s) adjacent to the proposed site driveways should be given consideration for inclusion in the study area. The study area shall be confirmed with planning director prior to commencement of the study. 
(3)  A traffic impact analysis study shall be prepared in accordance with SCDOT standards. 
(4)  A methodology memo shall be submitted prior to commencement of the traffic impact analysis study for approval by the planning director. 
(5)  Trip generation estimates shall be based upon methods provided in the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation, 10 th Edition, or latest revision. Other trip generation data collected locally may be used where approved by the planning director. 
(6)  Capacity and level of service analysis methodologies shall be based upon the Transportation Research Board's 2010 HCM, or its most recent revision. 
(7)  Intersection capacity analysis should be performed using Synchro, Version 10 or SIDRA, Version 8 or similar, as appropriate. 
(8)  The traffic impact analysis study shall assess the a.m. and p.m. peak hours and other hours, where deemed necessary by the planning director, for land uses that may generate high traffic volumes on weekends or at midday or nighttime periods. 
(9)  A study prepared in conjunction with a request for annexation or rezoning shall be based on the most intense development allowed by the proposed zoning, unless the owner of the property voluntarily agrees to limit the intensity of development on the entire tract of property. The owner must file a valid restrictive covenant with the Aiken County RMC Office which will forever limit the intensity of development on the property in a manner that is satisfactory to the planning director and/or the city attorney and must provide proof of filing to the planning director before the annexation or rezoning is complete. If as a result of the voluntary restriction, the net new trips shall be less than noted in section 42-178(a), a study may not be required; however a study of any access points for the proposed development shall be required. 
If the subsequent development on the property is less intense than the current use or the use on which an initial study was based, a revised study may be submitted to show expected net new trips are below the threshold noted in section 42-178(a). 
(10)  The planning director shall establish, publish and update, as needed, guidelines for applicants explaining requirements for the content, format and presentation of a study and the number of copies to be submitted. 
(11)  The city shall provide any relevant publicly available traffic count data in its possession within five business days of a request by the applicant. 
(12)  Traffic counts may be used if collected within 12 months of submittal of the study. Counts shall be collected when K-12 schools are in session unless otherwise approved by the planning director. 
(13)  If a traffic signal is being proposed, a signal warrant analysis shall be included in the study. The approval of a traffic signal on projected volumes may be deferred until volumes meet warrants given in the most recent version of the FHWA's Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). 
(b)  Study area and contents. 
(1)  The study area for the traffic impact analysis shall include the proposed site access points, signalized intersections immediately adjacent to the development, and additional intersections identified by the planning director. If intersections impacted by the development are within a coordinated traffic system, at least the two adjacent signalized intersections on the coordinated system should be analyzed, and analysis of the whole coordinated system should be considered by the planning director for inclusion in the study. Existing signal timings should be used for all signalized intersections in the existing conditions analysis. 
(2)  Contents of study. 
a.  Study area descriptions, roadway classifications, other projected transportation improvements and other approved developments in the study area shall be included in the study. 
b.  Assessment of existing conditions, future no build conditions, and future conditions at full buildout shall be provided. Phasing of future build conditions may be performed. If project is planned to be phased, no build conditions should be included for each phase. 
c.  Assessment of a.m. and p.m. peak hour conditions plus any other hours specified by the planning director shall be provided. 
d.  A mitigation plan for intersection and roadway segment improvements should be developed where analysis shows level of service is E or F during any study hour, to ensure level of service D or better for all study hours at signalized intersections. If an intersection currently operates at LOS E or F, a mitigation plan should be developed to ensure that the future LOS and delay are equivalent to or better than existing conditions. Mitigation plans for unsignalized intersections where analysis shows level of service is E or F for any study hour may be required. 
e.  Discussion of access point coordination with SCDOT for access points on SCDOT roadways will be required. 
f.  A vicinity map at a scale sufficient to identify the location of the project shall be provided. 
g.  A site plan with development plans at a scale of not less than 1 inch = 100 feet shall be provided. 
h.  Study shall note intensities for all project phases along with the buildout year with trip generation and distribution displayed in tabular or graphic format. 
i.  Existing, future no build and full buildout levels of service for access points and study area intersections should be summarized in tabular format (including phases as appropriate.) 
j.  Traffic flow diagrams showing existing, background and total future trips (including phases as appropriate) shall be provided. 
k.  All recommended improvements shall be presented in tabular and/or graphic format. 
(Ord. No. 10252004A, § 1, Exh. A, 10-25-2004; Ord. No. 11122007A, § 1, 11-12-2007; Ord. No. 02102020 B, § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2020)  
Sec. 42-180. - Use of the traffic impact analysis study. 
(a)  The city will notify the applicant within ten business days of submission if any required components of a study have been omitted or provide technical comments to applicant. Once comments have been received and addressed applicant can resubmit study for rereview. The city will notify the applicant within 15 business days of a complete submission as to additional comments, approval or disapproval of a study. 
(b)  The planning director shall only grant approval if the level of service at all studied signalized intersections is D or better; or, for intersections currently operating at LOS E or F, if the level of service and delay are equivalent to or better than existing conditions. Any such application for which the traffic impact analysis study shows a level of service worse than a D at a signalized intersection or not operating better than current level of service E or F conditions shall be referred to the planning director for a final determination. Unsignalized intersections performing at a level of service worse than a D may be approved, denied, or deferred at the discretion of the planning director. 
(c)  The applicant will pay for all of the cost of any necessary roadway, traffic control, or access improvements as a result of the project. The applicant must construct the improvements or changes or post a performance guarantee with the city to cover the cost of their construction prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Any posted performance guarantee shall be in an amount of 150 percent of the estimated construction cost of the project for a term of one year and may be in the form of cash, an irrevocable letter of credit, or a bond acceptable to the city. Such improvements may include, but are not limited to, installation of travel lanes, installation of turn lanes, installation of or modifications to traffic signals, and relocation or consolidation of driveways. 
(d)  All improvements on state roadways shall be coordinated with SCDOT. SCDOT may require additional improvements beyond those required by the city. A SCDOT encroachment permit will be required as part of the building permit process. 
(e)  Approval of a study will expire after two years unless a building permit is obtained for the project and construction begins. 
(Ord. No. 10252004A, § 1, Exh. A, 10-25-2004; Ord. No. 04252005A, § 1, 4-25-2005; Ord. No. 11122007A, § 1, 11-12-2007; Ord. No. 02102020 B, § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2020)  
Sec. 42-181. - Definitions. 
Applicant means an individual or corporation, partnership, or other entity undertaking development. 
Development means construction, expansion, or installation of a new building or structure, or a change in use of a building or structure or redevelopment of existing parcel. 
Level of service is defined as the operations of a study area intersection or roadway segment as it relates to the average delay per vehicle experienced. Level of service ranges from level of service A (low level of traffic congestion) to level of service F (high level of traffic and congestion). 
Project means a particular development on an identified parcel of land. 
Service area means the area within which the city may provide water and sanitary sewer service including areas outside of the city limits. 
Vehicle trip is as defined by the Trip Generation Handbook, 3 rd Edition, an ITE Recommended Practice, published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers, 2017, or subsequent updates. 
(Ord. No. 10252004A, § 1, Exh. A, 10-25-2004; Ord. No. 02102020 B, § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2020)  
Chapter 44 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; posting advertising matter to utility poles, trees or public buildings, § 4-1; buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; businesses, ch. 12; solid waste, ch. 32; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36; use of public streets, alleys, ways and places by utilities, § 36-10; telecommunications, ch. 40. 
State Law reference— Municipal water and sewerage systems, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-10 et seq. See also S.C. Code 1976, § 6-15-10 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 44-1. - Systems combined. 
The waterworks system and the sewer system, together with all improvements, extensions and betterments thereto, shall be combined into one system, to be known as the utilities division of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 25-1)  
Sec. 44-2. - Fiscal year of system. 
The water and sewer system shall be operated on a fiscal year basis, which shall commence on July 1 of each year and shall end on the June 30 of the following year. 
(Code 1980, § 25-2)  
Sec. 44-3. - Adoption of cross connection, backflow and back-siphonage control regulations. 
(a)  For the protection of the water supply of the city against possible contamination arising from problems involving cross connections, backflow and back-siphonage, the provisions of Appendix D of the Standard Plumbing Code, 1999 edition (published by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc.), entitled "Cross Connection, Backflow and Back-Siphonage Control" are adopted. 
(b)  Section F entitled "Cross-Connection Control" of Regulation 61-58.7 issued by the state department of health and environmental control (published in Vol. 24A of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1976, as amended, found at page 156-157 of chapter 61 of the state department of health and environmental control regulations adopted May 22, 1981) is adopted by reference and made applicable to the water supply system of the city and all connections thereto. 
(c)  The city plumbing official (which official also serves as the city building inspector) is hereby given the primary responsibility for enforcement of the provisions of this section and for maintaining all records pertaining thereto. 
(d)  The regulations and provisions of this section shall apply to the entire water supply system of the city, to all water customers of the city, and to all connections with the water supply system of the city, whether located inside or outside the city limits. 
(e)  The functions, duties, powers and responsibilities of the cross connection, backflow and back-siphonage control board referred to in Appendix D of the Standard Plumbing Code, 1982 edition, are delegated to the city building code appeals committee-board of adjustments and appeals. 
(Code 1980, § 25-2.1)  
Sec. 44-4. - Permit for connections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connection to the city's water and sewer system, without a permit so to do issued by the director of public works. It shall be unlawful for any developer, contractor, or any other person to make any connection to the city water or sewer system prior to approval by the state department of health and environmental control, and each day that such unauthorized connection exists prior to approval by the state department of health and environmental control shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable by a fine of $200.00 per day. 
(b)  Such fine shall be a lien upon the property affected thereby until the fine be paid in full. 
(c)  When any such unauthorized connection is discovered, it shall be presumed prima facie that such unauthorized connection was made by the developer. 
(Code 1980, § 25-3)  
Sec. 44-5. - Charges for connections and facilities. 
(a)  The charges for water connections, water taps, water meters sewer connections, and related services shall be as prescribed by ordinance, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out verbatim in this section. All such charges for services for properties outside the city limits shall be double the charges for properties located inside the city limits unless the ordinances establishing the charges expressly provided otherwise. 
(b)  In addition to the charges provided for in subsection (a) of this section, a sewer facilities charge shall be assessed on each new residential, commercial or other development, which, alone or in combination with other developments or areas, requires, contributes to, or contributed to, in the discretion of the city, the installation, expansion, upgrading or modification of sewer facilities by the city to provide adequate sanitary sewer service to the development or area. The charges paid on a development shall be placed in a separate account for sewer facilities construction and shall be expended only to defray bonded indebtedness, other obligations, or costs incurred or to be incurred by the city to install, expand, upgrade or modify facilities that receive or will receive sewage from the development. The charge must be paid by the developer, builder or owner prior to the sewer connection being made on the development, or where a development is comprised of individual lots, prior to the sewer connection being made on the individual lot on which the charge is assessed. The amount of the sewer facilities charge shall be as follows: Single-family residential: $400.00 per single-family residential lot. Commercial, multifamily residential and other developments: $400.00 times the equivalent number of single-family residential units, based upon a flow of 1,200 cubic feet per month. The sewer facilities charges set forth in this subsection shall be reviewed, and if appropriate, revised by the city no less than every two years. 
(c)  In addition to the charges provided for above, a water facilities impact fee shall be assessed on each new residential, commercial or other development, which, alone or in combination with other developments or areas, requires, contributes to, or contributed to, in the discretion of the city, the installation, expansion, upgrading or modification of water facilities by the city to provide adequate water service to the development or area. The charges paid shall be placed in a separate account for water facilities construction and shall be expended only to defray bonded indebtedness, other obligations, or costs incurred or to be incurred by the city to install, expand, upgrade or modify water facilities that will provide water service to the development. The charge must be paid by the developer, builder or owner prior to the water connection being made on the development, or where a development is comprised of individual lots, prior to the water connection being made on the individual lot on which the charge is assessed. The amount of the water facilities impact fee shall be as follows: Single-family residential: $750.00 per single-family residential lot. Commercial, multifamily residential and other developments: $750.00 times the equivalent number of single-family residential units, based upon a flow of 800 cubic feet per month. The water facilities impact fee set forth in this subsection shall be reviewed, and if appropriate, revised by the city no less than every two years. 
(Code 1980, § 25-4; Ord. No. 06242002B, § 1, 6-24-2002)  
Sec. 44-6. - Service charges and deposit to be fixed by ordinance. 
The charges for water and sewer service rendered by the city and the amount of deposit required to assure payment thereof shall be as prescribed by ordinance and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1980, § 25-5; Ord. No. 06092003C, § 1, 6-9-2003; Ord. No. 06112007B, § 1, 6-11-2007; Ord. No. 06162008A, § 1, 6-16-2008; Ord. No. 04092012, § 1(Exh. A), 4-9-2012; Ord. No. 03242014 , § 1(Exh. A), 3-24-2014; Ord. No. 04112016A , § 1, 4-11-2016; Ord. No. 05132019D , § 1, 5-13-2019)  
Sec. 44-7. - Annual notification of sewer user charge components. 
The city shall publish annually on a regular monthly billing a notice listing the monthly sewer rate user charges and the components thereof, including the portion thereof attributable to operation, maintenance and replacement of wastewater treatment facilities. Where the notice required by this section cannot be contained on such a billing, the city may provide the notice through a direct mailing to each customer. 
(Code 1980, § 25-5.1)  
Sec. 44-8. - No free service; charges to be paid by city. 
No water or sewer service shall be furnished or rendered free of charge to any person or to the city. The city shall pay the reasonable cost and value of all services furnished to it from current funds or from the proceeds of taxes. The city shall pay as hydrant rental the sum of $2.00 annually for each hydrant within the corporate limits of the city, the hydrant rental to be payable on or before June 30 of each fiscal year. 
(Code 1980, § 25-6)  
Sec. 44-9. - Applicability of charges for sewer service. 
Every customer receiving metered water service from the city shall be subject to the city's sewer service charge, whether he utilizes such sewer service or not. 
(Code 1980, § 25-7)  
Sec. 44-10. - Billing of service charges. 
Bills for water and sewer service shall be rendered every month. Monthly charges for water service shall begin to accrue immediately upon connection of such service. The director of the city department of finance shall promulgate, subject to review and approval by the city manager, written policies for the commencement of monthly charges and billings for sewer service and garbage and refuse service. The director of the department of finance also shall promulgate, subject to review and approval by the city manager, written policies for billing apartments, office buildings and similar multiunit structures and developments for monthly charges for water, sewer, garbage and refuse service. 
(Code 1980, § 25-8)  
Sec. 44-11. - When and where bills due and payable; late payment charge. 
Bills for water, sewer, garbage and similar services shall be due and payable at the city department of finance office, or such other places as the director of the department of finance shall designate, on or before the 20th day of the month in which the bill is issued. A late payment charge of $1.00 shall be added to unpaid bills of less than $40.00 after the 20th day of the month in which the bill is issued, and a late payment charge of ten percent of the amount of the bill due shall be added to unpaid monthly bills of $40.00 or more after the 20th day of the month in which the bill is issued. For purposes of this section, all charges for water, sewer, garbage and similar services appearing on one monthly billing statement shall be considered one bill. 
(Code 1980, § 25-9)  
Sec. 44-12. - Discontinuance of service. 
(a)  If any bill for water service, sewer service, or any other service the city council has authorized to be billed monthly remains unpaid for 20 days after the bill is rendered, any or all services to the customer may be immediately discontinued until the customer has paid the past due bill and any applicable reconnection charge. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to reconnect service when it has been discontinued under this section until all past due charges have been paid in full, including the reconnection charges. Any such reconnection must be effected by the city. 
(c)  Water or sewer service to customers located outside the city also may be terminated for the failure of a customer or property owner to comply with any terms or conditions established by the city council for the receipt of such service. Written notice of the discontinuance of service under this subsection shall be sent by the city by regular United States mail to the service address and to the billing address, if it is different from the service address, at least five days prior to the actual discontinuation of service. 
(d)  Water service to customers located outside the city who are furnished sewer service by a retail sewer provided who is supplied wholesale sewer capacity by the city may be terminated by the city for the failure of the customer to pay sewer charges to the sewer provider according to the terms of sewer service. Provided, however, that this provision shall not be applicable unless the city and sewer provider have entered into a written agreement allowing such terminations, including a term whereby the sewer provider agrees to indemnify and hold the city harmless from all liability for any such termination of service, the sewer provider has given the customer and the city at least 20 days written notice of such termination, and the sewer provider has given its customers and the city at least 30 days prior notice of the existence or implementation of a policy providing for such terminations. The city may decline to terminate water service to a customer when it determines the termination would not be appropriate. The city may require as a condition for implementation of this provision that the sewer provider enter into an agreement for the city to collect sewer charges from the provider's customers on the city's water system. 
(Code 1980, § 25-10)  
Sec. 44-13. - Metering of water; charge when meter fails to register. 
All water service shall be rendered upon a metered basis, except to private hydrants and automatic sprinkler systems, which shall be on a flat rate of rental prescribed by ordinance pursuant to section 44-6, and a separate meter shall be installed for each dwelling, business establishment or property served with water. The meters shall be read every month. In a case where a meter fails to register, the charge will be determined by an average of the most recent consumptions. 
(Code 1980, § 25-11)  
Sec. 44-14. - Tampering with water meter, operating cut-off or curb cocks located in water meter box; charges. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, except authorized representatives of the city utilities division or persons with appropriate authorization therefrom, to (i) tamper with any water meter; (ii) cut or remove any lock therefrom; or (iii) operate a cut-off or curb cock located in a water meter box which has been turned off by the city for nonpayment of billings or other reasons. The city manager or his designee may assess a charge based upon the actual current costs of the water meter or other apparatus and the installation thereof against any person or persons committing those acts or against the customer account designated for such water meter or apparatus in addition to any other charges assessed by the city therefor or any sentence judicially imposed therefor. The charges authorized by this section may be assessed whether or not the water meter or other apparatus is replaced. 
(Code 1980, § 25-12)  
Sec. 44-15. - Use of wells to provide water for domestic or commercial purposes prohibited; exception. 
(a)  The use of wells to provide water for commercial purposes or domestic purposes within the city limits is hereby prohibited and declared to be unlawful. 
(b)  The director of public works and his designated representatives are hereby given full authority to enforce this section by all appropriate measures. 
(c)  The prohibition on the use of wells set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the use of wells for irrigation and outdoor sprinkler systems, provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The well must be installed by a well driller certified by the state department of health and environmental control or the state board of certification of environmental systems operators, except that a property owner may personally install a well on property he or she owns when such installation is allowed by the state department of health and environmental control. All installations must comply with the applicable laws and regulations of the state and the well shall not be used as a source for drinking water. 
(2)  All permits required by the regulations and ordinances of the city relating to installation and inspection, including an electrical permit, must be timely obtained. 
(3)  The well shall be inspected at least annually by the building inspection section of the department of public safety and at the time of such inspection each user of the well shall pay an annual inspection fee of $15.00. Each well system shall be made available for immediate inspection by the city at any time and without prior notice. 
(4)  The well shall not be connected to any public water system or public sanitary sewerage system. 
(5)  An approved backflow preventor shall be installed at the water meter on the owners/user's side. 
(6)  Such wells shall be considered an accessory use as defined by the comprehensive zoning ordinance and shall meet all applicable requirements thereof. 
(7)  Any well found to be in violation of the conditions of subsections (c)(1) through (7) of this section shall be turned off or otherwise disconnected by the city until the user or owner thereof brings it into compliance with such conditions. 
(Code 1980, § 25-13)  
Sec. 44-16. - Emergency drought and water shortage policy—Declaration; purpose and intent. 
(a)  This ordinance is hereby declared necessary for the preservation of public health, safety, and welfare and shall take effect upon its adoption by the City of Aiken. 
(b)  Whenever, in the judgment of the governing body of the city, or when required by the Drought Response Act of 2000, or by the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center, it becomes necessary to conserve water in the service area, due to drought or other reasons, the city is authorized to issue a proclamation that existing drought or other conditions prevent fulfillment of usual water-use demands. The proclamation is an attempt to prevent depleting the water supply to the extent that water use for human consumption, sanitation, fire protection, or other essential needs becomes endangered. 
(c)  Immediately upon the issuance of a proclamation, the provisions, regulations, and restrictions set forth under this Ordinance [sections 44-16 through 44-25] shall become effective, and remain in effect, until the water shortage is terminated and the proclamation is rescinded. 
(d)  Water uses regulated, or prohibited, under this ordinance are considered to be non-essential and continuation of such uses during times of water shortage are deemed to constitute a waste of water, subjecting offenders to potential penalties contained in this ordinance, and section 1-13 of this Code. 
(e)  The provisions of this ordinance shall apply to customers using water supplied by the city's utilities division. 
(Ord. No. 06232003E, § 1, Exh. A, 6-23-2003)  
Sec. 44-17. - Same—Definitions. 
For the purposes of this ordinance [sections 44-16 through 44-25], the following definitions shall apply: 
Aesthetic water use means water use for ornamental or decorative purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls. 
Commercial and industrial water use means water use integral to the production of goods and/or services by an establishment having financial profit as their primary aim. 
Conservation means reduction in water use to prevent depletion or waste of the resource. 
Customer means any person, company, or organization using water supplied by the city's utilities division. 
Domestic water use means water use for personal needs or for household purposes such as drinking, bathing, heating, cooking, sanitation, or for cleaning a residence, business, industry, or institution. 
Drought response committee means a committee composed of state and local representatives, created for the purpose of coordinating responses to water shortages within drought management areas and making recommendations for action to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center. 
Drought emergency exists and [shall be] declared by the South Carolina Governor when the safety, security, health or welfare of the state or any portion of the state is threatened. 
Equivalent residential unit means a lot, one-third acre, containing a single-family residential structure with reasonable general adjustments being made for, but not limited to, the following factors: 
(1)  Commercial and land uses other than single-family residential; 
(2)  Open and/or forested land; 
(3)  Lot or tract size; 
(4)  Other generally accepted factors determined by the city engineer to be relevant to any calculations based upon the provisions of this article. 
Essential water use means water used strictly for fire-fighting purposes, health and medical purposes, maintaining minimum stream flow requirements, and minimum water levels in potable drinking water supplies and the above and below ground water tables, or the use of water to satisfy federal, state, or local public health and safety requirements is considered essential water use. 
Non-essential water use means categories of water use, other than essential water use, which may be curtailed during severe or extreme drought. 
Even-numbered address means street addresses, box numbers, or rural route numbers ending in 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or letters A-M; or any locations without addresses. 
Institutional water use means water used by government, public and private educational institutions, public medians and rights-of-way, churches and places of worship, water utilities, and other lands, buildings, and organizations within the public domain. 
Landscape water use means water used to maintain gardens, trees, lawns, shrubs, flowers, athletic fields, rights-of-way and medians. 
Odd-numbered address means street addresses, box numbers, or rural route numbers ending in 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, or letters N-Z. 
Palmer index means a measure of the severity of a drought, or a wet spell, in an area. Dry conditions are associated with negative values, wet conditions with positive values, and normal conditions have a value of zero. 
Water shortage means [the] lack of adequate available water to meet normal demands due to lower than normal precipitation, reduced stream flows or soil moisture, or lowering of the potentiometric surface in wells which causes water supplies to be less than usual, or due to failure of the city's water processing, pumping, or distribution systems. 
(Ord. No. 06232003E, § 1, Exh. A, 6-23-2003)  
Sec. 44-18. - Same—Nonessential water use. 
Nonessential water use categories, other than essential water use, may be curtailed as determined by city manager during severe or extreme drought or during periods of local problems creating water shortage problems. Some examples of non-essential water uses include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Residential and institutional. 
a.  Washing down sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts, or other hard surfaced areas. 
b.  Washing down buildings or structures for purposes other than immediate fire protection. 
c.  Flushing house gutters, or permitting water to run, or accumulate in, any curb or street. 
d.  Washing any motor bike, motor vehicle, boat, trailer, airplane, or other vehicle in public or private garages or elsewhere. 
e.  Maintaining fountains, reflection ponds, and decorative water bodies for aesthetic or scenic purposes, except where necessary to support any aquatic life in them. 
f.  Filling or maintaining public, or private, swimming pools. 
g.  Sprinkling lawns, plants, trees, and other flora on private or public property, except as may be provided elsewhere in this ordinance. 
(2)  Commercial and industrial. 
a.  Serving water routinely in restaurants. 
b.  Increasing water levels in scenic and recreational ponds and lakes, except for maintaining a minimum amount required to support fish and wildlife. 
c.  Irrigating golf courses and any portion of its grounds, except as otherwise provide under this ordinance. 
d.  Obtaining water from hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills, or for any purpose other than fire fighting. 
e.  Serving customers who have been given a ten-day notice to repair one or more leaks, but have failed to make repairs or comply with conditions contained in the notice. 
f.  Expanding commercial nursery facilities, placing new irrigated agricultural land in production, or planting or landscaping required by the site-design review process. 
(Ord. No. 06232003E, § 1, Exh. A, 6-23-2003)  
Sec. 44-19. - Responses to moderate, severe, and extreme drought alert phases and local water shortages. 
Levels of drought, as set forth in the South Carolina Drought Response Act of 2000, are incipient, moderate, severe, and extreme. Proclamations issued by the city shall coordinate an appropriate response to the level of drought which exists. Proclamations setting forth responses to the various drought alert phases may be made by the city. They should be based upon drought monitoring data, recommendations, declarations, or notifications supplied by the regional drought response committee, or the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources. 
(1)  Incipient drought alert phase. Upon notification of incipient drought conditions by the drought response committee, the city may notify all its personnel who maintain irrigation systems that the incipient drought conditions exists. The city may institute a comprehensive review of all city maintained irrigation systems to repair malfunctioning heads or timers. 
(2)  Moderate drought phase. Upon notification by the drought response committee that a moderate drought condition is present, and is expected to persist, or upon determination by the city that a moderate water supply shortage exists based on trigger levels, the city may seek voluntary reductions from its customers in the use of water for all purposes and voluntary reductions on using water during certain peak water demand periods. 
a.  Goal. 
1.  A 20-percent reduction in residential use. 
2.  A 15-percent reduction in remaining water uses, including, but not limited to, commercial, industrial, institutional, and irrigation. 
3.  A 15-percent reduction in overall water use. 
b.  General responses. 
1.  Issue a proclamation to be released to local media, city customers and to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center that moderate drought conditions are present. 
2.  Provide written notification to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center and routinely publish, in a newspaper of general circulation in the service area of the water system, the voluntary conservation measures that the customers are requested to follow during moderate drought conditions, including: 
(i)  Reduce residential water use to 75 gallons per person per day and a maximum of 300 gallons per household, or equivalent residential unit, per day; 
(ii)  Eliminate washing down of sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts and other hard surfaced areas; 
(iii)  Eliminate washing down of buildings for purposes other than immediate fire protection; 
(iv)  Eliminate flushing of gutters; 
(v)  Eliminate domestic washing of motorbikes, boats, cars, etc.; 
(vi)  Eliminate using water to maintain fountains, reflection ponds and decorative water bodies for aesthetic or scenic purposes, except where a minimum amount is necessary to support aquatic life; 
(vii)  Reduce watering lawn, plants, trees, gardens, shrubbery and flora on private or public property to the minimum amount necessary. Encourage outdoor watering to be done during off-peak hours; 
(viii)  Reduce the amount of water obtained from fire hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills or for any purpose other than firefighting or flushing necessary to maintain water quality; and 
(ix)  Limit normal water use by commercial and individual customers including, but not limited to, the following: 
(a)  Stop maintaining water levels in scenic and recreational ponds and lakes, except for the minimum amount required to support aquatic life; 
(b)  Cease water service to customers who have been given a ten-day notice to repair one or more leaks and have failed to do so. 
3.  Continue encouraging and educating customers to comply with voluntary water conservation. 
4.  Intensify maintenance efforts identifying and correcting water leaks in the distribution system. 
(3)  Severe drought phase. Upon drought response committee notification that a severe drought conditions is present, and is expected to persist, or upon determination by the city that a severe water supply shortage exists, the city may seek voluntary reduction in water use for all purposes; mandatory restrictions on all non-essential usage; and restrictions on times when certain water usage is allowed. Specifically, the goal during this phase is to achieve a reduction of 25 percent in residential water use, 20 percent in all other water use categories, and a 20-percent reduction in overall water use. To accomplish these goals, the city may take any of the following actions: 
a.  General responses. 
1.  Issue a public notice of drought conditions on water supply and demand in a newspaper of general circulation within the affected community and region. 
This statement shall include a list of voluntary water use curtailment measures. 
2.  Request customers of the city's utilities division to voluntarily comply with the listed water-use restrictions in all categories while severe drought conditions exist. 
3.  Issue a proclamation to be released to the local media, city customers and to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center that severe drought conditions are present. 
4.  Provide written notification to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center and routinely publish, in a newspaper of general circulation in the service area of the water system, the voluntary conservation measures and mandatory restrictions to be placed on the use of water supplied by the utility, including: 
(i)  Voluntary reduction of residential water use by utility customers to 65 gallons per person per day and a maximum of 250 gallons per household or equivalent residential unit per day. 
(ii)  Control utility customers landscape irrigation by staggering watering times. 
(iii)  Mandatory restrictions on the use of water supplied by the utility for activities including: 
(a)  Eliminate washing down sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts and other hard surfaced areas; 
(b)  Eliminate washing down buildings for purposes other than immediate fire protection; 
(c)  Eliminate flushing gutters; 
(d)  Eliminate domestic washing of motorbikes, boats, cars, etc.; 
(e)  Eliminate water use to maintain fountains, reflection ponds and decorative water bodies for aesthetic or scenic purposes, except where a minimum amount is necessary to support aquatic life; 
(f)  Eliminate obtaining water from fire hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills, or any purpose other than fire-fighting or flushing necessary to maintain water quality; and 
(iv)  Limit water use by commercial and individual customers including, but not limited to, the following: 
(a)  Stop maintaining water levels in scenic and recreational ponds and lakes, except for the minimum amount required to support aquatic life; 
(b)  Limit irrigating golf courses and any portion of its grounds; 
(c)  Cease water service to customers who have been given a ten-day notice to repair one or more leaks but have failed to do so; and 
(d)  Limit expanding commercial nursery facilities, placing new irrigated agricultural land in production, or planting or landscaping when required by the site design review process. 
(v)  Intensify maintenance efforts to identify and correct water leaks in the distribution system. 
(vi)  Cease installation of new irrigation taps on the water system. 
(vii)  Publicize the penalties that could be imposed for violations of mandatory restrictions and the procedures to be followed if a restrictions variance is requested. 
(viii)  Expand the use of education and public relations efforts and emphasize the penalties associated with violating the mandatory restrictions. 
(ix)  Provide the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center written monthly notification regarding voluntary and mandatory restrictions success. 
(4)  Extreme drought phase. Upon notification by the drought response committee that an extreme drought condition is present, and is expected to persist, or upon determination by the city that an extreme water supply shortage exists based on the trigger levels, the city may impose mandatory restrictions in the use of water for all purpose and on the times when certain water usage is allowed. Specifically, the goal during this phase is to achieve a reduction of 30 percent in residential water use, 25 percent in all other categories of water uses and a reduction in overall water use of 25 percent. To accomplish these goals, the city may take the following actions: 
a.  General responses. 
1.  Issue a public notice of drought conditions on water supply and demand in a newspaper of general circulation within the affected community and region. 
This statement shall include a list of voluntary water use curtailment measures. 
2.  Require customers of the city's utilities division to voluntarily comply with the listed water use restrictions in all categories while extreme drought conditions exist. 
3.  Issue a proclamation to be released to the local media, the city customers and to the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center that extreme drought conditions are present. 
4.  Provide the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources Drought Information Center written notification and routinely publish, in a newspaper of general circulation in the service area of the water system, the mandatory restrictions to be placed on the use of water supplied by the utility, including: 
(i)  Limiting residential water use to 55 gallons per person per day and a maximum of 225 gallons per household, or equivalent residential unit, per day. 
(ii)  Control landscape irrigation by the utility's customers by staggering watering times. 
(iii)  Mandatory restrictions on water use supplied by the utility for activities including: 
(a)  Eliminate washing down sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts and other hard surfaced areas; 
(b)  Eliminate washing down building for purposes other than immediate fire protection; 
(c)  Eliminate flushing gutters; 
(d)  No domestic washing of motorbikes, boats, cars, etc.; 
(e)  Eliminate water use to maintain fountains, reflection ponds, and decorative water bodies for aesthetic or scenic purposes, except where a minimum amount is necessary to support aquatic life; 
(f)  Eliminate obtaining water from fire hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills, or any purpose other than firefighting or any flushing necessary to maintain water quality; and
