b.  Recreational vehicles placed on sites shall either be: 
1.  On site for fewer than 180 consecutive days; or 
2.  Be fully licensed and ready for highway use, or meet the development permit and certification requirements of section 45-34, general standards outlined in section 45-41, and manufactured homes standards in subsection 45-42(3) and 45-42(4). 
(7)  Map maintenance activities. The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) requires flood data to be reviewed and approved by FEMA. This ensures that flood maps, studies and other data identified in section 45-4 accurately represent flooding conditions so appropriate floodplain management criteria are based on current data. The following map maintenance activities are identified: 
a.  Requirement to submit new technical data. 
1.  For all development proposals that impact floodway delineations or base flood elevations, the community shall ensure that technical or scientific data reflecting such changes be submitted to FEMA as soon as practicable, but no later than six months of the date such information becomes available. These development proposals include; but not limited to: 
(i)  Floodway encroachments that increase or decrease base flood elevations or alter floodway boundaries; 
(ii)  Fill sites to be used for the placement of proposed structures where the applicant desires to remove the site from the special flood hazard area; 
(iii)  Alteration of watercourses that result in a relocation or elimination of the special flood hazard area, including the placement of culverts; and 
(iv)  Subdivision or large scale development proposals requiring the establishment of base flood elevations in accordance with subsection 45-43(1). 
2.  It is the responsibility of the applicant to have technical data, required in accordance with subsection 45-42(7), prepared in a format required for a Conditional Letter of Map Revision or Letter of Map Revision, and submitted to FEMA. Submittal and processing fees for these map revisions shall also be the responsibility of the applicant. 
3.  The local floodplain administrator shall require a Conditional Letter of Map Revision prior to the issuance of a floodplain development permit for: 
(i)  Proposed floodway encroachments that increase the base flood elevation; and 
(ii)  Proposed development which increases the base flood elevation by more than one foot in areas where FEMA has provided base flood elevations but no floodway. 
4.  Floodplain development permits issued by the local floodplain administrator shall be conditioned upon the applicant obtaining a Letter of Map Revision from FEMA for any development proposal subject to subsection 45-42(7). 
b.  Right to submit new technical data. The floodplain administrator may request changes to any of the information shown on an effective map that does not impact floodplain or floodway delineations or base flood elevations, such as labeling or planimetric details. Such a submission shall include appropriate supporting documentation made in writing by the local jurisdiction and may be submitted at any time. 
(8)  Accessory Structures. 
a.  A detached accessory structure or garage, the cost of which is greater than $3,000, must comply with the requirements as outlined in FEMA's Technical Bulletin 7-93 Wet Floodproofing Requirements or be elevated in accordance with subsections 45-42(1) and 45-42(4) or dry floodproofed in accordance with subsection 45-42(2). 
b.  If accessory structures of $3,000 or less are to be placed in the floodplain, the following criteria shall be met: 
1.  Accessory structures shall not be used for any uses other than the parking of vehicles and storage, 
2.  Accessory structures shall be designed to have low flood damage potential, 
3.  Accessory structures shall be constructed and placed on the building site so as to offer the minimum resistance to the flow of floodwaters, 
4.  Accessory structures shall be firmly anchored to prevent flotation, collapse and lateral movement of the structure, 
5.  Service facilities such as electrical and heating equipment shall be installed in accordance with subsection 45-41(5), 
6.  Openings to relieve hydrostatic pressure during a flood shall be provided below base flood elevation in conformance with subsection 45-42(4)a, and 
7.  Accessory structures shall be built with flood resistance materials in accordance with Technical Bulletin 2, Flood Damage-Resistant Materials Requirements, dated 8/08, and available from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Class 4 and 5 materials, referenced therein, are acceptable flood-resistant materials. 
(9)  Swimming pool utility equipment rooms. If the building cannot be built at or above the BFE, because of functionality of the equipment then a structure to house the utilities for the pool may be built below the BFE with the following provisions: 
a.  Meet the requirements for accessory structures in subsection 45-42(8) 
b.  The utilities must be anchored to prevent flotation and shall be designed to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of the base flood. 
(10)  Elevators. 
a.  Install a float switch system or another system that provides the same level of safety necessary for all elevators where there is a potential for the elevator cab to descend below the BFE during a flood per FEMA's Technical Bulletin 4-93 Elevator Installation for Buildings Located in Special Flood Hazard Areas. 
b.  All equipment that may have to be installed below the BFE such as counter weight roller guides, compensation cable and pulleys, and oil buffers for traction elevators and the jack assembly for a hydraulic elevator must be constructed using flood-resistant materials where possible per FEMA's Technical Bulletin 4-93 Elevator Installation for Buildings Located in Special Flood Hazard Areas. 
(11)  Fill. An applicant shall demonstrate that fill is the only alternative to raising the building to meet the residential and non-residential construction requirements of subsections 45-42(1) or 45-42(2), and that the amount of fill used will not affect the flood storage capacity or adversely affect adjacent properties. The following provisions shall apply to all fill placed in the special flood hazard area: 
a.  Fill may not be placed in the floodway unless it is in accordance with the requirements in subsection 45-42(5)a. 
b.  Fill may not be placed in tidal or non-tidal wetlands without the required state and federal permits. 
c.  Fill must consist of soil and rock materials only. A registered professional geotechnical engineer may use dredged material as fill only upon certification of suitability. Landfills, rubble fills, dumps, and sanitary fills are not permitted in the floodplain. 
d.  Fill used to support structures must comply with ASTM Standard D-698, and its suitability to support structures certified by a registered, professional engineer. 
e.  Fill slopes shall be no greater than two horizontal to one vertical. Flatter slopes may be required where velocities may result in erosion. 
f.  The use of fill shall not increase flooding or cause drainage problems on neighboring properties. 
g.  Fill may not be used for structural support in the coastal high hazard areas. 
h.  Will meet the requirements of FEMA Technical Bulletin 10-01, Ensuring That Structures Built On Fill in or Near Special Flood Hazard Areas Are Reasonable Safe from Flooding. 
(12)  Standards for subdivision proposals and other development. 
a.  All subdivision proposals and other proposed new development shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage and are subject to all applicable standards in these regulations. 
b.  All subdivision proposals and other proposed new development shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage. 
c.  All subdivision proposals and other proposed new development shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood damage. 
d.  The applicant shall meet the requirement to submit technical data to FEMA in subsection 45-42(7) when a hydrologic and hydraulic analysis is completed that generates base flood elevations. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-43. - Standards for streams without established base flood elevations and floodways. 
Located within the areas of special flood hazard (Zones A and V) established in section 45-4, are small streams where no base flood data has been provided and where no floodways have been identified. The following provisions apply within such areas: 
(1)  In all areas of special flood hazard where base flood elevation data are not available, the applicant shall provide a hydrologic and hydraulic engineering analysis that generates base flood elevations for all subdivision proposals and other proposed developments containing at least 50 lots or five acres, whichever is less. 
(2)  No encroachments, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements and new development shall be permitted within 100 feet of the stream bank unless certification with supporting technical data by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that such encroachments shall not result in any increase in flood levels during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. 
(3)  If subsection 45-43(1) is satisfied and base flood elevation data is available from other sources, all new construction and substantial improvements within such areas shall comply with all applicable flood hazard ordinance provisions of article IV and shall be elevated or floodproofed in accordance with elevations established in accordance with subsection 45-35(k). 
(4)  Data from preliminary, draft, and final Flood Insurance Studies constitutes best available data. Refer to FEMA Floodplain Management Technical Bulletin 1-98 Use of Flood Insurance Study (FIS) Data as Available Data. If an appeal is pending on the study in accordance with 44 CFR Ch. 1, Part 67.5 and 67.6, the data does not have to be used. 
(5)  When base flood elevation (BFE) data is not available from a federal, state, or other source one of the following methods may be used to determine a BFE For further information regarding the methods for determining BFEs listed below, refer to FEMA's manual Managing Floodplain Development in Approximate Zone A Areas: 
a.  Contour interpolation. 
1.  Superimpose approximate Zone A boundaries onto a topographic map and estimate a BFE. 
2.  Add one-half of the contour interval of the topographic map that is used to the BFE. 
b.  Data extrapolation. A BFE can be determined if a site within 500 feet upstream of a reach of a stream reach for which a 100-year profile has been computed by detailed methods, and the floodplain and channel bottom slope characteristics are relatively similar to the downstream reaches. No hydraulic structures shall be present. 
c.  Hydrologic and hydraulic calculations. Perform hydrologic and hydraulic calculations to determine BFEs using FEMA approved methods and software. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-44. - Standards for streams with established base flood elevations but without floodways. 
Along rivers and streams where Base Flood Elevation (BFE) data is provided but no floodway is identified for a special flood hazard area on the FIRM or in the FIS. 
(1)  No encroachments including fill, new construction, substantial improvements, or other development shall be permitted unless certification with supporting technical data by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one foot at any point within the community. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-45. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO Zones). 
Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 45-4, are areas designated as shallow flooding. The following provisions shall apply within such areas: 
(1)  All new construction and substantial improvements of residential structures shall have the lowest floor elevated to at least as high as the depth number specified on the Flood Insurance Rate Map, in feet, above the highest adjacent grade. If no depth number is specified, the lowest floor shall be elevated at least three feet above the highest adjacent grade. 
(2)  All new construction and substantial improvements of non-residential structures shall: 
a.  Have the lowest floor elevated to at least as high as the depth number specified on the Flood Insurance Rate Map, in feet, above the highest adjacent grade. If no depth number is specified, the lowest floor shall be elevated at least three feet above the highest adjacent grade; or, 
b.  Be completely flood-proofed together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities to or above that level so that any space below that level is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. Certification is required as stated in section 45-34. 
(3)  All structures on slopes must have drainage paths around them to guide water away from the structures. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Secs. 45-46—45-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - VARIANCE PROCEDURES 
 
Sec. 45-51. - Establishment of appeal board. 
The zoning board of appeals, as established by the city council of the city of Aiken, shall hear and decide requests for variances from the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-52. - Right to appeal. 
Any person aggrieved by the decision of the appeal board or any taxpayer may appeal such decision to the court. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-53. - Historic structures. 
Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of historic structures upon the determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure and the variance is the minimum necessary to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-54. - Functionally dependent uses. 
Variances may be issued for development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use, provided the criteria of this article are met, no reasonable alternative exist, and the development is protected by methods that minimize flood damage and create no additional threat to public safety. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-55. - Agricultural structures. 
Variances may be issued to wet floodproof an agricultural structure provided it is used solely for agricultural purposes. In order to minimize flood damages during the base flood and the threat to public health and safety, the structure must meet all of the conditions and considerations of section 45-58, this section, and the following standards: 
(1)  Use of the structure must be limited to agricultural purposes as listed below: 
a.  Pole frame buildings with open or closed sides used exclusively for the storage of farm machinery and equipment, 
b.  Steel grain bins and steel frame corncribs, 
c.  General-purpose barns for the temporary feeding of livestock that are open on at least one side; 
d.  For livestock confinement buildings, poultry houses, dairy operations, and similar livestock operations, variances may not be issued for structures that were substantially damaged. New construction or substantial improvement of such structures must meet the elevation requirements of subsection 45-42(2) of this chapter; and, 
(2)  The agricultural structure must be built or rebuilt, in the case of an existing building that is substantially damaged, with flood-resistant materials for the exterior and interior building components and elements below the base flood elevation. 
(3)  The agricultural structure must be adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. All of the structure's components must be capable of resisting specific flood-related forces including hydrostatic, buoyancy, hydrodynamic, and debris impact forces. Where flood velocities exceed five feet per second, fast-flowing floodwaters can exert considerable pressure on the building's enclosure walls or foundation walls. 
(4)  The agricultural structure must meet the venting requirement of subsection 45-42(4) of this chapter. 
(5)  Any mechanical, electrical, or other utility equipment must be located above the base flood elevation (BFE), plus any required freeboard, or be contained within a watertight, floodproofed enclosure that is capable of resisting damage during flood conditions in accordance with subsection 45-41(5) of this chapter. 
(6)  The agricultural structure must comply with the floodway encroachment provisions of subsection 45-42(5) of this chapter. 
(7)  Major equipment, machinery, or other contents must be protected. Such protection may include protective watertight floodproofed areas within the building, the use of equipment hoists for readily elevating contents, permanently elevating contents on pedestals or shelves above the base flood elevation, or determining that property owners can safely remove contents without risk to lives and that the contents will be located to a specified site out of the floodplain. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-56. - Considerations. 
In passing upon such applications, the appeal board shall consider all technical evaluations, all relevant factors, all standards specified in other sections of this chapter, and: 
(1)  The danger that materials may be swept onto other lands to the injury of others; 
(2)  The danger to life and property due to flooding or erosion damage, and the safety of access to the property in times of flood for ordinary and emergency vehicles; 
(3)  The susceptibility of the proposed facility and its contents to flood damage and the effect of such damage on the individual owner; 
(4)  The importance of the services provided by the proposed facility to the community; 
(5)  The necessity to the facility of a waterfront location, where applicable; 
(6)  The availability of alternative locations, not subject to flooding or erosion damage, for the proposed use; 
(7)  The compatibility of the proposed use with existing and anticipated development, and the relationship of the proposed use to the comprehensive plan and floodplain management program for that area; 
(8)  The expected heights, velocity, duration, rate of rise, and sediment transport of the floodwaters and the effects of wave action, if applicable, expected at the site; 
(9)  The costs of providing governmental services during and after flood conditions including maintenance and repair of public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems, and streets and bridges; and 
(10)  Agricultural structures must be located in wide, expansive floodplain areas, where no other alternative location for the agricultural structure exists. The applicant must demonstrate that the entire farm acreage, consisting of a contiguous parcel of land on which the structure is to be located, must be in the special flood hazard area and no other alternative locations for the structure are available. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-57. - Findings. 
Findings listed above shall be submitted to the appeal board, in writing, and included in the application for a variance. Additionally, comments from the department of natural resources, land, water and conservation division, state coordinator's office, must be taken into account and included in the permit file. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-58. - Floodways. 
Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result unless a CLOMR is obtained prior to issuance of the variance. In order to ensure the project is built in compliance with the CLOMR for which the variance is granted the applicant must provide a bond for 100 percent of the cost to perform the development. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-59. - Conditions. 
Upon consideration of the factors listed above and the purposes of this chapter, the appeal board may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purposes of this chapter. The following conditions shall apply to all variances: 
(1)  Variances may not be issued when the variance will make the structure in violation of other federal, state, or local laws, regulations, or ordinances. 
(2)  Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief. 
(3)  Variances shall only be issued upon a showing of good and sufficient cause, a determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship, and a determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisance, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(4)  Any applicant to whom a variance is granted shall be given written notice specifying the difference between the base flood elevation (BFE) and the elevation to which the structure is to be built and a written statement that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk. Such notification shall be maintained with a record of all variance actions. 
(5)  The local floodplain administrator shall maintain the records of all appeal actions and report any variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) upon request. 
(6)  Variances shall not be issued for unpermitted development or other development that is not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Violations must be corrected in accordance with subsection 45-35(e) of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 45-61. - Effect on rights and liabilities under the existing Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance. 
This chapter in part comes forward by re-enactment of some of the provisions of the Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance enacted April 23, 2012 and it is not the intention to repeal but rather to re-enact and continue to enforce without interruption of such existing provisions, so that all rights and liabilities that have accrued there under are reserved and may be enforced. The enactment of this ordinance shall not affect any action, suit or proceeding instituted or pending. All provisions of the Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance of the city of Aiken enacted on April 23, 2012, as amended, which are not reenacted herein, are repealed. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 45-62. - Effect upon outstanding building permits. 
Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the plans, construction, size or designated use of any building, structure or part thereof for which a building permit has been granted by the chief building inspector or his authorized agents before the time of passage of this chapter; provided, however, that when start of construction has not occurred under such outstanding permit within a period of 60 days subsequent to passage of this chapter, construction or use shall be in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05142018B , § 1(Exh. A), 5-14-2018)  
Chapter 46 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, ch. 36; traffic, ch. 42. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 46-1—46-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Regulation of taxis by municipalities, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-1210 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-31. - Definition. 
The word "taxicab," as used in this article, shall mean any motor vehicle in which the public is transported from place to place for hire, not over fixed routes. The definition of "taxicab," as used in this article, shall not include ambulances, vehicles providing medical or medically related services during transportation, and vehicles operated by schools or child care facilities to transport children to and from such schools or facilities. 
(Code 1980, § 24-21) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-32. - Compliance with article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating taxicabs upon the streets or highways of the city without complying with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1980, § 24-22)  
Sec. 46-33. - Maximum number to be determined by council. 
The city council shall, from time to time, determine, by resolution, the maximum number of taxicabs required for the public convenience and necessity of the area of the city. 
(Code 1980, § 24-23)  
Sec. 46-34. - Identification. 
The word "taxi" shall be prominently and conspicuously painted, in contrasting colors, on the outside of each front door of a taxicab, or securely fastened to each such door in such manner that the work "taxi" is incapable of removal while the vehicle is in motion and incapable of removal without the application of tools. 
(Code 1980, § 24-24)  
Sec. 46-35. - Maintenance. 
Every taxicab operated in the city shall be maintained in a state of good repair at all times. 
(Code 1980, § 24-25)  
Sec. 46-36. - Inspection. 
(a)  The department of public safety is hereby charged with the duty of making such periodic inspection of all taxicabs operated in the city as it deems advisable. In the event it is found that a taxicab so inspected is not in a state of good repair, the director of public safety shall have the right to suspend the owner's right to operate such vehicle as a taxicab until the vehicle is placed in a state of good repair. 
(b)  If the owner fails to make a vehicle available for inspection under this section, the director of public safety shall have the right to suspend such owner's right to operate such vehicle as a taxicab until it has been made available. 
(Code 1980, § 24-26)  
Sec. 46-37. - Fares. 
Taxicab operators are authorized to set such fares for their services as they may deem reasonable. 
(Code 1980, § 24-27)  
Sec. 46-38. - Engaging cab with fraudulent intent. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to engage or use any taxicab, not intending, at the time when such taxicab is engaged, to pay the legal fare, but with the intent to defraud the owner or driver of such taxicab. 
(Code 1980, § 24-28)  
Sec. 46-39. - Revocation or suspension of licenses, permits and registration cards issued under article. 
(a)  The city council reserves unto itself the right to revoke any license to do business, as well as any driver's permit and registration card, issued under this article for good and sufficient reason, which, in its judgment and discretion, requires that such license, driver's permit and registration card be revoked. It shall be the duty of the department of public safety, from time to time, to make reports to the city manager relative to the conduct of, the activities of and convictions of any of the licensees and drivers of taxicabs which, in the opinion of the department of public safety, may be good and sufficient reason to revoke the license or driver's permit and registration card. After due notice to the licensee or taxicab driver concerned, the city council shall hold a hearing regarding the merits of the revocation of the license or driver's permit and registration card, as the case may be, and it shall record its judgment in the minutes of the hearing. 
(b)  In the event of cancellation or expiration of the policy of insurance required by section 46-59 the license to operate a taxicab covered by such policy shall be forthwith suspended and the right to operate the taxicab shall forthwith cease and terminate and it shall be unlawful to operate such taxicab until such time as proper evidence that the required insurance has again been obtained. 
(c)  In the event a holder of a taxicab driver's permit and registration card is found guilty of driving under the influence of intoxicating beverages or narcotics, disorderly conduct, breach of the peace or any other criminal offense, his permit and registration card shall be revoked. Nothing in this article shall limit the cause for which a taxicab driver's permit and registration card may be revoked by the city council. 
(Code 1980, § 24-29)  
Secs. 46-40—46-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Business licenses, § 12-31 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to require license to operate taxicab or other public conveyance, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-1-20. 
 
Sec. 46-56. - Filing of application. 
Any person desiring a license to operate a taxicab business, as required by the license ordinance of the city, shall file with the city clerk a written application for such license, upon forms to be furnished by the city. 
(Code 1980, § 24-35) 
State Law reference— Application for taxi license required, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-1210.  
Sec. 46-57. - Contents of application. 
The application for license to operate a taxicab business shall state the full name, age, home address and business address of the applicant and shall further state whether or not the applicant uses intoxicating beverages, narcotics or other drugs and whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of any violation of this Code or any ordinance of the city or of any state or federal statute or law, and if so, the nature of such conviction and the number of times convicted for each offense stated, and all other information concerning the applicant that shall, from time to time, be required. The application shall further state the make, body type, year, model, motor serial number and current state license plate number of each vehicle to be operated under the license, together with such other information in regard to such vehicles as may be required. 
(Code 1980, § 24-36)  
Sec. 46-58. - Applications by partnerships and corporations. 
If the applicant for license to operate a taxicab business is a partnership or corporation, the requirements of sections 46-56 and 46-57 shall be complied with by each partner of such partnership or by the principal or managing officer of such corporation in charge of the actual operation of the business within the city. 
(Code 1980, § 24-37)  
Sec. 46-59. - Applicant's insurance. 
The applicant for license to operate a taxicab business shall not be issued such license until and unless he first files with the city clerk proof of a policy of insurance indemnifying the public against personal injury or property damage which may be caused by the negligent operation of each vehicle to be used for hire pursuant to such license. Such insurance policy shall provide the amount of coverage required by state law. 
(Code 1980, § 24-38) 
State Law reference— Liability insurance for taxis required, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-1220.  
Sec. 46-60. - Fee. 
The fee for the license referred to in this division shall be as prescribed in the license ordinance. Such fee shall be paid, by cash or cashier's check, at the time of filing the license application. 
(Code 1980, § 24-39)  
Sec. 46-61. - Investigation and inspection prior to issuance. 
The department of public safety shall investigate the applicant and the facts stated in the application for a license to operate a taxicab business. It shall be the further duty of the department of public safety to make careful inspection of each vehicle to be used as a taxicab by the applicant. The department of public safety shall report the findings of such investigation and inspection and shall submit to the city clerk its recommendations as to whether or not such license should be issued. 
(Code 1980, § 24-40)  
Sec. 46-62. - Issuance or refusal. 
The city clerk may issue a license for the operation of a taxicab business, if the report and recommendations required by section 46-61, in his judgment, justify the issuance. If such report and recommendations do not, in his judgment, justify such issuance, the city clerk shall refuse to issue the license and shall refund the license fee to the applicant. 
(Code 1980, § 24-41) 
State Law reference— Revocation of taxi license, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-1350.  
Sec. 46-63. - Transfer. 
No license for the operation of taxicab business shall be transferred by the licensee to any other person, except upon written application by the licensee and transferee to the city clerk for approval of the transfer. Upon investigation, as required by the terms of this division, the department of public safety shall submit a report to the city clerk, together with its recommendations and the city clerk may approve such transfer if, in his judgment, the transfer is justified. 
(Code 1980, § 24-42) 
State Law reference— Transfer of taxi license, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-1360.  
Sec. 46-64. - License tag or sticker. 
(a)  Issuance and display. With each license issued under section 46-62, the city clerk shall furnish a metal tag or windshield sticker for each vehicle to be operated under the license, and such metal tag or windshield sticker shall be prominently displayed upon each such vehicle at all times while the vehicle is being operated in or about the city for hire. 
(b)  Transfer from one vehicle to another. The metal tag or sticker issued under subsection (a) of this section shall not be transferred from one vehicle to another vehicle, except upon a report to and the granting of permission by the city clerk, upon recommendation by the department of public safety. 
(c)  Replacement. In the event that the metal tag or sticker issued under subsection (a) of this section is lost or stolen, a new tag or sticker shall, upon application by the owner, be issued by the city clerk, upon payment of the costs therefor. 
(Code 1980, §§ 24-43—24-45)  
Secs. 46-65—46-85. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT AND REGISTRATION CARD 
 
Sec. 46-86. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any taxicab on the streets of the city, without having first obtained a taxicab driver's permit and registration card. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating a taxicab business to hire, employ or permit any person to drive a taxicab employed in such business, who does not have a valid registration card and driver's permit to drive such taxicab. 
(Code 1980, § 24-51)  
Sec. 46-87. - Application. 
Application for a permit and card required by this division shall be filed with the city clerk and shall state the full name, age and home address of the applicant, whether or not the applicant is of sound body, whether or not the applicant has good eyesight and good hearing and whether or not he uses intoxicating liquors, drugs or narcotics. The application shall further state whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of this Code or of any other ordinance of the city or of any state or federal law and, if so, the number of times and the nature of such violations and convictions. The application shall give all other information that may be required of the applicant. 
(Code 1980, § 24-52)  
Sec. 46-88. - Applicant's qualifications. 
No taxicab driver's permit or registration card shall be issued to any person who is under the age of 18 years or to any person who does not have a current and valid driver's license issued by the state. 
(Code 1980, § 24-53) 
State Law reference— Qualification of drivers, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-23-1270.  
Sec. 46-89. - Investigation and report, with recommendations by department of public safety. 
The department of public safety shall investigate the applicant and facts stated in the application filed under this division and shall forward a report, together with recommendations relative to the issuance of a taxicab driver's permit and registration card, to the city clerk. 
(Code 1980, § 24-54)  
Sec. 46-90. - Fee. 
A fee in such sum as is prescribed by ordinance, shall be paid to the city clerk for the city, for the issuance of each taxicab driver's permit and registration card, the fee so charged to be to cover the expense of providing the application and permit forms, registration card, photograph and costs of the investigation as required by this division. Any ordinance prescribing such fee is hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1980, § 24-55)  
Sec. 46-91. - Issuance. 
The city clerk may issue a taxicab driver's permit and registration card to the applicant, if the report and recommendations made by the department of public safety in his judgement, justify such issuance. 
(Code 1980, § 24-56)  
Sec. 46-92. - Numbering. 
A taxicab driver's permit shall be serially numbered, when issued, and each registration card shall bear the serial number of the driver's permit in conjunction with which it is issued. 
(Code 1980, § 24-57)  
Sec. 46-93. - Design and contents of card. 
A taxicab driver's registration card issued under this division shall be of such design and wording as may be recommended by the department of public safety. Such registration card shall afford sufficient space for a photograph of the person to whom it is issued, which photograph shall be furnished by the city and affixed to the registration card in the space so provided. The registration card shall further contain the name of the holder thereof, together with his fingerprints. 
(Code 1980, § 24-58)  
Sec. 46-94. - Display of card; permit to be carried. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of a taxicab to fail to conspicuously display his registration card at all times in the taxicab, in order that the registration card may be seen by any passengers in such vehicle. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a driver of a taxicab to operate such vehicle upon the streets and highways of the city without having in his immediate possession a valid driver's permit issued under this division. 
(Code 1980, § 24-59)  
Sec. 46-95. - Expiration and renewal. 
A taxicab permit and registration card shall expire and shall be renewed at the same time as drivers' licenses issued by the state highways and public transportation department expire and are renewed. 
(Code 1980, § 24-60)  
Secs. 46-96—46-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TOURISM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, adopted July 11, 2005, set out provisions designated as Art. I, §§ 46-1—46-37. Inasmuch as there were already provisions designated as §§ 46-31—46-37 and to allow for the inclusion of general provisions as pertain to this chapter, said article has been redesignated as Art. III, §§ 46-116—46-152 as set out herein. 
 
Sec. 46-116. - Definitions. 
Charter service, limousines, or mini-bus means a motor propelled vehicle operating under a South Carolina Public Service Commission class C "charter" certificate of public convenience and necessity. 
Motor coach means any multi-passenger vehicle seating more than 30 people, or exceeding 40 feet in length. 
Private passenger motor vehicle means a motor vehicle used for tours for hire. 
Public conveyances shall include taxicabs, charter services, limousines, mini-buses, public motor passenger vehicles, motor coaches, and private passenger motor vehicles. 
Public motor passenger vehicle means any taxicab, limousine, or mini-bus as described. 
Special permit means one issued for prior commitments or specific nontouring purposes for transporting passengers. 
Taxicab means a motor propelled vehicle operating under a South Carolina Public Service Commission class C "taxi" certificate of public convenience and necessity restricted to the seating capacity of not over six passengers, including the driver. 
Tour guide means any person who acts or offers as a guide for hire in the City of Aiken within automobiles, buses, or other motor vehicles when the primary purpose of riding in such vehicles is not transportation, but touring the City of Aiken. 
Tours means a visitation for hire by any means for purposes of sightseeing, which originates or is conducted within the city limits of Aiken, South Carolina. A tour for these purposes shall include only motorized vehicles and shall not include people on foot, bike, or in horse drawn carriages. Transportation whose primary purpose is point-to-point conveyance or which offers neither commentary nor narration and which does not involve stops for purposes of viewing is not considered a tour under these guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-117. - Application for business license. 
The owner and operator of any public conveyance used for tours or for touring for hire, before operating it within, or from, the city, shall make and file, with the city business license administrator, written application for a license, that shall be sworn to by the applicant, and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner, and in the event the owner is a corporation, a certified copy of the articles of incorporation. 
(2)  The number of vehicles actually owned, and the number of vehicles for tours actually operated by such owner or operator on the date of the application. 
(3)  The number of vehicles for which a permit is desired. 
(4)  The make of each vehicle, type, year made, identification number, passenger capacity, and classification for each vehicle for which an application for permit is submitted. 
(5)  An accurate and certified net worth statement of the owner, or applicant, over and above all debts, judgments, claims, or demands whatsoever. 
(6)  Record of conviction by any criminal court, if any, of the applicant or if the applicant is a corporation, the criminal court record of the officers, directors, and supervising employees thereof, including the general manager, and all operators. 
(7)  Copy of the current South Carolina Public Service Commission motor vehicle carrier's permit to render public motor passenger service under the classification for which applied application is made. 
(8)  A copy of owner's, or operator's, local passenger tariff filed on file with the South Carolina Public Service Commission, shall also be filed with the city. 
(9)  Copies of licenses, or certificates, of persons who will be operating the tour vehicles. 
(10)  Such other information as city council may, in its discretion, require. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-118. - Public convenience and necessity. 
The business license administrator, or city manager, may, when in either's judgment the public interest and safety require, grant, or refuse to grant, approval of a business license application for any public conveyance. In evaluating the application for public conveyance, the business license administrator, or city manager, shall take into consideration the demands of the public for quality service within or from the city; the financial responsibility of the applicant as established by the public service commission, when required; the number, kind and type of equipment, and any demand for increased parking upon the streets of the city, which may result; and whether the safe use of the streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be preserved by the granting of such license. Limousines, taxicabs and tour buses must pass all inspection requirements of the city and state, and must be air-conditioned. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-119. - Business license issuance; fee; expiration. 
The owner and operator of each public conveyance for which a license is granted by city council shall annually obtain a business license in accordance with the schedule of business license fees then in effect. Such license fees shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other license fees or charges established by proper authority and applicable to public conveyances. A permit shall be issued annually for each vehicle and shall be permanently affixed in a prominent place upon the vehicle. No more than ten permits shall be issued for any calendar year, with remaining applicants being placed on a waiting list in the order in which their applications are received. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-120. - Suspension and revocation of business license or vehicle permit. 
Any business license or vehicle permit may be suspended or revoked by the business license administrator, or city council, at any time in case: 
(1)  The owner's record of performance is unsatisfactory. 
(2)  The owner fails to operate the public conveyance in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  The owner shall cease to operate any public conveyance for a period of 30 consecutive days without having obtained permission for cessation of such operation from the city. Vehicle permits recovered under this section will be reissued to the first person or company on the waiting list for vehicle permits. 
(4)  The owner or operator of a public conveyance has been convicted of violating the laws of the state relating to the operation of such public conveyance. 
(5)  The owner or operator of a public conveyance refuses to allow inspection by the public safety department or the lawful city authority or agent of permits, proof of liability insurance, daily manifest, or safety and sanitary conditions of the vehicle. 
(6)  The holder of a license shall fail to register properly in the correct and true owner's name, the public conveyance covered by the license. 
(7)  The owner or operator fails to maintain in effect or show proof of liability insurance on each vehicle for which a permit is issued. 
(8)  Such other basis as appears in the business license ordinance, or is deemed sufficient by city council, the business license administrator, or the city manager. 
No business license shall be revoked unless, and until, seven days of notice of a hearing shall have been given to the holder of such license and such hearing is duly held thereon; the notice to contain the reasons for proposed suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-121. - City tour driver's permit—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a driver of a public motor passenger vehicle as herein defined without having in his or her possession a valid city tour driver's permit. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-122. - Same—Application; persons ineligible for permits. 
(a)  The driver of any public tour motor passenger vehicle shall, before driving it upon the streets of the city, possess a valid South Carolina driver's license, or commercial driver's license, and make and file with the parks, recreation, and tourism department director a written application for a city tour driver's permit which shall be sworn to by the applicant and shall include full name, date of birth, driver's license or commercial driver's license number, and residence of the applicant; and shall state that the applicant is possessed of all requirements necessary to operate such tour vehicles in a safe, prudent, and satisfactory manner; a statement as to whether or not subject uses intoxicating beverages, drugs, or narcotics; and a statement as to whether or not such applicant has been convicted of any provisions of this Code, or other ordinance, or state or federal law; and shall set forth the nature of such offense(s), if any, and such other information as may be required for determining qualifications. Any false entry on the application will be cause for disapproval of the permit. 
(b)  Before issuing any permit as required by section 46-4, the parks, recreation, and tourism department director, or his designee, shall investigate the facts set out in such application, and shall not grant a permit to any person who has been convicted of any major crime or the violation of laws and ordinances involving moral turpitude, alcohol beverage control, or who is a habitual user of drugs or alcohol, or who has a record of habitually violating traffic laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-123. - Same—Duration; expiration date. 
Tour driver's permits, as required by this chapter, shall be for the period of one year, and each such permit shall expire on December 31 of each year. The cost of the driver's permit will be $50.00 annually. A one-time initial processing fee of $25.00 must also be paid by applicants. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-124. - Tour driver permit card—Issuance. 
On approval of any tour driver's permit required by this chapter, the parks, recreation, and tourism director, or his designee, shall issue a card which shall bear on its face a photograph of the permittee, the number of the permit, the expiration date, name of company or corporation hiring the driver, and such other information as the director may direct. Temporary permits may be issued in the discretion of the parks, recreation and tourism director if circumstances warrant the need for a temporary tour operator. Temporary tour driver's permits shall be $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-125. - Same—Display. 
The public motor passenger vehicle operator's permit card shall, at all times, be kept on display in the public motor passenger vehicle operated by such operator, easily visible for the passenger, while such permittee is in control of such public motor passenger vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-126. - Transferability of driver's permit. 
The driver's permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall not be transferable between individuals or companies. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-127. - Contents of application. 
(a)  Each driver's permit, required by the provisions of this chapter, shall be applied for in writing, on such application form as the parks, recreation, and tourism department director may prescribe, which shall show that the applicant has obtained a driver's license from the South Carolina Division of Motor Vehicles after satisfactorily completing an examination, and which shall show the experience of the applicant as a driver of motor vehicles; whether such applicant has been convicted of a violation of a motor vehicle, traffic, or criminal law, giving particulars of each offense charged; and such other information as the director may prescribe. 
(b)  Such application shall be accompanied by at least two recent photographs of the applicant, the size of which shall be determined by the director. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-128. - Age of applicant. 
Every applicant for a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall be at least 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-129. - Revocation. 
Any driver's permit granted under the terms of this chapter may be revoked by the parks, recreation and tourism director, or city council, for violation of provisions of this chapter after notice to permittees in writing citing them to appear before the parks, recreation, and tourism department director, or city council, and show cause why the permit should not be revoked. The director or city council may refuse permission to operate a public motor passenger vehicle and revoke the driver's permit of drivers when it appears their physical condition or record for violation of traffic laws, city ordinances, or other state and federal laws applicable to public motor passenger service vehicles, that they are unfit operators of such a vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-130. - Appeal from revocation of permit. 
Any person dissatisfied with the decision by the parks, recreation, and tourism department director shall have the right of appeal to the city manager and thence, to the city council, provided such appeal be made in writing within seven days from the decision of the director. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-131. - Identification of vehicles. 
(a)  Holders of city business licenses for the operation of public motor passenger vehicles upon the streets of the city, shall have a number assigned to each such vehicle, and this number shall be posted on both sides and on the rear of the vehicle. Such numbers shall be in plain white or black paint and printed in Arabic numbers of not less than one-half inch in width and at least four inches in height. The number shall be of a different color than the body of such vehicle so as to make the numbers easily legible. 
(b)  Holders of a city business licenses for the operation of public motor passenger vehicles upon the streets of the city shall also have the name of the owner or company of such vehicle printed in legible letters of not less than one-half inch in width, and not less than four inches in height, upon each side of the vehicle. The fleet numbers and letters shall be of a permanent nature and shall be of a different color than the body of such vehicle so as to make the lettering easily legible. Magnetic signs of equal size designating ownership of the vehicle will meet this requirement for company or owner designation signs. 
(c)  The provision as set forth in subsections (a) and (b) above for numbering or displaying the company name on each side of public motor passenger vehicles shall not apply to charter service limousines. 
(d)  Bus decorations must not be themed in anyway. 
(1)  Standard designed buses or trolleys are permitted. 
(2)  Bus or trolley colors must not be harsh, loud, or gaudy to the eye. 
(3)  No fluorescent paint schemes are allowed. 
(4)  No graphic wraps are allowed. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-132. - Vehicle license plates required. 
(a)  All public motor passenger vehicles, including substitute or so-called emergency taxicabs, limousines, and mini-buses shall be required to display on the rear of each vehicle the applicable state taxi or bus license plate issued by the South Carolina Division of Motor Vehicles prior to operating under the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  All public motor passenger vehicles including substitute or so-called emergency taxicabs, limousines, and mini-buses shall be required to display on the front of each vehicle the metal license plate issued by the public service commission prior to operating under the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  License plates issued by the South Carolina Division of Motor Vehicles and the South Carolina Public Service Commission shall be permanently attached to the public motor passenger vehicle in the appropriate location and in the place normally provided for a license plate. 
(d)  Limousines are authorized to display public passenger license plates or personalized license plates issued by the South Carolina Division of Motor Vehicles in lieu of state taxi plates. All other licensing provisions of this chapter apply. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-133. - Transportation of alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to transport in a motor passenger vehicle, used as a public motor passenger vehicle in the transportation of passengers for hire, any containers of beer, wine or alcoholic beverages. This section shall not apply to unopened beer, wine, or alcoholic beverages belonging to a passenger being transported when such alcoholic beverages are in the baggage of such passengers, or upon his person. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-134. - Rates to be posted. 
All persons owning, driving, operating or controlling public conveyance, shall post therein a conspicuous place where it may be easily and conveniently read by any passenger, a card upon which shall be printed in plain legible type of the tariff rates. Such rates include baggage handling for passengers, and any other fee. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-135. - Solicitation of business prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or driver of any public motor passenger vehicle to solicit business upon the streets of the city, or to use his vehicle upon the streets of the city as a stand for soliciting business. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator or driver of any taxicab to solicit business upon the private property of others without the permission of the owner of such private property. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-136. - Maximum load. 
The maximum load for any public motor passenger tour vehicle while operated upon the streets of the city under this Code shall be 29 passengers and one driver, for a total of 30 persons. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-137. - Vehicles—Sanitation, safety condition, and maintenance. 
Every vehicle operating under this chapter shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times; shall be kept and maintained in a safe condition, properly maintained, and serviced at all times. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-138. - Same—Inspection. 
The public safety department of the city is hereby charged with the duty of making periodic inspections of all public motor passenger vehicles operating under this chapter and licensed to do business in the city. The public safety department director may, in its discretion, suspend the right of a public motor passenger vehicle to be operated until the same shall be placed in a state of good repair, or in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-139. - Refusal of passenger to pay lawful fare. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any of the vehicles mentioned in this chapter after having hired the same. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-140. - Operator to render overall service. 
(a)  All persons or firms engaged in the operation of public conveyances in or from the city, operating under the provisions of this chapter, shall render a good overall service to the public desiring to use such public transportation. Holders of licenses for public motor passenger vehicles issued pursuant to this chapter shall keep the office open 24 hours a day for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching public motor passenger vehicles unless such holder or operator in all advertisements shall specifically limit the hours of service so that the general public may be properly and fully informed. All calls received for public motor passenger vehicle service shall be answered promptly and, if such service cannot be rendered promptly, they shall immediately notify prospective passengers how long the delay will be and give the reasons for it. Any owner or driver who shall refuse to accept a call anywhere in the city, or who shall not be able to answer the call promptly and shall fail to promptly notify the proposed passengers shall be deemed in violation of this chapter, and the license granted to such owner or operator shall be revoked at the discretion of city council. 
(b)  The operator or owner may refuse service to disorderly or intoxicated persons or those individuals who have a history of failure to pay for services rendered. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-141. - Daily manifests. 
(a)  Every operator of a public conveyance shall maintain a daily manifest for each vehicle upon which are recorded all trips made each day showing the time, place of origin, destination of each trip and the number of passengers, the amount of the fare, and all such completed manifests shall be returned to the owner by the operator at the conclusion of his/her tour of duty. Daily manifests shall be promptly recapitulated by the owner and operator on a monthly tally sheet. The forms for each manifest shall be furnished to the operator by the owner and shall be of a character approved by city council. 
(b)  Every holder of a license pursuant to this chapter shall retain and preserve all daily operators' manifests in a safe place for at least the current calendar year and preceding calendar year, and such manifests shall be inspected periodically, from time to time, by the city manager or his designee or agent. Such manifests shall also be made available for inspection upon the request of any police officer. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-142. - Vehicle routes and size. 
(a)  Tour vehicles must not be longer than 40 feet and not carry more than 30 persons, including the driver. Tour buses exceeding this size are expressly forbidden from conducting tours within the Aiken City limits. Nothing in this section shall prohibit tour buses from parking in an appropriate location, as approved by the city manager, on a city side street or commercial parking lot in order to allow occupants to walk downtown or visit retail establishments in the city. Motor coaches are expressly prohibited from traveling within any residential or historic district in the city, or upon any unpaved road in the city limits, unless approved by the city manager. Any vehicles used for tours for hire, other than private passenger motor vehicles shall be restricted to the applicable Aiken Tour route, attached as Exhibit 'A.' 
(b)  Idling of engines is only allowed while passengers are embarking onto or debarking from vehicles, not to exceed 15 minutes except at Rye Patch and Hopelands. The tour bus will not stop during the tours in front of residences, businesses, or other locations. The tour bus will unload at Park Avenue and Newberry Street. The tour bus can be parked for extended stays (longer than 15 minutes) and motorcoaches must be parked on Union Street or Fairfield between Park Avenue and Richland Avenue. 
(c)  There are no route limitations on private passenger motor vehicles. 
(d)  There shall be no more than two tours in private passenger automobiles in operation at any one time. Schedules and routes of these tours will be coordinated through the parks, recreation, and tourism director or designee. 
(e)  No one other than a registered tour guide may conduct a tour for hire in a private passenger motor vehicle. A tour guide card will be placed in the rear window of the vehicle while touring for hire. 
(f)  Private passenger motor vehicles need only comply with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state regulating traffic generally. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005; Ord. No. 11132006A, § 2, 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-143. - Hours and capacity. 
Any motor touring vehicles may only operate in the historic districts from 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday provided however that tours in the RSS and HD zones can only operate from 11:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. Tours in the HD zone can only operate on Two Notch Road and Audubon Drive. Tour vehicles are expressly forbidden from operating on any other unpaved street within the RSS and HD zone. Tour carriages are permitted in these areas, however. 
No more than two tour vehicles are allowed to operate in the city limits at any one time. 
Tour Frequency 
January 1—January 31: Each Saturday regular tour plus two others in the month. 
February 1—end of February: Each Saturday regular tour plus three others in the month. 
March 1—May 31: Each Saturday regular tour plus four others each month. 
June 1—August 31: Each Saturday regular tour plus two others each month. 
September 1—October 31: Each Saturday regular tour plus four others each month. 
November 1—December 31: Each Saturday regular tour plus two others each month. 
The city manager, or his designee, up to two times per calendar year, may temporarily alter the routes of travel, and parking limitations of this article as well as the trip limitation provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005; Ord. No. 11132006A, § 2, 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-144. - Business licenses. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a tour within the city limits of Aiken, South Carolina, unless such person either holds a current business license granted by the City of Aiken, is employed by a tour company which holds a current business license for such activity, or has hired a certified tour guide to narrate the tour. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-145. - Certification. 
It shall be unlawful for persons to act or offer to act as a tour guide for hire within the city limits unless they have been certified by the city under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-146. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring tour guide certification shall submit an application in writing to the tour coordinator on a form to be supplied by the tour coordinator. 
(b)  An applicant for tour guide must not be less than 18 years of age and must provide the following materials: 
(1)  Positive identification. 
(2)  A current, valid driver's license if applicable to operate motorized or carriage tours. 
(3)  A recent photograph. 
(4)  Proof of successfully passing the City of Aiken certification examination. 
(c)  All applicants will submit to a background investigation to be completed by the public safety department and state law enforcement division (SLED). The background investigation through SLED will be at the applicant's expense. 
(d)  Any applicant that has been convicted of a felony or violation of laws involving moral turpitude will not be eligible for licensing. Any applicant that has pending charges of the same will not have their application processed until final disposition of the charges. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-147. - Issuance of certification. 
Upon successfully meeting all of the requirements under this article and the passage of the competency examination for tour guide certification, the tour coordinator shall issue to the application a photographic identification card indicating that the holder is a certified tour guide. 
(1)  The identification card must be visible at all times when conducting a tour. 
(2)  The identification card shall remain the property of the city and must be returned upon expiration, revocation, or suspension of the certification. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-148. - Competency examination. 
(a)  No person shall be issued a tour guide certification card unless that person has passed the tour guide certification examination given by the tour coordinator. The examination shall be given not less than quarterly and shall test the applicant's knowledge of the following: 
(1)  The history and architecture of Aiken. 
(2)  The local government. 
(3)  The proper conduct of tour guides. 
(4)  The regulations applicable to the conduct of tours within the city. 
(b)  The fee for the initial and subsequent tour guide certification examination shall be determined by city council. 
(c)  Dates for administration of the examination shall be announced and published by the tour coordinator. 
(d)  Applicants shall be provided with a tour guide manual and a list of source material from which examination questions may be taken. 
(e)  There shall be no limit upon the number of times an applicant may take the examination, upon payment of the applicable fee for each examination. 
(f)  Successful passage of the tour guide certification examination shall be upon a grade of 80 percent or greater. Upon each successful passage, a certified tour card shall be issued for a period of three years, during which time the applicant shall not be required to take the examination again. 
(g)  At the expiration of the three-year period, the certified tour guide shall be required to submit a new background investigation through SLED, as stipulated in section 7-11014. They shall also be required to take and similarly pass the tour guide certification examination again before being issued a new tour guide certification for another three-year period. 
(h)  All examination papers shall be fairly and impartially graded and shall be retained by the tour coordinator until the appeal period provided hereinafter has expired. 
(i)  A tour guide certification shall be in effect for 36 months from the date of issue. Certification may be renewed, upon application and payment of the required fee, for each 36-month period thereafter, unless the permit for the proceeding period has been revoked or is suspended. 
(j)  A tour guide certification card issued under this article is not transferable and is to be used solely by the person to whom it was issued. 
(k)  It shall be unlawful to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a tour guide verification identification card or cause or allow its defacement. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-149. - Appeals. 
Any decision by the tour coordinator to deny a license for an individual seeking to become a certified tour guide may be appealed to the city manager within ten business days of the decision. The decision of the city manager shall be final and binding. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-150. - Suspension and/or revocation. 
(a)  Upon the recommendation of the tour coordinator, the city manager may suspend or cause the suspension of a tour guide certification for the following reasons: 
(1)  Making false statements in the application for the tour guide certification. 
(2)  Operating a tour service or vehicle in violation of any provision of this article or state law. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by the suspension or revocation of a tour guide certification may appeal the decision to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-151. - Exemption of nonprofit organizations. 
The city manager shall have the authority to exempt nonprofit organizations from these regulations in order to conduct special, nonrecurring tours for a limited duration of time, and not to exceed two in any week. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-152. - Enforcement. 
The city manager shall designate the appropriate agency within city government to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Violations of this chapter shall carry a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00 per occurrence, up to 30 days in jail, or both. Tour operators may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 07112005A, § 2, 7-11-2005)  
Sec. 46-153. - Not-for-hire tours—Buses. 
(a)  Individuals conducting tours to special groups for no cost may do so in accordance to the provisions set forth in section 46-133 "Transportation of alcoholic beverage prohibited," section 46-136 "Maximum load," section 46-137 Vehicles—Sanitation, safety condition and maintenance," section 46-142 "Vehicle routes and size," section 46-143 "Hours and capacity," section 46-145 "Certification," and section 46-152 "Enforcement." 
(b)  Donations for non-profit organizations may be accepted in lieu of fees. 
(Ord. No. 11132006A, § 2, 11-13-2006)  
Secs. 46-154—46-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - TRANSPORTATION OF HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES FOR PURPOSES OF TOURING 
 
Sec. 46-201. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City: A body politic and a political subdivision of South Carolina known as the City of Aiken including all areas within the city limits. 
Company: The holder of a license to operate a horse-drawn carriage business under the provisions of this chapter whether a person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
Driver: Any person who drives or operates a horse-drawn carriage upon the streets of the city for a licensed carriage company. 
Driver's permit: The written authority granted by the city and issued by the public safety department for an individual to drive or operate a horse-drawn carriage within the city. 
Horse-drawn carriage: Any hack or carriage which is operated by being drawn by a horse, mule, or other beast of burden for hire, for the transportation of passengers. 
Inspector: The individual employee or department of the city charged with the responsibility for administering and enforcing the Aiken City Code. 
License: The right and privilege granted by the city for operation of a tour business incorporating the use of one or more horse-drawn carriages within the corporate limits of the city. 
Not-for-hire tours: Touring conducted by a tour guide for an educational group, local school group, leadership program, local churches, local assisted living facilities, economic development partnership or City of Aiken, but the guide does not receive compensation. 
Permit: Includes the carriage company permission to operate or the individual carriage identification number, or as the case may be. 
Point-to-point: Vehicles for hire which primarily do not follow a reoccurring route, rather transport passengers from one specific location to another. 
Public conveyances: Transportation of people by a carriage-for-hire. 
Special event: A prearranged tour to accommodate a one-time, nonrecurring special occasion such as a convention or nonprofit activity. 
Street: Means and includes any street, alley, lane, avenue, court or public right-of-way or thoroughfare in the city. 
Tour guide: Any person who acts or offers as a guide for hire in the City of Aiken when the primary purpose is touring the City of Aiken. 
Touring: Activities where the primary purpose is to pass by and see historic, architectural sites, cultural attractions or scenic areas in the city, but shall not include mere point-to-point travel. 
Vehicle for hire: Employment of a horse-drawn carriage for passengers, generally for a fee or a fare, for the purposes of touring, point to point transportation, or special events. The vehicle is not deemed to be "for hire" when such passengers are not on board. 
Veterinarian: A veterinarian licensed in South Carolina who specializes in large animals. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-202. - Licensing and permits. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall operate a business involving the use of one or more horse-drawn carriages for hire upon the streets of the city unless a license for such business has first been granted by the city. The owner shall make and file, with the city business license administrator, written application for a license, that shall be sworn to by the applicant, and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner, and in the event the owner is a corporation, if requested, a copy of its articles of incorporation. 
(2)  Record of conviction by any South Carolina criminal court, if any, of the applicant or if the applicant is a corporation, the criminal court record of the officers, directors, and supervising employees thereof, including the general manager, and all operators. This record must be obtained from the Aiken Department of Public Safety. 
(3)  Such other information as city council may, in its discretion, require. 
(b)  The city shall reserve the right for its animal control officer, with or without a licensed veterinarian to inspect, and, at its own expense with or without the permission of the tour company, any animal or equipment actively used for the purpose of touring. 
(c)  The carriage company shall give to the public safety animal control officer of the city the name, address, and telephone number of the veterinarian who certifies the health of its horses. The carriage company shall also maintain the following information on each horse and make this information available, upon request from the city: 
(1)  The current veterinarian examination record; 
(2)  Annual immunization record including, but not limited to, rabies, Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis, eastern and western equine encephalomyelitis, tetanus, influenza, and negative Coggins test; 
(3)  A picture of the horse and a name or other designation for the horse; 
(4)  Description of any identifying characteristics, marks, or brands; 
(d)  No more than three horse-drawn carriage tour companies shall be licensed to operate in the city. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-203. - Public conveyance and necessity. 
The business license administrator, may grant, or refuse to grant, approval of a business license application for any public conveyance. In evaluating the application for public conveyance, the tourism supervisor, or his designee, shall take into consideration the demands of the public for quality service within, or from, the city; the number, kind and type of equipment, and any demand for increased parking upon the streets of the city, which may result; and whether the safe use of the streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be preserved by the granting of such license. Carriages must pass all inspection requirements of the city and state. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-204. - Suspension and revocation of business license or vehicle permit. 
Any and carriage permits may be suspended by the tourism supervisor, at any time in case: 
(1)  Any applicant who fails to comply with the requirements of this article shall not be issued or reissued carriage identification number until proof of compliance is presented by the applicant and certified by the attending veterinarian, public safety, codes enforcement, or the tourism supervisor. All of the requirements of this chapter both serve as conditions for issuance of a carriage identification number and apply to the business once operational. 
(2)  The business license administrator may temporarily suspend the business license of any carriage company for violation of any provision of the business license ordinance. The carriage company may appeal any such suspension to city council provided a written appeal has been submitted to the business license administrator within ten days of the suspension decision. 
(3)  The tourism supervisor shall determine whether a company which applies for a carriage tour operator's license is, indeed a stand alone company, with separate ownership, management and equipment. Existing carriage tour companies shall not be given a license to operate for a new company created in name only. If city council, after notice and a hearing, determines that there exists collusion or other sharing of ownership between companies holding a license to operate carriage tours, that operator or operators' carriage identification number shall be revoked. 
(4)  The owner's record of performance is unsatisfactory. 
(5)  The owner shall cease to operate any public conveyance for a period of 30 consecutive days without having obtained permission for cessation of such operation from the city. Permits recovered under this section will be reissued to the first person or company on the waiting list for permits. 
(6)  The owner or operator of a public conveyance has been convicted of violating the laws of the state relating to the operation of such public conveyance.
