(7)  The owner or operator of a public conveyance refuses to allow inspection by the public safety department or the lawful city authority or agent of permits, daily manifest, records as outlined in section 46-202, "Licensing and Permits", subsection (c), or safety and sanitary conditions of the vehicle. 
(8)  The holder of a license shall fail to register properly in the correct and true owner's name, the public conveyance covered by the license. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-205. - Vehicle-for-hire or carriage-for-hire. 
Holders of a city business license for the operation of horse-drawn carriages upon the streets of the city shall be assigned a current year city identification number which will be maintained by the tourism supervisor. The permit number shall be attached on the rear of the carriage body and shall be permanently displayed thereon. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-206. - Carriage driver's permit required. 
(a)  No person shall operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire upon the streets of the city and no person who owns or operates a horse-drawn carriage company shall permit a horse-drawn carriage to be driven at any time for hire unless the driver of the carriage shall first have obtained, and maintains, a valid horse-drawn carriage driver's permit issued by the city. Driver's permits will be issued and records will be maintained by the city. 
(b)  Application. The driver of any horse-drawn carriage shall possess a valid driver's license and make and file with the city a written application for a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit. Such application shall be sworn to by the applicant and shall include the full name, date of birth, driver's license state and number, and residence of the applicant. All drivers of horse-drawn carriages shall be required to pass a horse-drawn carriage competency examination indicating the driver is knowledgeable and capable of handling horses and horse-drawn carriages in emergency situations and that the applicant possesses all requirements necessary to operate a horse-drawn carriage in a safe, prudent and satisfactory manner. The examination shall be conducted by the city or its assigned representative. A statement as to whether or not such applicant has been convicted of violating any provision of this chapter, or other city ordinance, state or federal law; and shall set forth the nature of the offense(s), if any, and furnish other information as may be required for determining the applicant's qualifications. Any false entry on the application will be cause for disapproval of the driver's permit. 
(c)  Horse-drawn carriage driver's permits and carriage operation permits shall begin to be issued on July 1 each year and all issued permits shall expire on June 30 of the following year. The cost of the carriage driver's permit will be as set by city council. A one-time initial processing fee of $25.00 must also be paid by applicants. 
(d)  On approval of any carriage driver's permit the city shall issue a card which shall bear on its face a photograph of the permittee, permit number, expiration date, and any other information as the city designee may direct. 
(e)  The drivers' permit card shall, at all times, be kept on their person while that permittee is in control of the carriage. 
(f)  Carriage driver's permit(s) issued pursuant to this article, shall not be transferable between individuals. 
(g)  Every applicant for a permit under the provisions for this chapter shall be at least 21 years of age. 
(h)  Any carriage driver's permit granted under the terms of this chapter may be suspended by the city for any violation of this chapter and after due notice to the permittee in writing, citing him to appear before the municipal court and show cause why his permit should not be permanently revoked. The city may revoke the city driver's permit of any driver when, in his judgment, the driver's physical condition or record for violation of traffic laws, city ordinances, moral turpitude, or other state and federal laws applicable to public passenger service vehicles which indicates the permittee an unfit operator of such a public passenger vehicle or carriage. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-207. - Tour guide certification. 
It shall be unlawful for persons to act or offer to act, as tour guides for hire within the city limits unless they have been certified by the city under the provisions of Ord. No. 07112005A and Code sections 46-144—46-148, and all related sections. The carriage driver may also be the tour guide, but must be certified for each role. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-208. - Insurance. 
Any company offering horse-drawn vehicle tours in the City of Aiken shall be required to provide proof of insurance at the time of the operating permit application and upon request by any inspecting agent of the city. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-209. - Design standards. 
(a)  Animal-drawn vehicles shall be authentically styled traditionally colored passenger carriages, similar to surreys, or rockaways; car tires are not appropriate. Wagons which patently were designed for cargo instead of passengers will not be approved. Carriages shall not exceed 16 feet in length or six feet and four inches in width. Carriages will be measured in length from end to end including the wheels but excluding the shaft. Carriages will be measured in width from outermost point to outermost point. 
(b)  Carriages must be approved by the city. Any person dissatisfied with any city decision to either approve or not to approve the carriage, shall have the right of appeal to the city's equine commission. Any such appeal must be submitted in writing to the city manager's office within ten days from the date that the decision by the inspector is rendered. Any person dissatisfied with the decision of the city's equine commission to not approve the carriage, shall have the right of appeal to the city council. Any such appeal must be submitted in writing to the city manager's office within ten days from the date that the decision by the city's equine commission is rendered. The decision of city council is final. 
(c)  No commercial advertising of any kind is permitted on any part of a carriage, horse, harness or driver. The carriage company name and phone number shall be permissible with lettering no more than 14 inches high. 
(d)  Harness shall be suitable for the particular horse and carriage configuration to be used for any such tour. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-210. - Identification of carriages/posting of information. 
(a)  Information on the carriage vehicle's official gross weight and dimensions shall be maintained with the vehicle whenever the vehicle is in operation. The vehicle's official rated capacity for number of passengers shall be conspicuously posted on or in the vehicle. 
(b)  The number of carriages actually owned, and the number of carriages for tours actually operated by such owner or operator on the date of the application. 
(c)  The number of carriages for which a permit is desired. 
(d)  The make of each carriage, type, year made, city issued identification number, and passenger capacity for each carriage for which an application for permit is submitted. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-211. - Condition of carriages and harnesses. 
(a)  Each horse-drawn carriage operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in a safe mechanical condition, with all safety equipment remaining intact and operative at all times when the carriage is in service. 
(b)  Carriages in operation 30 minutes before sundown shall have side carriage lamps and illuminated red tail lights in accordance with South Carolina Code 56-5-4650 and related sections. 
(c)  The interior and exterior finish of each carriage shall be maintained. All metal should be clean. Each carriage will be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free of litter and debris at all times, suitable for public transportation of passengers. 
(d)  Harness used shall be clean and in good condition. Bitless bridles are forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-212. - Safety equipment. 
The following safety equipment shall be maintained on each carriage at all times: 
(1)  A first aid kit. 
(2)  A two-way radio or mobile telephone for immediate communication with the company's home office. 
(3)  A halter and lead shank for each animal hitched to the carriage. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-213. - Traffic related regulations. 
The operator of any animal-drawn vehicle within the city shall be subject to vehicle and traffic provisions of this ordinance and shall operate his or her carriage in accordance with the traffic laws of the state. 
(1)  No driver shall permit an animal to pull a carriage at a speed faster than a slow trot, except for emergency situations. In such emergencies, the driver shall take all precautionary measures possible so not to endanger any passenger or other person. 
(2)  Due to the nature of operating animal-drawn vehicles in areas of congestion and heavy traffic within the city, it shall be unlawful to operate an animal-drawn vehicle except when the animals are under complete control and with due care for the safety of others. Due caution should be exercised when emergency vehicles are present and using emergency warning lights or sirens. 
(3)  Whenever three or more motor vehicles are backed up behind a horse-drawn carriage the driver shall, at the earliest reasonable opportunity, pull the carriage over to the side of the road to allow those vehicles to pass. 
(4)  All carriages for hire must keep moving at all times and may not stop except as required by traffic regulations and by subsection (b), above and where particular exigencies reasonably require it. 
(5)  In the case of an accident or breakdown, the vehicle should be moved, if possible, so as to not impede traffic. 
(6)  Any driver who experiences a mechanical failure of the carriage or harness while on the roads, will move the passengers to safety and then unhitch the horse from the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-214. - General operating regulations. 
(a)  The total number of horse-drawn carriages allowed to operate at any one time upon the streets of the city is limited to six of which four may be on tour. Any carriages in excess of the four on tour shall only be permitted, if the carriage is in transport to or from their staging area. The carriages in operation shall be divided equally among the carriage companies. 
(b)  In order to relieve congestion on the streets and to mitigate impact upon residents and businesses no more than one carriage shall be driven along any three-block section in the same direction at any one time. A three-block section is defined as that linear segment of any individual street circumscribed by four contiguous intersecting streets. Where these spacing requirements are not met, the drivers of the last carriages to enter that section shall generally be deemed to have committed the violation. This provision applies only to carriages while used for hire. However, drivers of carriages which are not being used for hire are encouraged to observe these spacing requirements. 
(c)  Carriage company shall be responsible for maintaining the cleanliness of the loading zone. 
(d)  No driver shall collect fares, make change, or take on or discharge passengers when the carriage is in motion. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for a driver of any carriage to leave the vehicle, or the immediate premises there of, while the vehicle is parked or while awaiting passengers. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit passengers verbally or by gesture, directly or indirectly, or to advertise or hawk tickets at any loading zone, upon the streets, or in any public outdoor space of the city. The sale of tour tickets may only occur inside, on private property or other locations as designated by city council. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful to consume or transport alcoholic beverages aboard any carriage while touring. 
(h)  A driver may refuse service to any potential customer who appears to be impaired or disorderly. 
(i)  Any driver or operator discovering personal property left on his carriage shall deliver or report such property to the office of the carriage company within 12 hours after the discovery. The driver's report shall include brief particulars to enable the company to identify the owner of the lost property. The driver will advise any passenger claiming to have lost property while on tours to report such loss to the police. The company shall retain any found property for at least 60 days before disposal. 
(j)  Carriages shall not be operated in adverse weather conditions. 
(k)  Drivers must keep the horse's reins in their hands while an animal is hitched to the carriage. Only the driver may handle the reins, whip, and brake. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-215. - Loading zones. 
(a)  Passengers may be loaded or discharged only in designated loading zones. Carriages may remain in loading zone only while loading or discharging passengers or while waiting to load passengers for a prearranged tour. However; no carriage may remain in a loading zone for more than ten minutes without providing water to the horse. 
(b)  The following locations are designated as loading zones: 
(1)  In front of the Washington Center for the Performing Arts located at 126 Newberry Street. 
(2)  Location on private property (i.e. outside of the road right-of-way and any public areas) for prearranged tours or special events. 
(3)  Location on street adjacent to homes, restaurants, hotels, churches, and other establishments for prearranged tours or special events for persons departing from or arriving at those establishments provided that there is no off-street parking otherwise available and that the carriage is parked outside of any travel lane. 
(4)  The city may establish additional loading zones and conditions for those loading zones. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-216. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Horse-drawn carriages for hire, including those used for tours or special event shall be operated on the streets of the city only as follows (with the exception in subsection (b) below): 
(1)  During Eastern Daylight Time: 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. No tour may begin after 7:30 p.m. 
(2)  During Eastern Standard Time: 8:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. No tour may begin after 5:00 p.m. 
(3)  During the holiday season (Thanksgiving through New Year's Day): 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. No tour may begin after 10:30 p.m. 
(b)  Until after 11:00 a.m., tours are prohibited on the streets including Two Notch between Audubon and South Boundary; Mead Ave. east of Sumter Ave. towards Two Notch; Grace Ave. east of Sumter Ave. to Powderhouse Rd.; and Orangeburg St. between Grace Ave. and South Boundary. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006; Ord. No. 11232015 , § 1, 11-23-2015)  
Sec. 46-217. - Geographic area of operation and routes. 
(a)  The permitted area of operation for horse-drawn carriages carrying passengers for touring or special events is defined as follows: 
(1)  General areas for touring carriages for hire include all land bounded on the north by Edgefield Avenue, on the east by the Williamsburg Street, on the south by South Boundary, and on the west by Fauberg Street and the remaining Historic District land bounded on the north by South Boundary, on the east by Powderhouse Road, on the south by Price Avenue, and on the west by Hitchcock Woods. 
(2)  Only carriages for hire which are equipped with brakes are allowed on Laurens St. from the railroad overpass south to New Lane and on Newberry St. between Colleton Ave. and New Lane. 
(b)  Routes are established as follows: 
(1)  Carriages used for touring must operate the route within the geographical area outlined in the above subsection (a). 
(2)  Carriage operators wishing to tour outside of the above geographical area must submit a written request to the tourism supervisor at least seven normal business days prior to touring. If approved, a special route permit shall be issued and must be in possession of the carriage driver at all times during the special tour. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-218. - Special exceptions. 
The city manager or his designee may approve exceptions to this article regarding routes, maximum number of carriages, and hours for special events. Special events may include, but are not limited to parades or the annual carriage drive. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-219. - Stables, exercise and paddock area. 
(a)  When stables or exercise lots are maintained within the city limits, the company shall maintain the structure and premises in a sanitary condition through the proper use of lime and pesticides and comply with the following conditions: 
(1)  Manure shall be cleaned from the stable, exercise and paddock area daily and then placed in covered containers or a Dempsey dumpster. Such containers shall be at least 50 feet from any other dwelling or pool, patio or other structure on an adjoining lot and at least 25 feet from any property line, notwithstanding any other provision contained in this chapter having requirements for covered containers. 
(2)  All manure shall be removed from the premises at least weekly or more often as necessary to prevent or reduce the propagation of flies and creation of odors. 
(3)  Exercise and paddock areas shall be designed and maintained to drain so as to prevent ponding and propagation of insects. The area shall be designed and maintained so as to prevent the pollution by drainage or run off into adjacent streams or other water bodies. 
(4)  Any spilled feed on the property shall be promptly removed so as to prevent attraction of flies, rodents and birds, or the creation of odors. 
(5)  Provisions shall also be made for insect control. 
(6)  The exercise or training areas on the property shall be dampened to prevent dust. 
(b)  Horses will be provided the following conditions: 
(1)  Each individual animal shall have a stall large enough for the animal to safely turn around; but no individual animal may be kept in a stall less than ten feet by 12 feet or 120 square feet in area, except that standing stalls may be used for less than 12 hours per day. Ceilings in stalls and stables shall be at least nine feet from the bedding and flooring. 
(2)  Ventilation adequate to ensure good health and comfort of animals shall be provided in stable and stall areas. 
(3)  Adequate and leak-free roofing is required for any stable or stall area in which animals are housed in the city. 
(4)  Adequate amounts of straw bedding or shavings in stalls shall be kept clean and dry. 
(5)  Adequate fresh water shall be provided in paddocks and stalls at all times while any animal is present. 
(6)  Food shall be kept free of contamination and stored in rodent-proof containers. 
(c)  Complaints regarding any stable or lot that is not maintained in compliance with the foregoing requirements should be filed with the City of Aiken animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-220. - Treatment and condition of horses. 
(a)  A licensed veterinarian shall certify, after due and proper inspection, the good health of each animal before it is placed in service. A minimum of one such health inspections and certificates shall be required for each animal each calendar year. 
(b)  No driver may use more than a light touch of the whip upon any animal, and no driver or other person may forcefully strike an animal, or make movements or noise intended to frighten or harm an animal. 
(c)  Horses shall be allowed access to fresh water at least every one hour while in service. 
(d)  Horses shall not be in harness more than two and one-half hours consecutively without at least 30 minutes of rest. 
(e)  No animal shall be subject to any condition or treatment, whether in service or out of service, which will impair the good health and physical condition of that animal. This includes providing shade as relief from heat when not working. 
(f)  Unless written approval is given by a licensed veterinarian, no animal having open sores or wounds or any disease or ailment, shall be permitted to be in service on the streets of the city. 
(g)  Prompt veterinary care and services shall be provided for sick horses, and when deemed necessary by a licensed veterinarian, the sick horse shall be promptly removed from the immediate service. 
(h)  Each animal shall have its hooves properly trimmed and shod for street use. 
(i)  Each animal shall be groomed daily in order that there are no signs of fungus, dandruff, or a dirty coat. 
(i)  Harnesses shall be properly fitted, maintained, and clean so that no irritating material will come in direct contact with the animal. 
(j)  Horse shall not be worked in extreme conditions of heat and humidity which may be harmful to the horse. 
(k)  Carriage animals shall be a minimum of 1,000 lbs. No one horse may be used to pull more than one and one-half times it's own weight. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-221. - Inspections, compliance, and enforcement. 
(a)  Any law enforcement officer, the tourism supervisor, a city-contracted inspector, or city code enforcement official shall be empowered to inspect the stables, stalls, horses, carriages and other operating facilities of any carriage company doing business within the city limits, during normal business hours, with or without prior notice, and to examine operating practices of any carriage company to ensure continuous compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  The public safety department shall have the authority to immediately remove from operation upon the streets of the city any horse-drawn carriage which does not meet the requirements of this chapter, and may prohibit operation of the carriage until deficiencies have been corrected. Any person dissatisfied with the decision of the public safety department shall have the right of appeal to the city manager. Any such appeal may be submitted in writing to the city manager within ten days from the date that the decision by the public safety department is rendered. The decision of the city manager is final. 
(c)  Operators and agents of the carriage company and passengers shall comply with all city ordinances and state and federal laws which govern the treatment of animals, including horses, mules or other beast of burden. Failure to comply with this chapter can result in revocation of the business permit and punishment at the discretion of the municipal court. 
(d)  Violations of this section shall carry a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00 per occurrence, or punished within the jurisdictional limits of the city court. Tour operators may contest their citations in municipal court. 
(e)  The carriage company, upon continued violation of the provisions of this section by the company, its agents, employees or persons acting on its behalf, the right to operate horse-drawn carriages, shall also be suspended as follows: 
(1)  Upon two violations within a six-month period, the company shall be suspended for a period not to exceed seven days. 
(2)  Upon three violations within a one-year period, the company shall be suspended for a period not to exceed 30 days. 
(3)  Upon four violations within a one-year period, the company shall be suspended for a period not to exceed 180 days. 
(4)  Once a 180-day suspension period has been served, if the company continues to violate the ordinance and receives three violations within the one-year period following the 180-day suspension, all permits and certifications will be permanently revoked. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-222. - Compliance with other requirements. 
Companies shall also comply with all building code and zoning ordinance conditions to the extent any conflict shall arise, the more restrictive provision shall control. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-223. - Not-for-hire tours. 
(a)  Individuals conducting tours to special groups for no cost may do so in accordance to the provisions set forth in section 46-206 "Carriage driver's permit required," section 46-207 "Tour guide certification," section 46-209 "Design standards," section 46-211 "Condition of carriages and harnesses," section 46-212 "Safety equipment," section 46-213 "Traffic related regulations," section 46-214 "General operating regulations," section 46-215 "Loading zones," section 46-216 "Hours of operation," section 46-217 "Geographic area of operation and routes," section 46-218 "Special exceptions," section 46-219 "Stables, exercise and paddock area," section 46-220 "Treatment and condition of horses," section 46-221 "Inspections, compliance, and enforcement," and section 46-224 "Tour reports." 
(b)  Donations for non-profit organizations may be accepted in lieu of fees. 
(c)  Not-for-hire tours whether accepting donations or not shall adhere to section 46-224 "Tour Reports" as described below. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Sec. 46-224. - Tour reports. 
(a)  Each operator shall, on the date or within the time period hereinafter prescribed, make a report to the tourism supervisor on forms provided, the total number of tours conducted and the total number of tickets sold for each tour conducted. Required reports shall be remitted to the tourism supervisor on or before the fifteenth day of the following month after the quarter. The quarters are defined as January to March, April to June, July to September, and October to December. If the due date for reporting falls on a Saturday or Sunday, or a federal, state, or City of Aiken observed holiday then reporting is considered timely on the following business day. Furthermore, if the due date for reporting falls during the period of a natural disaster which directly precluded the responsible party from timely submitting the reports and payments, an additional ten-day extension may be granted upon written request to the tourism supervisor. A natural disaster is defined as a hurricane, earthquake, flood, or tornado. The responsible party is considered directly precluded from timely submitting reports if their offices are deemed by emergency officials to be damaged to the extent of being unsafe or unavailable for use due to the disaster or postal service to the immediate area is suspended during the due date. 
(b)  Failure to file the required reports as required by this section will subject the operator to a $50.00-penalty. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any misrepresentation of the information required by returns as set forth in subsection (a) hereof, shall subject any tour operator to suspension and/or revocation of the tour guide certificate as may be determined by the tourism supervisor. The tour operator may appeal any such suspension or revocation to the city manager provided a written appeal has been submitted to the director of parks, recreation and tourism within ten days of the decision to suspend or revoke. 
(Ord. No. 11132006B, § 2(Exh. A), 11-13-2006)  
Secs. 46-225—46-250. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - WALKING TOURS 
 
Sec. 46-251. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms mean: 
City: A body politic and a political subdivision of South Carolina known as the City of Aiken including all areas within its city limits. 
Company: The holder of a license to operate a walking tour business under the provisions of this chapter whether a person, firm, partnership, or corporation. 
Inspector: The individual employee or department of the city charged with the responsibility for administering and enforcing this code. 
License: The right and privilege granted by the city for operation of a business incorporating the use of one or more walking tours within the city. 
Not-for-hire tours: Touring conducted for educational groups, nonprofit organizations, local religious organizations, local assisted living facilities, economic development partnership, or the City of Aiken when the tour guide receives no compensation. 
Street: Means and includes any street, alley, lane, avenue, court, or public right of way or thoroughfare in the city limits. 
Tour guide: Shall mean any person who acts or offers as a guide for hire in the City of Aiken when the primary purpose is touring the City of Aiken. 
Touring: Operation of a walking tour of at least eight, but no more than 40, persons where the primary purpose is to walk to see historic and architectural sites, cultural attractions, or scenic areas in the city. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-252. - Licensing of walking tour companies for hire. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to operate a business involving the use of one or more walking tour companies for hire upon the streets of the city unless a license for such business has first been granted by the city. 
(b)  Each walking tour company, as a condition of holding a license under the provisions of this chapter, shall establish and maintain a fixed headquarters on public, or private, property for the operation of the company's business. The headquarters shall conform to all applicable city ordinances. 
(c)  Applicants shall provide their most recent tax return, income verification, profit/loss statements, or other verification of gross receipts as part of their business license application. 
(d)  Applicants shall also provide a record of conviction by any criminal court, if any, of any tour guides, the applicant, or, if the applicant is a corporation, the criminal court record of the officers, directors, and supervising employees thereof, and all operators. Applicants will obtain these criminal record reports from the Aiken Department of Public Safety. 
(e)  Any applicant who fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall not be issued a business license until proof of compliance is presented by the applicant and certified by the city tour supervisor, public safety department, or codes enforcement officer. All of the requirements of this chapter both serve as conditions for issuance of a license and apply to the business once operational. 
(f)  The business license administrator, or other designated official, may temporarily suspend the business license of any walking tour company for violation of any provision of this ordinance. The walking tour company may appeal any such suspension to city council provided a written appeal has been submitted to the business license administrator within ten days of the suspension decision. 
(g)  No more than two separate walking tour companies shall be licensed to operate in the city. 
(h)  The business license administrator, tourism director, or other designated official, shall determine whether a company that applies for a walking tour operator's license is, indeed a different company, with separate ownership, management, and equipment. Existing walking tour companies shall not be given a license to operate for a new company created in name only. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-253. - General operating regulations. 
(a)  The guide and guests of a walking tour shall not trespass on private property, block streets, or deny access to driveways. The tour company shall be responsible for collection and removal of all trash generated by guests. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to consume, or transport, alcoholic beverages while participating in any walking tour. 
(c)  A guide may refuse tour service to any potential customer who appears to be uncooperative, boisterous, impaired, disorderly, or in any manner disruptive to conducting a tour. 
(d)  Walking tours shall not be operated in adverse weather conditions as determined by the tourism supervisor. 
(e)  Speaker phones, bullhorns, or other audio amplification devices are prohibited on walking tours. 
(f)  Walking tour routes must be approved by the city manager or another person designated by the city manager. 
(g)  No animals shall be permitted on tours, except service animals or animals trained to assist the visually impaired. 
(h)  Any person conducting a walking tour must be certified by the City of Aiken tourism supervisor as a tour guide. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-254. - Hours of operation, number of guests, and frequency of tours. 
Walking tours for hire shall be operated on the streets of the city only as follows: 
(1)  Tours are permitted between 9:30 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. in the downtown commercial districts. 
(2)  Tours are permitted between 9:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. in residential areas. However, tours using routes which focus on city commercial areas, which utilize residential streets, may operate until 9:00 p.m. 
(3)  In the Horse District (HD) zone, Residential Single Family, Stable (RSS) zone, and on Colleton Avenue, walking tours must begin after 11:00 a.m. and terminate before 6:00 p.m. 
(4)  No more than four walking tours per month may be conducted outside the downtown commercial area, except on a tour route which is specifically approved for use after 6:00 p.m. 
(5)  Prior to 6:00 p.m., walking tours in the downtown commercial area are limited to 28 guests. 
(6)  After 6:00 p.m., tours in the downtown commercial area are permitted up to 40 guests. Tour groups numbering between 28 and 40 guests must have an additional person assisting with the tour. Tour assistants will not require such certification, but must be recognized designees of the tour company. 
(7)  Any walking tour outside the downtown commercial area, except on those routes approved for use after 6:00 p.m., are limited to 15 guests. After 6:00 p.m., up to 40 guests are allowed on specifically approved routes. 
(8)  No more than two walking tours may be conducted at any one time, and tours must be spaced at least two blocks apart except at the tour departure or completion area. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-255. - Tour guide certification. 
It shall be unlawful for persons to act, or offer to act, as tour guides for hire within the city limits unless they have been certified by the city. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-256. - Special events. 
The city manager, or a city manager designee, may approve exceptions to this chapter regarding routes, maximum number of guests, and hours for special events. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-257. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city manager shall designate the appropriate agency within city government to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Violations of this chapter are unlawful and shall carry a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00 per occurrence. Other punishment within the jurisdiction of the municipal court may also be exacted from violators. Tour operators may contest any citation in municipal court. 
(b)  A walking tour company, upon continued violation of the provisions of this article by the company, its agents, employees or persons acting on its behalf, then its right to operate a walking tour shall be administratively suspended as follows: 
(1)  Upon two violations within a three-month period, the company shall be suspended for a period not to exceed seven days. 
(2)  Upon three violations within a one-year period, the company shall be suspended for a period not to exceed 30 days. 
(3)  Upon four violations within a one-year period, the company shall be suspended for a period not to exceed 180 days. 
(4)  Once a 180-day suspension period has been served, if the company continues to violate the ordinance and receives three violations within the one-year period following the 180-day suspension, all permits and certifications will be permanently revoked. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-258. - Not-for-hire tours. 
(a)  Individuals conducting tours to special groups for no cost may do so in accordance to the provisions set forth in section 46-253 "General operating regulations," section 46-254 "Hours of operation and frequency," section 46-255 "Tour guide certification," section 46-256 "Special events," and section 46-257 "Enforcement." 
(b)  Donations for non-profit organizations may be accepted in lieu of tour fees. 
(c)  Not-for-hire tours whether accepting donations or not shall adhere to section 46-259 "Tour reports" as described below. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 46-259. - Tour reports. 
(a)  Each operator shall, on the date or within the time period hereinafter prescribed, make a report to the tourism supervisor, on forms provided, the total number of tours conducted and the total number of guests for each tour conducted. Required reports shall be remitted to the tourism supervisor on or before the fifteenth day of the following month after the quarter. The quarters are defined as January to March, April to June, July to September, and October to December. If the due date for reporting falls on a Saturday or Sunday, or a federal, state, or City of Aiken observed holiday then reporting is considered timely on the following business day. Furthermore, if the due date for reporting falls during the period of a natural disaster which directly precluded the responsible party from timely submitting the reports and payments, an additional ten-day extension may be granted upon written request to the tourism supervisor. A natural disaster is defined as a hurricane, earthquake, flood, tornado, or winter weather that prevents normal business from being conducted. The responsible party is considered directly precluded from timely submitting reports if their offices are deemed by emergency officials to be damaged to the extent of being unsafe or unavailable for use due to the disaster or postal service to the immediate area is suspended during the due date. 
(b)  Failure to file the required reports under this section will subject the operator to a $50.00 civil penalty. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any misrepresentation of the information required by returns as set forth in subsection (a) hereof, shall subject the tour operator to suspension and/or revocation of his business license by the business license administrator and/or the tour guide certificate as may be determined by the director of parks, recreation and tourism or the director's designee. The tour operator may appeal any such suspension or revocation to the city manager or the city manager's designee provided a written appeal has been submitted to the business license administrator within ten days of the decision to suspend or revoke. 
(Ord. No. 01082007, § 2(Exh. A), 1-8-2007)  
ARTICLE VI. - TOWING FRANCHISES 
 
Sec. 46-260. - Nonexclusive franchise—City council authority to grant. 
The city council may and is empowered to grant to any qualified person, a nonexclusive franchise to engage in the business of providing conventional towing services and heavy duty towing services in response to requests by the department of public safety. Heavy duty towing services are defined as services with wreckers capable of towing motor vehicles weighing over 7,000 pounds. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011)  
Sec. 46-261. - Minimum eligibility for towing franchise. 
Aiken Department of Public Safety shall investigate the facts listed in the application for a nonexclusive towing franchise. Within 60 days after completion of the investigation, the application shall be reviewed by city council unless any one of the following exists: 
(1)  The applicant has been removed from the franchise list within the last 24 months; 
(2)  A material statement made in the application is untrue; 
(3)  A fact exists of which the director of public safety or his designee has knowledge of which would be cause for removal or suspension of the applicant from the rotation list; 
(4)  The applicant has not been issued a city business license; 
(5)  The applicant has a felony conviction; 
(6)  The applicant has not obtained the required insurance. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011)  
Sec. 46-262. - Right of owner or driver to request a towing service. 
The owner or driver of a wrecked or disabled vehicle shall have the right to choose any towing service, even if such service has not been granted a city franchise. Before calling any towing service to tow a wrecked or disabled vehicle, the investigating officer on the scene should, if practical, determine the wrecked or disabled vehicle owner's or driver's preference for towing services. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011)  
Sec. 46-263. - Rules and regulations for conventional towing services. 
All towing services granted a nonexclusive conventional towing franchise must comply with the following: 
(1)  All towing services shall maintain a secure storage area for all vehicles towed. This may be a locked building or a secured fenced-in area where the stored vehicles and other property shall not be accessible to the public. Each service will have personnel available during normal business hours for the public to have access to their vehicle, if needed. 
(2)  Each towing service shall provide the department of public safety with normal working hours, business day and night phone numbers, holiday phone numbers, pager numbers, and cellular phone numbers, as available. 
(3)  All towing services shall be equipped with, and utilize, legally authorized lighting and other safety equipment to protect the motoring public. This equipment shall be maintained in good working order. 
(4)  The following equipment must be carried on all wreckers: brooms, shovels, a container to haul glass and other debris from the highway, a five-pound-ABC-rated fire extinguisher, absorbent material, and safety chains and tie-down chains (for haulers rollback). The towing service shall clean the roadway prior to leaving a wreck scene. 
(5)  Towing services shall be available to the department of public safety 24 hours each day, seven days per week, and 52 weeks per year. Each towing service shall keep its facilities adequately staffed during all service hours. Each towing service shall respond to a request for the release of a motor vehicle from its service facility the following business day or on an agreed upon time of release that is within reason for both parties. 
(6)  Towing services shall not respond to a scene for service unless requested by a proper public safety authority. 
(7)  Motor vehicles that have been reported stolen or which have been designated as evidence shall be towed to a location to be determined by the officer on the scene. Once a stolen vehicle is approved by the department of public safety for release, the vehicle owner, or the owner's designee, must show proof that the towing charge has been paid, and then the owner's vehicle will be returned. 
(8)  All other motor vehicles must be towed to the service's facility and secured there until claimed by the owner, or other person entitled to lawful possession of the motor vehicle, or if unclaimed, until lawful disposal of the motor vehicle has been effected by the towing service in accordance with state law. 
(9)  Towing services must be available to respond within 30 minutes to any scene where an officer will be standing by awaiting that response. In the event that 30 minutes expires without wrecker arrival, the officer may request the on-duty dispatcher to confirm the expiration of time, attempt to contact the tardy towing service to advise of the cancellation, and summon the next towing service on the appropriate list. In the event that the tardy towing service arrives after cancellation and summoning of another towing service, the tardy towing service will be turned away. Repeated failures to respond to any scene within 30 minutes may result in removal from the rotation list. 
(10)  The towing service must have a wrecker of sufficient size and strength to handle a job. A separate rotation list shall be maintained for the heavy-duty wreckers. Where services of a heavy-duty wrecker are needed, a heavy-duty wrecker shall be called from the heavy-duty wrecker list. 
(11)  Charges for work performed and storage fees must be in compliance with the current version of the South Carolina Highway Patrol Wrecker Rotation Fee Schedule which is published by the South Carolina Department of Public Safety. 
(12)  Wrecker operators must conduct themselves in a proper manner at all collision scenes and when dealing with the public. 
(13)  Towing services and operators shall be familiar, and comply, with the laws regarding business solicitations on South Carolina highways. 
(14)  Each towing service on the city franchise rotation list must have signs on its vehicle doors indicating the company's name, address, and telephone number. The signs must be plainly visible with letters not less than two inches high in a color which contrasts to that of the wrecker. 
(15)  Each wrecker on the vehicle rotation list shall be equipped with a towing log. The log shall be maintained by the towing service and shall accurately reflect all towing done by the towing service at the request of the Aiken Department of Public Safety. The towing log format should be the same design as now required by the South Carolina Highway Patrol. Each towing service owner shall be responsible for producing this towing log to the city upon request. 
(16)  All towing services on the city franchise rotation list shall carry liability insurance on its wreckers, and its premises, in an aggregate amount not less than $750,000.00. 
(17)  All towing services on the franchise lists shall carry garage keepers liability insurance covering customer's vehicles in a prorata amount calculated upon the basis of the square footage of vehicle storage space for that business on a formula approved by the city manager. In no event shall this garage keepers insurance be in an aggregate amount of less than $50,000.00. 
(18)  Towing services shall be responsible for securing personal property in a vehicle at a towing scene to the best of their ability. In no event, however, shall a towing service be responsible for personal items that do not come into the possession of the towing service. 
(19)  The towing service shall be available to release, within a reasonable period of time, all essential personal property in any towed vehicle to the rightful owner on a 24-hour per day, seven-day per week basis. The towing service location shall have an agent present during normal business hours and at the request of any rightful owner of any towed vehicle, or owner's designee, the towing service must immediately release all essential personal items including, but not limited to, medicines, medical equipment, keys, clothing, tools of their trade, child restraint systems, and perishable items. 
(20)  The towing service shall, upon receipt of proof of ownership or right of possession and the payment of service fees for the motor vehicle, release the motor vehicle to its owner or other person entitled to its lawful possession. Towing services shall effect the release of motor vehicles during all service hours, and shall provide the person taking possession of the motor vehicle an itemized invoice specifying all service fees paid, and record and maintain for the term of the franchise, plus three years, the following information for each motor vehicle released: 
a.  Date and time of release. 
b.  Motor vehicle year, make, model, body style, and VIN. 
c.  License plate number and state. 
d.  Name, address, driver's license number and state; and the residence and business telephone number for the person taking motor vehicle possession. 
(21)  Any complaints from a towing service regarding any incidents involving a public safety officer or the department's operation of the wrecker list must be received by the director of public safety within 15 days of the alleged incident. 
(22)  Failure of any towing service to comply with these regulations may result in their removal from the rotation list. Violation of any of these provisions is hereby declared unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011; Ord. No. 03112019 , § 1, 3-11-2019)  
Sec. 46-264. - Rules and regulations for heavy duty towing services. 
All towing services granted a heavy duty nonexclusive towing service franchise must comply with the following: 
(1)  All towing services shall maintain a secure storage area for all vehicles towed. This may be a locked building or a secured fenced-in area where the stored vehicles and other property shall not be accessible to the public. Each service will have personnel available during normal business hours for the public to have access to their vehicle, if needed. 
(2)  Each towing service shall provide the department of public safety with normal working hours, business day and night phone numbers, holiday phone numbers, pager numbers, and cellular phone numbers, as available. 
(3)  All wreckers shall be equipped with, and utilize, legally authorized lighting and other safety equipment to protect the motoring public. This equipment shall be maintained in good working order. 
(4)  The following equipment must be carried on all wreckers: brooms, shovels, a container to haul glass and other debris from the highway, a five-pound-ABC-rated fire extinguisher, absorbent material, and safety chains and tie-down chains (for haulers rollback). The towing service shall clean the roadway prior to leaving a wreck scene. 
(5)  Towing services shall be available to the department of public safety 24 hours each day, seven days per week, and 52 weeks per year. Each towing service shall keep its facilities adequately staffed during all service hours. Each towing service shall respond to a request for the release of a motor vehicle from its service facility the following business day or on an agreed upon time of release that is within reason for both parties. 
(6)  Towing services shall not respond to a scene for service unless requested by a proper public safety authority. 
(7)  Motor vehicles that have been reported stolen or which have been designated as evidence shall be towed to a location to be determined by the officer on the scene. Once a stolen vehicle is approved by the department of public safety for release, the vehicle owner, or the owner's designee, must show proof that the towing charge has been paid, and then the owner's vehicle will be returned. 
(8)  All other motor vehicles must be towed to the service's facility and secured there until claimed by the owner, or other person entitled to lawful possession of the motor vehicle, or if unclaimed, until lawful disposal of the motor vehicle has been effected by the towing service in accordance with state law. 
(9)  Towing services must be available to respond within 45 minutes to any scene where an officer will be standing by awaiting that response. In the event that 45 minutes expires without wrecker arrival, the officer may request the on-duty dispatcher to confirm the expiration of time, attempt to contact the tardy towing service to advise of the cancellation, and summon the next towing service on the appropriate list. In the event that the tardy towing service arrives after cancellation and summoning of another towing service, the tardy towing service will be turned away. Repeated failures to respond to any scene within 45 minutes may result in removal from the rotation list. 
(10)  The towing service must have a wrecker of sufficient size and strength to handle a job. A separate rotation list shall be maintained for the heavy-duty wreckers. Where services of a heavy-duty wrecker are needed, a heavy-duty wrecker shall be called from the heavy-duty wrecker list. 
(11)  Charges for work performed and storage fees must be in compliance with the current version of the South Carolina Highway Patrol Wrecker Rotation Fee Schedule which is published by the South Carolina Department of Public Safety. 
(12)  Wrecker operators must conduct themselves in a proper manner at all collision scenes and when dealing with the public. 
(13)  Towing services and operators shall be familiar, and comply, with the laws regarding business solicitations on South Carolina highways. 
(14)  Each wrecker on the city towing service rotation list must have signs on its vehicle doors indicating the company's name, address, and telephone number. The signs must be plainly visible with letters not less than two inches high in a color which contrasts to that of the wrecker. 
(15)  Each wrecker on the vehicle rotation list shall be equipped with a towing log. The log shall be maintained by the towing service and shall accurately reflect all towing done by the towing service at the request of the Aiken Department of Public Safety. The towing log format should be the same design as now required by the South Carolina Highway Patrol. Each towing service owner shall be responsible for producing this towing log to the city upon request. 
(16)  All towing services on the rotation list shall carry liability insurance on its wreckers, and its premises, in an adequate amount not less than $750,000.00. 
(17)  All towing services on the rotation list shall carry garage keepers liability insurance covering customer's vehicles in a prorata amount calculated upon the basis of the square footage of vehicle storage space for that business on a formula approved by the city manager. In no event shall this garage keepers insurance be in an aggregate amount of less than $50,000.00. 
(18)  Towing services shall be responsible for securing personal property in a vehicle at a towing scene to the best of their ability. In no event, however, shall a towing service be responsible for personal items that do not come into the possession of the towing service. 
(19)  The towing service shall immediately release personal property in any towed vehicle to the rightful owner on a 24-hour per day, seven-day per week basis. The towing service location shall have an agent present during normal business hours and at the request of any rightful owners of any towed vehicle, or owners' designee, the towing service must immediately release personal items including, but not limited to, medicines, medical equipment, keys, clothing, tools of their trade, child restraint systems, and perishable items. 
(20)  Towing services shall, upon receipt of proof of ownership or right of possession and the payment of service fees for the motor vehicle, release the motor vehicle to its owner or other person entitled to its lawful possession. Towing services shall effect the release of motor vehicles during all service hours, and shall provide the person taking possession of the motor vehicle an itemized invoice specifying all service fees paid, and record and maintain for the term of the franchise, plus three years, the following information for each motor vehicle released: 
a.  Date and time of release. 
b.  Motor vehicle year, make, model, body style, and VIN. 
c.  License plate number and state. 
d.  Name, address, driver's license number and state; and the residence and business telephone number for the person taking motor vehicle possession. 
(21)  Any complaints from a towing service regarding any incidents involving a public safety officer or the department's operation of the wrecker list must be received by the director of public safety within 15 days of the alleged incident. 
(22)  Failure of any towing service to comply with these regulations may result in their removal from the rotation list. Violation of any of these provisions is hereby declared unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011; Ord. No. 03112019 , § 1, 3-11-2019)  
Sec. 46-265. - Public safety administration of franchise towing services. 
(a)  The wrecker rotation list shall be administered fairly and in a manner designed to ensure that all towing services on the list have an opportunity to provide involuntary towing service business arising from the rotation list. Standard procedure for selecting the next eligible wrecker on the city towing service rotation list will be made by proceeding to call the next service on the list. 
(b)  Towing services shall be called from the rotation lists as set forth above. If a particular towing service is unavailable when called, it shall be passed over and the next wrecker on the appropriate list shall be called to the scene. However, if a towing service or wrecker driver is unable to answer the call, the dispatcher shall be notified about the reason for that towing service's unavailability and log it in the towing log book. Repeated failures by a towing service to respond to calls for service may result in removal from the rotation list. 
(c)  If an officer must cancel a wrecker, it will be done as soon as possible. If possible, the wrecker will be cancelled by the communications center prior to its arrival. However, if the wrecker must be cancelled at the scene, the officer shall inform the dispatcher to place the towing service back on the top of the appropriate rotation list. 
(d)  Aiken Department of Public Safety staff and officers are prohibited from owning any financial interest or any form of ownership interest in any towing service granted a franchise under this chapter. 
(e)  Aiken Department of Public Safety staff and officers are prohibited from recommending services from a particular towing service. 
(f)  Except in cases such as wrecked or disabled motor vehicles where the request for towing is made by a public safety officer at the direct request of the owner or driver of the vehicle, a tow report shall be completed for all motor vehicles for which services are provided. Upon completion of the tow report by the official it shall be reviewed for accuracy and signed by the official and towing service representative at the scene. Motor vehicles shall not be moved from the scene until the tow report has been completed and its removal authorized by the official. Tow reports must set forth at least the following minimum information: 
(1)  Status: Abandoned/derelict/confiscated/stolen/evidence/nuisance. 
(2)  Year, make, model, and body style of motor vehicle. 
(3)  Vehicle identification number (VIN). 
(4)  License plate number and state. 
(5)  Detailed description of the physical condition of the motor vehicle to include any damage, missing parts or accessories, and such other information as will accurately describe the motor vehicle's condition at the time of the tow. 
(6)  Itemized list of all personal property contained in the motor vehicle, as well as any personal property removed by the towing service or official for preservation and safekeeping. 
(7)  Name and address of last registered owner of vehicle. 
(8)  Name and address of all known registered lienholders. 
(9)  Name, badge number and signature of requesting officer. 
(10)  Towing service information. 
(g)  Except in cases such as wrecked or disabled motor vehicles where the request for towing is made by a public safety officer at the direct request of the owner or driver of the vehicle a towing report is not required. In these cases the towing service may obtain owner and lienholder information by making a written request to the Aiken Department of Public Safety. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011)  
Sec. 46-266. - Suspension from franchise list. 
Any towing service granted a nonexclusive franchise may be suspended by the director of public safety or his designee from such list if the towing service fails to comply with any of the conditions, regulations or requirements of this chapter. Upon learning of grounds for suspension, the director of public safety or his designee shall immediately, by written notice, inform the owner of the towing service of his action of suspension. The director of public safety or his designee may reinstate the towing service to the rotation list upon satisfactory proof that the towing service is in compliance with the conditions, regulations, and requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011)  
Sec. 46-267. - Removal from franchise list. 
(a)  Any towing service placed on the rotation list may be removed from such list for one or more of the following grounds: 
(1)  The towing service has been suspended from the rotation list at least once and repeatedly or intentionally fails to comply with any of the conditions, regulations or requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  The towing service fails to perform the duties established by this chapter or the towing franchise agreement by any of the following: fails to timely answer calls, fails to respond to calls within a reasonable time, fails to maintain clean and orderly storage facilities, or at any time fails to clean the roadway of glass and debris at an accident scene. 
(3)  The owner of the towing service sells 51 percent or more of the business, provided the person or persons purchasing the business may apply for placement on the rotation list. 
(4)  The owner of a towing service applies for placement on the rotation list under another name. 
(5)  When any fact exists that would constitute a ground for denial of an application pursuant to this chapter or the towing franchise agreement. 
(b)  The director of public safety or his designee, upon learning of grounds for removal, shall immediately, by written notice, inform the owner of the towing service of his action of removal and the grounds for removal. Within ten days after receipt of the written notice, the owner shall have the right to file a written request for a hearing before the director of public safety or his designee. If the owner files a timely hearing request, the director of public safety or his designee shall set a time and place for the hearing. All parties involved shall have the right to offer testimony, documents, and tangible evidence at a hearing on the issues and to be represented by counsel. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011)  
Sec. 46-268. - Appeal. 
(a)  Within five business days after receiving written notification that any applicant has been removed from the rotation list, the applicant shall have the right to appeal such order by filing a written notice of appeal, including a written statement stating the grounds of the appeal with the city clerk. The written statement shall include, but not be limited to, statements why the applicant believes the decision of the director of public safety should be reconsidered. Upon the filing of the notice of appeal and written statement, the city clerk shall set a time, date and place for a public hearing on the matter and shall notify the applicant of the hearing. The hearing shall be heard at a regular meeting of the council not later than 30 days after the written notice and statement was filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  Such appeal shall be heard by the city council, which may affirm, amend, or reverse the decision, or take other action deemed appropriate, subject to the limitations of the terms and conditions of the towing franchise agreement. 
(c)  In conducting the hearing, the city council shall not be limited to the technical rules of evidence under the South Carolina Rules of Evidence. 
(d)  If no appeal is filed within the time prescribed, the action of the director of public safety or his designee shall be final. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, in the event that any appeal is filed, the appellant shall not be allowed to participate in any tows or be placed on the tow rotation list until such time as the appellant is approved or reinstated. 
(Ord. No. 05092011, § 1(Exh. A), 5-9-2011)

PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a republication of the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Aiken, South Carolina. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1999 Code, as revised June 2009, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1999 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of three parts separated by a decimal. The figure before the first decimal refers to the chapter number. The figure after the first decimal is the article number. The figure after the second decimal refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of chapter 1, article 2, is numbered 1.2.1. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
ZONING CODE 1:1 ZONING CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES ZCT:1 ZONING CODE INDEX Zi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Dennis Sinnett, Vice-President of Supplementation, and Kelly Heaton and Janet Cramer, Editors, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Sara Ridout, City Clerk, and Ed Evans, Planning Director, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
Copyright 
    All editorial enhancements of this Code are copyrighted by Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Aiken, South Carolina. Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Aiken, South Carolina. 
(c) Copyrighted material. 
Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Aiken, South Carolina. 2014.
